column4: Dominican Republic;The aircraft was on a tourist excursion flight

column7: Dominican Republic. Destination was Santiago de Los Caballeros
column8: with nine tourists on board. On the return flight
column9: at approximately 70 miles northwest of the Punta Cana Airport
column10: the captain decided to fly to the La Romana Airport (the alternate airport)
column11: to refuel because he did not perform this operation at the Cibao Airport and because the fuel quantity indicator in the left tank was inoperative. He had doubts about the remaining fuel in the tanks. On the way to the alternate airport
column12: the no.1 engine failed. The captain attempt to to restart the engine but this failed. Engine no. 2 was still running. The pilot
column13: aware that the fault that turned off engine no.1 was the lack of fuel
column14: made the decision to land in a sugarcane field near El Prado
column15: located in the province of El Seybo
column16: for fear that the remaining engine would also go out
column17: perhaps without a suitable place to land later. Given these conditions
column18: the captain chose a segment of a lane in the middle of two cane fields
column19: where he made the emergency landing. The surface of this trail was not totally flat. After having a landing run of about 100 feet
column20: the nose wheel collided with a stone
column21: breaking the nose landing gear. Directional control was lost and the aircraft turned to the left
column22: entering a cane field.;17:20;Britten-Norman BN-2A-26 Islander;Caribair

column6: United States of America;Caravan N948FE was owned by Federal Express and operated by Corporate Air as Airspur Flight 8810 (CPT8810) when it departed Casper (CPR) at 07:44 for a cargo flight to Steamboat Springs. At 08:32
column7: the pilot requested the VOR/DME-C instrument approach to the Steamboat Springs Airport (SBS) runway 32. The flight was cleared for the approach via the BQZ (Robert VORTAC) 280 degrees radial 9 DME fix. At 08:39
column8: the pilot was advised that radar services were terminated and frequency change was approved. The pilot's acknowledgement of the clearance was the last radio contact with the flight. At 08:34 the Caravan impacted against the side of Emerald Mountain at an elevation of 7864 feet (2406 m). Airfield elevation is 6878 feet (2104 m).;08:58;Cessna 208B Super Cargomaster;null;Saturday 5 May 2001

column1: An Express Jet Embraer E145

column2: at an altitude of 5000 feet

The three hostages were released in July 2008.";08:43;Cessna 208B Grand Caravan;One Leasing;Thursday 13 February 2003

column1: 4-apr-16;ATR 42-600;PK-TNJ;TransNusa Aviation Mandiri;Jakarta-Hali...;2014-09-22  (1 year 7 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Damaged beyond repair;Pushback / towing (PBT);-;-;-;"Batik Air flight ID7703
column2: operated by a Boeing 737-800 with registration PK-LBS
column3: collided with an ATR-42-600 aircraft on takeoff from runway 24 at Jakarta-Halim Perdana Kusuma Airport (HLP)
column4: Indonesia. Dark
column5: night time conditions existed at the time of the accident.

column1: The ATR-42-600
column2: operated by TransNusa Aviation Mandiri and registered PK-TNJ
column3: was parked at stand B-1 on the north apron of Halim Airport and was to be moved from the north to the south apron. For this the aircraft had to cross the active runway.

column1: A towing car was used with a driver and one supporting personnel. Two engineers occupied the pilot seats in the aircraft. The engineers were assigned to apply aircraft brakes if required during the towing process.
The towed aircraft was towed without aircraft electrical power fed to the system and the navigation light
column2: strobe light and the aircraft radio communications were off. The communication between the towing car driver and Halim Tower was performed by a handheld radio communication on frequency 152.7 MHz.

column1: At 19:45 local time flight ID7703 requested pushback clearance to the Halim Tower controller on frequency 118.6 MHz. The aircraft was parked on parking stand B-2 and was approved to push back.
After the ID7703 completed the pushback
column2: the towing car driver of the towed aircraft requested clearance to Halim Tower Control Unit to reposition from parking stand B-1 to the south apron. The towing car driver was instructed to follow ID7703 and to report when on taxiway C. The communication between the towing car driver and Halim Tower was handled by the assistant controller.

column1: The controller heard the communication between the assistant and towing car driver
column2: he recognized the position of the towed aircraft was on the parking stand B-1.

column1: The ID7703 flight crew did not know that there was a towing aircraft behind as communications with the car were on a different frequency. At 19:48
column2: ID7703 received taxi clearance to runway 24 via taxiway C.
the controller instructed ID7703 to hold on taxiway C due to an arriving aircraft. The assistant stated that when ID7703 was holding on short taxiway C
column3: the towing car began moving the ATR-42.

column2: ID7703 received clearance from controller to enter runway 24 to back track for departure. The aircraft that had just arrived would use parking stand B-1. Therefore
column3: the assistant controller instructed the towing car driver to expedite the tow and report when on taxiway C. The controller was not observing the ATR at that time. The towing car was about to enter taxiway C at that time.

column2: ID7703 reported ready for takeoff. The controller did not see any vehicle or object on the runway then issued clearance for takeoff. The pilot stated that during line up
column3: the lights surrounding the turn pad were very bright and affected his forward vision for a short time. It was common practice in Halim to lineup at the turn pad beyond the threshold runway 24.

column1: After receiving the takeoff clearance
column2: the Second in Command (SIC) as pilot flying (PF) opened the power and pressed the Take Off / Go Around (TOGA) button.

column1: The towing car driver stated that
column2: when he saw ID7703 was lining up for takeoff
column3: he asked Halim Tower whether ID7703 was initiating the takeoff. There was no reply from Halim Tower. The towing car driver then sped up the towing and turned to the right side of the runway.

column1: When ID7703 was accelerating through approximate 80 knots
column2: the SIC saw an object warned the captain. The pilots could not identify the object but later on when the object became closer
column3: the SIC realized that there was an aircraft.

column1: The captain took over control and applied the right rudder towards the right side of runway centerline and maintained a course between the runway centerline and the runway edge. The PIC intended to reject the takeoff shortly after they felt an impact. The impact occurred at a ground speed of about 130 knots
column2: after passing V1. The pilot rejected takeoff and the aircraft stopped at approximately 400 meter from the towed aircraft which stopped at the left of the runway 24 centerline at approximately 100 meters from taxiway G.

column1: The captain noticed fire on the left wing tip and immediately shut down both engines
column2: activated the fire extinguishers of both engines and Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) and commanded to the flight attendant ""evacuation from the right"".

column1: The flight attendants opened all aircraft passenger doors and the escape slides deployed. Most of passengers were evacuated from the left forward door (L1).
Both aircraft sustained substantial damage. There were no reported injuries to the accident.
The outer portion of the left wing of the Boeing 737
column2: about 5
column4: was severed. The ATR-42s left hand wing
column5: outboard of the no.1 engine
column6: was severed
column7: along with the entire empennage.";19:55;ATR 42-600;TransNusa Aviation Mandiri;Monday 4 April 2016

09-MAR-2002;Antonov An-2TP;LY-AVD;Svedijos Prekés;near Rocca di Mezzo;1972;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 1 / Occupants: 1;Damaged beyond repair;En route (ENR);Unknown;Budapest-Ferihegy Airport (BUD/LHBP)
column2: Hungary;Tunis-Carthage Airport (TUN/DTTA)
column3: Tunisia;"Antonov 2 LY-AVD departed from Budapest at 08:29 for a VFR flight with destination Tunis. According to the flight plan the track would over fly Split
column4: Pescara
column5: the crossing of the Apennines towards Ostia and then onwards its destination
column6: Tunis. The meteorological conditions over the central part of Italy on that March the 9th were characterized by a cold front associated with numerous thunderstorm areas
column7: low cloud coverage over the mountainous Apennines accompanied by icing conditions. After leaving Split
column8: and crossing the Adriatic sea LY-AVD over flew Pescara at 13:20 where the pilot informed the local ATC that the aircraft was inbound Aneda (a reporting point 19 NM East of Monte Rotondo) at a cruising altitude of 5.500 feet (1.676 m). While in vicinity of Pescara
column9: ATC requested and obtained confirmation from LY-AVD that VFR conditions were maintainable. The radio communication ended with the instruction to LY-AVD

column1: to contact Rome AIS Centre. There is no record of communication attempt by the crew and it is presumed that the aircraft
column2: soon after that radio communication
column3: impacted with the Monte Rotondo mountain side at an altitude of 6.167 feet (1.880 m) with an estimated ground speed of 115 Kts.";13:39;Antonov 2TP;Svedijos Prekés;Saturday 9 March 2002

column1: 21-MAY-2002;Let L-410UVP;9Q-CGX;Sky Executive;near Calabar Airp...;1985;Fatalities: 5 / Occupants: 5;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;Approach (APR);Ferry/positioning;Port Harcourt Airport (PHC/DNPO)
column2: Nigeria;Calabar Airport (CBQ/DNCA)
column3: Nigeria;Let 410 9Q-CEX was being flown by a Congolese crew on behalf of the Nigerian airline company Sky Executive Airlines. The aircraft departed Abuja around 16:30 for a passenger flight to Port Harcourt. At Port Harcourt all passengers disembarked. The aircraft then took off for a ferry flight to Calabar. On approach the pilot declared an emergency due to an electrical failure. At 65 km out the crew commenced a descent to 2500 feet. The descent was continued past this altitude until the Let crashed in a swamp. During the investigation into the cause of the accident it was found out that the aircraft was non-compliant with the maintenance requirements
column4: and proper documentation of the aircraft and crew members. Also
column5: the plane had exceeded the prescribed annual inspection time by 248 hours
column6: and the engines were not maintained in accordance with the standard procedure. Contrary to NCAA regulations a Flight Data Recorder (FDR)
column7: nor a Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR) were installed.;19:42;Let L-410UVP;Sky Executive Airlines;Tuesday 21 May 2002

column1: Upon departure at 07:00 (10:00 UTC)
column2: the crew was not aware of the 09:20 UTC special weather report
column3: with information that the weather conditions had deteriorated and were below the minima for IFR operations

column1: 07-MAY-2005;Swearingen SA227-DC Metro 23;VH-TFU;Transair Australia
column2: op.for Aero-Tropics;near Lockhart Riv...;1992;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 13 / Occupants: 13;Damaged beyond repair;Approach (APR);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Bamaga Airport
column3: QLD (ABM/YBAM)
column4: Australia;Lockhart River Airport
column5: QLD (IRG/YLHR)
column6: Australia;"The pilot in command and copilot commenced duty in Cairns for the scheduled Cairns (CNS) - Lockhart River (IRG) - Bamaga (ABM) - Lockhart River (IRG) - Cairns (CNS) flight. The flight was operated by Transair but conducted on behalf of Aero-Tropics Air Services. Aero-Tropics would provide ground handling
column7: pilot briefing facilities and marketing services. Transair provided the airplane and crew.

column1: The Metro 23 aircraft departed Cairns at 08:31. During the descent to Lockhart River on the northbound flight
column2: the crew intended to perform a runway 30 RNAV (GNSS) approach. Late in the approach
column3: the crew appropriately manoeuvred the aircraft to land on runway 12. The engines were shutdown at 09:50. The aircraft departed Lockhart River at 09:58 and arrived at Bamaga at 10:39. The aircraft was refuelled at Bamaga for the return flight to Cairns via Lockhart River to collect two passengers. The pilot in command commented to the ground agent prior to departing Bamaga that the weather was 'bad' at Lockhart River and it may not be possible to land there. The forecast conditions at the aerodrome included a broken10 cloud base 1
column4: 000 ft above the aerodrome for periods of up to 60 minutes. The aircraft departed Bamaga at 11:07 and climbed to the cruising altitude of FL170. Descent was commenced at 11:32. Three minutes later the copilot advised Brisbane ATC that the aircraft was on descent
column5: passing 10
column6: 000 ft AMSL with an estimated time of arrival at Lockhart River of 11:38. At 11:39 the copilot broadcast on the CTAF (Common Traffic Advisory Frequency) that the crew was conducting the runway 12 RNAV (GNSS) approach
column7: and that the aircraft was at the 'Whisky Golf' (LHRWG) waypoint and tracking for the 'Whisky India' (LHRWI) waypoint. At 11:41 the airplane was over the LHRWI intermediate fix and descent was recommenced at 4.8 NM from the LHRWF waypoint. This was 3.1 NM before the descent point specified on the approach chart for the 3.49 degree constant angle approach path to the missed approach point. After levelling briefly at 3000 feet 18 degrees of flaps were selected. The aircraft then commenced descent 1.4 NM before the final approach fix (FAF). This was 0.3 NM (approximately 7 seconds) after the descent point specified for the constant angle approach path. The average rate of descent was 1000 ft/min
column8: increasing to 1700 ft/min. At 11:43 the Metro was over the FAF at an altitude of 2379 feet. The altitude at this stage should have been 2860 feet. The flight descended then through the segment minimum safe altitude of 2
column9: 060 ft. It continued to descend until it flew into the side of a heavily timbered ridge in the Iron Range National Park. The height of the initial impact with trees was 1
column10: 210 ft
column11: which was about 90 ft below the crest of the ridge.";11:43;Swearingen SA227-DC Metro 23;null;Saturday 7 May 2005

column1: 3-jan-09;Learjet 45XR;N279AJ;Aero Jet Services;Telluride Re...;;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;Landing (LDG);Ferry/positioning;Scottsdale Airport

column4: United States of America;"A Learjet 45
column5: N279AJ
column6: sustained substantial damage when attempting to land during a snowstorm at Telluride Regional Airport
column7: CO (TEX). The positioning flight was conducted using instrument flight rules and had departed Scottsdale Airport
column8: AZ (SDL) at 15:03 MST. The pilot occupying the left seat was not injured and the pilot occupying the right seat received minor injuries.

column1: In a statement to the NTSB provided by the Pilot-In-Command
column2: upon arrival to TEX the weather was reported to be below minimums; the crew elected to hold over the Cones VOR and wait to see if weather conditions would improve. The crew was given instructions
column3: by air traffic control
column4: to hold as published and to expect further clearance (EFC) at 16:30. When the weather improved to a visibility of 4 miles and a ceiling of 2300 feet
column5: the PIC requested a descent and approach to KTEX. At approximately 4 miles from the airport
column6: the pilot acquired the airport environment but was not in position to land
column7: so he called for a missed approach back to Cones VOR. The pilot then requested a second attempt to land stating that ""if we did not land
column8: we would like to be sequenced to into KMTJ"" Montrose Regional Airport Montrose
column9: CO
column10: their alternate airport. On the second approach
column11: both crew members stated that they had acquired the runway environment; however
column12: they were still too high for a visual approach. The crew elected to do a 360-degree
column13: right
column14: descending turn
column15: in order to get in a better position for landing. On completion of the turn
column16: they again affirmed the runway environment and that they were aligned with the extended centerline of the runway. The airplane touched down and after full thrust reversers were deployed
column17: the nose gear collapsed. The airplane began to slide in snow and came to a stop about mid-field
column18: in an upright position.

column1: An initial FAA examination of the area indicated that the airplane had touched down about 20-feet to the right
column2: of the runway. Additionally
column3: the airplane's wings were torn from the fuselage and the tail section had separated just aft of the engines
column4: during the contact with the ground.

column1: Weather reported at KTEX 10 minutes prior to the accident was winds 260 degrees at 8 knots
column2: visibility of 3 miles
column3: scattered clouds at 400 feet
column4: broken clouds at 2300 feet
column5: temperature of 6 degrees Celsius
column6: dew point of 6 degrees Celsius
column7: and altimeter setting 29.85 inches of mercury.";16:59;Learjet 45XR;Aero Jet Services;Saturday 3 January 2009

column1: The pilot stated that he initiated a fuel transfer due to a fuel imbalance. To affect the fuel transfer
column2: he said he ""began crossfeed right to left."" When the airplane was about 5 to 10 miles away from Spruce Creek Airport

column5: and also executed a left turn to begin setting up to land
column6: when suddenly
column7: both engines ceased operating. When he levelled the wings both engines restarted due to auto-ignition. He said the fuel gages showed 300 to 350 lb of fuel for the right tank
column8: and 100 to 150 pounds on the left

column10: he again entered a left bank to prepare for a left base to runway 23

column15: he said a car pulled out onto the taxiway
column16: and stopped on the centerline
column17: so he applied power to avoid the car. He said he climbed straight out
column18: and when he made a climbing left turn
column19: he said the engines ceased operating a third time
column20: and the airplane descended towards a cluster of condos. With no runway or clear area in sight
column21: the pilot said he guided the airplane to a retention pond.";19:15;Beechcraft 300 Super King Air;Mass Bay Kustom Leasing;Wednesday 14 April 2004

column1: 23-apr-99;DHC-6 Twin Otter 200;N719AS;Samoa Aviation;Fituita Airp...;;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 12;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Pago Pago International Airport (PPG/NSTU)

column3: American Samoa;"Samoa Air flight 906
column4: a DHC-6-200
column5: N719AS
column6: veered off the runway and collided with a ditch and an embankment while landing at Fitiuta
column7: Tu'a
column8: American Samoa. The aircraft sustained substantial damage; however
column9: neither of the 2 flight crewmembers nor any of their 12 passengers were injured.

column1: The flight originated from Pago Pago
column2: American Samoa
column3: at 06:09 as a regularly scheduled non-stop domestic passenger flight to Fitiuta. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed at the time and a composite IFR/VFR flight plan was filed.

column1: The captain overflew the Fitiuta airfield to assess winds conditions and the windsock indicated a quartering headwind for runway 12. During rollout the airplane veered immediately right when the power levers were brought into beta. The captain corrected with rudder and braking but was unable to maintain directional control. The aircraft ran off the right side of the runway and collided with a ditch and an embankment. After deplaning
column2: the crew found that the winds were a 60-degree tailwind on runway 12. The windsock's pivot point on the pole was rusted and would not rotate. The aircraft with the same landing weight and a 60-degree 10-knot tailwind would require a 1
column3: 600-foot landing roll on the 2
column4: 350-foot runway without the assistance of both props in beta. The beta pin had backed out of position on the left engine's beta control linkage. The beta pin
column5: cotter pin
column6: and washer were found in the bottom of the engine cowling. The left engine had been changed 2 days prior to the accident. As the mechanics finished the beta pin area during engine installation
column7: the inspector checked the area and found that the pin was in place and properly safety wired. Following the inspector's signoff of the area
column8: the mechanics discovered that the teleflex cable was too short for the beta valve to be flushed and subsequently had to be adjusted. The director of maintenance readjusted the cable
column9: which required disturbing the safety wire on the beta pin. One of the two mechanics that had been instructed to re-safety the connections after the adjustment thought that the rear portion had already been safetied and did not recheck the area. The inspector believed the area had already been checked and did not re-examine the beta pin.";06:45;de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter 200;Samoa Aviation;Friday 23 April 1999

column1: 1-apr-11;CASA C-212-CC40 Aviocar 200;C-FDKM;Fugro Aviation Canada;near Saskatoon Ai...;1981;Fatalities: 1 / Occupants: 3;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;Approach (APR);Survey/research;Saskatoon Airport
column2: SK (YXE/CYXE)
column3: Canada;Saskatoon Airport
column4: SK (YXE/CYXE)
column5: Canada;"A Fugro Aviation Canada CASA C-212-CC40
column6: C-FDKM
column7: was destroyed in a forced landing accident in Saskatoon
column8: SK
column9: Canada. One of the three crew members was killed.

column1: The airplane departed Saskatoon Airport
column2: SK (YXE) at 15:03 for a geophysical survey flight to the east of Saskatoon.

column1: At about 18:14 the aircraft experienced a shudder from the right engine just before it smoothly spooled down. The propeller rotation slowed and the aircraft yawed. The right engine torque fell below 20%. The crew confirmed that the right engine had lost power. Altitude at the time was 2300 feet and the 2 survey sensors were deployed behind and below the aircraft.
The captain set maximum power on the left engine and the crew commenced to shut down the right hand engine. As the first officer had more experience on the aircraft than the captain
column2: the pilots agreed to let the FO continue as pilot flying. The captain would continue with the checklists and radio communications.

column1: At 18:17 the captain notified the Saskatoon control tower of the situation with a MAYDAY call
column2: advising they had lost power on one engine and were returning to Saskatoon.
the aircraft had climbed to 2600 feet asl and accelerated to about 99 KIAS
column3: and the pilots had instructed the survey equipment operator to recover the survey sensors. The survey equipment operator got up to do so. The recovery process took 4 to 5 minutes. At 18:25
column4: the flight reached 3100 feet asl (about 1400 agl)
column5: the maximum altitude following the right engine power loss.

column2: airspeed was about 105 to 110 KIAS
column3: and both pilots had visual contact with the runway. The FO's plan was to fly a high steep approach
column4: and he had not yet reduced the left engine power lever setting for the approach. The tower cleared the flight to land on runway 27.

column1: Meanwhile the fuel level left tank or fuel pressure left engine annunciators had illuminated
column2: along with the master caution light. Neither pilot observed these annunciations.

column1: At about 18:28
column2: airspeed was 105 KIAS or greater when the left engine smoothly lost power with no surging. The captain observed the torque indicator smoothly and rapidly decreasing from 100% to 20% within a couple of seconds. The airplane decelerated and yawed to the left. The altitude was 3000 feet asl (about 1300 feet agl).

column1: Both pilots immediately concluded the flight would not reach the runway
column2: and the captain pointed out a large street to the FO as a feasible forced landing site and the FO concurred. Neither pilot could see any better alternative. The left hand prop was then feathered.

column1: The FO maintained control of the aircraft throughout the descent. Airspeed slowed initially to 100 KIAS and later to 90 KIAS. The goal was to control the descent and impact
column2: with a minimum airspeed of 90 KIAS to prevent a departure from controlled flight.

column1: The pilots observed traffic on the road. They revised the intended touchdown site to the grass beside 51st Street
column2: to the right of the traffic and light poles and the left of what they perceived as a frangible fence.

column1: Late in the descent the pilots identified that the fence was actually a noise abatement wall. The FO concluded that the flight could not be extended beyond the noise abatement wall and advised the other crew members. The aircraft landed astride the wall at 90 KIAS. When the aircraft came to a stop
column2: the captain turned off the batteries and the master switch and pressed the cockpit engine fire extinguisher buttons.";18:30;CASA C-212-CC40 Aviocar 200;Fugro Aviation Canada;Friday 1 April 2011

column1: The aircraft maintenance log indicated that on the previous flight (from Anchorage to Seattle
column2: arriving at 07:18)

column4: and that the captain's course deviation indicator (CDI) was frozen. The frozen captain's CDI was determined to be a non-deferrable
column5: Aircraft-on-Ground (AOG) item. There was also a deferred maintenance item (DMI) on the number 1 thrust reverser. Due to concerns expressed by the captain of the incoming flight about the operability of the thrust reversers in consideration of icy runway conditions at Anchorage
column6: maintenance also decided to lube
column7: inspect
column8: and check all four thrust reversers for proper operation.

column1: One mechanic working on the number 2 thrust reverser asked the mechanic working on the number 1 thrust reverser to finish up the aircraft and close all engine cowls

column4: but that he and another mechanic were unable to secure and lock the doors. He stated that about 16:00
column5: they returned to the shop for assistance in locking and securing the cowling doors. He stated that at that time
column6: he entered in the turnover log that all four cowling doors required securing
column7: and also verbally reported this to two other mechanics from the next shift.

column1: One of the company mechanics who took the turnover report on the cowl doors from the first-shift mechanic stated that at about 1530
column2: he received a tie-in from that mechanic (the one assigned to the number 1 thrust reverser) that all cowlings on N811CK needed to be closed.

column1: He noted that the cowlings for the number 1 and number 2 engines were closed and that those for the number 3 and 4 engines were wide open. He assisted in closing the number 3 engine cowl
column2: but did not check the number 1 or number 2 cowlings to ensure that they were secured.

column3: Michigan

column1: The flight engineer reported that the cowlings were closed when he arrived at the aircraft

column1: The flight crew made visual contact with the runway and decided to deviate to the right (west) of the offset Localizer (LLZ) to runway 23. The flight continued towards the runway from a position right of the runway centerline. The flight crew was aiming to land the aircraft at a point between the runway threshold and the touchdown zone.
As the aircraft approached runway 23 it was still in the final right turn over the landing threshold.

The aircraft touched down on runway 23 between the runway threshold and the touchdown zone and to the left of the runway centerline. The Flight Data Recorder (FDR) data indicated that the aircraft was banking more than 11° to the right as the aircraft touched down. At the same time the vertical acceleration was approximately 3.9 G and the rate of descent was greater than 13 feet per second.
The right main landing gear (MLG) shock strut fuse pin sheared and the right MLG collapsed

The test flight was determined to be a high risk. The flight crew reported that during the high-speed descent
column6: at approximately 24
column7: 000 feet
column8: the control yoke began to vibrate rapidly for approximately 3-5 seconds after which elevator control was lost. After declaring an emergency the crew diverted to Salina. Pitch control was established by using horizontal stabilizer pitch trim. The flight crew reported that during final approach to the runway the aircraft nose began to drop and that the flying pilot was unable to raise the nose using a combination of horizontal stabilizer trim and engine power. column9: striking an airport perimeter fence and a berm.;13:00;Learjet 25D;Avcon Industries;Tuesday 12 June 2001

column5: experienced an in-flight fire aft of the left engine shortly after takeoff from Cyril E. King Airport (STT)
column6: Saint Thomas
column7: U.S. Virgin Islands.

column1: The flight was cleared for takeoff from runway 28 at Saint Thomas Airport at 07:47 hours local time.

column2: the local controller advised the flightcrew
column3: ""Convair seven seven quebec observe a lot of smoke coming from your left engine are you in need of any assistance sir""
column4: to which the captain (pilot not flying) stated
column5: ""ah no we are fine..."" The captain attributed the smoke trailing from the left engine to the age of the airplane.

column1: The crew then switched frequencies to San Juan Combined En Route Approach Control (San Juan CERAP). Upon receiving a message from the local controller at Saint Thomas
column2: CERAP reported to the flight crew that flames were now observed on the left hand engine.

column1: After being notified of the fire
column2: the co-pilot reported they checked the engine instruments and did not have any indication of a fire. About that time the owner of the company who was airborne in another airplane told them they needed to return. The captain ordered the co-pilot to go into the cabin to visually look at the left engine and after returning to the cockpit informed the captain there was a fire. The captain advised that he executed the procedures for fire checklist and secured the left engine but the fire continued. The flight returned for landing at Saint Thomas
column4: the pilot of a company airplane reported
column5: ""...you definitely have a fire going.""

column1: The flight continued towards Saint Thomas and ATC communications were transferred to STT ATCT. At 07:53:21
column2: the flight was cleared to land. The captain later reported that while returning to Saint Thomas
column3: he noticed an issue with the left aileron which the co-pilot assisted with. The airplane was landed on runway centerline at 90 knots
column4: but the flightcrew were unable to stop the airplane. The captain also reported that there was no steering
column5: the brakes were not working properly. During the landing roll the airport fire rescue vehicles followed the airplane while attempting to extinguish the fire and avoiding debris that was separating from the airplane. The airplane departed the right side of the runway
column6: crossed a taxiway and a perimeter road
column7: then went through the airport perimeter fence and came to rest upright with the nose section over a public road outside of the airport property.

column1: After the airplane came to rest
column2: the flightcrew exited the airplane from the overwing exits
column3: and the fire rescue vehicles converged on the airplane and extinguished the fire.";07:56;Convair CV-340-71;Tiger Contract Cargo;Monday 17 January 2011

column6: United States of America;"The Do-328Jet was flown to Myrtle Beach on a maintenance repositioning flight. Five passengers were also on board. after obtaining an IFR clearance

column2: ""except for this bleed shutoff valve.""

column7: ""I'm aborting"" and ""we have no airspeed."" The airplane could not be stopped on the remaining runway length. It went through the perimeter fence and crossed Observation Road

column3: Spain;"Airbus G-UKLL was operated by Leisure International Airways and used to operate a holiday charter flight on behalf of Sabre Airways from Manchester to Ibiza. Flight 4064 departed at 22:30
column4: some 15 minutes behind the planned schedule. The handling pilot for the sector was the first officer; this was decided during the pre-flight briefing
column5: given the good meteorological conditions expected at destination. As soon as the Ibiza METAR had been obtained
column6: while still in the cruise phase
column7: the first officer planned for an ILS approach to runway 24
column8: set up the navigation aids and programmed the Flight Management Guidance Computers (FMGC's) accordingly. He pre-selected the BSCU (Brake and Steering Control Unit) Autobrake system to Low. Upon this selection
column9: a 'BRAKES BSCU CH 2 FAULT' was annunciated to the crew. There was no ECAM procedure to be followed. The selection was repeated but the fault remained. The Status Page displayed 'Inop Sys BSCU2 Fault' ('Inoperative System
column10: BSCU Channel 2 Fault'). The crew checked the relevant section of the Flight Crew Operating Manual Volume 3 and this stated that the indication was for' Crew Awareness'. No further crew action was specified. At 00:46 hrs the crew were authorised to land on runway 24
column11: wind of 020deg at 5 knots. The aircraft made the flare and a gentle touchdown about 800 metres from the start of runway 24. A slight tailwind component was apparent
column12: of approx. 4 kt. Reverse thrust was selected and initial deceleration appeared normal. The commander considered that more braking was required in order to slow the aircraft to achieve the planned turn off the runway
column13: so he advised the first officer to apply more braking.

column1: The first officer tried to apply more braking but found this ineffective. He informed the commander of this and
column2: around 80 kt
column3: the first officer reduced reverse thrust. The commander immediately took control
column4: reapplied reverse thrust and attempted to apply the brakes. He too found that there was no braking available. Therefore
column5: the commander began to swerve the aircraft each way in an attempt to increase the available braking distance and slow the aircraft down by lateral skidding before reaching the end of the runway
column6: with the tyres leaving rubber marks on the runway surface. The aircraft left the end of the runway
column7: entering the paved stopway and then into and beyond the 60 m overrun area. The captain elected to turn the aircraft to the right to remain within the aerodrome boundary. The nose landing gear collapsed as the aircraft ran on softer and more rugged terrain to approach an earth embankment and then came to rest with both engines partially embedded in it.";ca 00:50;Airbus A320-212;Air UK Leisure;Thursday 21 May 1998

column1: The flight crew received weather information and IFR route clearance from the controller at Fort Lauderdale International Airport
column2: Florida
column3: USA. Departure time was 13:06 hours local time. From the cockpit voice recorder it was evident that the flight crew failed to brief or discuss the weather for departure or enroute. Additionally
column4: they failed to complete several important checklists as required and did not observe sterile cockpit procedures during startup
column5: run-up
column6: taxi and takeoff.

column1: The enroute and approach checklists were not conducted prior to arriving near their destination of Marsh Harbour Airport
column2: Bahamas. The crew was aware of the weather conditions at Marsh Harbor
column3: which included heavy rainshowers; however
column4: they never formulated a plan for diversion if the weather was bad at their time of arrival.

column1: As the approach continued there were constant disagreements between both pilots as to who had the runway in sight. Due to the weather conditions
column2: visibility of the runway was intermittent
column3: yet the crew continued descending visually in an attempt to land the aircraft on a runway that was not in sight and not served by an instrument landing system (ILS).

column1: The crew flew a non-stabilized approach and speed was not constant as they kept increasing and decreasing speed throughout the final approach. The captain
column2: who initially was the non-flying pilot
column3: while on final approach and below 500 feet AGL
column4: assumed control of the aircraft from the flying pilot (first officer). At some point the captain lost use of his windshield wiper as it went over-center and was stuck. During the final moments of the approach. The copilot again assumed control of the aircraft and seconds before touch down
column5: the captain (despite having no visual contact with the runway due to the intense downpour of rain and the non-use of his windshield wiper)
column6: again took control of the aircraft from the first officer.

column1: By the time the aircraft touched the runway
column2: there were several control wheel exchanges between both pilots while neither had a visual of the runway.

column1: The aircraft initially touched down at 17:49:02 with a recorded vertical load factor of +2.16G
column2: approximately 14 seconds after crossing the threshold of runway 09. Upon initial landing however
column3: the aircraft bounced and became airborne
column4: reaching a calculated maximum height of approximately 15 feet AGL.

column1: The aircraft bounced a second time at 17:49:07 with a recorded vertical load factor of +3.19G. During this second bounce
column2: the pitch attitude was 1.8 degrees nose down
column3: heading 102 degrees magnetic and airspeed 106 KIAS.

column1: The aircraft made consecutive contact with the runway approximately three times. The third and final bounce occurred at 17:49:14 with a recorded vertical load factor of +3.66G. During the third bounce
column2: the pitch attitude was 2.2 degrees nose down
column3: heading 099 degrees magnetic and airspeed 98 KIAS.

column1: As a result of the hard touchdown
column2: damage was sustained to the right wing and right hand engine/propeller. The right hand engine parameters recorded a rapid loss of power with decreasing engine speed and torque
column3: and subsequent propeller stoppage. The aircraft veered off to the right at approximate time of 17:49:20 on a heading of 131 degrees magnetic at a point approximately 6
column4: 044 feet from the threshold of runway 09.

column1: The recorded airspeed was 44 KIAS with the left hand engine torque at 26 % and the right hand engine torque at 0%. The aircraft came to a full stop at approximate time 17:49:25 on a heading of 231 degrees magnetic. When the aircraft came to a stop
column2: the flight and cabin crew and 21 passengers evacuated the aircraft. The evacuation was uneventful using the main entrance door.";13:50;Saab 340B;SkyBahamas Airlines;Thursday 13 June 2013

column1: 05-MAR-2016;Boeing 767-34AFER (WL);N305UP;UPS;Albuquerque ...;1995-12-02  (20 years 3 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Cargo;Louisville International Airport

column5: United States of America;"A Boeing 767-300F
column6: N305UP
column7: operated by United Parcel Service (UPS) as flight 916 was substantially damaged following a tailstrike during landing on runway 03 at the Albuquerque International Sunport Airport (ABQ)
column8: New Mexico. Neither of the 2 flight crew were injured. The flight originated from the Louisville International Airport (SDF)
column9: Kentucky.

column1: The airplane sustained damage to a 23 foot long section of lower fuselage skin
column2: 4 fuselage stringers
column3: 5 fuselage frames
column4: 3 floor stringers and the tail skid. The replacement of the frames and stringers was considered a major repair.

column1: According to the operator
column2: the captain was the pilot flying
column3: and the first officer the pilot monitoring for the flight from SDF-ABQ. Ground operations were normal in SDF and no aircraft loading or Weight and Balance discrepancies were noted. The climb
column4: cruise
column5: and descent portion of the flight were uneventful. Weather conditions at ABQ prior to arrival were reported as visual conditions
column6: with wind from 090 at 20 knots gusting to 29 knots. The target approach speed used was 146 knots. The crew was vectored to the ILS approach to runway 03 and joined the localizer and glideslope using the autopilot. The autopilot was then disengaged at 1103 feet Height Above Touchdown (HAT) and at 1000 feet HAT the approach met all UPS Stabilized Approach criteria with the aircraft fully configured at flaps 30
column7: gear down
column8: and speed 145 knots. At 500 feet HAT the approach continued to meet all stabilized approach criteria with speed 146 knots. Flight data indicated that the crosswind component at this point was 23 knots from the right.

column1: At 158 feet above touchdown the approach met all stabilized approach criteria and the captain disconnected the autothrottles. UPS guidance recommends use of the autothrottle until 50 feet above touchdown. From this point on the approach until touchdown
column2: the aircraft pitch attitude began to increase as the airspeed slowly decreased. Flight Data indicates that the thrust levers were at a reduced thrust setting when the autothrottles were disconnected and remained at that setting until touchdown. At 1.75 seconds from touchdown the airspeed had decayed to 129 knots and the aircraft pitch had increased to 7.2 degrees. The crosswind had also decreased and was now 13 knots from the right. At touchdown the airspeed was 128 knots and pitch attitude 8.4 degrees. The tailskid impacted the runway at touchdown followed immediately by the lower aft fuselage as the pitch attitude increased momentarily to 8.6 degrees. Initial tailskid impact occurred at approximately 800 feet from the runway threshold.

column1: The crew reported that they encountered a 10 knot wind loss just prior to touchdown and landed firmer than normal
column2: but didn't suspect that they had struck the tailskid.";06:31;Boeing 767-34AFER (WL);United Parcel Service - UPS;Saturday 5 March 2016

column1: 10-jan-00;Saab 340B;HB-AKK;Crossair;near Nassenwil;1990;Fatalities: 3 / Occupants: 3;Fatalities: 7 / Occupants: 7;Damaged beyond repair;En route (ENR);International Scheduled Passenger;Zürich-Kloten Airport (ZRH/LSZH)
column2: Switzerland;Dresden Airport (DRS/EDDC)
column3: Germany;"At 17:00 HB-AKK arrived at Zurich tarmac position F74 following a flight from Guernsey. The aircraft was then prepared for flight CRX498 to Dresden.

column1: Taxi clearance was given at 17:50 and the crew taxied to runway 28. At 17:54 the aircraft was cleared for takeoff. Takeoff and climb were conducted with flaps at 0 degrees
column2: which is normal for a Saab 340 departing from runway 28. The aircraft climbed normally at 136 knots IAS. After retracting the gear the Flight Director was switched on
column3: NAV mode engaged and LRN1 captured. The initial track was normal
column4: except for a track drift to the south of about 7deg. While climbing through 2500 feet QNH the crew switched to Zurich Departure Control and were recleared to climb to FL110. At 17:55 the crew were cleared to make a left turn to intercept airway R234 to the ZUE beacon (the Zurich East -ZUE One Yankee departure). A left turn was initiated
column5: during which the first officer entered a command in the Flight Management System (FMS). After having turned left for 7 seconds the captain started a right turn
column6: which would be consistent with Flight Director commands generated by the FMS for a 'direct to ZUE'. The right turn was continued with an increasing bank angle
column7: which continued to 42deg with a constant rate of climb
column8: whilst the pitch concurrently reduced to 0deg. Right aileron input then caused a increase in right roll rate. The first officer advised the captain that the aircraft should actually turn to the left. This was also noted by the Zurich departure controller at 17:56:20
column9: who asked the crew about the direction of the turn. The first officer replied: ""Moment please
column10: stand by"". Upon which the Departure controller recleared the flight to continue the right turn direct to ZUE. By then the pitch had also decreased rapidly
column11: accompanied by a marked speed increase and the Saab entered a high speed high-rate spiral descent. At 17:56:28 the aircraft crashed in an open field.

column1: Weather reported included temperature 2deg C; dew point 1deg C; 1032 mB wind WNW/3 knots and light drizzle. The captain was an employee of Moldavian Airlines

column3: of which 1900 hrs on the Saab 340B. The f/o had a total experience of 1800 hours
column4: of which 1100 hours on the Saab 340B";17:56;Saab 340B;Crossair;Monday 10 January 2000

column5: United States of America;"Citation N86CE departed Sun Valley (SUN) at 05:50 MST on a flight to Carlsbad (CLD). The airplane climbed to its assigned cruising altitude of FL380
column6: which was reached at about 06:06 MST. The descend for Carlsbad was started an hour later
column7: at 06:06 PST. Air traffic control cleared the flightcrew for the ILS approach to runway 24
column8: which was 4
column9: 897 feet long. The flightcrew then reported that they had the runway in sight
column10: cancelled their IFR clearance
column11: and executed a VFR approach in VFR conditions to the airport. The reported winds favoured a landing toward the east
column12: onto the opposite runway (runway 6). During the approach
column13: after a query from the first officer
column14: the captain indicated to the first officer that he was going to ""...land to the east
column15: consistent with the reported winds. However
column16: the final approach and subsequent landing were made to runway 24
column17: which produced a six-knot tailwind. During the approach sequence the captain maintained an airspeed that was approximately 30 knots higher than the correct airspeed for the aircraft's weight
column18: resulting in the aircraft touching down about 1
column19: 500 feet further down the runway than normal
column20: and much faster than normal. The captain then delayed the initiation of a go-around until the first officer asked if they were going around. Although the aircraft lifted off the runway surface prior to departing the paved overrun during the delayed go-around it impacted a localizer antenna platform
column21: whose highest non-frangible structure was located approximately 304 feet past the end of the runway
column22: and approximately two feet lower than the terrain at the departure end of the runway. The aircraft continued airborne as it flew over downsloping terrain for about 400 more feet before colliding with the terrain and a commercial storage building that was located at an elevation approximately 80 feet lower than the terrain at the end of the runway. The localizer antenna platform was located outside of the designated runway safety area
column23: and met all applicable FAA siting requirements.";06:40;Cessna 560 Citation V;Goship Air;Tuesday 24 January 2006

column1: The Sunwing aircraft was being prepared to be towed to another location at the airport. A Sunwing maintenance technician was in the cockpit of C-FPRP
column2: and the aircraft's APU was running. Two ground personnel were in the cab of the tow vehicle. The tow vehicle was informed by the North Apron controller to pushback at their discretion.

column2: and an evacuation was ordered shortly after. The tow vehicle operator pulled the Sunwing aircraft back towards the gate to separate the two aircraft.

column3: Luxembourg;"The aircraft was operating a scheduled freight flight from Barcelona
column4: Spain to Luxembourg. The aircraft's actual departure time in Barcelona was 11:13 local time. At 12:40
column5: flight CLX 793 contacted Luxembourg Approach (APP) for the first time and was advised by the approach controller that Low Visibility Procedures (LVP) were in operation.

column1: Fog prevailed at Luxembourg airport with a cloud base at 100 feet overcast and a visibility of 100 meters
column2: temperature and dew point were at 1°C.

column1: The aircraft was cleared for an ILS approach on runway 24 at 12:49. RVR readings were 350/275/375 meters. At 12:50:55
column2: CLX 793 reported established on the localiser for runway 24 and was transferred to Tower. RVR readings had decreased to 350/250/350 meters.

column1: CLX 793 contacted Luxembourg Tower (TWR) at 12:51:40 and reported established on the ILS 24. The Tower Controller then cleared them to land.

column2: reaching decision height at 17 ft
column3: the Pilot Flying called out 'landing’. During the flare
column4: the airplane impacted a maintenance van 'ELE 23' positioned slightly to the right of the centreline of runway 24 and about 340 meters from the threshold
column5: with the front-end pointing into the opposite direction (060°). The roofline of the van was at a height of 2.54 m (8 ft). The right hand body landing gear of the Boeing 747-400F impacted the roof of ELE 23 with tire nr 12 slightly below the roofline of the van on a backward sloped roof section and rolled over it
column6: damaging the roof on the whole length of the vehicle. The van's lightbar
column7: as well as its R/T antennas
column8: were ripped off on impact. The maintenance crew working on the centreline lights outside of ELE 23 ran off the side of the runway as soon as they noticed an increasing noise from a landing aircraft.

column1: The aircraft landed safely at 12:53:51.
After touchdown
column3: the Pilot Flying mentioned to the Pilot Monitoring (PM) that there was a car in the touchdown zone. The PM
column4: monitoring the instruments during landing in accordance

column1: with company procedures
column2: didn't notice it.

column1: The aircraft vacated runway 24 at taxiway Echo and at 12:56:28
column2: while taxiing to apron P7
column3: the PF informed the Tower controller about a car in the touchdown zone. The controller asked if there was a problem and the PF denied. The aircraft continued to the parking position on apron P7 without further incident.";12:53;Boeing 747-4R7F;Cargolux;Thursday 21 January 2010

column5: United States of America;"A Learjet plane
column6: operating as Royal Air Freight flight RAX988
column7: was destroyed when it impacted water and terrain while maneuvering to final approach to runway 34 at Chicago Executive Airport (PWK). The wreckage came to rest on the west bank of the Des Plaines River
column8: in a forest preserve south of the airport. Both pilots were killed in the accident.

column1: The flight departed Pontiac-Oakland County International Airport
column2: MI (PTK) at 13:35 and was scheduled to pickup cargo at Chicago-Executive Airport
column3: IL (PWK).

column1: During the descent and 14 minutes before the accident
column2: the airplane encountered a layer of moderate rime ice. The captain
column3: who was the pilot flying
column4: and the first officer
column5: who was the monitoring pilot
column6: made multiple statements which were consistent with their awareness and presence of airframe icing. After obtaining visual flight rules conditions
column7: the flight crew cancelled the instrument flight rules clearance and continued with a right
column8: circling approach to runway 34. While turning into the base leg of the traffic pattern
column9: and 45 seconds prior to the accident
column10: the captain called for full flaps and the engine power levers were adjusted several times between 50 and 95 percent. In addition
column11: the captain inquired about the autopilot and fuel balance. In response
column12: the first officer stated that he did not think that the spoilerons were working. Shortly thereafter
column13: the first officer gave the command to add full engine power and the airplane impacted terrain.

column1: There was no evidence of flight crew impairment or fatigue in the final 30 minutes of the flight. The cockpit voice recorder showed multiple instances during the flight in which the airplane was below 10
column2: 000 feet mean sea level that the crew was engaged in discussions that were not consistent with a sterile cockpit environment
column3: for example a lengthy discussion about Class B airspeeds
column4: which may have led to a relaxed and casual cockpit atmosphere. In addition
column5: the flight crew appears to have conducted checklists in a generally informal manner. As the flight was conducted by a Part 135 operator
column6: it would be expected that both pilots were versed with the importance of sterile cockpit rules and the importance of adhering to procedures
column7: including demonstrating checklist discipline.

column1: For approximately the last 24 seconds of flight
column2: both pilots were likely focusing their attention on activities to identify and understand the reason for the airplane's roll handling difficulties
column3: as noted by the captain's comment related to the fuel balance. These events
column4: culminating in the first officer's urgent command to add full power
column5: suggested that neither pilot detected the airplane's decaying energy state before it reached a critical level for the conditions it encountered.";ca 13:30;Learjet 35A;Royal Air Freight;Tuesday 5 January 2010

column1: 12-MAR-2015;Raytheon 390 Premier I;G-OOMC;Pool Aviation;Blackpool Ai...;2005;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Int'l Non Scheduled Passenger;Avignon-Caum Airport (AVN/LFMV)
column2: France;Blackpool Airport (BLK/EGNH)
column3: United Kingdom;"The aircraft planned to fly from Avignon Airport
column4: France to Blackpool Airport
column5: with two flight crew and two passengers. The co-pilot performed the external checks; this included checking the fluid level in the hydraulic reservoir. The aircraft was refuelled to 3
column6: 000 lb and
column7: after the passengers boarded
column8: it departed for Blackpool. The commander was the pilot flying (PF).

column1: The takeoff and cruise to Blackpool were uneventful.
The commander planned and briefed for the NDB approach to runway 10
column2: which was to be flown with the autopilot engaged. Whilst descending through FL120
column3: the left
column4: followed by the right
column5: hydraulic low pressure cautions illuminated. Upon checking the hydraulic pressure gauge
column6: the pressure was noted to be ‘cycling up and down’
column7: but for the majority of the time it indicated about 2
column8: 800 psi (in the green arc). During this time the hydraulic low pressure cautions went on and off irregularly
column9: with the left caution being on more often than the right. The co-pilot then actioned the ‘HYDRAULIC SYSTEM - HYDRAULIC PUMP FAILURE’ checklist. It stated that if the hydraulic pressure was a minimum of 2
column10: 800 psi
column11: the flight could be continued.

column1: Just before the aircraft reached the Blackpool NDB
column2: the commander commented ""it’s dropping""
column3: but he could not recall what he was referring to. This was followed by the roll fail and speed brk [brake] fail caution messages illuminating. The co-pilot then actioned the applicable checklists. These stated that the Landing Distances Required (LDR) would increase by approximately 65% and 21%
column4: respectively. As the roll fail LDR increase was greater than that of the speed brk fail
column5: the crew used an LDR increase of 65% which the co-pilot equated to 5
column6: 950 ft. Runway 10 at Blackpool has an LDA of 6
column7: 131 ft
column8: therefore they elected to continue to Blackpool.

column1: The roll fail checklist stated that a ‘FLAPS UP’ landing was required. The co-pilot then calculated the VREF of 132 kt
column2: including a 20 kt increment
column3: as stipulated by the ‘FLAPS UP
column5: OR 20 APPROACH AND LANDING’ checklist. The commander then continued with the approach.

column1: At about 4 nm on final approach the co-pilot lowered the landing gear
column2: in response to the commander’s request. About 8 seconds later the commander said ""just lost it all""; referring to the general state of the aircraft. This was followed almost immediately by the landing gear unsafe aural warning
column3: as the main landing gear was not indicating down and locked. Whilst descending through 1
column4: 000 ft
column5: at just over 3 nm from the threshold
column6: the commander asked the co-pilot to action the ‘ALTERNATE GEAR EXTENSION’ checklist.

column1: The commander then discontinued the approach by selecting ALT HOLD
column2: increased engine thrust and selected a 500 ft/min rate of climb on the autopilot. However
column3: a few seconds later
column4: before the co-pilot could action the checklist
column5: the main gear indicated down and locked. The commander disconnected the autopilot and continued the approach. The crew did not consider reviewing the ‘HYDRAULIC SYSTEM - HYDRAULIC PUMP FAILURE’ checklist as they had not recognised the symptoms of loss of hydraulic pressure.

column1: When ATC issued the aircraft its landing clearance the wind was from 140° at 17 kt. This equated to a headwind component of about 10 kt and a crosswind of about 12 kt. As the aircraft descended through 500 ft (the Minimum Descent Altitude (MDA) for the approach) at 1.5 nm from the threshold
column2: the commander instructed the co-pilot to advise ATC that they had a hydraulic problem and to request the RFFS to be put on standby. There was a slight delay in transmitting this request
column3: due to another aircraft on frequency
column4: but the request was acknowledged by ATC.

column1: The aircraft touched down about 1
column2: 500 ft from the start of the paved surface at an airspeed of 132 kt and a groundspeed of 124 kt. When the commander applied the toe (power) brakes he felt no significant retardation. During the landing roll no attempt was made to apply the emergency brakes
column3: as required in the event of a power brake failure. The co-pilot asked if he should try to operate the lift dump
column4: but it failed to function
column5: due to the lack of hydraulic pressure. At some point
column6: while the aircraft was on the runway
column7: the co-pilot transmitted a MAYDAY call to ATC. When an overrun appeared likely
column8: the commander shut down the engines. The aircraft subsequently overran the end of the runway at a groundspeed of about 80 kt. The commander later commented that he was in a ""state of panic"" during the landing roll and was unsure whether or not he had applied the emergency brake.

column1: As the aircraft left the paved surface the commander steered the aircraft slightly right to avoid a shallow downslope to the left of runway’s extended centreline. The aircraft continued across the rough
column2: uneven ground
column3: during which the nose gear collapsed and the wing to fuselage attachments were severely damaged. Once it had come to a stop
column4: he shut down the remaining aircraft systems. The passengers and crew
column5: who were uninjured
column6: vacated the aircraft via the entry/exit door and moved upwind to a safe distance.";11:48;Raytheon 390 Premier I;Pool Aviation;Thursday 12 March 2015

column8: 000 feet msl. At 16:15

column10: the pilot declared an emergency because of a lack of engine power
column11: reporting that they were ""dead stick"" and without any power. About 23 seconds later
column13: the pilot transmitted ""we've lost all power
column14: and we have no hydraulics."" When the controller asked if the airplane remained controllable
column15: the pilot replied ""ah
column16: barely controllable."" The controller advised that all runways at South Bend were available for landing and issued the current winds
column17: which were 130-degrees at 10 knots. At 16:15:22
column18: the pilot transmitted that the airplane’s navigational systems were inoperative and requested a radar vector toward the airport. The controller replied that the airport was 9 miles directly ahead of the airplane's current position. At 16:16:12
column19: the controller told the pilot to turn 10-degrees left to intersect runway 9R. At 16:16:15
column20: the pilot replied ""26DK
column21: turning left."" No additional voice communications were received from the accident airplane. The approach controller continued to transmit radar vectors toward runway 9R without any response from the accident pilot. At 16:18:58
column22: the approach controller told the accident airplane to go-around because the main landing gear was not extended. (The tower controller had informed the approach controller that only the nose landing gear was extended) The accident airplane was then observed to climb and enter a right traffic pattern for runway 9R. The airplane made another landing approach to runway 9R with only the nose landing gear extended. Several witnesses observed the airplane bounce several times on the runway before it ultimately entered a climbing right turn. The airplane was then observed to enter a nose low descent into a nearby residential community.

2-apr-11;Gulfstream G650;N652GD;Gulfstream Aerospace;Roswell Inte...;2010;Fatalities: 4 / Occupants: 4;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;Takeoff (TOF);Test;Roswell International Air Center Airport
column2: NM (ROW/KROW)
column3: United States of America;Roswell International Air Center Airport
column4: NM (ROW/KROW)
column5: United States of America;"A Gulfstream G650 jet was damaged beyond repair in a takeoff accident at Roswell International Air Center Airport
column6: NM (ROW). The two pilots and the two flight test engineers were fatally injured.

column1: The accident occurred during a planned one-engine-inoperative (OEI) takeoff when a stall on the right outboard wing produced a rolling moment that the flight crew was not able to control
column2: which led to the right wingtip contacting the runway and the airplane departing the runway from the right side. After departing the runway
column3: the airplane impacted a concrete structure and an airport weather station
column4: resulting in extensive structural damage and a postcrash fire that completely consumed the fuselage and cabin interior.

column1: The National Transportation Safety Board's (NTSB) investigation of this accident found that the airplane stalled while lifting off the ground. As a result
column2: the NTSB examined the role of ""ground effect"" on the airplane's performance. Ground effect refers to changes in the airflow over the airplane resulting from the proximity of the airplane to the ground. Ground effect results in increased lift and reduced drag at a given angle of attack (AOA) as well as a reduction in the stall AOA. In preparing for the G650 field performance flight tests
column3: Gulfstream considered ground effect when predicting the airplane's takeoff performance capability but overestimated the in ground effect stall AOA. Consequently
column4: the airplane's AOA threshold for stick shaker (stall warning) activation and the corresponding pitch limit indicator (on the primary flight display) were set too high
column5: and the flight crew received no tactile or visual warning before the actual stall occurred.

column1: The accident flight was the third time that a right outboard wing stall occurred during G650 flight testing. Gulfstream did not determine (until after the accident) that the cause of two previous uncommanded roll events was a stall of the right outboard wing at a lower-than-expected AOA. (Similar to the accident circumstances
column2: the two previous events occurred during liftoff; however
column3: the right wingtip did not contact the runway during either of these events.) If Gulfstream had performed an in-depth aerodynamic analysis of these events shortly after they occurred
column4: the company could have recognized before the accident that the actual in-ground-effect stall AOA was lower than predicted.

column1: During field performance testing before the accident
column2: the G650 consistently exceeded target takeoff safety speeds (V2). V2 is the speed that an airplane attains at or before a height above the ground of 35 feet with one engine inoperative. Gulfstream needed to resolve these V2 exceedances because achieving the planned V2 speeds was necessary to maintain the airplane's 6
column3: 000-foot takeoff performance guarantee (at standard sea level conditions). If the G650 did not meet this takeoff performance guarantee
column4: then the airplane could only operate on longer runways. However
column5: a key assumption that Gulfstream used to develop takeoff speeds was flawed and resulted in V2 speeds that were too low and takeoff distances that were longer than anticipated.

column1: Rather than determining the root cause for the V2 exceedance problem
column2: Gulfstream attempted to reduce the V2 speeds and the takeoff distances by modifying the piloting technique used to rotate the airplane for takeoff. Further
column3: Gulfstream did not validate the speeds using a simulation or physics-based dynamic analysis before or during field performance testing. If the company had done so
column4: then it could have recognized that the target V2 speeds could not be achieved even with the modified piloting technique. In addition
column5: the difficulties in achieving the target V2 speeds were exacerbated in late March 2011 when the company reduced the target pitch angle for some takeoff tests without an accompanying increase in the takeoff speeds.

column1: Gulfstream maintained an aggressive schedule for the G650 flight test program so that the company could obtain Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) type certification by the third quarter of 2011. The schedule pressure
column2: combined with inadequately developed organizational processes for technical oversight and safety management
column3: led to a strong focus on keeping the program moving and a reluctance to challenge key assumptions and highlight anomalous airplane behavior during tests that could slow the pace of the program. These factors likely contributed to key errors
column4: including the development of unachievable takeoff speeds
column5: as well as the superficial review of the two previous uncommanded roll events
column6: which allowed the company's overestimation of the in-ground-effect stall AOA to remain undetected.";09:34;Gulfstream G650;Gulfstream Aerospace;Saturday 2 April 2011

column1: At 02:05 the crew reported at 2100 m
column2: runway in sight. The airplane still had an airspeed of 540 km/h. The maximum speed at which the landing gear may be lowered was 400 km/h. At 02:06:56 the airplane level off at 900 m
column3: the airspeed still being about 420 km/h. The first officer ordered the gear down and the speed further decreased to 395 km/h with engines at idle. The airspeed further decreased to 365 km/h where the recommended speed was 370 km/h in this stage of the flight. Power was added slowly. This was only just sufficient for maintaining an altitude of 850 m at 355-360 km/h. At 02:07:46
column4: while still in the left hand turn
column5: the angle of attack increased to 16
column6: 5° because the autopilot attempted to maintain altitude with a decreasing speed. An aural warning then sounded
column7: indicating a high angle of attack. The first officer attempted to correct this and by using the control column
column8: he disconnected the autopilot. Because he deflected the control column to the left
column9: the left bank increased trough the maximum permissible value of -30° to -44°
column10: and then to -48°. With the nose pitched down the speed increased to 400 m.

column1: The airplane entered a layer of clouds

column1: The captain intervened and attempted to control the airplane. He alternately deflecting the steering wheel to the left and right. An intensive deflection of steering control to the right
column2: caused a positive angular acceleration of +4
column3: 4°/sec2. The captain reacted by deflecting the steering wheel to the left again. The first officer now realizes that the airplane is in a severe left bank (-45°) and indicates that they should be rolling to the right.

column1: Because of an increase in vertical descent rate (20 m/sec)

column1: The pilot stated that the purpose of the flight was a Beechcraft B100 initial training flight with a second pilot who occupied the right pilot seat. According to the Federal Aviation Administration inspector

column4: he performed the airplane checklist items that the flight instructor read to him. The left seat pilot said that the landing gear extended

column1: The aircraft came to rest approximately 2
column2: 518 feet from runway 18 touchdown end and 100 feet west of the runway edge in a field of grass. The right hand main gear was collapsed
column3: right hand prop blades were bent and the right wing leading edge and tip was damaged. Evidence of fuel leakage was noted surrounding the right wing in the grass. The wing top skin outboard of the engine nacelle displayed evidence of wrinkling.

column1: Post-accident examination revealed the bottom right wing skin to the integral fuel tank was torn resulting in an approximate five by three inch hole. The right main gear actuator assembly exhibited numerous bent parts and was broken out of its mounting structure. The inboard top actuator mounting structure was torn away from the airframe. The right nacelle fuel tank bulkhead was ruptured with the top of the gear actuator resting inside the tank area. The top wing skin wrinkling was not as evident post recovery but still shows signs of damage. Puncture damage to the fuselage pressure vessel was noted in 5 places below the copilot side window and a two-inch crack or tear was found on the belly skin approximately centered between the main gear legs.
The rigging for the landing gear system could not be checked nor could functional gear swing test be performed due to damage incurred to the system from the accident.
The accident aircraft

column1: 29-jan-13;Canadair CRJ-200ER;UP-CJ006;SCAT;near Almaty Airpo...;2000;Fatalities: 5 / Occupants: 5;Fatalities: 16 / Occupants: 16;Destroyed;Approach (APR);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Kokshetau Airport (KOV/UACK)
column2: Kazakhstan;Almaty Airport (ALA/UAAA)
column3: Kazakhstan;"A Canadair CRJ-200 operated by SCAT was destroyed in an accident near Almaty Airport (ALA)
column4: Kazakhstan
column5: killing all 16 passengers and five crew members. Flight DV760 operated on a domestic flight from Kokshetau Airport (KOV) to Almaty (ALA).

column1: Weather forecast obtained by the crew before departure showed a visibility of 800 m at Almaty with a vertical visibility of 90 m
column2: and temporary reduced visibility to 200 meters. The flight took off at 11:19 hours local time. The captain was Pilot Flying.

column1: At 12:00 the flight contacted Almaty Control and received the current weather conditions which showed a limited visibility for runway 23R of 200 m. At 12:40 the flight was cleared to descend to FL80. By then visibility had decreased to 175 m. The captain decided to continue descent and prepare for an approach to decision height. The captain became increasingly stressed by the poor weather conditions. After reaching FL80 the crew were told to remain at that altitude because of another flight in the area.
This provoked a strong emotional reaction from the captain.

At 12:57 the flight was then cleared down to 1600 m. During the descent the lack of improvement of weather conditions caused a greater and greater irritation on the part of the captain. When turning to finals the runway visual range (RVR) for the first
column2: mid and last part of runway 23R was reported as 275-250-225 m in freezing fog with a vertical visibility of 40 meters. With continuing visibility updates the flight crew kept descending until it was clear that a landing was impossible given the lack of visual contact with the ground.

column1: A missed approach was initiated at 13:10 from a height of 180 m. The autopilot was disconnected and the TO/GA button was pushed. Engine power increased and the flaps were raised to 8°. In the four seconds after pressing to TO/GA button there were no control inputs. Then the captain pushed the control column forward
column2: causing the aircraft to descend. The EGPWS warning sounded as the pitch changed to -9. The observer pilot tried to draw attention on the EGPWS warning but there was no response on the controls by the flight crew. Pitch angle further increased to -16° and vertical speed was -20 to -30 m/sec. The aircraft impacted the ground at high speed and a -20° pitch angle and broke up.";13:10;Canadair CL-600-2B19 Regional Jet CRJ-200ER;SCAT;Tuesday 29 January 2013

column2: op.for Air Nostrum;Melilla Airp...;1990;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 5;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 14;Damaged beyond repair;Landing (LDG);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Málaga Airport (AGP/LEMG)

column4: Spain;"Flight 8276 was being operated by Denim Air
column5: under a wet-lease agreement with Air Nostrum. The Fokker took off from Málaga at 11:32 for a cross-Mediterranean flight to the Spanish enclave of Melilla. The aircraft climbed to its assigned cruising altitude of FL130. After contacting Melilla tower at 11:48 the crew were told to start the descent on their own discretion and to expect a runway 33 approach. A company flight was second on approach and requested runway 15 for landing. The ATC asked the crew of PH-FZE ""would you admit to use one five or do you prefer to keep on runway three three?"" The question was repeated and it took some time for the crew of PH-FZE to answer: ""We can accept runway one five"" at 11:56. They were then cleared to runway 15 with wind 250° and 11 kt. Four minutes later the aircraft was cleared to land with wind 240° at 12 kt varying between 210° and 300°. Due to the runway change
column6: the pilot in command had decided to land with flaps 35° and a reference speed of 95 KIAS. The aircraft made some S-turns to lose altitude because it was a little high in the approach path. The airplane overflew the displaced threshold of runway 15 at approximately 15 ft. During the landing
column7: the pilot in command realised that he could not engage the propeller ground idle/reverse
column8: he said ""I have no reverse"" and applied brakes in an attempt to stop the aircraft. Later on
column9: the co-pilot also applied brakes. During the landing roll the aircraft did not decelerate as expected. The wheel number 3 became locked and was deflated by a flat spot. The aircraft started to veer to the left of the runway until wheel number 1 left the runway at around 150 m before the end of the 1347 m long runway. The Fokker continued down an embankment of around 15 m in height and came to rest against the airport perimeter fence. The fuselage broke near seat rows 6 to 8
column10: and the floor was heavily deformed between those rows. After the aircraft came to a stop
column11: the captain had been injured
column12: and the crew members were frozen for a while
column13: until the flight observer pilot who was in the jump seat stated that the occupants should leave the aircraft immediately and started carrying out the on-ground emergency checklist. He pulled both fire handles and tried to close both fuel levers
column14: but he was unable to close those levers. Then the captain turned on the evacuation lights. In the mean time
column15: after a while and in absence of commands from the cockpit
column16: the rear flight attendant instructed the passengers
column17: who were all seated in the rear part of the cabin
column18: to leave the aircraft through door 2R
column19: which opened without problem.";12:01;Fokker 50;null;Friday 17 January 2003
