column4: Kyrgyzstan;"A Boeing 747-412F cargo plane was destroyed after impacting terrain near Bishkek-Manas International Airport (FRU). All four crew members and 35 persons on the ground were killed.

column1: Flight TK6491 departed Hong Kong on a cargo service to Istanbul
column2: carrying a load of 85618 kgs. An en route refueling and crew change stop was planned at Bishkek
column3: Kyrgyzstan.

column1: Weather at Bishkek was poor with winds from 60°at 1 m/s and a visibility (RVR) of 400m at the beginning of the runway; 350m at the mid-point and 400m at the end of the runway. Vertical visibility was 50 m. Air temperature was -9°C
column2: dew point -10°C
column3: pressure (QNH) was 1023
column4: 9 hPa.

column1: The initial descent towards Bishkek was normal. The crew contacted Approach Control at 07:06 hours and were cleared for a descent to FL060 as per TOKPA 1 STAR (Standard terminal arrival route). The aircraft overflew the TOPKA reporting point at 07:11 at FL092 while in descent. According to the approach chart
column2: FL060 or above should be reached when overflying TOKPA.

column1: Shortly afterwards the controller cleared the flight for an ILS approach to runway 26. At 07:12 the controller cleared the crew for further descent to altitude 3400 ft. The aircraft was meanwhile crossing FL074. The crew was busy monitoring the flight altitude and was aware they were higher than the STAR chart.
The localizer was capture at 3600 ft agl. At that time the altitude should have been 1345 ft agl (3400 ft amsl).
At 07:15:21 after the crew confirmed capturing the localizer
column2: the flight was handed over to Tower Control.

column1: At a distance of 1.7 nm the aircraft reached 3400 ft amsl and the ALT HOLD OPER autopilot mode was engaged longitudinally. At that point the flight was already over 400 ft above the glideslope. The glideslope mode was armed (G/S MODE ARM)
column2: but the glideslope was not captured.

column1: At 07:15:31 while the aircraft was in level flight at 3400 ft amsl Outer Marker overflight was recorded (as per the approach chart Outer Marker overflight altitude is 2800 ft amsl).
A glideslope signal was captured at 07:15:52
column2: at that time the aircraft was almost over VOR/DME MANAS at a distance of approximately 1.1 nm from the runway 26 threshold
column3: at an angle of approximately 9°. However
column4: as per the approach chart
column5: the rated glideslope angle is 3°. The aircraft automatically initiated descent with a vertical speed of up to 1425 ft/min.

column1: Six seconds after the glideslope capture LAND 3 autoland status annunciation was recorded. The crew called out the annunciation.

At 07:16:01 at 3300 ft amsl the aircraft crossed the Middle Marker (as per the approach chart MM overflight altitude is 2290 ft amsl). After  the  glideslope  descent  was  initiated  the  glideslope  pointer  was  fluctuating within - 4 to + 4 dots.

column2: at 3150 ft amsl
column3: AP CAUTION and FMA FAULT 2 events were recorded. These events were continuously recorded almost until the end of the flight. An FMA FAULT 2 means that the autopilot can no longer track the actual glideslope
column4: but will track a constant 3° glide path until a valid glideslope signal is regained or until the crew intervenes by disengaging the autopilot or initiating a go-around.

column1: As the aircraft was descending LAND 3 status degraded to LAND 2
column2: which was confirmed by the crew callout. LAND 2 means that the autopilot flight director system redundancy is reduced to the use of only two of the three autopilots.

column1: The EGPWS 'Glideslope' alert was then triggered 5 times.

At 07:17:04 the flight crossed the runway 26 departure end at a height of about 110 ft. Decision height was 99 ft. The FO then called ""Minimums"" and the captain informed that there was no visual contact and called to go-around.

At 58 ft radar altitude the TOGA switch was pushed and engine power increased. 3.5 seconds after the TOGA switch had been pushed the aircraft hit slightly upsloping terrain and obstacles. The ground speed at the time of impact was 165 kt. The maximum recorded vertical acceleration was 6 g.

Initial impact occurred at a distance of approximately 930 m from the runway 26 departure end. It collided with a concrete airport fence and rolled into a holiday village. The aircraft broke up and spilt fuel caught fire.";07:19;Boeing 747-412F;ACT Airlines;Monday 16 January 2017

column1: 5-jan-04;Fokker 70;OE-LFO;Austrian Airlines;near München-Fran...;1995;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 4;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 28;Substantial;Approach (APR);International Scheduled Passenger;Wien-Schwechat International Airport (VIE/LOWW)
column2: Austria;München-Franz Josef Strauss Airport (MUC/EDDM)
column3: Germany;"Flight OS111 departed Vienna at 07:27 for a flight to Munich. A few minutes before 8 o'clock in the morning the crew were cleared to descend from FL280 to FL100. The ice detection system was triggered during descent to FL100. Engine and airframe anti-icing systems were switched on simultaneously. FL100 was reached at 07:59:58 hrs. The pilots stated that they encountered icing conditions when the airplane entered the clouds. At FL100 ice is reported to have formed at the windscreen edges. Vibrations on the no. 2 engine increased temporarily after a flight time of six minutes at FL100. As the airplane was approximately 12.5 NM south of Munich airport
column4: the crew was instructed to descend to FL90 and to change heading to 020 degrees. Heavy vibrations on the no. 2 engine occurred during descent. According to crew statements
column5: the airbrakes were extended in order to increase thrust setting on the engines without increase in airspeed. Immediately afterwards the warning VIB HIGH ENG2 was triggered at FL90. The actions of the Abnormal Procedure Vibration High checklist were carried out. However
column6: the no. 2 engine was not shut down for lack of other failure indications. Afterwards no more problems for the no. 2 engine were indicated. Simultaneously with the strong vibrations
column7: vibrations and noises from the rear cabin area were heard in the cockpit. At 08:08:14 hrs the EPR of the no. 1 engine dropped from 1.5 to 1.1 and stayed at about 1.0 after that. In the cockpit heavy vibrations had been noticed also and a rattling noise had been heard. But the vibrations were not displayed on the multifunctional display as originating from the engines. At 08:08:22 hrs
column8: the captain declared an emergency because of severe engine problems and requested an immediate landing. The airplane was immediately cleared to descend to 5
column9: 000 ft based on a QNH of 1
column10: 017 hPa and to change to a heading of 080 degrees. The crew requested an approach as short as possible. While leaving FL90
column11: the EPR of the no. 1 engine dropped also from 1.4 to 1.0 within the next four minutes; this EPR reduction was incremental and occurred independent of the thrust setting. At 7
column12: 000 ft the air brakes were extended for a short time and engine thrust increased. During the descent to 5
column13: 000 ft the airplane was transferred to Munich Director. After 08:12:45 hrs when the airplane had reached approximately 5
column14: 000 ft the EPR of the no. 2 engine retained values of about 1.0 also. Munich Director immediately issued a clearance to further descend to 3
column15: 500 ft. The air brakes where extended again for a period of 44 seconds. Thereby the airspeed was reduced to approximately 170 kt. With the landing gears extended and the flaps set to 15 degrees
column16: the airspeed was about 150 kt. The airplane was guided to the landing course of the ILS 26L approximately 8 NM in front of the threshold. At approximately 4
column17: 000 ft flaps were extended to 25 degrees. After the airplane had descended in landing configuration to the cleared altitude of 3
column18: 500 ft and horizontal flight had been established
column19: the crew noticed that by pushing the thrust levers forward
column20: the EPR on both engines did not increase to the required value. The speeds N1 and N2 and the exhaust gas temperatures (EGT) of both engines increased
column21: the EPRs
column23: remained at values of around 1.0. After the message of the crew that they were just approaching the ILS the flight was transferred to Munich Tower. Airspeed decreased to approximately 115 kt. The autopilot was immediately switched off
column24: the airplane again established in descent
column25: the flaps reset to 15 degrees and the landing gears retracted. Airspeed increased to approximately 135 kt. The flaps were again set to 25 degrees. The airplane received clearance to land. At 08:16:10 hrs the controller informed the crew that the Fokker was approximately 500 ft below the glide path. At this time the height measured by the radio altimeter was 500 ft AGL. At the same time the GPWS sounded: ""Too low"" and ""Gear"". The crew informed the controller that the runway could not be reached and that the landing would take place approximately 4 NM short of the runway: ""...We will not make it...to the runway...we are touching down probable 4 Miles before the field...""). From approximately 400 ft AGL downwards the airplane was clear of clouds. The landing gear was selected down 13 seconds prior to ground contact. The captain informed the cabin crew of the imminent emergency landing through the repeated exclamation ""Brace for impact"" 5 seconds prior to touch down. At 08:16:35 hrs
column26: the airplane touched down on a snow covered field approximately 2.5 NM short of the runway with landing gears partly extended and came to rest severely damaged lying on the fuselage after a sliding distance of 220 m. All occupants left the airplane without assistance via the forward passenger door exit.";08:17;Fokker 70;Austrian Airlines;Monday 5 January 2004

column5: Canada;"At 17:00 Alberta Citylink flight 933 took off from Calgary on a scheduled flight to Lloydminster. The crew planned a non-precision automatic direction finder (ADF) approach to runway 25 at Lloydminster with an overcast ceiling of 400 feet
column6: visibility of 5 statute miles in blowing snow and mist
column7: and the wind from 110 degrees true at 7 knots. When the aircraft was inbound
column8: the flight service station (FSS) specialist reported that the visibility had decreased to 3 sm. The crew were aware of approximately to ¼ inch build-up of ice on the aircraft during descent and so planned for a flap 20 landing. The first officer was flying the approach from the right-hand seat while the captain was monitoring the instruments and looking outside the aircraft for visual contact with the runway environment. When the captain saw the runway from the minimum descent altitude (MDA)
column9: he took control for the landing. The aircraft was north of the extended centre line of runway 25. Flaps 35 was selected
column10: the power was reduced to flight idle
column11: a turn to regain the centre line was carried out
column12: and a descent was commenced from MDA. The aircraft contacted the runway surface heavily
column13: moving left to right. As a result
column14: the left main landing gear collapsed. Both propellers struck the runway
column15: and the left propeller separated from the engine. The aircraft slid along the runway on the belly pod for a distance of about 1 800 feet. The left wing contacted the snow on the edge of the runway
column16: resulting in a turn of about 160 degrees. The evacuation took place immediately after the aircraft came to rest; all occupants escaped quickly through the right
column17: over-wing exit.

column1: The aircraft was sold to Dodson International Inc. to be used for spares.";18:10;British Aerospace 3112 Jetstream 31;Alberta Citylink;Tuesday 20 January 1998

column1: 4-jan-02;Canadair Challenger 604;N90AG;Epps Air Service;Birmingham I...;1999;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 3 / Occupants: 3;Damaged beyond repair;Takeoff (TOF);Executive;Birmingham International Airport (BHX/EGBB)
column2: United Kingdom;Bangor International Airport
column3: ME (BGR/KBGR)
column4: United States of America;"Challenger N90AG was prepared for a flight from Birmingham
column5: UK to Bangor. The flight was cleared to taxi at 12:01 hrs. The captain was pilot-non-flying and was seated in the right cockpit seat. During taxi
column6: the crew completed their normal Before Takeoff Checks; these included confirmation that the control checks had been completed and that anti-ice might be required immediately after takeoff. Flap 20 had been selected for takeoff and the following speeds had been calculated and briefed by the pilots: V1 137 kt; VR 140 kt; V2 147 kt. By 12:06
column7: the aircraft was cleared to line up on runway 15. At 12:07 hrs
column8: N90AG was cleared for takeoff with a surface wind of 140°/8 kt. Takeoff appeared normal up to lift-off. Rotation was started at about 146 kt. Lift-off occurred 2 seconds later
column9: at about 153 kt and with a pitch attitude of about 8 degrees nose-up. Immediately after lift-off
column10: the aircraft started to bank to the left. The rate of bank increased rapidly and 2 seconds after lift-off the bank angle had reached 50 degrees. At that point
column11: the aircraft heading had diverged about 10 degrees to the left. Opposite aileron
column12: followed closely by right rudder
column13: was applied as the aircraft started banking; full right aileron and full right rudder had been applied within 1 second and were maintained. As the bank angle continued to increase
column14: progressively more aircraft nose-up elevator was applied. Stick-shaker operation initiated 3.5 seconds after lift-off. The left winglet contacted the runway shoulder
column15: the outboard part of the left wing detached and the aircraft struck the ground inverted
column16: structurally separating the forward fuselage. Fuel released from ruptured tanks ignited and the wreckage slid to a halt on fire. The last recorded aircraft attitude was approximately 111 degrees left bank and 13 degrees nose-down pitch.";12:07;Canadair CL-600-2B16 Challenger 604;Epps Air Service;Friday 4 January 2002

column1: 4-feb-09;AMI DC-3-65TP;N834TP;National Test Pilot School;Mojave-Kern ...;1947;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Takeoff (TOF);Training;Mojave-Kern County Airport

column6: N834TP
column7: collided with terrain during takeoff at Mojave
column8: California. The certified flight instructor (CFI) and the student pilot were not injured; the airplane sustained substantial damage to the fuselage and wings from impact forces.

column1: The student pilot was performing the takeoff. During the takeoff roll on runway 30
column2: the airplane began to drift to the right
column3: and the student applied left rudder to correct for the drift. The CFI advanced the right throttle during the ground roll in an attempt to counteract the right yaw. The tail wheel came off the ground about 80 knots
column4: and the airplane swerved to the right. The CFI applied left rudder in an attempt to stop the yaw and drift. As the airplane was about to depart the runway
column5: the pilots did not reduce the throttles or apply brakes as they felt that it would be safer to attempt to get airborne.

column1: The airplane slowed as it departed the runway surface. It collided with a series of berms
column2: which sheared off the left landing gear and left engine. The right landing gear collapsed
column3: and the airplane came to rest in a nose down attitude.

column1: The operator stated that the student pilot inadvertently set the rudder trim to the full right position when he adjusted the rudder pedals during the prestart checks. The rudder trim was in the full right position for the takeoff
column2: and found in the same position upon post accident inspection.

column1: The DC-3 involved was a turbine conversion and highly modified with a belly radar pod and chin FLIR turret. It was formerly operated by the South African Air Force as a maritime patrol aircraft.";08:52;Aero Modifications AMI DC-3-65TP;National Test Pilot School;Wednesday 4 February 2009

03-MAY-2006;Airbus A320-211;EK32009;Armavia;near Adler/Sochi ...;1995-06-28  (10 years 10 months);Fatalities: 8 / Occupants: 8;Fatalities: 105 / Occupants: 105;Destroyed;Approach (APR);International Scheduled Passenger;Yerevan Airport (EVN/UDYZ)
column2: Armenia;Adler/Sochi Airport (AER/URSS)
column3: Russia;Armavia flight 967 departed Yerevan (EVN) at 00:47 on a scheduled flight to Sochi (AER). Weather at Sochi was poor with rain and poor visibility. Radio contact with Sochi was established at 01:10. The flight crew discussed the current weather conditions at Sochi with the approach controller. At 01:26 the crew decided to return to Yerevan due to the below minima weather conditions at Sochi. At 01:30 the crew again requested the latest weather information. Visibility now was reported as 3600 m with a cloud base at 170 m. The captain now decided to continue to Sochi instead. Clearance was give to descent to an altitude of 3600 m. At 02:00 further descent instructions for 1800 m were issued by the air traffic controller. Weather conditions for an approach to runway 06 were now equal to the airport minima. Sochi Tower then cleared the flight to descend to 600 m. The glideslope was captured and the gear was lowered at 02:10. The crew reported ready and where cleared for landing. Weather was reported as 4000 m visibility with a cloud base at 190 m. Weather deteriorated quickly and thirty seconds later the controller reported that the cloud base was now at 100 m. He instructed the flight to abort the approach and told the crew to make a climbing right hand turn to an altitude of 600 m. The aircraft was flying at 300 m and performed a climbing turn to 450 m. Simultaneously the groundspeed dropped and the Airbus descended until it contacted the water and broke up. Wreckage sank to a depth of 700 m.;02:13;Airbus A320-211;Armavia;Wednesday 3 May 2006

column1: 2-feb-13;ATR-72-500;YR-ATS;Alitalia
column2: opb Carpatair;Roma-Fiumici...;1997-11-05  (15 years 3 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 4;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 46;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Pisa-Galileo Galilei Airport (PSA/LIRP)

column4: Italy;"An ATR-72 passenger plane
column5: registered YR-ATS
column6: sustained substantial damage in a landing accident at Roma-Fiumicino Airport (FCO)
column7: Italy. Of the 50 occupants
column8: five sustained serious injuries.

column1: Alitalia flight AZ1670 had departed Pisa-Galileo Galilei Airport (PSA) on a domestic flight to Roma-Fiumicino Airport (FCO). This flight was operated by Carpatair on behalf of Alitalia.

The airplane flew the approach in strong cross wind conditions with wind shear reported at runway 16L some fifteen minutes before the landing. Shortly before touchdown the airplane suddenly lost altitude and impacted the runway with the nose landing gear. This was at a distance of 567 meters from the runway threshold.
It bounced three times
column2: causing the nose and main gear to collapse. The airplane slid off the left side of the runway and came to rest in the grass near taxiway DE
column3: at a distance of about 1780 meters from the runway threshold. The aircraft had also performed a rotation on the vertical axis of 170°
column4: thus assuming a definitive orientation of about 330° magnetic. It came to rest 400 m from fire station no. 1. However
column5: it took the fire services ten minutes to reach the airplane because they were not aware of the precise location of the accident.

column1: The airplane landed in strong winds from 250 degrees on runway 16L. Runway 25 at Fiumicino was Notamed not available for landings due to work in progress.
The Fiumicino Notam reported at the time of the accident of the following limitations of the runway 16L ILS:
- LOCALIZER AT 17NM MRA 3000FT AND AT 25NM MRA 4000FT
- GLIDE PATH COVERAGE REDUCED AT 8.5NM
Weather about the time of the accident:
LIRF 021920Z 25028G41KT 9999 SCT023 SCT040 11/04 Q0992 WS RWY 16L NOSIG
[19:20 UTC / 20:20 LT: Wind 250 degrees at 28 knots
column2: gusting to 41 knots; Visibility: 10+ km; Scattered clouds at 2200 feet AGL and 4000 feet AGL; Temperature: 11°C; Dewpoint: 4°C; Pressure: 992 mb; Windshear at runway 16L]

column1: 04-MAY-2009;Airbus A320-211;N311US;Northwest Airlines;Denver Inter...;1990;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 7;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 147;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport

column5: United States of America;"An Airbus A320-211
column6: registration N311US
column7: operated by Northwest Airlines as flight NW557
column8: experienced a tailstrike resulting in substantial damage upon landing on runway 16L at Denver International Airport
column9: CO (DEN). The flight was a regularly scheduled passenger flight which departed from Minneapolis-St. Paul Airport
column10: MN (MSP) at 11:39.

column1: The flight to the DEN area was reported as routine
column2: with VFR weather prevailing. At about 12:02
column3: as the flight was entering the DEN terminal area
column4: the crew briefed an approach speed of 139 knots for a visual approach to runway 16L. The First Officer (FO) was the pilot flying (PF) and reported the approach was stable at 1
column5: 000 feet above the runway threshold. At 12:16:15 ATC cleared the flight to land and issued a wind advisory of 260 degrees at 5 knots. The flight crew extended the gear and selected flaps 3.

column1: The autopilot was disengaged at 12:17:38
column2: at approximately 750 feet above touchdown. The auto-thrust and flight directors were engaged. During the approach
column3: the crew noted that the aircraft was experiencing approximately 7 knots of tailwind
column4: and as the approach progressed FDR data indicated the tailwind component increased to approximately 11 knots.

column1: As the airplane passed approximately 50 feet above touchdown the rate of descent was about 800 feet per minute (fpm). The captain stated he expected nothing more than a firm touchdown. The FO initiated the flare at about 45 feet. He stated that he attempted to arrest the sink rate with larger than normal aft stick deflection. During the flare
column2: passing 20 feet above the runway
column3: the automated ""retard"" call-out began a sequence of three annunciations. This automatic call-out is designed to remind the pilot to move the thrust levers to the idle detent. The thrust levers remained in the climb detent (CLB).

column1: During the flare
column2: the airplane pitched up to about eight degrees nose up and airspeed decreased to about 132 knots. The airplane touched down on both main landing gear with a vertical load of about 1.56 G. At the time of initial touchdown

column1: Radio altimeter values increased
column2: indicating the aircraft then bounced. The FO held 16 degrees aft stick input (approximately full aft travel)
column3: and moved the thrust levers to idle during the bounce. Ground spoilers deployed (thrust lever position and wheel spin up logic was satisfied) and the airplane touched down a second time in an eleven degree nose up attitude
column4: with FO still applying full aft stick input. At this point the captain began adding some nose down stick input however pitch attitude continued increasing to about 12.5 degrees nose up. The Airbus FCOM indicates that the max pitch up angle with gear compressed is 11.7 degrees. A ""dual input"" automatic call-out was recorded
column5: indicating the system detected both pilots making stick inputs
column6: and the sound of a loud bang was heard on the cockpit voice recorder. As the captain stick input moved further forward
column7: in the airplane nose down direction
column8: and the FO stick back pressure relaxed
column9: the airplane began to pitch downward and about 3 seconds after the loud bang the nose wheel touched down. Thrust levers were then moved to the reverse position and autobraking began. The remainder of the roll out was normal.

column5: Australia;"A Beechcraft B200 Super King Air (registered VH-SGT) collapsed on touchdown at Perth airport. The aircraft was extensively damaged as a result of the collapse. No injuries were sustained by the pilot or passengers from the accident.

column1: Approximately two hours earlier
column2: the aircraft was chartered to fly from Perth to Mount Hale
column3: WA when shortly after takeoff from Perth the aircraft experienced a malfunction of the landing gear system. The main wheels and nose gear had become jammed and were unable to fully retract when selected up by the pilot.

column1: The pilot completed the emergency checklist actions contained in the Aircraft Flight Manual
column2: but was unable to retract or extend the gear using either the automated control or the manual emergency system. The pilot then requested assistance from a passenger to operate the manual emergency extension system.

column1: The landing gear remained jammed despite the additional force applied to the lever from the passenger.

The pilot contacted air traffic services and requested further assistance from company engineering personnel to visually assess the extension state of the landing gear. Two aerodrome passes were completed throughout the troubleshooting exercise and the pilot remained in radio contact with both groups during this phase.
Following the flyovers and after holding over Rottnest Island at 5
column2: 000 ft for a period of approximately two hours
column3: the pilot flew the King Air back to Perth airport.

column1: With the gear still jammed in the partially retracted position
column2: both the left and right main landing gear assemblies collapsed after the aircraft touched down on runway 24. The aircraft was substantially damaged as a result of the collapse.

column1: The Australian Transport Safety Bureau investigation revealed that two major system components had failed which could have prevented the landing gear from properly retracting/extending; the geared components within the right main landing gear actuator had fractured
column2: and the left torque tube support bearing had seized from contamination and lack of lubrication. Although each component failure was apparently unrelated
column3: the examination was not able to conclusively establish which failure had been the primary contributing factor in this landing occurrence. The Super King Air 200 aircraft landing gear system configuration was such that should either one of these component assemblies cease to function
column4: extension or retraction of the landing gear would not have been possible.";17:03;Beechcraft B200 Super King Air;Network Aviation Australia;Monday 9 April 2007

column1: The aircraft operated as East Air flight ETJ704 from Moscow's Domodedovo Airport to Kulob.

column3: 45 m wide)
column4: was cleared of snow on the north side. The south side

column1: On both sides of the path a 50-95 cm high snow berm was present.

column2: at a speed of 255 km/h. column1: The aircraft was operating a non scheduled flight from Imphal to Lengpui with ten persons on board including the pilot. The aircraft took off normally from Imphal at 10:00 hrs and subsequently came in contact with ATC Lengpui at 10:23hrs. ATC Lengpui conveyed the latest available weather with visibility as 4500 m. The pilot requested special VFR which was approved by the tower controller.
Visibility further dropped to 2000 m and the pilot preferred to enter a holding pattern
column2: in coordination with ATC at 10 miles maintaining visual separation with terrain at an altitude of 6500 feet. The pilot thereafter without any communication with ATC reported downwind for runway 17 and subsequently reported for final. When the aircraft reported final
column3: the controller after sighting the aircraft gave the landing clearance with wind as calm and runway surface wet.

column1: The aircraft touched down well past the threshold at a high speed with a remaining distance in which it was impossible to stop the aircraft. It climbed a 10 feet high platform constructed to install the Localizer antenna at the end of runway 17. As the speed of the aircraft was high
column2: it continued past the localizer platform and fell in a ravine approximately 60 feet deep.

column1: All 9 passengers and the pilot escaped unhurt. There was no fire.";10:45;Cessna 208B Grand Caravan;Northeast Shuttles;Wednesday 4 May 2011

column1: The estimated flight time for the flight was 40 minutes. The aircraft took off westbound. After levelling the aircraft the co-pilot gave his seat to the cameraman
column2: one of the passengers. The co-pilot remained at third row left seat from thereon until the aircraft met the accident. According to the crew and passengers

column1: the aircraft made few orbits (right bank) around the island at the initial levelled height and
column2: then descended lower heights and made few more orbits around the lagoon for photography. The passenger seated at the cabin wearing the headset informed the PIC that they got all the shots they wanted and now he could land. PIC started a descending turn (right bank) while keeping the passenger at the co-pilot seat in order to give a different view to him. Before the PIC could complete the turn
column3: the right wing and/or float hit the water. The accident resulted in both wings being broken at the root. Left float was detached and right float got stuck
column4: between the engine and the fuselage
column5: blocking the co-pilot exit. Empennage was twisted upside down. The depth of the lagoon at the site of wreckage was about 1 metre. All the passengers and crew were able to escape the aircraft without any fatalities.";10:15;de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter 200;null;Tuesday 2 June 2009

column1: 27-MAY-2004;Raytheon 390 Premier I;N5010X;Raytheon;Las Vegas-No...;2002;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 1;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 1;Damaged beyond repair;Landing (LDG);Private;Palm Springs International Airport

column5: United States of America;"A Raytheon 390 Premier I jet sustained substantial damage in a landing accident at Las Vegas-North Air Terminal

column1: The pilot stated that he was high and fast during the descent into Las Vegas but that the approach was ""stable"" by 500 feet. He stated that he maintained his Vref speed of 112 knots from there until touchdown.

The passenger stated that he felt that the approach was ""fast"" and that the pilot was ""behind the power curve"" because of high minimum enroute altitudes in the area and that they had to ""hustle down"" during the descent. The passenger indicated that the flight crossed the runway threshold ""maybe a bit more"" that 10 knots above Vref and touched down about 10 knots above Vref. He said it was not a stabilized approach.
Landing distance calculations and other evidence suggest that the lift dump panels did not extend after landing; however
column2: the investigation did not determine the reason(s) for the lack of lift dump. No evidence was found of any failures affecting the lift dump or braking systems. Evidence and interview statements reveal that the pilot flew an unstabilized approach to the runway and landed well above target speed. The high landing speed was result of the pilot's excessive airspeed on the approach and a tailwind component of about 8 knots. Although the pilot landed the airplane within the touchdown area
column3: the airplane's speed upon touchdown was about 17 knots above the prescribed speed. After exiting the end of runway 7
column4: the airplane continued and impacted a perimeter fence and came to rest approximately 735 feet beyond the end of runway.";15:57;Raytheon 390 Premier I;Raytheon Aircraft;Thursday 27 May 2004

column4: United States of America;Ketchikan-Waterfront SPB
column5: AK (WFB)
column6: United States of America;"The float equipped DHC-3T Turbine Otter aircraft
column7: operated by Promech Air
column8: was destroyed when it impacted steep
column9: mountainous tree-covered terrain about 25 miles northeast of Ketchikan above Ella Lake in the Misty Fjords area of Alaska. The pilot and eight passengers were killed.

column1: The accident airplane was the third of four Promech-operated float-equipped airplanes that departed at approximate 5-minute intervals from a floating dock in Rudyerd Bay. The accident flight and the two Promech flights that departed before it were carrying cruise-ship passengers who had a 12:30 ""all aboard"" time for their cruise ship that was scheduled to depart at 13:00. The sightseeing tour flight
column2: which the cruise ship passengers had purchased from the cruise line as a shore excursion
column3: overflew remote inland fjords; coastal waterways; and mountainous
column4: tree-covered terrain in the Misty Fjords National Monument Wilderness.

column1: Promech pilots could choose between two standard tour routes between Rudyerd Bay and Ketchikan
column2: referred to as the ""short route"" (which is about 52 nautical miles
column3: takes about 25 minutes to complete
column4: and is primarily over land) and the ""long route"" (which is about 63 nm
column5: takes about 30 minutes to complete
column6: and is primarily over seawater channels). Although the long route  was less scenic
column7: it was generally preferred in poor weather conditions because it was primarily over water
column8: which enabled the pilots to fly at lower altitudes beneath cloud layers. Route choice was at each pilot's discretion based on the pilot's assessment of the weather. The accident pilot and two other Promech pilots (one of whom was repositioning an empty airplane) chose the short route for the return leg
column9: while the pilot of the second Promech flight to depart chose the long route.

column1: The accident flight encountered deteriorating weather conditions with terrain becoming obscured by overcast clouds with visibility restricted in rain and mist.

Although the accident pilot had climbed the airplane to an altitude that would have provided safe terrain clearance had he followed the typical short route (which required the flight to pass two nearly identical mountains before turning west)
column2: the pilot instead deviated from that route and turned the airplane west early (after it passed only the first of the two mountains). The pilot's route deviation placed the airplane on a collision course with a 1
column3: 900-ft mountain
column4: which it struck at an elevation of about 1
column5: 600 ft mean sea level. In the final 2 seconds of the flight
column6: the airplane pitched up rapidly before colliding with terrain. The timing of this aggressive pitch-up maneuver strongly supports the scenario that the pilot continued the flight into near-zero visibility conditions
column7: and
column8: as soon as he realized that the flight was on a collision course with the terrain
column9: he pulled aggressively on the elevator flight controls in an ineffective attempt to avoid the terrain.";12:16;de Havilland Canada DHC-3T Vazar Turbine Otter;Promech Air;Thursday 25 June 2015

column3: Netherlands;"A Dornier 328 operated by SkyWork Airlines (HB-AEO) and an Embraer ERJ-190 operated by KLM Cityhopper (PH-EXB) were involved in a serious runway incursion incident at Basel/Mulhouse/Freiburg EuroAirport

column5: AK (AIN/PAWI)
column6: United States of America;The pilot had contacted the Barrow Flight Service Station (FSS) eleven times on the day of the accident to obtain weather briefings. The conditions were below VFR minimums
column7: which were required to conduct the passenger-carrying commercial flight in a single-engine airplane. The conditions later improved and the pilot departed under a special VFR clearance. The pilot performed two approaches at the Wainwright Airport (AIN) in IMC that were consistent with the two GPS approaches that were available there. Weather data and witnesses indicate that daylight conditions
column8: low clouds and poor visibility prevailed
column9: with cloud tops at 1
column10: 000 feet. After the second approach
column11: the pilot radioed that he was heading back to the departure airport because he could not see the airport. The airplane impacted the frozen Arctic Ocean in a right bank and at a 60-degree nose-down attitude about three miles away from the location of the pilot's last radio transmission. An examination of the airplane before it sank through cracking ice
column12: revealed no pre-impact mechanical malfunctions. An examination of the propeller revealed that it was under a power setting consistent with a maneuvering airspeed at the time of impact. The airplane was nearly full of fuel and over its published maximum gross weight at impact. Small pieces of clear ice
column13: about 1/4-inch thick
column14: were found on portions of the tail surfaces. Interviews with operator employees and the pilot's wife revealed that the pilot may have felt pressure from himself and passengers to complete the flight.;20:30;Cessna 208B Grand Caravan;Hageland Aviation Services;Thursday 10 April 1997

column1: The pilot stated to the NTSB that the flight was a familiarization flight for a new member of their chapter of the Commemorative Air Force. The flight departed the Cable airport and flew east along the mountains
column2: headed to San Bernardino. They contacted the San Bernardino tower and were instructed to enter the crosswind for runway 24. As part of the before landing checklist

column1: During the postaccident examination of the airplane
column2: about 16 ounces of water were removed from the fuel system.  Water was present in the lower gascolator
column3: the fine fuel filter (upper gascolator)
column4: and subsequent fuel line to the carburetor inlet.  A brass screen at the carburetor inlet and 2 carburetor fuel bowl thumb screens also contained corrosion
column5: water
column6: and rust.

column1: The approved aircraft inspection checklist called for washing the carburetor and main fuel filter every 50 hours and cleaning and/or replacing the fine fuel filter every 100 hours.  The fine fuel filter is not easily accessible and not able to be drained during a preflight inspection. The mechanic who completed the most recent inspection stated that he did not drain or check the fine fuel filter. The last logbook entry that specifically stated the fuel filters were cleaned was about 4 years before the accident.";12:00;Antonov An-2R;American Airpower Heritage Museum;Friday 6 May 2016

column3: Italy;After engine servicing at Nürnberg
column4: Learjet 35A I-MOCO was prepared to return to Rome. The airplane
column5: with two pilots and the chief technician of the operator on board
column6: took off from runway 10 at 15:31. After five nautical miles the aircraft turned to the south. Less than three minutes after departure at an altitude of 5900 feet and an airspeed of 250 knots
column7: the no. 1 engine failed. The captain decided to return to the airfield. Preparing for the approach to runway 10
column8: the flaps were set at 8 degrees and the landing gear was extended. Because the aircraft was above the glideslope
column9: power was reduced to idle and the flaps were lowered to 20 and a little later further down to 40 degrees. At that moment the airspeed dropped considerably. The thrust lever of the remaining right hand engine was then advanced to near takeoff power. Due to the asymmetric thrust the plane yawed to the left at a height of 200-300 feet. The captain ordered the first officer to raise the flaps back to the 20 degree position. The Learjet then stalled to the left
column10: rolled inverted and crashed into trees.;15:40;Learjet 35A;E.A.S. Aeroservizi;Thursday 8 February 2001

column6: registration N8327A
column7: was damaged in a tail strike accident while landing on runway 25L at Las Vegas-McCarran International Airport
column8: NV (LAS) in calm winds and good visibility.

column1: According to the operator
column2: the captain was the pilot flying and the first officer (FO) was the pilot monitoring. Both pilots indicated that takeoff through the initial descent was uneventful. The aircraft was configured for a flaps 30 landing. During the ILS approach to runway 25L
column3: the captain used the Heads-up Guidance System (HGS) in the IMC mode.

column1: During the decent below 100 feet
column2: the FO indicated that the runway environment was dark and sensed the runway was ""coming close fast"". He noted a slightly increased descent rate and before he could make a callout
column3: the captain had begun to take corrective action.

column1: During the descent
column2: the captain stated he was hand flying the airplane (autopilot and autothrottles were off) and used the localizer
column3: glideslope and flare cues from the HGS. At approximately 30 feet
column4: he transitioned from the HGS to the runway environment
column5: noting it appeared ""pitch black."" He then noticed the runway edge lights and what appeared to be an increased sink rate.

column1: Both pilots indicated the airplane touched down firm
column2: then bounced
column3: and the second touch down was harder than the first. Neither were aware that they had struck the tail. The captain did not recall seeing a tail strike warning indication from the HGS.

column1: Post flight inspection revealed that the tail strike indicator was compressed and deep scrapes and wear damage to the lower aft fuselage skin. Further investigation revealed multiple fractured frames and buckled stringers
column2: shear ties and straps.

column3: Tanzania;"The aircraft was departed Khartoum for a flight to Mwanza where it was supposed to pick up a cargo of 38 tonnes of fish fillet from Vick Fish Processors for delivery in Europe. When it went dark en route to Mwanza
column4: the radio altimeter integral light was found to be unserviceable. The crew were not able to fix the problem and the continued using the FMS. The crew contacted Mwanza tower at 16:58 and were being advised that there was no power at the airport and that efforts were being made to use a standby generator. Further information passed on the crew reportedly included VOR
column5: DME and NDB all unserviceable
column6: weather: wind calm
column7: 8 km visibility
column8: temperature 25deg C and QNH 1015. After holding for 10 minutes
column9: the airport generator came on and the runway lights went on. The first officer
column10: who was pilot flying
column11: started a visual runway 12 approach. When well established on finals with full landing configuration
column12: the captain told the f/o that he was too low
column13: and a few seconds later he told the f/o he was too high. Both the captain and the flight engineer then told the f/o to go around. The f/o overshot and climbed to 5500 feet on the downwind leg. Turning on the left base the captain remarked that the turn was too tight: "".. I will do a 360-degree turn to the right and position you finals"". The captain thus took over control and started a right turn at 4400 feet. Just before completing the turn
column14: the f/o said: ""do not go down anymore
column15: the altimeter is reading 4100 feet"". Almost aligned with the runway
column16: the f/o took over control again. At that same moment the aircraft bounced 2 or 3 times yawing to the left and came down to a halt in the middle of the lake.";17:36;Boeing 707-351C;Trans Arabian Air Transport - TAAT;Thursday 3 February 2000

column1: It appeared that the pilot's decision to go to the bathroom shifted the weight of the already unbalanced plane and caused it to become unstable and uncontrollable while in an area of strong turbulence. column2: the plane rose more than 100 feet with its nose down
column3: and was then rocked by wind shear three times greater than what is defined as extreme turbulence. Within the first 12 seconds that they encountered problems

column5: negatively impacting the ability of the crew to successfully circumnavigate around the severe weather.

column1: firefighters to inspect the aircraft for fire. Firefighters

column1: cargo compartment. Before it was extinguished

column1: Investigation revealed that the pilots thought the Coca runway was short. To be able to stop the plane on the runway without excessive use of the brakes

column1: 3-aug-17;ATR-72-500;PK-WFF;Wings Air;Medan-Kualan...;2009-07-16  (8 years );Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 5;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 67;Substantial;Taxi (TXI);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Medan-Kualanamu International Airport (KNO/WIMM)
column2: Indonesia;Meulaboh-Cut Nyak Dhien Airport (MEQ/WITC)
column3: Indonesia;"An ATR 72-500 operated by Wings Air as flight IW1252 (PK-WFF) and a Boeing 737-900 operated by Lion Air as flight JT197 (PK-LJZ) both sustained substantial damage in a ground collision accident on the active runway 23 at Medan-Kualanamu International Airport
column4: Indonesia.

column1: The ATR 72-500 operated as scheduled passenger flight from Medan with intended destination of Meulaboh Airport. On board IW1252 were two pilots
column2: one observer pilot
column3: two flight attendants and 67 passengers. The pilot in command acted as Pilot Flying (PF) and the second in command acted as Pilot Monitoring (PM).

column2: the flight attendant of IW1252 advised the pilot that the boarding process was completed. The pilot then requested push back and engine start clearance from the Medan Ground controller
column3: which was approved.

column2: IW1252 requested taxi clearance to the Medan Ground controller and was instructed to taxi to runway 23 following U2 taxi route
column3: which was from apron V to holding point runway 23 on taxiway C
column4: via taxiway U - T - and B.

column2: flight JT197 reported to the Medan Tower controller that the aircraft was established on the localizer of runway 23. The Medan Tower controller acknowledged this and issued a landing clearance with additional information regarding the wind conditions and barometric pressure.

IW1252 contacted Medan Tower and was instructed to continue to taxi and hold on short of runway 23. Flight IW1252 requested to depart via the taxiway D intersection with the intention to expedite the departure. This was approved. Taxiway D was a Rapid Exit Taxiway (RET) for runway 05.

IW1252 advised Medan Tower that the aircraft was close to reaching runway 23. Medan Tower then requested confirmation that IW1252 was ready for immediate departure. There was no reply and the Medan Tower controller repeated the request and received the reply that IW1252 was able for immediate departure.

column1: Medan Tower intended to let IW1252 depart immediately after flight JT197 had landed
column2: since there was another arriving aircraft behind JT197.

the Medan Tower controller radioed: ""Wings Abadi one two five two behind traffic Lion short final landed passing line up behind runway two three from intersection delta additional clearance after departure direct Meulaboh"".
IW1252 read back: ""after departure direct to Meulaboh Wings Abadi one two five two"". Thereafter
column3: IW1252 continued the taxi for line up on runway 23.

column2: IW1252 crossed the runway holding position marking (yellow line). At the same time
column3: the Medan Tower controller was monitoring the distance of the second arriving aircraft on the radar display.

column1: As JT197 was on short final
column2: the flight crew noted IW1252 ahead and assumed that the ATR aircraft would not enter the runway. Therefore
column3: the PF decided to continue the landing approach and focused on handling the aircraft.

column2: JT197 touched down and the attention of the Medan Tower controller changed back from the radar display to the runway environment.

column1: IW1252 by then crossed the runway side marking (white line) and continued to enter the runway. The flight crew of JT197 saw that the ATR was entering the runway.

column2: the left wing of JT197 impacted with the right hand wing of IW1252.

column1: The flight crew of JT197 subsequently radioed the Medan Tower controller that there was another aircraft on the runway and this was acknowledged. The Medan Tower supervisor on duty noticed two aircraft on the runway and the Medan Tower controller panicked. Thereafter
column2: the Medan Tower supervisor took over the communication of Medan Tower.
the pilot of JT197 contacted the Medan Tower twice
column3: and received a response at 11:02:01 by the Medan Tower supervisor
column4: who then instructed them to vacate the runway via taxiway G.

column2: JT197 advised the Medan Tower that the aircraft had touched down and asked why there was another aircraft on runway 23. The Medan Tower supervisor requested the pilot to standby.

the Medan Tower supervisor instructed the other arriving aircraft pilot to overshoot due to traffic. The other arriving aircraft pilot requested to make orbit to the left on final approach which was approved.

column1: While the Boeing 737-900 was taxiing to the parking bay
column2: the Medan Tower supervisor issued takeoff clearance to IW1252
column3: with additional clearance to turn left heading 315 after airborne. IW1252 responded that they were unable to depart. The Medan Tower supervisor then instructed the IW1252 pilot to hold on the runway.

column2: the Medan Tower supervisor again issued takeoff clearance IW1252
column3: to which the pilot responded by requesting to return to the apron for inspection of any damage to the aircraft. The Medan Tower supervisor approved the request and instructed them to vacate the runway via taxiway E then to contact Medan Ground.

column1: As the ATR was taxiing back to the apron another departing aircraft was cleared to line up on runway 23
column2: with takeoff clearance being issued at 11:07:21.

JT197 advised the Medan Ground controller pf the possibility of aircraft debris on the runway that might become hazard to the other aircraft. The Medan Ground controller acknowledged and relayed the information to Medan Tower supervisor. At 11:10:26
column3: the flight that had just departed advised Medan Tower that there was Foreign Object Debris (FOD) on the runway.

column1: Despite these reports
column2: Medan Tower issued landing clearance to another arriving aircraft at 11:10:44.
after landing on runway 23
column3: the other arriving flight advised Medan Tower that there was FOD on the runway. It took until 11:31 for the runway to be closed. After all the debris were collected and runway cleaned
column4: the runway was reopened and resumed to normal operation at 11:55.";11:00;ATR 72-212A (ATR-72-500);Wings Air;Thursday 3 August 2017

column6: United States of America;The flight crew received flight release documents containing weather information from airline dispatch that was incomplete and did not contain pertinent Convective SIGMETs and a tornado watch bulletin. However
column7: the flight crew stated that before departure from Atlanta (ATL)
column8: they looked at a computerized weather display and observed a line of adverse weather conditions along their intended route of flight. During initial climb after takeoff
column9: the flight crew noticed that they were approaching a line of thunderstorms. The captain initially planned to fly around this line but noticed a 10-mile gap in the line that was depicted on the airplane's on-board weather radar display. The captain decided to fly through the gap
column10: which he could also see when he looked outside of the airplane. Radar and weather data indicate that the airplane penetrated an extreme weather echo (VIP level 6) that likely contained a severe thunderstorm
column11: hail
column12: and severe to extreme turbulence. The thunderstorm top was above 45
column13: 000 feet. Neither the flight attendants nor the passengers received an adequate or timely briefing to remain seated and to prepare for the possibility of turbulence. The aft flight attendant and a passenger were seriously injured during the turbulence encounter. Hail shattered the front windshield and damaged the pitot system
column14: radome
column15: wings
column16: tail
column17: and engines. The flight crew successfully performed an emergency landing at Chattanooga-Lovell Field
column18: TN (CHA). The investigation revealed that the captain had been involved in two other air carrier incidents involving adverse weather conditions. It also revealed that the airline lacked adequate training and guidance regarding hazardous weather interpretation and avoidance
column19: as well as adequate procedures to notify flight attendants about potential turbulence. According to FAA guidance
column20: flight crews should avoid intense or extreme level radar echoes by at least 20 miles. This guidance also instructs pilots that such echoes should be separated by at least 40 miles before flight is attempted between the echoes.;19:20;McDonnell Douglas DC-9-32;AirTran Airways;Thursday 7 May 1998

column1: The weather report at Jumla at that time was fair with bright sunshine and north easterly 02 knots wind. The wind direction had changed at the time of take off from south westerly.
The aircraft left Surkhet valley and established contact with Nepalgunj Tower as per normal procedure. At 11:49 the aircraft reported 'Virgin Pass'
column2: one of the reporting points en-route to Jumla.

column1: At 11:55 the aircraft established contact with Jumla Information and received weather information and runway 27 for landing. Wind was reported being 240 at 4 kts. The pilot decided to use runway 09 and reported turning final at 12:01. The aircraft appeared on final approach with high speed. The captain carried out missed approach without informing Jumla control tower. He coordinated his position and intention to use runway 27 with the pilot of aircraft 9N-AHR operated by Sita Air which was to land 7 minutes behind him. The captain flew over to the right of Jumla control tower
column2: while executing the missed approach and headed towards a hill. The captain then made a sharp left turn with a high bank angle with an intention to land on runway 27 while informing to vacate the runway for trailing 9N-AHR aircraft. During this process the aircraft lost speed as well as altitude considerably and hit the paddy field to the east of the airport. The Twin Otter bounced up and traversed a further 200 feet approximately or so ultimately hitting a terrace
column3: cart wheeled came to rest turning 180 degrees with tail section twisted. It instantly caught fire.";12:03;de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter 300;Yeti Airlines;Wednesday 21 June 2006

column1: 08-MAY-2009;MD-90-30;HZ-APW;Saudi Arabian;Riyadh-King ...;1999;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 7;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Ferry/positioning;Jeddah-King Abdulaziz International Airport (JED/OEJN)
column2: Saudi Arabia;Riyadh-King Khalid International Airport (RUH/OERK)
column3: Saudi Arabia;"A Saudi Arabian Airlines MD-90 was substantially damaged during a runway excursion accident Riyadh (RUH). The seven crew members escaped unhurt.

column1: The airplane operated on a repositioning flight from Jeddah. During the flight
column2: the captain discussed the use of manual spoilers during landing with the first officer. He further stated that; as he ""had only around 400 hours in the aircraft"" as a captain
column3: he wanted to ""see the effect' of landing with manual spoilers. He further explained that the flight provided an opportunity to ""do it manually"" (use manual spoilers) as it was a repositioning flight and
column4: the weather and dry runway conditions were ideal. As such
column5: he discussed the procedure with the first officer and elected to land with the auto ground spoiler system unarmed.

column1: The flight was uneventful. During the approach to Riyadh the Landing Checklist was completed
column2: which included the arming of the auto ground spoiler system for landing. After the Landing Checklist was completed
column3: the captain disarmed the auto ground spoiler system with the intention of applying manual ground spoilers after landing. The auto braking system was also not armed prior to landing.

column1: The final approach and touchdown to runway 15 Left at Riyadh were uneventful. The touchdown airspeed was 135 knots calibrated air speed (CAS).
On touchdown
column2: the captain manually extended the spoiler/speed brake lever
column3: but did not latch it in the fully extended (EXT) position (fully aft and latched upwards). The captain then removed his right hand from the speed brake lever in order to deploy the thrust reversers. The first officer noted the movement of the spoiler/speed brake lever and called ""Spoilers Deployed"".

column1: Since the spoiler/speed brake lever was not fully pulled aft and latched upwards
column2: the lever automatically returned to the forward retracted (RET) position. This movement of the spoiler/speed brake lever was not noticed by the captain and the first officer. In response
column3: the ground spoilers re-stowed before being fully deployed and
column4: a speed brake/flap configuration (SPD BRK/FLP CONFIG) Level 1 Amber Alert occurred. This alert occurred as the aircraft was not yet fully weight on wheels (WOW) and the aircraft still sensed a flight condition with speed brakes deployed and flaps extended beyond six degrees.

column1: Six seconds after touchdown on the right main landing gear
column2: the nose gear touched down and the aircraft transferred to a ground condition (WOW on nose gear and main wheel spin up). The SPD BRK/FLP CONFIG alert extinguished when the nose gear oleo actuated ground shift on landing.

column1: After touchdown
column2: the aircraft banked to the right and began to drift right of the runway centerline. In response
column3: he applied left rudder
column4: deployed the thrust reversers and applied left aileron.

column1: But this did not have any noticeable effect.
The captain saw the approaching G4 taxiway exit and in an attempt to keep the aircraft from leaving the runway surface beyond the G4 taxiway exit
column2: he decided to direct the aircraft towards the taxiway. He then applied a right rudder input which caused the aircraft to commence a rapid sweeping turn to the right towards the G4 taxiway exit.

column1: The aircraft left the runway at high speed
column2: traversed the full width of the G4 taxiway
column3: and exited the surface at its southern edge. The aircraft then entered a sand section and travelled the distance infield between the edge of the G4 taxiway and the adjacent section of taxiway GOLF. The left main landing gear collapsed during this time. The aircraft came to rest on taxiway GOLF.

column1: There was no post impact fire.";15:58;McDonnell Douglas MD-90-30;Saudi Arabian Airlines;Friday 8 May 2009

column5: Australia;"A Boeing 747-422
column6: operated by  United Airlines
column7: was taxiing for departure at Melbourne Airport
column8: Australia. At the same time
column9: a Boeing 767-338ER operated by Qantas was stationary on taxiway Echo and waiting in line to depart from runway 16. The tail section of the 767 was protruding into taxiway Alpha while it was stationary on taxiway Echo awaiting a clearance to enter the runway.

column1: The pilots of the 747 received a clearance to taxi
column2: which included a taxi route from the international apron to the holding point on taxiway Bravo
column3: for a departure from runway 16
column4: via taxiways Uniform then Alpha. The pilot in command of the 747 deviated from the taxi clearance issued by the surface movement controller and turned the 747 right into taxiway Echo
column5: to pass behind the 767. The left wing tip of the 747 collided with the right horizontal stabiliser of the 767 as the 747 crew attempted to manoeuvre behind the 767.

column1: The taxiway dimensions and markings at Melbourne Airport complied with international standards and were suitable for use by the aircraft types involved in the occurrence.
The 747 crew was aware of the 767
column2: and chose to pass behind it rather than wait on taxiway Alpha until the 767 was no longer obstructing the taxiway. The decision by the pilot in command of the 747 to deviate off the centreline of taxiway Alpha and taxi behind the 767 did not comply with the taxi clearance issued by the SMC. It was based on his assessment that it was safe to do so. The pilot in command of the 747 misjudged the distance between the wingtip of the 747 and the right horizontal stabiliser of the 767
column3: which resulted in the collision.";13:08;Boeing 747-422;United Airlines;Thursday 2 February 2006

column1: The flight originated at Parker
column2: Arizona
column3: about 17:54
column4: and was destined for Palomar
column5: California. The pilot was receiving VFR advisories from SOCAL Tracon en route to Palomar. The pilot became nauseous en route and began to vomit. At 1838
column6: he advised SOCAL that he was sick and radio contact was lost. He reported that he had removed his headset and turned on the external speaker. The airplane had descended from 16
column7: 500 feet msl and was on an established course to the destination. It was level at 10
column8: 500 feet msl and being flown by the autopilot. As the vomiting became nonproductive the pilot became light headed. The last thing that he recalled was approaching ""ESCON
column9: an intersection on the landing approach to Palomar. When the pilot regained consciousness he looked outside the airplane to determine where he was. The surface was obscured in cloud cover. On his left side was a Navy F-18 fighter plane. The F-18 pilot was communicating by hand signals
column10: asking if he was ok
column11: and indicated he should turn around towards land. The accident pilot determined that he was 186 nautical miles southwest of his destination
column12: and over the ocean. He disconnected the autopilot and started a right-hand turn to reverse his course. After reversing course and checking his instruments
column13: he determined that he was very low on fuel and did not have enough to make his destination. The pilot repeatedly attempted contact with Southern California Terminal Radar Approach Control (SOCAL)
column14: but without success. Another aircraft on the coast responded and stated that they would relay the pilot's message to SOCAL. The pilot declared a medical emergency and advised that he would not be able to return to land.

column1: Within 10 minutes the fuel onboard was exhausted and the pilot configured the airplane for the best angle of glide and ditching at sea. Subsequently
column2: the pilot descended through low stratus and ditched the airplane in the ocean at dusk
column3: about 19:45
column4: on the Mission Bay Vortac 237-degree radial at 160 miles.

column1: The pilot exited the airplane with a hand held VHF radio
column2: two flashlights
column3: a cell phone
column4: and a trash bag for flotation
column5: and climbed onto the top of the fuselage to await rescue. At this time it was dark. He verified that his emergency locator transmitter was operating with his VHF radio. After about 30 minutes
column6: a Navy S-3B circled the area. After the third circle of the area the search plane saw the pilot's flashlight and circled the downed plane until a rescue helicopter arrived. A Navy frogman was dropped into the water and subsequently the pilot was hoisted onboard the helicopter.

column2: both of which were below weather minimums. The pilot and copilot departed from Des Moines Airport in weather minimums that were below the approach minimums for the departure airport. While en route

column1: The company's procedures did not allow flight crew to depart to an airport that was below minimums but did allow for the flight crew
column2: at their discretion
column3: to perform a ""look-see"" approach to approach minimums if the weather was below minimums. column1: The aircraft took off from runway 14R at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport at 14:21 hours local time (11:21 UTC). Weather about the time of departure at Domodedovo Airport included limited visibility (2100m) during light snowfall. Temperature was -5°C
column2: overcast cloud deck at 2600 feet AGL.

column1: The Interstate Aviation Committee stated that
column2: prior to departure
column3: the heating of the three pitot tubes had not been turned on.

column1: After takeoff
column2: at an altitude of 130-150 m (425-490 ft) above ground level
column3: the autopilot was switched on. Flaps were raised as the aircraft climbed through an altitude of 550 m (1800 feet).

column1: About 2 minutes 30 seconds after the takeoff
column2: at an altitude of about 1300 meters (4265 feet) and an instrument speed of 465-470 km/h
column3: there were discrepancies between the air speed readings on the captain's side compared to the standby airspeed indicator. The airspeed on the copilot's side is unknown as this parameter was not registered by the flight data recorder. There were no significant difference in the altitude indications. After another 25 seconds
column4: the discrepancies reached about 30 km/h with the speed on the captain's side being greater.

column1: After about 50 seconds
column2: at an altitude of about 2000 meters (6560 ft)
column3: the airspeed on the standby airspeed indicator was higher and continued to increase while the airspeed on the captains ASI continued to decrease.

column1: The flight crew then disconnected the autopilot. The airspeed on the captain's side continued to decrease
column2: while the standby ASI showed 540-560 km/h. About 50 seconds after the autopilot was turned off
column3: the flight passed an altitude of 1700-1900 m (5580-6230 ft) with vertical loads ranging from 1.5 to 0.5 g. Subsequently the aircraft entered a steep descent with the ASI on the captain's side showing 0 km/h
column4: and the standby ASI showing 200 km/h. The pitch angle decreased to -30/-35 degrees with a vertical load factor of  0 g.

column1: The aircraft impacted a snowy field around 14:27:05 and disintegrated. Before the collision with the ground
column2: the standby ASI had increased to 800 km/h with the captain's ASI still displaying 0 km/h.

column1: Cirrus Airlines Flight 1567 departed Berlin-Tempelhof Airport (THF) at 16:30 on a domestic service to Mannheim Airport (MHG). The copilot was Pilot Flying (PF).
During the flight the copilot commented that he had difficulties in landing at Mannheim. The captain replied that he did fine.

At 17:36 the flight was cleared for a LOC/DME approach to runway 27. One minute later the flight reached the prescribed altitude of 5000 feet. The descent was continued until the PF noticed his error. The captain instructed the PF to arrest the descent and climb back towards 5000 feet. By then the flight had descended to 3800 feet
column2: 100 feet below the Minimum Sector Altitude (MSA).

column1: After reaching the Final Approach Fix at 5000 feet
column2: the crew reported that they were established on the localizer. Langen Radar instructed the flight to contact Mannheim Tower.

column1: The airplane was configured for the final approach and landing
column2: with the captain telling the PF not to worry several times. The PF attempted to flare the airplane for landing
column3: but the aircraft floated over the runway without touching down. The PF then stated: ""Oh - your control"". The captain took over control and replied ""My control"". At that moment the airplane was 200 m past the runway threshold. Touchdown was accomplished at 530 m
column4: with 480 m of runway remaining.

column1: The airplane failed to decelerate as expected and the captain called for manual braking action. The airplane overran the runway end at a speed of 50 knots. The left hand main gear collapsed as it hit a pothole. The aircraft then slid into an earthen wall and came to rest. There was no fire.
Overran runway on landing and hit an earthen wall. One wing and engine severely damaged.";17:45;Dornier 328-110;Cirrus Airlines;Wednesday 19 March 2008

8-jan-16;Canadair CRJ-200PF;SE-DUX;West Air Sweden;near Oajevágge;1993;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;En route (ENR);Cargo;Oslo-Gardermoen Airport (OSL/ENGM)
column2: Norway;Tromsø/Langnes Airport (TOS/ENTC)
column3: Norway;"A Canadair CRJ-200 cargo plane of West Air Sweden was destroyed when it impacted remote terrain near Akkajaure
column4: Sweden. Both pilots were killed.

column1: The aircraft departed Oslo-Gardermoen Airport
column2: Norway at 23:10 hours local time on a mail and package flight to Tromsø
column3: Norway.

column1: The take-off
column2: departure and climb to cruising altitude
column3: flight level 330
column4: were performed according to normal procedures. The flight was uneventful until one minute and 20 seconds before the impact. The event started at 00:19:20 hrs
column5: one hour and ten minutes into the flight in night time conditions of darkness without moonlight
column6: clouds or turbulence. The lack of external visual references meant that the pilots were totally dependent on their instruments which consisted of three independent attitude indicators.

column1: Suddenly a very fast increase in pitch was displayed on the left attitude indicator. The pilot in command
column2: who was the pilot flying and seated in the left seat exclaimed a strong expression. The displayed pitch change meant that the pilot in command was subjected to a surprise effect and a degradation of spatial orientation. The autopilot was
column3: most probably
column4: disconnected automatically
column5: a ""cavalry charge"" aural warning and a single chime was heard
column6: the latter most likely as a result of miscompare between the left and right pilots' flying displays (PFD).

column1: Both elevators moved towards nose down and nose down stabilizer trim was gradually activated from the left control wheel trim switch. The aeroplane started to descend
column2: the angle of attack and G-loads became negative up to -1 G. Both pilots exclaimed strong expressions and the co-pilot said ""come up"".

column1: About 13 seconds after the start of the event the crew were presented with two contradictory attitude indicators with red chevrons pointing in opposite directions. At the same time none of the instruments displayed any comparator caution due to the PFDs declutter function in unusual attitude.
Bank angle warnings were heard and the maximum operating speed and Mach number were exceeded 17 seconds after the start of the event
column2: which activated the overspeed warning.

column1: The speed continued to increase
column2: a distress call was transmitted and acknowledged by the air traffic control and the engine thrust was reduced to flight idle.

column1: The crew was active during the entire event. The dialogue between the pilots consisted mainly of different perceptions regarding turn directions. They also expressed the need to climb. At this stage
column2: the pilots were probably subjected to spatial disorientation. The aircraft collided with the ground one minute and twenty seconds after the initial height loss.

column1: Investigation revealed that the erroneous attitude indication on PFD 1 was caused by a malfunction of the Inertial Reference Unit (IRU 1). The pitch and roll comparator indications of the PFDs were removed when the attitude indicators displayed unusual attitudes. In the simulator

column2: the wind was already at left cross to tail-cross (left rear quadrant) and at variable direction from 160 degrees - 060 degrees momentary at 013 degrees with wind speed variably increasing from 1 knot to 6 knots. At 70 feet RA

column1: From 35 feet RA until before touchdown the wind shifted direction within the left rear quadrant and this time coming from 060 degrees to 112 degrees at increasing speed from 05 knots to 12 knots. Two seconds before touchdown the aircraft's true heading
column2: which was initially at 240 degrees
column3: changed to 230 degrees with groundspeed decreasing to 119 knots
column4: drift angle increasing from +1 degree until +9 degrees just before touchdown. The left cross-tail wind from 122 degrees to 112 degrees showed an increasing wind speed from 16 knots to 22 knots.

column1: The aircraft touched down with a heading of 230 degrees
column2: changing further left to heading 220 degrees. Meanwhile the right hand main landing gear hit five runway edge lights with the wheels momentarily treading a portion of soft ground near the right runway edge.

column1: At the moment when the nose wheel settled on the ground and the wind speed dissipated to a low of 7 knots

column3: United Kingdom;"A Cessna 525 Citation CJ1+ corporate jet plane
column4: registered HB-VOV
column5: sustained substantial damage in a takeoff accident at Grenchen Airport
column6: Switzerland. The airplane operated on a flight from Grenchen Airport. Destination of the ferry flight was Newquay-Cornwall Airport (NQY) in England.

column1: The co-pilot was pilot flying (PF) and the commander was pilot not flying (PNF).

HB-VOV left stand ""white alpha"" at 08:48 LT. The crew had previously received the necessary clearance to take off from runway 07 after a request to Grenchen aerodrome control (tower). The de-icing system was switched on from the outset in view of the prevailing conditions. The taxi checklist was completed on the short route to the runway 07 holding position via taxiway WHISKEY. This included
column2: among other things
column3: testing the functionality of the brakes
column4: which was carried out by both crew members. No anomalies were found.

column1: At approximately the same time
column2: the Grenchen aerodrome control air traffic control officer (ATCO) arranged for a runway inspection
column3: as visibility did not allow a view from the tower to the end of runway 07.

column1: After receiving clearance at 08:51 LT
column2: the commander steered the aircraft onto runway 07 and initially turned west
column3: in order to have the maximum runway length available for the subsequent takeoff (backtrack). After a further 180 degree clockwise turn
column4: HB-VOV was positioned just north of the runway centerline
column5: pointing to the east. To take advantage of the available runway length
column6: the commander
column7: according to his own statements
column8: did not manoeuvre the aircraft precisely onto the runway centerline. Runway 07 has a takeoff run available (TORA) of 3281 ft (1000 m).

column1: The ATCO observed HB-VOV taxiing onto the runway and instructed the crew to hold on the runway
column2: as a runway inspection was still in progress. In view of the expected delay
column3: the commander then set the parking brake.

column2: the crew of HB-VOV received takeoff clearance: ""Hotel Oscar Victor
column3: wind zero six zero degrees six knots
column4: runway zero seven
column5: cleared for takeoff"".

column1: The commander then switched on the pitot heater and landing lights
column2: pushed the thrust levers forward and handed control over to the copilot. He instructed the copilot
column3: in view of the reduced visibility
column4: to carry out a so-called standing takeoff.

column1: At a power setting with a low-pressure compressor speed N1 of approximately 90% of the rated speed the copilot took his feet off the brake pedals
column2: set takeoff thrust and steered the aircraft on the runway centerline. The set takeoff thrust was checked by both crew members.

column1: The ATCO watched the HB-VOV takeoff roll and noticed slower acceleration than usual.
After checking the takeoff thrust and the speed indications at the beginning of the takeoff roll
column2: the commander had the impression that the aircraft's acceleration was lower than usual. HB-VOV attained a speed of 80 kt before taxiway ECHO 1
column3: i.e. rather late
column4: but still within a framework which seemed acceptable to the commander. On reaching rotation speed (VR)
column5: in the co-pilot's estimation approximately 250 m before the end of the runway
column6: the commander called out ""rotate""
column7: whereupon the copilot pulled on the control column. Both crew members immediately noticed that the nose of the aircraft was not lifting. After a repeated callout by the commander

CV-580As had been converted to aerial tankers (water bombers) for fighting forest fires. The accident flight was a training flight that consisted of stop-and-go circuits at the La Ronge Airport (YVC). The purpose of the training was to instruct and cross-qualify new CV-580A captains as first officers for future training requirements. The first two circuits were unremarkable; all altitudes
column8: speeds
column9: and aircraft performance were as expected for the exercises being carried out.

column1: The final approach leg of the third circuit differed from the first two in that the aircraft's speed was lower. The airspeed was stabilized at 103 knots indicated airspeed (KIAS). The rate of descent and respective altitudes were unstable compared with those of the first two circuits. The captain had called for a power setting of 150 to 200 hp on both engines on short final approach
column2: and the flaps
column3: which had been set at 24°
column4: were selected to 28°. The aircraft entered a high sink rate of approximately 1280 feet per minute.

column1: In an effort to arrest the high sink rate
column2: the captain
column3: who was the pilot flying

column5: briefly increased pitch attitude
column6: and then touched down on the runway

column8: the pilot not flying
column9: responded to the captain's call for power by rapidly advancing both power levers to a point beyond the maximum power setting limit. When the power levers were advanced
column10: the left propeller immediately autofeathered and the left engine shut down. The captain
column11: noting the position of the power levers
column12: quickly retarded them to a position he assumed would give maximum power.

column1: During the final approach leg and on the go-around
column2: the captain was not continuously setting or monitoring the engine power settings and consequently was unaware of the engine power or the nature of the emergency. The elapsed time between encountering the high sink rate and initiating the go-around was approximately seven seconds.

The go-around was commenced at an airspeed of approximately 94 KIAS (V1 minus 2)1. The gear was then selected up during a momentary positive rate of climb and the flaps were retracted at an airspeed of 95 KIAS

column1: 15-jun-00;Swearingen SA227-AC Metro III;ZK-RCA;Air New Zealand Link
column2: opb Eagle Airways;Gisborne Air...;1986;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Training;Gisborne Airport (GIS/NZGS)
