column4: New Zealand;"A Swearingen SA227-AC Metro III turboprop sustained substantial damage in a landing accident at Gisborne Airport (GIS)
column5: New Zealand. Both pilots were not injured.

column1: ZK-RCA took off from Gisborne for a planned one-hour crew-training flight. A check and training captain (the captain) and a pilot undergoing command training
column2: who was the pilot flying
column3: were on board the aircraft.

column1: The flight included emergency procedure exercises with simulated engine failures
column2: circuits and landings using runway 14. The first circuit was normal using both engines. The second circuit was flown with the left engine power lever retarded to simulate a left engine failure shortly after takeoff. On short final approach a single-engine go-around was commenced from the decision height and the aircraft recircuited with the left engine simulated as inoperative.

column1: The third circuit was flown at an altitude lower than normal. A moderate wind from the south-west created a right crosswind for the landing. The pilots said the approach was normal until about a height of 50 feet before landing when the aircraft descent rate increased. They said the landing was somewhat firmer than normal and firmer than they expected. Although the
aircraft landed straight it began to veer to the left and the pilot under training was unable to maintain directional control. The captain ordered a go-around.
the left undercarriage HAD collapsed rearwards to about 40 degrees past its normal down position.

When the aircraft became airborne the crew selected the undercarriage up but the left undercarriage red in-transit indicator light remained on. After the aircraft climbed to 1500 feet above mean sea level the captain reselected the undercarriage down. The nose and right undercarriage position indicator lights displayed normal green (down) indications but the left
undercarriage red in-transit indicator light remained on.
After the aircraft became airborne the aerodrome controller told the crew that the left undercarriage was not down correctly but was hanging at about 45 degrees. The crew
column2: unsure whether the undercarriage was inclined forward or trailing
column3: loaded the aircraft with positive “g” (vertical acceleration) in an attempt to force the undercarriage into the down locked position.

column1: The red indicator light remained on. The pilot under training then flew the aircraft at low level past the control tower and the controller confirmed the undercarriage was trailing at about 45 degrees aft of its normal down position.

The pilot under training flew the aircraft to the east and to a higher altitude where the crew considered their options. The captain spoke to the company’s Gisborne base manager and company personnel at Hamilton
column2: advising them of the situation. The captain elected to fly ZK-RCA to Hamilton Aerodrome where the company’s headquarters and engineering base were located. Hamilton Aerodrome was an international aerodrome with a higher category of emergency services and a longer runway than Gisborne Aerodrome.

column1: The flight to Hamilton was flown with the undercarriage selected up but at a speed below the undercarriage extended speed limitation of 173 knots. The captain spoke with the operator’s engineering personnel and the Metro fleet captain. Following the fleet captain’s advice the crew swapped seats to occupy their more familiar positions
column2: with the captain in the left seat and the pilot under training in the right seat. The captain completed 2 low approaches and overshoots at Hamilton Aerodrome for engineering and flying personnel to view the undercarriage in the down selected and up selected positions. This was carried out to analyse the possible failure and to assist the captain to decide what action he should take.

column1: In the retracted position the left undercarriage wheels protruded below the engine nacelle some 45 degrees below the normal horizontal up position. The captain decided to land the aircraft with the undercarriage selected up
column2: in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendation. He orbited over the aerodrome burning off fuel to the minimum
column3: leaving about 10 minutes of fuel to complete a landing
column4: or carry out a go-around for a second approach if necessary.

column1: In the meantime the emergency rescue services and the operator put together a plan to attend the aircraft as it landed and to recover it from the runway. The crash fire service sprayed fire retardant foam along the runway to reduce the potential for fire.

The captain flew a stabilised approach to runway 18. On short final some 50 feet before touchdown he directed the second pilot to pull both the red engine stop and feather knobs. This action cut the fuel supply to both engines and feathered the propellers. The second pilot also closed the fuel shut-off valves and hydraulic shut-off valves. The captain selected the batteries off.

ZK-RCA touched down straight and slid some distance before it slewed to the right side of the runway and onto the grass where it turned through about 170 degrees and came to rest. About 1700 m of runway were used during the landing. The pilots evacuated the aircraft immediately through the emergency exit over the right wing
column2: having already informed the emergency

column1: services of their plan.

Once the pilots cleared the aircraft the emergency fire service sprayed fire retardant under the aircraft around likely hot spots. This action had been predetermined and was taken to eliminate the potential for fire to erupt in the event any fuel lines or fuel tanks had ruptured. The fire retardant was biodegradable and non-corrosive. No fire occurred.";14:00;Swearingen SA227-AC Metro III;null;Thursday 15 June 2000

column4: registered P2-MCZ
column5: departed Port Moresby-Jackson's Airport at 01:40 UTC for Sasereme. It was a regular public transport flight that had been planned to refuel at Sasereme and continue to Balimo and on to Daru. For the flight to Sasereme
column6: the pilot in command (PIC) was the support/monitoring pilot
column7: and the copilot was the handling pilot. The aircraft arrived over the Saserema airstrip at 02:40. While en-route
column8: the crew was informed by the company flight operations staff that it had been raining at Sasereme throughout the previous night until morning
column9: but the prevailing weather was fine.

column1: The flight was being conducted under the visual flight rules (VFR) procedures. The copilot had not flown into Sasereme before
column2: so this was a training flight for her. During the cruise before top of descent
column3: the crew discussed the approach and landing requirements. Because of the wet
column4: slippery and rough airstrip surface conditions and a landing weight of 5
column5: 300 kg
column6: they agreed on a 30 degrees flap settings and a approach speed of 73 knots.

column1: The weather
column2: as observed by the crew
column3: was sunny and fine with few clouds around and the wind was estimated to be light and variable (2 to 3 kt) even though there was no wind sock available to indicate the actual wind velocity. The crew opted to land on strip 14 and joined the circuit on left downwind.

column1: Passing through 50 ft the copilot flared the aircraft and it floated in ground effect. As the main landing gear touched down on the centreline of the strip it skipped
column2: became airborne and stayed in ground effect for at least another 20 m. On the second touchdown the aircraft yawed to the left and at that point the PIC took over the controls and applied full reverse thrust. He applied right rudder to regain the centreline
column3: but at the same time the left main landing gear started impacting the ruts in the surface of the strip
column4: severely degrading directional control.

column1: The PIC subsequently reported that at that point he felt it was not safe to apply power for an aborted landing. He moved the left power lever out of reverse while keeping full reverse and right rudder input on the right engine and began pulsing the brakes. The left main wheel continued impacting more ruts as the aircraft decelerated. Eventually the left main wheel hit a deep rut pulling the aircraft sharply to the left off the runway.

That partially dislodged the landing gear from the airframe causing the left wing to impact the ground. The aircraft came to rest about 5 m from the edge of the airstrip. The PIC shut down the engines while the copilot assisted the passengers from aircraft through the right rear cabin door.";02:40 UTC;de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter 300;Airlines PNG;Tuesday 15 May 2012

column4: New Zealand;"A Beechcraft 1900D
column5: registered ZK-EAK

column7: New Zealand. There was no injury to the crew or the 15 passengers.

column1: The flight
column2: operated by Eagle Airways
column3: departed Timaru Airport (TIU) at 07:10 on a domestic service to Wellington International Airport (WLG). After takeoff the aircraft was climbed to a cruising altitude of 21000 feet and the flight progressed uneventfully north towards Wellington.

column1: At 08:12 ZK-EAK was approaching the commencement of the ILS approach and the crew started to configure the aircraft for the approach and landing. Initial flap was extended and approaching the glide path the first officer moved the landing gear lever to lower the gear
column2: but the undercarriage failed to extend.

column1: The first officer returned the gear lever to the up position and at 08:15 he advised air traffic control (ATC) that they had a landing gear problem and were initiating the missed approach procedure. The aircraft was climbed to above the cloud and levelled at 6000 feet. ATC gave radar vectors to take ZK-EAK initially to the west of Wellington.
The landing gear lever was selected down a second time and again there was no indication of any gear movement. The crew checked electrical switches and panels
column2: and found nothing that would stop the gear lowering. The crew decided that before completing further fault analysis
column3: the aircraft should be positioned in an area away from cloud and other traffic. Knowing the area around Woodbourne was clear of cloud
column4: the first officer got ATC clearance to descend in that direction. The captain told the passengers what had happened and of their intention to divert to the Woodbourne area to hold.

column1: The aircraft was established in a holding pattern clear of Woodbourne Aerodrome and the crew carried out the quick reference handbook (QRH) actions for manual extension of the landing gear. Control of the aircraft was passed to the first officer to allow the captain to operate the manual pump to lower the landing gear. The captain reported that as he operated the pump handle he felt no resistance or pressure that would normally be expected. After pumping the handle for some time without success
column2: he lowered and secured the handle and assumed control of the aircraft again.

column1: The first officer contacted the operator’s maintenance facility at Woodbourne and briefed the staff on the situation. He also advised the Woodbourne aerodrome controller. The controller replied that a full emergency response had been activated.
The crew reviewed the QRH and repeated the actions for manual gear lowering
column2: but the landing gear remained retracted. The operator’s maintenance staff contacted the crew and offered several suggestions on possible causes and actions that might assist
column3: including isolating electrical power to the landing gear motor
column4: but the landing gear remained in the up position.

column1: The crew
column2: having exhausted all possible options to lower the landing gear and aware of the amount of fuel remaining
column3: prepared the aircraft for a wheels-up landing at Woodbourne. The first officer left his seat and individually briefed the passengers for the landing
column4: including what they were required to do and when and how to exit the aircraft after landing. The first officer then checked passenger security and stowed all of the cabin bags in the front row of seats before returning to his seat.

column1: The crew reviewed the QRH actions for a wheels-up landing
column2: and after excess fuel had been used
column3: turned off all non-essential electrical items
column4: including pulling the landing gear control circuit breakers to prevent uncommanded movement of the landing gear. The crew set the flap to 17º and positioned the aircraft for a landing on runway 24. At about 09:02 the aerodrome controller confirmed emergency services were in place and cleared the aircraft to land.

column1: At about 500 feet
column2: as ZK-EAK was turned to final approach
column3: the first officer instructed the passengers to brace for the landing. At 09:07
column4: ZK-EAK touched down. On first contact with the runway
column5: the first officer started to shut down the engines while the captain kept the aircraft straight. The aircraft took nearly 15 seconds to come to a halt
column6: after which the crew completed securing the aircraft and the passengers started to vacate the aircraft using all 4 exits.";09:07;Beechcraft 1900D;null;Monday 18 June 2007

column1: Before pushback from the gate
column2: the first officer
column3: who was the pilot monitoring
column4: initialized the flight management computer (FMC) and mistakenly entered the incorrect departure runway (27R instead of the assigned 27L). As the captain taxied onto runway 27L for departure
column5: he noticed that the wrong runway was entered in the FMC. The captain asked the first officer to correct the runway entry in the FMC
column6: which she completed about 27 seconds before the beginning of the takeoff roll; however
column7: she did not enter the FLEX temperature (a reduced takeoff thrust setting) for the newly entered runway or upload the related V-speeds. As a result
column8: the FMC's ability to execute a FLEX power takeoff was invalidated
column9: and V-speeds did not appear on the primary flight display (PFD) or the multipurpose control display unit during the takeoff roll.

column1: Once the airplane was cleared for takeoff on runway 27L
column2: the captain set FLEX thrust with the thrust levers
column3: and he felt that the performance and acceleration of the airplane on the takeoff roll was normal. About 2 seconds later
column4: as the airplane reached about 56 knots indicated airspeed (KIAS)
column5: the flight crew received a single level two caution chime and an electronic centralized aircraft monitoring (ECAM) message indicating that the thrust was not set correctly. The first officer called ""engine thrust levers not set."" According to the operator's pilot handbook
column6: in response to an ""engine thrust levers not set"" ECAM message
column7: the thrust levers should be moved to the takeoff/go-around (TO/GA) detent.

column1: However
column2: the captain responded by saying ""they're set"" and moving the thrust levers from the FLEX position to the CL (climb) detent then back to the FLEX position. As the airplane continued to accelerate
column3: the first officer did not make a callout at 80 KIAS
column4: as required. As the airplane reached 86 KIAS
column5: the automated RETARD aural alert sounded and continued until the end of the CVR recording. According to Airbus
column6: the RETARD alert is designed to occur at 20 ft radio altitude on landing and advise the pilot to reduce the thrust levers to idle. The captain later reported that he had never heard an aural RETARD alert on takeoff
column7: only knew of it on landing
column8: and did not know what it was telling him. He further said that when the RETARD aural alert sounded
column9: he did not plan to reject the takeoff because they were in a high-speed regime
column10: they had no red warning lights
column11: and there was nothing to suggest that the takeoff should be rejected.

column1: The first officer later reported that there were no V-speeds depicted on the PFD and
column2: thus
column3: she could not call V1 or VR during the takeoff. She was not aware of any guidance or procedure that recommended rejecting or continuing a takeoff when there were no V-speeds displayed. The captain stated that he had recalled the V-speeds as previously briefed from the Taxi checklist
column4: which happened to be the same V-speeds for runway 27L. The captain continued the takeoff roll despite the lack of displayed V-speeds
column5: no callouts from the first officer
column6: and the continued and repeated RETARD aural alert.

column1: The airplane rotated at 164 KIAS. The captain had ""the perception the aircraft was unsafe to fly"" and that he decided ""the safest action was not to continue
column2: so he commenced a rejected takeoff. FDR data indicate that the captain reduced the engines to idle and made an airplane-nose-down input as the airplane reached 167 KIAS (well above the V1 speed of 157 KIAS) and achieved a 6.7 degree nose-high attitude. The airplane's pitch decreased until the nosegear contacted the runway. However
column3: the airplane then bounced back into the air and achieved a radio altitude of about 15 ft. The tail of the airplane then struck the runway surface
column4: followed by the main landing gear then the nose landing gear
column5: resulting in its fracture. The airplane slid to its final resting position on the left side of runway 27L.

column1: The operator's SOPs address the conditions under which a rejected takeoff should be performed within both low-speed (below 80 KIAS) and high-speed (between 80 KIAS and V1) regimes but provide no guidance for rejecting a takeoff after V1 and rotation. Simulator testing performed after the accident demonstrated that increasing the thrust levers to the TO/GA detent
column2: as required by SOPs upon the activation of the ""thrust not set"" ECAM message
column3: would have silenced the RETARD aural alert.

column1: At the time of the accident
column2: neither the operator's training program nor manuals provided to flight crews specifically addressed what to do in the event the RETARD alert occurred during takeoff; although
column3: 9 months before the accident
column4: US Airways published a safety article regarding the conditions under which the alert would activate during takeoff. The operator's postaccident actions include a policy change (published via bulletin) to its pilot handbook specifying that moving the thrust levers to the TO/GA detent will cancel the RETARD aural alert.";18:30;Airbus A320-214;US Airways;Thursday 13 March 2014

column8: was landing on runway 13 at New York-LaGuardia Airport (LGA) when it departed the left side of the runway

column10: and came to rest with the airplane's nose on an embankment next to Flushing Bay. The 2 pilots

column1: Flight 1086 was a regularly scheduled passenger flight from Atlanta-Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport
column2: Georgia
column3: where it departed at 09:23 hours local time.

column1: Given the winter weather conditions at LaGuardia
column2: the flight crew was concerned about the available landing distance on runway 13 (7003 ft / 2135 m). While en route to LGA they spent considerable time analyzing the airplane’s stopping performance.

column1: The flight crew also requested braking action reports about 45 and 35 minutes before landing
column2: but none were available at those times because of runway snow clearing operations. The unavailability of braking actions reports and the uncertainty about the runway’s condition created some situational stress for the captain
column3: who was the pilot flying.

column1: After runway 13 became available for arriving airplanes
column2: the flight crews of two preceding airplanes (which landed on the runway about 16 and 8 minutes before the accident landing) reported good braking action on the runway
column3: so the flight crew expected to see at least some of the runway’s surface after the airplane broke out of the clouds. However
column4: the flight crew saw that the runway was covered with snow
column5: which was inconsistent with their expectations based on the braking action reports and the snow clearing operations that had concluded less than 30 minutes before the airplane landed. The snowier-than-expected runway
column6: along with the relatively short runway length and the presence of Flushing Bay directly off the departure end of the runway
column7: most likely increased the captain’s concerns about his ability to stop the airplane within the available runway distance
column8: which exacerbated his situational stress.

column1: The captain made a relatively aggressive reverse thrust input almost immediately after touchdown. Both pilots were aware that 1.3 EPR was the target setting for contaminated runways.
As reverse thrust EPR was rapidly increasing
column2: the captain’s attention was focused on other aspects of the landing
column3: which included steering the airplane to counteract a slide to the left and ensuring that the spoilers had deployed
column4: which was a necessary action for the autobrakes to engage. The maximum EPR values reached during the landing were 2.07 on the left engine and 1.91 on the right engine
column5: which were much higher than the target setting of 1.3 EPR. These high EPR values likely resulted from a combination of the captain’s stress; his relatively aggressive reverse thrust input; and operational distractions
column6: including the airplane’s continued slide to the left despite the captain’s efforts to steer it away from the snowbanks alongside the runway. All of these factors reduced the captain’s monitoring of EPR indications. The high EPR values caused rudder blanking
column7: which occurs on MD-80 series airplanes when smooth airflow over the rudder is disrupted by high reverse thrust
column8: and a subsequent loss of aerodynamic directional control. Although the captain stowed the thrust reversers and applied substantial right rudder
column9: right nosewheel steering
column10: and right manual braking
column11: the airplane’s departure from the left side of the runway could not be avoided because directional control was regained too late to be effective.

column1: The airplane departed the left side of runway 13 about 3
column2: 000 feet from the approach end of the runway. The tracks were on a heading of about 10 degrees from the runway heading.

column1: About 4
column2: 100 feet from the approach end of the runway

column1: The airplane carried 12 crew members an 216 passengers. Flight AF447 departed at 19:29 local time (May 31) from Rio de Janeiro (GIG). The takeoff weight was 232.8t (for a MTOW of 233 t)

column1: The flight progressed as planned with the crew contacting several air traffic control centres along the way. Cruising altitude was FL350.

column3: 565 km from Natal
column4: Brazil.

column1: At 01:48 UTC the aircraft went out of the radar coverage of CINDACTA III
column2: Fernando de Noronha. The meteorological situation in the area of AF447's flight path over the Atlantic was typical of that encountered in the month of June in the inter-tropical convergence zone. There were powerful cumulonimbus clusters on the route of AF447. Some of them could have been the centre of some notable turbulence.
the captain woke the second co-pilot and said ""[...] he’s going to take my place"". The captain then attended the briefing between the two co-pilots
column3: during which the Pilot Flying said
column4: in particular ""the little bit of turbulence that you just saw [...] we should find the same ahead [...] we’re in the cloud layer unfortunately we can’t climb much for the moment because the temperature is falling more slowly than forecast"" and that ""the logon with Dakar failed"". The captain left the cockpit at 02:01:46 UTC.

column1: The airplane was flying at FL350 and at Mach 0.82 and the pitch attitude was about 2.5 degrees. Autopilot 2 and auto-thrust were engaged. At 02:06:04
column2: the PF called the cabin crew
column3: telling them that ""in two minutes we should enter an area where it’ll move about a bit more than at the moment
column4: you should watch out"" and he added ""I’ll call you back as soon as we’re out of it"".

column2: the PNF said ""you can maybe go a little to the left [...]"". The airplane began a slight turn to the left

column2: the autopilot then auto-thrust disengaged and the PF said ""I have the controls"". The airplane began to roll to the right and the PF made a left nose-up input. column3: then a few moments later in the speed displayed on the integrated standby instrument system (ISIS).

column2: the PNF said ""so
column3: we’ve lost the speeds"" then ""alternate law [...]"".

column1: The airplane’s pitch attitude increased progressively beyond 10 degrees and the plane started to climb. The PF made nose-down control inputs and alternately left and right roll inputs. The vertical speed
column2: which had reached 7
column3: 000 ft/min
column4: dropped to 700 ft/min and the roll varied between 12 degrees right and 10 degrees left. The speed displayed on the left side increased sharply to 215 kt (Mach 0.68). The airplane was then at an altitude of about 37
column5: 500 ft and the recorded angle of attack was around 4 degrees. From 02:10:50
column6: the PNF tried several times to call the captain back.

column2: the stall warning was triggered again. The thrust levers were positioned in the TO/GA detent and the PF maintained nose-up inputs. The recorded angle of attack

column4: continued to increase. The trimmable horizontal stabilizer (THS) passed from 3 to 13 degrees nose-up in about 1 minute and remained in the latter position until the end of the flight.

column1: Around fifteen seconds later
column2: the speed displayed on the ISIS increased sharply towards 185 kt; it was then consistent with the other recorded speed. The PF continued to make nose-up inputs. The airplane’s altitude reached its maximum of about 38
column3: 000 ft

column1: At around 02:11:40

column4: 000 ft

column6: 000 ft/min. The airplane’s pitch attitude did not exceed 15 degrees and the engines' N1's were close to 100%. The airplane was subject to roll oscillations that sometimes reached 40 degrees. The PF made an input on the sidestick to the left and nose-up stops

column2: the PF said ""I don’t have any more indications""

column4: the thrust levers were in the IDLE detent and the engines' N1's were at 55%. Around fifteen seconds later
column5: the PF made pitch-down inputs. In the following moments
column6: the angle of attack decreased
column7: the speeds became valid again and the stall warning sounded again.

column2: the PF said ""we’re going to arrive at level one hundred"". About fifteen seconds later
column3: simultaneous inputs by both pilots on the sidesticks were recorded and the PF said ""go ahead you have the controls"".

column1: The angle of attack

column5: United States of America;"The DC-9-31
column7: operated by Northwest Airlines as flight NW682
column8: was substantially damaged when it was struck by an aircraft tug during passenger boarding. The flight was parked at gate D3 at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International/Wold-Chamberlain Airport
column9: Minnesota and was bound for the Philadelphia International Airport
column10: Pennsylvania. No injuries were reported. The driver of the tug and a food service worker received minor injuries.

column1: The aircraft was parked and was being prepared for departure by various ground workers including the tug driver and workers restocking the aircraft food supply. The driver of the tug said that he was moving the vehicle into position in order to connect the aircraft tow bar in preparation for pushback. He said that when he placed the tug into gear
column2: it lurched forward into the parked aircraft. He said that pieces of the aircraft protruded through the windshield of the vehicle and pinned him into his seat. He said that he was unable to shift the vehicle into reverse and his leg was pinned on the accelerator pedal. Other ground workers in the area attempted to shut off the tug's engine. The driver said that the vehicle continued to drive forward until the engine was finally shut off. During the event
column3: the pilot of the aircraft had applied the brakes when he noticed the unplanned movement of the airplane. The aircraft was pushed backward about 30 feet causing damage to the nose section of the fuselage. A food service worker was injured when he jumped from his vehicle which was parked next to the aircraft.

column1: Subsequent to the accident
column2: the tug was placed on jacks and a check performed. During the check it was found that the normal engine shutoff switch would not shut the engine off if the engine was operated at high throttle settings. It was further discovered that at high throttle settings
column3: the brake system was not able to stop the rotation of the drive wheels. No anomalies were found during this test that would explain the lurching described by the tug driver. Subsequent to the testing
column4: the throttle system of the tug was replaced as a precautionary measure by the airline.

column1: During the course of the investigation
column2: it was found that the tug had been involved in a previous incident where an aircraft was damaged. A report of the previous incident was obtained. The driver of the tug during the previous incident reported that the tug lurched when he was attempting to move the tug into position to connect to the aircraft.";14:37;McDonnell Douglas DC-9-31;Northwest Airlines;Tuesday 1 May 2001

column4: and the commander said to the co-pilot ""charlie
column5: one hundred
column6: strong wind from the right"". The commander advanced the power levers
column7: the co-pilot said ""autocoarsen high"" and the engine torques increased symmetrically. The commander instructed the co-pilot to ""set takeoff power"" to which the co-pilot replied ""apr armed"". Approximately one second after this call

column1: During the early stages of the takeoff
column2: left rudder was applied and the aircraft maintained an approximately constant heading. As the aircraft continued accelerating
column3: the rudder was centralised
column4: after which there was a small heading change to the left
column5: then to the right
column6: then a rapid heading change to the left causing the aircraft to deviate to the left of the runway centreline.

column1: The pilot applied right rudder but although the aircraft changed heading to the right in response
column2: it did not alter the aircraft’s track significantly and the aircraft skidded to the left
column3: departing the runway surface onto the grass at an IAS of 80 kt. The power levers remained at full power as the aircraft crossed a disused runway and back onto grass. During this period the nose landing gear collapsed before the aircraft came to a halt approximately 38 m left of the edge of the runway and 250 m from where it first left the paved surface.

column1: After the aircraft came to a halt
column2: the captain saw that the propellers were still turning and so called into the cabin for the passengers to remain seated. One of the passengers shouted for someone to open the emergency exit but the cabin crew member instructed the passengers not to do so because the propellers were still turning. The co-pilot observed that the right propeller was still turning so operated the engine fire extinguishers to shut down both engines. When the passenger seated in the emergency exit row on the right of the aircraft saw that the right propeller had stopped
column3: he decided to open the exit. He climbed out onto the wing and helped the remaining passengers leave the aircraft through the same exit
column4: instructing them to slide off the rear of the wing onto the ground. The left propeller was still turning at the time the right over-wing exit was opened and the passenger seated in the left-side emergency exit row decided not to open the left exit.

column1: The technique for controlling the direction of the aircraft on the runway is to use rudder assisted by nose wheel steering (NWS) at low speeds because the rudder has reduced effectiveness below 40 kt.
When rudder is used
column2: the requirement for NWS to assist directional control will reduce progressively as speed increases above 40 kt and rudder effectiveness increases. It is likely that no assistance will be required by 60 kt and
column3: therefore
column4: there will be no step-change in NWS directional effect when the pilot releases the steering control. During this attempted takeoff
column5: rudder was approximately neutral from 40 kt
column6: the point at which it would have become effective
column7: and directional control was probably maintained through NWS alone (asymmetric thrust or differential braking having been discounted). If rudder had been applied
column8: there would have been a reduced NWS requirement at any given speed and therefore there would have been a reduced likelihood of a change directional effect when the NWS control was released. The lack of data showing NWS commands meant that these considerations could not be verified.";08:33;Saab 340B;null;Friday 2 January 2015

column1: Sabreliner N3RP was inactive since October 2007

column1: The maintenance facility released the Sabreliner to the pilots on February 1. The Sabreliner was located on the maintenance facility ramp in the northwest corner of Fort Lauderdale-Executive Airport. The pilot and copilot boarded the airplane

column3: and started both engines.

column1: About 15:40
column2: the Sabreliner began to taxi out
column3: and contacted the FXE ATCT ground controller to coordinate maneuvering around a Cessna Caravan that was headed in the opposite direction on the same ramp. The ground controller replied ""...don't have you in sight if you guys are in the foxtrot one ramp that is uncontrolled."" The accident crew responded that they were aware of that
column4: but that they wanted to ""get out of the way"" of the Caravan. Ground control then asked for the accident crew's intentions
column6: the accident crew replied ""taxi out for departure and I'll get the clearance as soon as I get clear of the Caravan."" At 15:42:50 the Caravan pilot broadcast ""mayday mayday mayday watch out watch out watch out.""

column1: According to the pilot of the Caravan
column2: he had deplaned his passengers and was taxiing his airplane to its parking location. Since the Sabreliner was blocking his intended path
column3: the Caravan pilot stopped to let the Sabreliner pass. He then saw the Sabreliner coming towards him
column4: and the left wing of the Sabreliner struck the Caravan's propeller. The Sabreliner continued moving at a speed that the Caravan pilot estimated to be 10 knots
column5: and the right wing of the Sabreliner struck a DH-125 that was under tow by a tug. The Sabreliner continued to move forward until it struck another
column6: stationary Sabreliner (N430MP). The Caravan pilot estimated that the accident Sabreliner had traveled 20 to 30 yards beyond the Caravan before it finally stopped.

column3: Afghanistan;"The Ariana flight was hijacked during a domestic flight. The plane was diverted to Tashkent (TAS)
column4: Uzbekistan. Food and fuel were provided there. Ten passengers were released before the airplane took off again. It then landed at Aktyubinsk (AKX)
column5: Kazakhstan. Three passengers were released there and fuel was added for a flight to Moscow-Sheremetyevo (SVO)
column6: Russia. At Moscow nine more passengers were released. After Moscow the plane continued to London-Stansted Airport (STN). Nine more passengers were released of the course of three days. On February 9
column7: four men
column8: including the pilot and first officer
column9: escaped from a cockpit window. The remaining passengers were released on February 10.

column1: Eighty-nine of the 166 passengers remaining and crew members requested asylum in Britain
column2: while the other 77 people returned to Afghanistan. Of the 89 people who remained
column3: 12 were charged in connection with the hijacking.";null;Boeing 727-228;Ariana Afghan Airlines;Sunday 6 February 2000

column2: it stopped climbing and yawed to the left. Several witnesses heard abnormal sounds

column4: and its nose dropped to a nearly vertical attitude. Just before impact

column3: United Kingdom;The TNT Boeing 737 departed Liege (LGG) on an early morning cargo flight to Stansted (STN). Visibility at the destination airport was poor and had decreased below minima. The 05:20 METAR reported a visibility of 250 m
column4: runway 23 RVR of 450 m in fog. The crew entered a holding pattern to await an improvement in the weather. After 30 minutes in the hold and with continued deterioration in the visibility
column5: the flight crew decided to divert to East Midlands (EMA). The weather at East Midlands required the crew to conduct a Category IIIA approach to runway 27. The approach was uneventful until
column6: at approximately one mile from the runway threshold
column7: the autopilot was momentarily disconnected and re-engaged. The aircraft then went above the glide-slope before developing a high rate of descent. At the same time
column8: it deviated to the left of the centre-line. A go-around was initiated but the aircraft touched down heavily on the grass area to the left of the runway threshold. The right main landing gear broke off
column9: causing damage to the right inboard flap
column10: wing/body fairing and rear freight hold door and resulting in the loss of hydraulic System ‘A’. The aircraft continued for a short distance with the right engine
column11: right outboard flap track fairing and right wing tip in contact with the ground before lifting off again. A Mayday was declared and the crew diverted to Birmingham (BHX) where weather conditions were good. An emergency landing was carried out on runway 33 at 05:02. During the subsequent ground roll
column12: the right engine sustained further damage but the aircraft came to rest on the runway supported by the left main landing gear and right engine.;04:40;Boeing 737-301F;TNT Airways;Thursday 15 June 2006

column1: 1-feb-08;Cessna 525 CitationJet CJ1;N102PT;private;near Augusta Stat...;2001;Fatalities: 1 / Occupants: 1;Fatalities: 1 / Occupants: 1;Damaged beyond repair;En route (ENR);Private;Augusta State Airport

column5: United States of America;"The Cessna 525 CitationJet CJ1 N102PT was parked in a hangar at Augusta State Airport
column6: ME (AUG) in the morning
column7: at the pilot's request. However
column8: the airline that used the hangar needed to house a plane. Since they had priority
column9: the Citation was taken out of the hangar about 16:30 and moved back to the ramp area. While the airplane was on the ramp
column10: the weather condition had turned from light snow to freezing rain. The pilot and her passenger arrived at the airport about 17:15. About 1730
column11: the airplane's engines were started and the airplane was observed taxing. The FBO representative heard the pilot's announcements over the radio in the FBO. He also noticed the airplane was not on the taxiway
column12: but on the grass area on the south side of the asphalt taxiway. At that time the ground was covered with snow and ice. The FBO representative noted the pilot did not activate the airport's taxi and runways lights via the common airport frequency radio channel. It was observed that the airplane taxied through a ditch
column13: which was covered with ice and snow. The airplane's engines were heard at a high rate of power about this time. It was later discovered that the airplane's left main tire broke through the ice and became stuck in the ditch. The airplane continued on the grass area after the high engine power was heard. The FBO representative heard the pilot announce the wrong runway (runway 35) that she was planning to depart from. The FBO representative turned on the runway and taxi lights after hearing the incorrect runway announcement. The pilot later announced a change of departure from runway 35 to runway 17
column14: while the airplane was observed back taxing on runway 26 onto taxiway ""C"". About 17:45 the airplane took off from runway 17.

column1: After takeoff
column2: the pilot contacted the Air Traffic Controller (ATC) and reported that she was at 1
column3: 000 feet
column4: climbing to 10
column5: 000 feet. About one minute

column1: later
column2: the pilot declared an emergency and stated
column3: ""We've got an attitude indicator failure"". About seven seconds later
column4: the pilot announced over the frequency they were not certain which way they were turning. Radar contact was lost shortly after that.";17:48;Cessna 525 CitationJet CJ1;J. Symons;Friday 1 February 2008

column3: before exiting to the left onto taxiway J. The airplane then continued to taxi to the southwest and transitioned onto taxiway AA. As the airplane approached the intersection of the taxiway and a service road

column6: Canada;"Jazz Aviation flight JZA7795 was a scheduled domestic flight from Toronto/Lester B. Pearson International Airport
column7: Canada
column8: to Sault Ste. Marie Airport.

column1: On board the DHC-8-102 aircraft were 15 passengers
column2: 2 flight crew members
column3: and 1 cabin crew member. The captain performed the role of pilot flying (PF) and the first officer performed the role of pilot monitoring (PM).

column1: Just prior to descent from cruise altitude
column2: the PF briefed the PM for the expected approach into Sault Ste. Marie. The PF was aware of the marginal weather conditions and included the possibility of a go-around and diversion in the briefing.

column1: As part of the briefing
column2: the flight crew set the approach speed bugs to the appropriate speed for aircraft weight and flight conditions. The crew determined that the applicable landing reference speed (Vref) was 96 knots
column3: which required an approach speed bug setting of 101 knots.

column1: When the aircraft was approximately 42 nautical miles (nm) from CYAM
column2: the controller at the Toronto Area Control Centre cleared the flight to descend to 5000 feet above sea level (ASL) and
column3: given the expected weather conditions
column4: requested that the crew report when they had the airport in sight for the visual approach.

column1: As JZA7795 reached 15 nm from Sault Ste. Marie in level flight at 5000 feet ASL
column2: the crew reported that the in-flight visibility was reduced due to ice crystals. In consideration of this
column3: they requested to be cleared for the VOR/DME approach to runway 30
column4: rather than the visual approach
column5: and were cleared as requested.

column1: While descending out of 3000 feet ASL
column2: the flight crew passed through the area of ice crystals and acquired the airport visually. Although the flight was now in visual conditions
column3: the crew noticed a significant snow shower approaching the arrival runway from the west. They reported these conditions to the controller
column4: who cleared the flight for the visual approach
column5: instructing them to deviate as necessary from the VOR approach.

column1: At 18:21:34 the aircraft passed over the final approach fix
column2: 8.7 nm from the runway threshold
column3: at a height of 2840 feet above ground level (AGL) and an indicated airspeed of 204 knots. The aircraft was descending on a 3° vertical path
column4: although this was done visually
column5: rather than with avionics-based vertical navigation guidance.

column1: The aircraft slowly decelerated from 204 to 181 knots while maintaining the 3° vertical path in descent from 2840 feet to 1500 feet.

column2: when JZA7795 was 5 nm from Sault Ste. Marie
column3: the flight crew contacted the Sault Ste. Marie control tower for landing clearance. The controller informed the crew that the wind was from 310° magnetic (M) at 22 knots with gusts to 29 knots
column4: and mentioned the line of weather currently rolling across the runway. The controller further informed the crew that
column5: due to this weather
column6: the runway visual range (RVR) visibility had decreased to 1100 feet
column7: with the runway lights set to level 4 intensity. The PM responded that they could see the approaching weather.

column1: At 18:23:05 and at 1500 feet
column2: the power levers were moved toward flight idle and the engine torque reduced to between 3% and 4%. The aircraft began to decelerate more rapidly.

column1: The tower controller then informed JZA7795 that the RVR had now reduced to 1000 feet
column2: with the runway lights now at level 5 (full) intensity. Wind was reported as from 310°M at 25 knots
column3: and JZA7795 was cleared to land.

column2: at 1000 feet and 2.8 nm from the runway threshold
column3: the flaps were extended to 15° and the PF increased torque to 25%. The aircraft's airspeed was 148 knots.

column1: Between 1000 feet and 500 feet on approach
column2: the aircraft generally maintained the 3° vertical path as the speed decreased from 148 to 122 knots. The engine torque varied during that time between 5% and 30% to account for configuration changes and wind gusts.

column1: At 500 feet
column2: the airspeed was 122 knots
column3: or 21 knots higher than the bugged approach speed of 101 knots. The aircraft was on the appropriate vertical path and torque was steady at 25%. The PF made the 8° left turn to align the aircraft with the runway heading.

column2: air traffic control (ATC) provided one last update to JZA7795
column3: stating that the RVR was now 1200 feet.

column1: At 200 feet and at an airspeed of 124 knots
column2: the PF began to reduce torque to idle and
column3: as a result
column4: the airspeed began to decrease rapidly. Although the aircraft's nose-up pitch was gradually increased and vertical speed was relatively stable
column5: the vertical path steepened due to the decreasing airspeed and resultant ground speed reduction. The aircraft drifted below the 3° vertical path. This would normally be visually indicated by 4 red lights on the precision approach path indicator (PAPI)
column6: meaning the aircraft is too low.

column1: At some point below 200 feet
column2: the flight crew lost visual reference to the ground due to the approaching weather system of blowing snow. The approach was continued.
the terrain awareness and warning system (TAWS) issued a verbal alert to the pilots indicating that the aircraft's height was 50 feet.

column1: Then
column2: at 20 feet
column3: torque was increased toward 30%. At 18:25:19
column4: the aircraft contacted the ground approximately 450 feet (137 meters) prior to the runway threshold at an airspeed of 94 knots.

column1: The ground preceding the runway was covered in approximately 8 to 12 inches of snow.
The aircraft was in a level pitch attitude when it contacted the surface and touched down with a peak vertical acceleration of 2.32g.
Following touchdown
column2: the nose landing gear assembly and wheel struck and damaged an approach light located 300 feet prior to the runway threshold. The flight crew heard a thump
column3: but had not seen the light and were unsure what had caused the noise.

column1: The aircraft came to a stop on the runway centreline
column2: approximately 1500 feet past the threshold. The flight crew assessed the ground visibility as very poor
column3: due to the blowing snow.

column1: Unsure of the aircraft's status
column2: the flight crew informed the tower controller that the aircraft may have landed short of the runway and may have clipped the nosewheel. The crew asked the control tower to send a vehicle to their position to assess the situation
column3: and requested that a bus be sent to move the passengers.

column1: When the emergency vehicles arrived and assessed the condition of the aircraft
column2: no significant damage was noticed. Upon receiving this information
column3: the flight crew elected to taxi the aircraft to the gate.

column1: The aircraft taxied to the gate without further incident
column2: and the crew shut down the engines and deplaned the passengers.

column1: The crew did not believe there was damage to the aircraft and
column2: therefore
column3: did not pull the circuit breaker to prevent the cockpit voice recorder data from being overwritten. As a result
column4: relevant data that would have been captured on the 30-minute cockpit voice recorder was overwritten while the aircraft remained electrically powered at the gate.

column1: After exiting the aircraft at the gate
column2: the crew was notified of damage to an approach light and contacted maintenance to have the aircraft inspected.

column1: The aircraft sustained significant damage
column2: mostly localized to the area near the nose landing gear
column3: which had struck the approach light.

column1: The nose gear and nose gear doors were damaged and required replacement. Additionally
column2: both main landing gear were determined to have exceeded load limits and required replacement.";18:25;de Havilland Canada DHC-8-102;null;Tuesday 24 February 2015

column1: Flight OZ-214 originated in Seoul-Incheon International Airport (ICN)
column2: South Korea were it departed at 16:35 local Korean time. Destination of the flight was San Francisco
column3: CA.

column1: The weather at San Francisco was fine with 6-7 knot winds and a visibility of 10+ miles. The pilot undergoing initial operating experience was in the left hand seat as Pilot Flying. An instructor pilot was sitting in the right hand seat. The relief first officer was in the jump seat at the time of the approach.
The pilot flying had logged about 9700 flying hours. Flight 214 was his tenth flight leg on a Boeing 777 while undergoing initial operating experience.
The flight was cleared for an approach to runway 28L
column2: the ILS glidepath of which had been declared unserviceable in the current Notam.

column1: The airplane was configured for landing with 30 degrees of flaps and gear down. Target threshold speed was 137 knots. According to preliminary information from the cockpit voice recorder
column2: the crew did not state and anomalies or concerns during the approach. The throttles were at idle and autothrottle armed.

column1: At 1600 feet the autopilot was disengaged. The aircaft descended through an altitude of 1400 ft at 170 kts and slowed down to 149 kts at 1000 feet.
At 500 feet altitude
column2: 34 seconds prior to impact
column3: the speed dropped to 134 kts
column4: which was just below the target threshold speed. The airspeed then dropped significantly
column5: reaching 118 knots at 200 feet altitude. The instructor pilot reported that he noticed four red PAPI lights and concluded that the autothrottle had not maintained speed.

column1: Eight seconds prior to impact
column2: the throttles were moved forward. Airspeed according to the FDR
column3: was 112 knots at an altitude of 125 feet. Seven seconds prior to impact
column4: one of the crew members made a call to increase speed.

column1: The stick shaker sounded 4 seconds prior to impact. One second later the speed was 103 knots
column2: the lowest recorded by the FDR. One of the crew members made a call for go a around at 1.5 seconds before impact. The throttles were advanced and the engines appeared to respond normally.

column1: The main landing gear and rear fuselage then struck a sea wall
column2: just short of runway 28L. Airspeed was 106 knots. The empennage separated at the rear bulkhead.

column1: The airplane then ballooned
column2: yawed left and spun 360 degrees before it came to rest to the left of runway 28L
column3: 735 m (2400 ft) from the seawall.

column1: A post impact fire occurred when a fuel tank ruptured inboard of the no. 2 engine
column2: spilling fuel on the hot engine
column3: causing it to ignite.

column1: The ILS glidepath for runway 28L and 28R at SFO had been declared unserviceable from June 1 until August 22.";11:28;Boeing 777-28EER;Asiana Airlines;Saturday 6 July 2013

column5: Canada;"A Dassault Falcon 10 corporate jet sustained substantial damage in a runway excursion accident at Toronto-Buttonville Airport

column1: At approximately 15:00
column2: the aircraft departed runway 05 at Toronto-Pearson International Airport
column3: ON (YYZ) for a ferry flight to Buttonville. At 15:03
column4: the Toronto ACC controller cleared the aircraft for a contact approach to runway 33
column5: to begin the descent
column6: and to keep the approach tight
column7: as there was traffic to follow. At that point
column8: the aircraft was approximately 3 nm from the airport
column9: descending through 2600 feet asl with a ground speed of 230 knots
column10: and heading towards the threshold of runway 33 on a tight left base.

column1: Then the crew was instructed to switch to the Buttonville tower frequency. The Buttonville tower controller provided altimeter information and cleared the aircraft to land on Runway 33. At this time
column2: the aircraft was descending through 1400 feet asl with a ground speed of 210 knots
column3: and was located approximately 0.3 nm from the inbound track to runway 33. The aircraft levelled out from the right turn and was heading in an eastward direction. It flew through the inbound track at a transverse angle of about 120° at approximately 1 nm final. In an attempt to regain the runway centreline
column4: the aircraft banked left
column5: exceeding 30° of bank. The aircraft overflew the runway centreline by approximately 0.3 nm.

column2: the ground proximity warning system (GPWS) issued an aural alert to pull up. A missed approach was called by the FO in a low tone of voice and using non-standard phraseology. The captain responded
column3: but continued the approach. Shortly afterwards
column4: the GPWS sounded another aural alert to pull up.

column1: The aircraft was approximately 300 feet above ground level
column2: 0.7 nm south of runway 33 and 0.3 nm east of the inbound track
column3: in a left bank towards the runway threshold. The captain called for full flaps and banked the aircraft steeply to the right after regaining the runway centreline while on short final.

column1: The FO reminded the captain of the landing reference speed (Vref)
column2: 4 and twice called out Vref plus 5 knots.
the aircraft touched down hard on the main landing gear in a nose-high attitude
column3: then immediately departed the runway surface to the right. The ground speed during the runway excursion could not be determined
column4: but was estimated to be less than 110 knots. The captain applied the brakes and initially attempted to steer the aircraft onto the runway using the rudder. However
column5: due to the infield's grass surface
column6: braking and steering responses were minimal. Although the tiller was available for nose-wheel steering
column7: it is not normally used until the speed is below 80 knots.

column1: The aircraft traversed the grass infield to the intersection of taxiways Charlie and Bravo
column2: continued onto taxiway Bravo
column3: and struck a runway/taxiway identification sign before crossing the intersection of taxiways Bravo and Alpha. The aircraft struck the sign with the right side of the nose section
column4: the inboard leading edge and the right-wing slats. The sign was struck with sufficient force that it was torn away from its base and came to rest behind the aircraft on the apron. The aircraft came to a stop on the grass just beyond the intersection of taxiways Bravo and Bravo/Alpha.";15:04;Dassault Falcon 10;Skycharter;Friday 17 June 2011

column1: The purpose of the flight was a test flight following the installation of the airplane's interior prior to delivery of the airplane to its owner. The flight departed from Appleton about 10:10. The flight returned about three hours later.
While the airplane was inside the final approach fix
column2: an amber left side hydraulic quantity low crew alerting system (CAS) message illuminated. The pilot flying (PF) noticed the hydraulic fluid quantity decreasing. Subsequently
column3: an amber left hydraulic system fail CAS message appeared. The pilot not flying (PNF) pulled out the checklist to accomplish the left hydraulic system failure procedures and then suggested a go-around because the landing runway was about 500 feet shorter than the recommended minimum runway length indicated in the checklist. The PF decided to land due to the hydraulic quantity indications
column4: prior autopilot problems
column5: and the airplane's landing configuration. The PNF turned on the auxiliary pump about 500 feet above ground level
column6: and both the PF and PNF thought the auxiliary hydraulic system could support normal spoilers
column7: brakes
column8: and nosewheel steering. The PF selected right thrust reverser aft and began pressing the brakes
column9: but he felt no braking action. He reached for the emergency brakes; however
column10: he did not immediately apply them to slow the airplane because he decided that there was not enough distance remaining to stop the airplane on the runway. Therefore
column11: he attempted to go around with insufficient runway remaining by advancing the throttles to the maximum continuous thrust setting. The PNF did not see the airspeed increase and believed that not enough runway remained to get airborne
column12: so he pulled the throttles back to avoid a runway overrun. The airplane exited the runway and sustained substantial damage. A review of the cockpit voice recorder transcript indicated that
column13: before the emergency
column14: the flight crew did not maintain a disciplined cockpit environment that focused on operationally relevant discussion but instead repeatedly made reference to and discussed objects on the ground and other operationally irrelevant topics. The lack of a sterile cockpit did not promote crew coordination and communication and adherence to procedures
column15: which would have helped mitigate this emergency.";13:15;Gulfstream GV-SP (G550);Gulfstream Aerospace;Monday 14 February 2011

column1: It was scheduled to arrive at Lihue at 05:15. The pilot had routine contact with air traffic control
column2: and was advised by the controller to maintain 6
column3: 000 feet at 05:01 when the airplane was 11 miles from the destination airport. Two minutes later the flight was cleared for a visual approach to follow a preceding Boeing 737 (Aloha Airlines Flight 917) and advised to switch to the common traffic advisory frequency at the airport. The pilot altered his flight course to the west
column4: most likely for spacing from the airplane ahead
column5: and descended into the water as he began a turn back toward the airport. The majority of the wreckage sank in 4
column6: 800 feet of water.

column1: The pilot most likely descended into the ocean because he became spatially disoriented. Although visual meteorological conditions prevailed
column2: no natural horizon and few external visual references were available during the visual approach. This increased the importance of monitoring flight instruments to maintain awareness of the airplane attitude and altitude. The pilot's tasks during the approach
column3: however
column4: included maintaining visual separation from the airplane ahead and lining up with the destination runway. These tasks required visual attention outside the cockpit. These competing tasks probably created shifting visual frames of reference
column5: left the pilot vulnerable to common visual and vestibular illusions
column6: and reduced his awareness of the airplane's attitude
column7: altitude and trajectory.";05:08;Beechcraft 1900C-1;Alpine Aviation;Monday 14 January 2008

column6: at some point below 4

column9: the MASTER CAUTION light illuminated. The co-pilot
column10: who was pilot flying
column11: observed the RUDDER CONTROL MANUAL annunciator light and then saw that the right hydraulic system pressure was about 1
column12: 000 pounds per square inch (PSI). The right engine hydraulic pump switch was selected to 'off' and the flight was continued while the captain referred to the NWA DC-9 Cockpit Operating Manual (COM) to complete the procedures. He also discussed the problem with maintenance control on the ground. The approach and landing at Minneapolis were briefed thoroughly. Approximately 18:50
column13: the captain contacted dispatch to request that they ""call out the trucks"" for their arrival. At 19:01 the captain radioed to MSP center ""ah we got a hydraulic problem
column14: we're gonna go ahead and declare an emergency. ah everything should be okay but just gonna have to land a little faster and we're gonna have the trucks standing and everything."" The landing gear was extended early in the approach because the crew was uncertain if they would have to use the Emergency Gear Extension Handle. This was not necessary as the gear extended successfully. The first officer flew a long slow downwind from Farmington to a downwind leg to runway 22. He turned onto the localizer course at an altitude about 3
column15: 000 feet. The flight was then cleared for the approach to runway 22. A safe landing was carried out at 19:23. After landing the flaps were retracted and the After Landing checklist was completed. The crew received taxi instructions
column16: and after crossing runway 30L
column17: he made a right turn onto taxiway A. They made a slight gradual turn into the gate area. He had just started to turn into the gate from taxiway A when the nose wheel steering failed. The first officer then advised Ground Control that they were experiencing steering problems and would probably have to be towed to the gate. He then called MAINT and told them the same thing. Then the captain

column1: lost the brakes. The first officer stated that he saw the captain's hands ""come up"" and apply reverse thrust. The airplane came to a stop. The first officer stated that he called maintenance again and told them that they had lost steering and brakes and that they needed to have the airplane chocked. maintenance asked if they would shut down the engines and the captain said
column2: no
column3: he needed them first officer the reversers. The first officer stressed that they needed to get somebody out there right away; they were in a very precarious situation. maintenance said they would have somebody out as soon as they could. The first officer made a PA announcement to the passengers telling them that the airplane was experiencing a system malfunction; they were going to stay put and then be towed to the gate. At 19:36 they began to slowly roll first officer ward. The captain He tried using the engine reverse thrust to stop the airplane
column4: but the thrust reversers did not deploy. As the DC-9 started moving towards a Northwest Airlines A.319 (N368NB) and impacted the A.319 with a speed of approximately 16 mph. The DC-9 hit the aft part of the A.319 right wing after sliding under its horizontal stabilizer.";19:36;Airbus A319-114;Northwest Airlines;Tuesday 10 May 2005

column6: United States of America;"Learjet N182K departed Norfolk (ORF) at 12:39

column8: including the missed approach procedures. Weather at the time included a 100-foot broken cloud layer
column9: and at the airport
column10: 2 miles visibility. The approach was flown over water
column11: and at the accident location
column12: there was dense fog. Two smaller airplanes had successfully completed the approach prior to the accident airplane. The captain flew the approach and the first officer made 100-foot callouts during the final descent
column13: until 200 feet above the decision height. At that point
column14: the captain asked the first officer if he saw anything. The first officer reported ""ground contact
column15: then noted ""decision height."" The captain immediately reported ""I got the lights"" which the first officer confirmed. The captain reduced the power to flight idle. Approximately 4 seconds later
column16: the captain attempted to increase power. However
column17: the engines did not have time to respond before the airplane descended into the water and impacted a series of approach light stanchions
column18: commencing about 2
column19: 000 feet from the runway. Neither crew member continued to call out altitudes after seeing the approach lights
column20: and the captain descended the airplane below the decision height before having the requisite descent criteria. The absence of ground references could have been conducive to a featureless terrain illusion in which the captain would have believed that the airplane was at a higher altitude than it actually was.

column1: The flight was cleared for a runway 28 RNAV (GNSS) approach. During the approach a local transient fog layer moved over the airport. The Runway Visual Range in the touchdown zone decreased rapidly as low as 350 m. After that

column1: The captain said
column2: ""Wait a second

column4: if visible. The captain instructed the first officer to check radio altitude carefully. Afterward

column6: then
column7: the captain called out for executing a go-around

column10: immediately after that

column1: The aircraft smashed down ORL lights and proceeded on the runway. The left main gear folded due to severe damage

column1: When the purser came into the cockpit

column1: Back in the cabin she heard flight attendants in the rear of the cabin calling and it seemed that smoke was coming up in the rear. She decided that an emergency evacuation was required

column5: United Kingdom;"After the aircraft took off from London-Gatwick Airport
column6: the landing gear was selected up but the gear position indicators remained red
column7: indicating that the landing gear was not in the position selected. The crew followed the emergency checklist and selected gear down and the indications changed to green
column8: indicating that the landing gear was now down-and-locked.

column1: The crew elected to continue to Guernsey
column2: Channel Islands with the undercarriage down. The aircraft performed an ILS approach and landed on runway 27. On touchdown
column3: the aircraft pulled to the left and the co-pilot reported that there was no brake pressure. The commander suspected a tyre had burst and that hydraulic pressure had been lost. He therefore changed to the alternative braking system
column4: slowed the aircraft and vacated the runway. The flight crew continued to taxi the aircraft and eight minutes passed before Guernsey ATC were informed that a tyre may have burst. Another aircraft landed on the runway during this period and before a runway inspection was initiated.

column1: Once G-RAJJ was parked
column2: the crew discovered that the shock absorber on the left landing gear had separated and the tyre on the No 1 mainwheel had burst. Debris from the tyre and shock absorber was subsequently found on runway 27. The shock absorber separated either as a result of a hard landing
column3: or incorrect gas pressures and oil level in the shock absorber. The physical damage to the shock absorber diaphragm threads and locking bolts started at least two flight cycles prior to the accident flight and may have occurred whilst it was fitted to another aircraft.";19:54;British Aerospace BAe-146-200;Cello Aviation;Monday 23 February 2015

column1: 10-jun-08;Airbus A310-324;ST-ATN;Sudan Airways;Khartoum-Civ...;1990-08-23  (17 years 10 months);Fatalities: 1 / Occupants: 11;Fatalities: 29 / Occupants: 203;Destroyed;Landing (LDG);International Scheduled Passenger;Damascus International Airport (DAM/OSDI)
column2: Syria;Khartoum-Civil Airport (KRT/HSSS)
column3: Sudan;"An Airbus A310-324 passenger plane
column4: registered ST-ATN
column5: was destroyed in an accident at Khartoum-Civil Airport
column6: Sudan. There were 203 passengers and 11 crew members on board. One crew member and 29 passengers were killed.

column1: The aircraft was operated with a deactivated no. 1 engine reverser as per Minimum Equipment List (MEL) procedures
column2: being a carry forward defect. This was accepted by the pilot who operated the return flight from Khartoum to Amman.

column1: Sudan Airways Flight 109 was the return leg from Amman
column2: Jordan to Khartoum
column3: Sudan with an en route stop at Damascus
column4: Syria. The airplane diverted to Port Sudan due to inclement weather at Khartoum. After staying on ground at Port Sudan for about 1:15 hour
column5: and being informed that the weather was getting better
column6: the captain decided to continue to Khartoum.

column1: Weather was poor with CB clouds and a thunderstorm as the Airbus approached Khartoum. The flight was cleared to land on runway 36 with wind information given as 320 degrees at 7 knots. In reality however
column2: there was a 15 knot tail wind. The runway was reported being wet.

column1: The Airbus touched down 900 metres past the runway threshold and the captain selected both thrust reversers to maximum reverse. Reverser no. 2 deployed normally and no. 1 remained stowed. Because of asymmetrical reverse
column2: the airplane skidded to the right. Ten seconds after touch down both reversers were stowed and thrust levers were set to idle. The captain put the aircraft back to the centre line by using differential braking. The captain then switched the anti-skid off and applied full braking on both pedals
column3: causing the wheels to lock. The aircraft longitudinally overran the runway and came to a stop 215 meters after the runway end. Then it caught fire on its right side.

column1: Fire services arrived late at the scene of the accident due to acute shortage in fire fighting personnel
column2: and the fact that there was no means of communication between the fire station and the vehicles.";20:26;Airbus A310-324;Sudan Airways;Tuesday 10 June 2008

column1: 22-MAR-2000;IAI 1125 Astra SPX;C-FRJZ;Jetport Inc.;Fox Harbour ...;1997;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants:;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants:;Substantial;Approach (APR);Unknown;?;Fox Harbour Airport
column2: NS
column3: Canada;"IAI Astra C-FRJZ departed on a night-time flight to the private airstrip at Fox Harbour
column4: NS.

column1: The departure and en route portions of the flight to Fox Harbour were unremarkable until preparation for the descent. The owner of the IAI Astra jet had made it clear to this crew
column2: and to other crews on previous occasions
column3: that he expected arrivals and approaches to be flown in minimum time. The operating crew and other employees confirmed this pressure
column4: and aircrew therefore planned and conducted their operations accordingly. In preparation for the arrival and the approach to Fox Harbour
column5: the crew inserted a series of waypoints in the flight management system to guide them for a straight-in approach and landing on runway 33.

column1: In general
column2: the descent was flown at high speed on a track following the navigation waypoints programmed in the flight management system by the crew. Speed brakes were required to slow the aircraft during the descent. Example speeds show that the aircraft was at 340 knots indicated airspeed (KIAS) at 10 000 feet
column3: 310 KIAS at 5000 feet
column4: and 250 KIAS at 1000 feet. At 1000 feet
column5: the aircraft was levelled and decelerated to configure for approach and landing. About this time
column6: there was a slight quartering tailwind component
column7: estimated to be about six knots. Because the speed was high throughout the descent
column8: flaps and landing gear selections were delayed and
column9: consequently
column10: not fully extended until about three miles from the runway. At this time
column11: the co-pilot went ""heads down"" to ensure that all checklist items were complete and to confirm that the aircraft was properly configured to land. When he next looked up
column12: he observed that the aircraft was low in relationship to the runway and advised the captain
column13: who corrected by levelling the aircraft. The aircraft altitude was recorded on radar to be between 200 and 300 feet above sea level while tracking inbound to the airport. A short distance before the tree line the aircraft began descending again. The co-pilot saw trees between the aircraft and the runway and called for an overshoot. The captain had begun the overshoot on the co-pilot's call; however
column14: the action was not taken in time to avoid striking the trees.

column1: About 50 feet above ground level and 1300 feet from the threshold of runway 33
column2: the aircraft struck the trees and descended 10 feet into the treetops
column3: then climbed away. Damage to the aircraft comprised wing leading-edge dents
column4: minor fuselage perforations
column5: leading- and trailing-edge flap dents and perforations
column6: nose and landing-gear door damage
column7: and foreign object damage to both engines. Tree debris was entangled in the landing gear; some of this debris fell from the aircraft during the overshoot. Debris that entered the engines subsequently resulted in an odour of burning wood and some smoke in the cabin.

column1: Once the aircraft began climbing on the overshoot
column2: the crew raised the landing gear and the trailing-edge flaps. Both systems functioned normally. The initial decision to raise the landing gear and the flaps was re-examined during the overshoot climb
column3: resulting in the leading-edge flaps being left extended. The crew contacted air traffic control on the overshoot
column4: declared an emergency
column5: and requested clearance to Charlottetown. Charlottetown was chosen because it was nearby and clearly visible from Fox Harbour
column6: had landing aids
column7: and had airport emergency response services. The aircraft continued to Charlottetown for a straight-in approach and an uneventful landing and shutdown.";null;IAI 1125 Astra SPX;Jetport Inc.;Wednesday 22 March 2000

column1: 15-MAR-2012;Convair CV-440-38;N153JR;Jet One Express;near San Juan-Lui...;1953;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;Initial climb (ICL);Cargo;San Juan-Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport (SJU/TJSJ)
column2: Puerto Rico;Sint Maarten-Juliana Airport (SXM/TNCM)
column3: Sint Maarten;"A Convair CV-440 cargo plane crashed into a lagoon shortly after departure from San Juan-Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport (SJU)
column4: Puerto Rico. Both pilots were killed.

column1: The airplane took off from runway 10 at San Juan-Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport bound for Sint Maarten-Juliana Airport (SXM). It carried 12100 pounds of cargo mainly consisting of bread. Shortly after takeoff the captain declared an emergency
column2: stating that they wanted to return to the airport. They reported smoke coming from one of the engines. Air traffic control cleared the flight to land on runway 10
column3: but the crew requested runway 28 for landing. This was approved and the controller cleared N153JR to land
column4: stating that the wind was ""150 at 3"".

column1: The flight came down in the Torrecilla Lagoon on the east side of the airport. It sank in 30-50 feet of water.
Investigation showed that the estimated ramp weight of the airplane was 47
column2: 710 lbs. The Convair CV-440’s maximum allowable takeoff weight of 48
column3: 000 lbs requires use of both the antidetonation injection and autofeather systems; however
column4: because neither system was used on the accident flight
column5: the maximum allowable takeoff weight was 40
column6: 900 lbs.

column1: Flight crew injuries were consistent with the first officer flying the airplane at the time of impact; however
column2: considering the first officer’s limited recent experience in the Convair CV-440 and the performance deficiencies identified in his training and certification history
column3: he was likely not capable of handling the emergency without help from the captain.

column1: The captain on the other hand was likely suffering from acute sleep loss at the time of the accident
column2: which would have negatively affected his ability to guide the first officer in properly handling the emergency.";07:38;Convair CV-440-38;Jet One Express;Thursday 15 March 2012

column8: Indiana. The captain
column9: first officer
column10: and sole passenger were not injured.

column1: The captain was the pilot-flying during the accident flight. After departure
column2: the flight had to circumnavigate around numerous thunderstorms that affected the planned route of flight. When the flight was within 25 nautical miles (nm) of its intended destination
column3: the flight crew cancelled the instrument flight plan and concluded the flight under visual flight rules.

column1: The captain noted the wind was from 310 degrees at 19 knots
column2: gusting 27 knots. A 5 nm straight-in final approach was flown to runway 36 (5
column3: 500 feet by 100 feet). The captain reported that the landing reference speed (Vref) was 110 knots
column4: which included a 5 knot gust factor. As the airplane touched down on its main landing gear
column5: it encountered a wind gust that raised the left wing. The captain corrected with a left roll input as he simultaneously reduced the airplane's pitch in an attempt to place the nose wheel onto the runway
column6: but the airplane became airborne and drifted off the runway. The airplane touched down for the second time in the grassy area alongside the runway where the subsequent landing roll was completed without further incident. The captain reported that there were no preimpact mechanical malfunctions or failures that would have precluded normal operation of the airplane.

column1: A postaccident examination of the airframe revealed that the right main landing gear had shifted/twisted inside the wheel well damaging both forward and aft spar assemblies. Additionally
column2: the aft movement of the nose landing gear had damaged the forward pressure bulkhead. Both engines appeared to have ingested foreign object debris past their first compressor stages.";22:50;Dassault Falcon 100;Aviation Transport Solutions LLC;Wednesday 23 March 2011

column5: Australia;"A Beech B200 Super King Air aircraft
column6: registered VH-SGT
column7: sustained damage when its main landing gear collapsed on touch down on runway 24 at Perth Airport
column8: Australia. The aircraft had earlier departed the aerodrome on a charter flight with one pilot and seven passengers on board.

column1: The pilot had elected to return to the airport after detecting a problem during the retraction of the aircraft's landing gear. He attempted to manually extend the landing gear
column2: but was unable to confirm that the landing gear had locked in position for the subsequent precautionary landing. The main landing gear collapsed as the aircraft touched down.

column1: Examination of the aircraft landing gear by the aircraft operator revealed an incorrectly installed thrust bearing in the hydraulic actuator for the left main landing gear. The result was that the axial loads normally carried by the thrust bearing were transferred to the actuator's pinion gears which fractured under abnormal operational loads. That damage seized the actuator and prevented the manual extension of the aircraft's landing gear by the pilot.";15:12;Beechcraft B200 Super King Air;Network Aviation Australia;Tuesday 18 January 2005
