column1: 13-apr-10;Boeing 737-322;PK-MDE;Merpati Nusantara;Manokwari-Re...;1990-03-16  (20 years 1 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 7;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 103;Damaged beyond repair;Landing (LDG);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Sorong-Dominique Edward Osok Airport (SOQ/WAXX)
column2: Indonesia;Manokwari-Rendani Airport (MKW/WASR)
column3: Indonesia;"A Boeing 737-322 passenger plane
column4: registered PK-MDE
column5: sustained substantial damage in a runway excursion accident at Manokwari-Rendani Airport (MKW/WASR)
column6: Indonesia. All 103 passengers and seven crew members survived but ten sustained serious injuries.

column1: Merpati Flight MNA836 operated on a scheduled flight from Sorong-Dominique Edward Osok Airport (SOQ/WAXX). Departure was delayed for almost three hours due to heavy rain over Manokwari.
The flight was planned under Instrument Flight Rules (IFR). The destination
column2: Manokwari
column3: had no published instrument approach procedure. Terminal area operations
column4: including approach and landing
column5: were required to be conducted under the Visual Flight Rules (VFR).

column1: At 10:46 the crew made the first direct contact with Rendani Radio and reported their position as 14 Nm from Manokwari
column2: and maintaining altitude 10
column3: 500 feet. Following this radio contact
column4: Rendani Radio informed the crew that the weather was continuous slight rain
column5: visibility 3 kilometers
column6: cloud overcast with cumulus-stratocumulus at 1
column7: 400 feet
column8: temperature 24 degrees Celsius
column9: QNH 1012 hectopascals.

column1: The controller then instructed the crew to descend and joint right downwind for runway 35
column2: and to report when overhead the airport. Shortly after
column3: the crew reported overhead the airport at 5
column4: 000 feet. The controller then instructed the crew to report when they were on final approach for runway 35. The crew acknowledged this instruction.

column1: At 10:54 the crew reported that they were on final for runway 35. The controller informed them that the wind was calm
column2: runway condition was wet and clear.

column1: The crew read back the wind condition and that the runway was clear
column2: but did not mention the wet runway condition.

column1: The aircraft was observed to make a normal touchdown on the runway
column2: about 120 meters from the approach end of runway 35. Witnesses on the ground and on board reported that engine reverser sound was not heard during landing roll.

column1: During the landing roll
column2: the aircraft veered to the left about 140 meters from the end of runway 35
column3: then overran the departure end of runway 35. It came to a stop 205 meters beyond the end of the runway in a narrow river; the Rendani River.

column1: The airport rescue and fire fighting unit was immediately deployed to assist the post-crash evacuation. Due to the steep terrain 155 meters from the end of runway 35
column2: the rescuers had to turn back and use the airport’s main road to reach the aircraft. The accident site was in an area of shallow muddy water surrounded by mangrove vegetation.

column6: United States of America;"During the day several evaluation flights were made of a pilot

column9: and feathered the propeller. During the final leg of the traffic pattern

column15: and to reduce the flap setting to 10 degrees. The airplane continued to pitch up

column3: Germany;"On 6 July 2001 at 18:46

column5: France for flight TSC906 to Berlin-Schönefeld Airport (SXF) with 14 crew members and 197 passengers.

column1: At 18:50 the crew contacted Marseilles and requested a heading of 350 degrees to avoid the area of active clouds that the crew had noticed on their weather radar. The controller cleared the flight to climb to
FL160
column2: at the requested course. The flight was cleared to climb further to FL190 and at 18:55 instructed to turn right to the MOREG reporting point. During the turn towards the reporting point
column3: while the autopilot was connected
column4: the crew saw that they were approaching an active cell. The captain
column5: who was PNF
column6: instructed the copilot to tighten the turn
column7: which reached a 45° bank angle.

column1: At 18:56 Marseille transferred the flight to Geneva Control. It was during this first turn to MOREG that the first burst of hail hit the plane for a duration of one to two seconds. Then a second hailstorm struck the plane
column2: with a duration of 10 to 15 seconds.

column1: At that moment the captain took control of the aircraft putting the airplane in a 60° bank angle. The plane lost 500 feet altitude.
The crew did not declare an emergency but advised ATC of his intention to turn back to Lyon. The captain asked the flight engineer to depressurize the cabin
column2: which was conducted during descent. There was no rapid depressurization.

column1: The windshield of the cockpit was badly damaged. The copilot had the best visibility and carried out the final approach and landing at Lyon-Saint Exupery. The plane landed safely at 19:16.";19:00;Lockheed L-1011-385-1-14 TriStar 150;Air Transat;Friday 6 July 2001

column5: Canada;"The aircraft took off from Montréal (YUL) at 17:56 for a night IFR flight to Bromont Airport
column6: QC (ZBM). Approximately nine minutes before the landing
column7: the co-pilot activated the aircraft radio control of aerodrome lighting (ARCAL) and contacted the approach UNICOM at Bromont. The Bromont Airport dispatcher informed the crew that only the PAPI was operational. A NOTAM had been issued on 17 February 2005
column8: indicating that the runway edge lights would be out of order until 22:00 UTC
column9: 22 February 2005. The PAPI and the approach lights lit up when the co-pilot activated the ARCAL
column10: because their switches had been left on. At approximately 1000 feet (300 m) asl and five miles (8 km) from the threshold
column11: the flight crew had the approach lights and the PAPI in sight. It was not evident whether the PAPI was positioned on the right or the left side of the runway. The airport chart published by Jeppesen indicated ""PAPI L"" (left). In response to a query from the crew
column12: the Bromont dispatcher indicated that the PAPI was on the right side of the runway. From his location facing the aircraft
column13: the PAPI was to the dispatcher's right. The approach was continued visually
column14: keeping to the left of the PAPI. At approximately two miles (3
column15: 2 km) from the runway threshold
column16: the co-pilot noticed that the approach lights were at his right. He reported his observation to the captain
column17: who paid little attention to it. Less than two seconds before the crash
column18: the co-pilot asked the captain whether he had the runway in sight. The captain did not reply and continued the descent until the aircraft touched down 300 feet (90 m) to the left of runway 05L
column19: 1800 feet (550 m) beyond the threshold. When the captain realized that he was not on the runway
column20: he applied full power to execute a missed approach; however
column21: the aircraft hit a ditch approximately four feet (1
column22: 20 m) deep that was perpendicular to the flight path. The nose wheel and right landing gear collapsed. The aircraft came to a stop facing back the way it had come
column23: after travelling a distance of 1800 feet during which it made a full turn followed by a 180-degree turn.";18:25;Hawker Siddeley HS-125-600A;Scott Aviation;Monday 21 February 2005

column1: The flight was destined for Atlanta
column2: Georgia. According to the captain
column3: the ramp was covered with snow and ice
column4: and their gate position required a pushback with a nose swing of about 120 degrees. The airplane had an inoperative APU
column5: and he elected to start both engines at the gate prior to pushback because a single engine crossbleed start would require an N1 of 80 percent on the operative engine. After both engines were started
column6: the pushback was initiated. As the tug neared a 90 degree position to the right side of the nose of the airplane
column7: it started to move forward
column8: and then stopped when it struck the tug
column9: after which the captain set the brakes. The captain added that he had not applied the brakes until after the airplane came to rest.

column2: and that the initial part of the push was without incident. As the airplane entered an area where the ramp was icy
column3: he turned the nose of the airplane to the west. The nosewheels on the airplane started slipping
column4: and he was unable to communicate this to the cockpit crew. He stopped the tug and the airplane slid into the tug.

column3: Spain;"A Canadair CRJ200ER passenger jet
column4: registration EC-IBM
column5: was on a scheduled passenger flight operated by Air Nostrum
column6: with call sign ANS-8665
column7: from Valladolid Airport (VLL) to Barcelona Airport (BCN). Onboard the aircraft were 40 passengers and a crew of 4.

column1: On the two previous flights
column2: there had been problems with extending the flaps before landing
column3: first in Paris and then in Valladolid
column4: where the aircraft had to land with the flaps retracted.

column1: During the ground tests performed by the crew in Valladolid
column2: the flaps extended and retracted normally
column3: and so the captain decided to continue with the flights as scheduled.

column1: During the flight
column2: the crew went over the abnormal procedures to be followed in case of a repeat failure of the flaps system.

column1: After taking off from Valladolid
column2: the flaps were retracted normally and remained retracted during the cruise and descent phases until the initial approach to Barcelona
column3: at which time they failed to extend to the 8-degree position when commanded
column4: resulting in a ""flap fail"" warning on the EICAS (Engine Indication and Crew Alerting System). The copilot noted the discrepancy between the commanded 8° position on the flaps lever and the 0° indicated position. At that time they were below the clouds and under ATC radar control.

column1: In the zero-flaps configuration
column2: the ILS approach speed
column3: in accordance with the relevant procedure
column4: had to be maintained above 180 kt. ATC cleared them for the runway 25R approach and informed of a moderate intensity crosswind of 14 kt from 320°.

column1: The aircraft descended until it touched down at an IAS of 172 kt
column2: at which time the crew realized they had not lowered the landing gear. After a long slide on the runway
column3: the aircraft stopped 240 m before the end of the runway.

column1: There was no fire
column2: though high temperatures and kerosene leaks were detected. A firefighting vehicle that was on the tarmac immediately reported to the scene
column3: and sprayed the part of the aircraft in contact with the ground with fire retardant foam. The aircraft
column4: which was stranded in the middle of the runway
column5: was evacuated using the two front doors 1L and 1R
column6: and the 2R overwing exit. The emergency window on the left side was not opened.

column1: Two passengers were slightly bruised during the evacuation. The remaining occupants were not injured.";15:06;Canadair CL-600-2B19 Regional Jet CRJ-200ER;Air Nostrum;Wednesday 24 January 2007

column5: United States of America;"The mishap aircraft
column6: call sign Pacer 43
column7: was conducting pattern work operations during an off-station training mission at Ellsworth AFB
column8: SD (RCA). Shortly before impact
column9: the mishap crew was conducting a simulated single-engine approach to runway 31 at Ellsworth AFB. Subsequent analysis showed that there was a significantly greater amount of fuel in the left wing and left wing tip tank than the right. The gross fuel imbalance resulted from an unmonitored transfer of fuel from the right wing and right wing tip tank to the left that was initiated by the crew approximately nine and one-half minutes before impact. As the aircraft approached the point when it would normally transition to a flare
column10: it leveled off and began a climbing turn to the west
column11: toward the tower. It did not touch down prior to the turn
column12: but veered left immediately during the flare
column13: and then rolled back to wings level momentarily as it climbed.

column1: The heavier left wing
column2: and application of power to the right engine for the go-around
column3: caused the aircraft to roll back into a steeper left turn
column4: stayed in a climbing left turn with the bank continuing to increase until il rolled through more than 90 degrees of bank. As the aircraft reached the highest point of the climb (approximately 450 feet)
column5: the bank angle was more than 90 degrees
column6: and perhaps slightly inverted as the

column1: nose dropped and the aircraft began to descend. The aircraft impacted the ground in a grassy field.";14:30;Learjet C-21A (Learjet 35A);United States Air Force - USAF;Saturday 2 February 2002

column3: India;"Jet Airways flight 9W2423 was a scheduled service from Delhi to Varanasi and Khajuraho. The aircraft departed from Varanasi Airport at 12:45 local time and the flight was normal till touch down on runway 19 on Khajuraho Airport. The captain was pilot flying and co-pilot was carrying out duty of Pilot Monitoring.

column1: The captain carried out an ILS approach and landing on runway 19 at Khajuraho Airport. At touchdown the aircraft pitch was 4.39° with a vertical deceleration of 1.65G and a touchdown speed of  120 kts (Vref -4kts). During landing roll
column2: 15 seconds after touchdown
column3: at speed 36 knots the left main landing gear aft trunnion pin broke and the aircraft started deviating to the left of the center line. The aircraft came to stop on the runway with damage to the left hand main landing gear and resting on the no.1 engine
column4: nose and right hand landing gear. Hydraulic fluid spillage occurred due to damage to the main landing gear.

column1: An emergency evacuation was carried out on the runway. All four main doors
column2: escape slides and four emergency over wing exits were opened. However
column3: the passengers used two escape slides (L1 and R1) for evacuation. One cabin crew member received minor injuries (bruises) during evacuation.

column1: The runway was closed after the accident as aircraft became disabled on the runway.  The disabled aircraft was removed from the runway at 16:45 hours.";13:21;Boeing 737-85R;Jet Airways;Monday 13 April 2015

column1: According to the Libyan investigation report

column3: who both survived

12-jan-99;Fokker F-27 Friendship 600;G-CHNL;Channel Express;Guernsey Air...;1975-02-24  (23 years 11 months);Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Damaged beyond repair;Approach (APR);Cargo;London-Luton Airport (LTN/EGGW)
column2: United Kingdom;Guernsey Airport
column3: Channel Islands (GCI/EGJB)
column4: United Kingdom;"The Fokker F-27 was operating on a cargo flight to Guernsey
column5: carrying newspapers. The aircraft departed Luton at 16:14. and climbed to cruising altitude FL150 / 160). The descent was begun at about 60 miles from Guernsey Airport and the aircraft was vectored onto final approach by Jersey Radar. The approach checklist was actioned and the flaps were lowered to 16° just before the aircraft was turned to intercept the ILS localizer. With less than six miles to run to the threshold the commander told the first officer that he could see the runway and was content to continue the approach visually. The first officer informed ATC that they wished to continue the approach visually; they were given the appropriate clearance and control of the aircraft was then handed over to Guernsey Tower. Initially the aerodrome controller cleared the aircraft to continue the approach (there was departing traffic on the runway) and the commander called for flaps to 26° followed by the landing checklist. About one minute later the commander said ""three whites"" (meaning that he was aware that the aircraft was slightly high on the glide path indicated by the precision approach path indicator lights) which the first officer acknowledged. The commander then said ""ok the decision is to land
column6: speed below one four four
column7: flaps forty"". The first officer acknowledged the instruction to select flaps to 40° and announced ""running"". There followed a pause of about five seconds before the first officer said
column8: ""flaps fourty gear and clearance you have - oops"". The commander then said
column9: in an anxious tone of voice ""ok flaps twenty six"" and the engines could be heard accelerating on the cockpit voice recording. There then followed a number of expletives from the commander interspersed with some loud clicks as controls or switches were operated and the sound of a warning horn which stopped before the end of the recording. On approach the aircraft had lost control
column10: attaining a nose-high attitude. The plane stalled
column11: clipped a house on Forest Road with its left wing and ploughed into a field short of the runway.";17:06;Fokker F-27 Friendship 600;Channel Express;Tuesday 12 January 1999

column3: Kyrgyzstan;"A US Air Force Boeing KC-135R Stratotanker aircraft left Bishkek-Manas Airport at 14:30 LT for a combat aerial refueling mission.

column1: Upon takeoff
column2: a flight control system malfunction
column3: the board found
column4: generated directional instability
column5: causing the aircraft's nose to slowly drift from side-to-side or ""rudder-hunt."" This condition
column6: not fully diagnosed by the crew
column7: progressed into a more dangerous oscillatory instability known as a ""Dutch roll."" The board identified that a poor layout of key information in the inflight manual and insufficient crew training contributed to the mishap by detracting from the crew's ability to act on critical information during their troubleshooting to turn off either of two cockpit switches which may have eliminated the malfunction.

column1: Having not recognized the Dutch roll condition
column2: the crew initiated a left turn to remain on-course along the planned route of flight and used a small amount of left rudder to coordinate the turn. The use of rudder

column1: The accident flight was operated as part of the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) to transport military equipment.
The original schedule was for the crew to operate flight NCR510 from Chateauroux
column2: France to Camp Bastion
column3: Afghanistan
column4: and then continue to the Dubai World Center at Al Aktoum
column5: UAE. Because no Pakistan over-flight permit was obtained
column6: the flight was re-routed as NCR102 to operate from Camp Bastion to Bagram
column7: refuel
column8: and continue NCR102 from Bagram to Dubai.

column1: According to the load manifest
column2: while in Camp Bastion
column3: the airplane was loaded by National Air Cargo ground personnel with 94
column4: 119 kg of cargo
column5: including 5 Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) armored military vehicles that were loaded on the main deck of the airplane. Two of these vehicles weighed about 12 tons each
column6: and the other three weighed about 18 tons each.

column1: It was the first time National Airlines had transported 18-ton military vehicles when they were loaded on the accident airplane in Camp Bastion.
The airplane departed Camp Bastion at 07:45Z and arrived into Bagram at 09:23Z (13:53 local time). On arrival into Bagram
column2: the crew experienced a brake overheat condition after landing on runway 03. The crew parked the airplane on the Foxtrot ramp and ran a checklist to address the brake temperature indications in the cockpit
column3: and discussed the required cooling time of 1 to 1.5 hours.

column1: The crew did not take on any additional cargo in Bagram
column2: and only took on fuel for the flight to Dubai.

column1: At about 14:27 hours local time while the airplane was still on the ramp in Bagram
column2: the captain was made aware of a broken strap found by one of the other crewmembers
column3: and the cockpit crew had a discussion about a possible shift of the cargo load during landing in Bagram.

column1: There was additional discussion on re-securing the load prior to departure.
Flight NCR102 taxied out normally for departure on runway 03 at Bagram at 15:14. After receiving clearance
column2: takeoff was commenced at 15:26. The takeoff roll appeared normal. The airplane rotated normally around the Charlie intersection of the runway. Approximately 9 seconds after the crew called to rotate the airplane
column3: the cockpit voice recorder (CVR) stopped recording
column4: and approximately 3 seconds later the flight data recorder (FDR) stopped recording. According to witnesses and video evidence
column5: after becoming airborne
column6: the airplane continued to pitch up until it appeared to stall
column7: turn to the right
column8: then descended to impact with the ground just beyond the departure end of runway 03 and to the right.

column1: An investigation of the wreckage revealed at least the aft-most MRAP broke loose of its restraints during takeoff
column2: shifted aft and damaged the FDR/CVR before penetrating the aft pressure bulkhead. The MRAP’s aft movement was determined to have compromised at least Hydraulic Systems #1 and #2 and may have contacted the stabilizer jackscrew assembly.";15:27;Boeing 747-428BCF;National Airlines (National Air Cargo);Monday 29 April 2013

column1: The same flight crew made the return flight back to Colombo after 4 hours and 20 minutes ground time in Bangkok. The crew had received the weather report prior to departure. The aircraft was refueled adding 6681 kg of fuel to the remaining 8300 kg bringing the total fuel onboard to 14981 kg.
Flight SCB 702 departed Bangkok. The scheduled flight time for Bangkok - Colombo was five hours and twenty minutes with a scheduled time of arrival of 17:00 hours.

SCB 702 made the first radio contact with Sri Lanka air traffic control at 16:16. The area controller passed SCB702 the latest weather report effective for Colombo. At 16:40 the controller radioed: ""There is a sigmet valid up to 1415 UTC
column2: Colombo FIR CBs
column3: Thunderstorms were found having tops up to FL360 over Sri Lanka including Colombo and Ratmalana airfields and now contact Colombo Director on 132.4 Mhz.""

column1: When the crew contacted the approach radar controller (Director) they were asked to report the radial and DME from Colombo
column2: (i.e. from ""DVOR/DME KAT""). SCB 702 reported as saying ""074 radial and 55 DME ready for descent"". Later
column3: flight SCB 702 made two unsuccessful ILS approaches to runway 04. While on a radar heading to get established on the ILS to runway 22 for a third attempt to land

column1: The captain was the pilot flying and the takeoff
column2: climb and cruise portion of the flight was uneventful. Prior to landing

column4: indicating that they would conduct a visual approach to runway 26

column1: On final approach
column2: the local controller cleared the flight to land and reported the winds were 310 degrees at 16 knots. The flight crew stated that at 1000 feet AGL the landing checklist was complete
column3: the airplane was fully configured for landing and the approach speed was set to 132 knots (Vref + 5).

column1: Recorder data indicated that during the final approach
column2: the autothrottle was disconnected about 800 feet above the ground and the airspeed decreased to as low as 129 knots but did not go below Vref (127 knots). The first officer (FO) stated that he called out the low airspeed and adjusted the target airspeed from 132 to 134 knots. The captain increased power during the approach but the airspeed remained slightly below Vapp until landing. Pitch attitude on final approach was stable at about 5 to 6 degrees nose up. The pitch attitude at touchdown was about 7 degrees and the airplane touched down first on the right main landing gear (MLG) and then on the left MLG. The flight crew stated that they felt that the airplane bounced and both called for a go around simultaneously. About one second after the initial touchdown
column3: the ground spoilers began to deploy
column4: followed by an increase in pitch in the next two seconds from 4.2 degrees to 12.7 degrees. Thrust levers advanced to near maximum thrust about one second after the left MLG touched down and as the ground spoilers were in transit. Pitch attitude continued to increase to more than 14 degrees while the airplane was still on the ground. Neither flight crewmember was aware of a tail strike until the captain discovered damage to the airplane during the post flight inspection.

column1: The Emergency Medical Services (EMS) positioning flight departed Great Falls International Airport
column2: MT (GTF)
column3: at 20:40. Instrument meteorological conditions prevailed at the departure airport and dark night visual meteorological conditions prevailed at the destination airport.

column1: The airplane was approximately 42 nautical miles from the tower-controlled destination airport
column2: when the pilot was cleared for the visual approach. The flight did not arrive at the airport and reports were received that it had crashed.

column1: The wreckage was located later that evening approximately 80 feet below the peak of a ridge that rose to an elevation of approximately 5
column2: 700 feet.

column1: The airport is located in a large valley and is surrounded by rising mountainous terrain. At night
column2: clouds and terrain are difficult for pilots to see
column3: and a gradual loss of visual cues can occur as flight is continued toward darker terrain. Additionally
column4: the horizon is less visible and less distinct at night than during the day. Because the pilot was descending the airplane over rural
column5: mountainous terrain that provided few visual ground reference cues
column6: and because the overcast cloud layer would have prevented moonlight from illuminating the terrain
column7: it is likely that the pilot did not see the rising terrain as the airplane continued toward it. The airplane was equipped with an Enhanced Ground Proximity Warning System; however
column8: impact damage to the unit precluded post accident testing. It is not known how the unit was configured during the flight or what type of alerts the pilot received prior to impact. Post accident examination of the wreckage

column6: 5 km out

column12: 5 km to go the airplane descended slightly at 1-1

column5: United States of America;"An Airbus A320-232
column6: N655AW
column7: was substantially damaged when the engine cowling separated and struck the horizontal stabilizer during takeoff at Las Vegas-McCarran International Airport
column8: Nevada. There were no injuries. The aircraft was operated by America West Airlines as flight 2747
column9: a regularly scheduled domestic passenger flight
column10: destined for Columbus
column11: Ohio.

column1: According to the operator
column2: the pilot reported there had been an abnormal vibration as the aircraft accelerated through takeoff rotation speed (Vr). Several passengers pressed their flight attendant call buttons and alerted the flight attendants who
column3: in turn
column4: reported the cowling separation to the cockpit crew. The return for landing at the departure airport at 13:31 was unremarkable. The aircraft was taxied to the terminal gate and the passengers deplaned normally.

column1: Postflight inspection revealed that the outboard
column2: forward cowl door on the left (number 1) engine had separated from the engine nacelle. There was a 10-inch cut through the landing gear (strut) door and there were 3 holes in the lower surface of the left horizontal stabilizer
column3: each approximately 2 inches wide and 8 inches long. The cowling door hold-open rod penetrated the lower skin and aft spar web of the horizontal stabilizer. No damage was observed on the wing or wing flap. The opposite (inboard) cowl door and the ""bull nose
column4: where the two doors hinge at the 12 o'clock position
column5: were damaged but remained attached to the nacelle. The cowl door over-center type latches on the inboard door were found latched
column6: however
column7: the hooks were intact and undamaged. Similarly
column8: the latch receptacles on the outboard door were visibly undamaged. The latches were painted red.

column1: The operator reported that the aircraft remained overnight in Las Vegas and an ""RON-check"" (Remain Over Night) had been performed during hours of darkness. The RON-check required that the cowling doors be opened; however
column2: the mechanic performing the work reported that the cowl doors were closed and re-latched about 05:30 - 06:00 during hours of daylight. In the morning
column3: the aircraft was handed over from the maintenance graveyard shift to the day shift. Maintenance items remained to be completed in areas of the aircraft other than the number 1 engine. The takeoff where the cowling separated was the first flight following return to service.";13:14;Airbus A320-232;America West Airlines;Monday 12 June 2000

column1: 18-jun-09;Learjet 40;N998AL;Alex Lyon & Sons;Fort Worth-M...;2005;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Taxi (TXI);Test;-;-;The Learjet 45 was being operated by two A&P mechanics for the purpose to taxi out for an engine test run on the no. 1 engine. During taxi it was necessary to stop the aircraft for motor vehicle traffic. The mechanic advanced the throttles for taxi and to climb a 15 to 20 foot hill. When the mechanic attempted to reduce the throttles only the no. 2 engine could be retarded. The no. 1 engine was at a high power setting and could not be reduced. The aircraft left 4 skid marks as the main tires were locked for approximately the length of a little more than a football field. The mechanics could not shut down the no. 1 engine. Control of the aircraft was lost with the no. 1 engine at a high power setting. The right wing impacted the corner of a hanger. The nose gear broke and an embankment stopped the aircraft. The mechanics were then able to shut down both engines and exited the aircraft with no injuries.;null;Learjet 40;Alex Lyon & Sons Sales Managers & Auctioneers Inc.;Thursday 18 June 2009

column1: 08-MAR-2014;Boeing 777-2H6ER;9M-MRO;Malaysia Airlines;near Indian Ocean;2002-05-14  (11 years 10 months);Fatalities: 12 / Occupants: 12;Fatalities: 227 / Occupants: 227;Destroyed;En route (ENR);International Scheduled Passenger;Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KUL/WMKK)
column2: Malaysia;Beijing-Capital Airport (PEK/ZBAA)
column3: China;"Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 from Kuala Lumpur
column4: Malaysia to Beijing
column5: China was reported missing on March 8
column6: 2014. There were 227 passengers and 12 crew members on board.

column1: The Boeing 777-2H6ER took off from Kuala Lumpur International Airport's runway 32R at 00:41. At 00:42 the flight was cleared to climb to FL180 and was issued a direct track by Lumpur Approach to the IGARI waypoint. MH370 was then transferred to Lumpur Radar and was cleared to climb to FL250. At 00:50 the flight was further cleared to the planned cruising altitude of FL350. MH370 reported maintaining FL350 at 01:07. Last radio contact was at 01:19 when the Kuala Lumpur Radar controller instructed the flight to contact the radio frequency of Ho Chi Minh Air Traffic Control Centre
column2: Vietnam: ""Malaysian Three Seven Zero contact Ho Chi Minh 120 decimal 9 Good Night"". One of the flight crew members replied: ""Good night
column3: Malaysian Three Seven Zero.""

column1: At 01:21 MH370 was observed on the radar screen of the Kuala Lumpur Radar controller as it passed over waypoint IGARI. Nine seconds later the radar label for MH370 disappeared from the radar screen. The transponder was switched off.
At 01:38 Ho Chi Minh ATCC contacted Kuala Lumpur ATCC on the whereabouts of MH370. Kuala Lumpur ATCC contacted the airline's operations centre
column2: Singapore ACC
column3: Hong Kong ACC
column4: and Phnom Penh ACC
column5: failing to establish the location of MH370.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the airplane flew in a westerly direction back over peninsular Malaysia before turning northwest. Primary radar data showed that the aircraft tracked along the Malacca Strait. During this time the aircraft passed close to waypoints VAMPI
column3: MEKAR
column4: NILAM and possibly IGOGU along a section of airway N571. The final primary radar fix occurred at 02:22.

column1: From then on seven handshakes between the aircraft's SATCOM system and the Inmarsat ground station were recorded. Last satellite data was recorded at 08:11 Malaysian time.

Initially search efforts focused on the South China Sea area. On 24 March 2014 further analysis of the Inmarsat satellite data indicated that MH370 flew south and ended its flight in the southern part of the Indian Ocean.
A surface search was conducted of probable impact areas along an arc
column2: identified by calculations based on Inmarsat data. The search was carried out from 18 March - 28 April 2014. This search effort was undertaken by an international fleet of aircraft and ships with the search areas over this time progressing generally from an initial southwest location along the arc in a north-easterly direction. No debris associated with MH370 was identified either from the surface search
column3: acoustic search or from the ocean floor search in the vicinity of acoustic detections
column4: which were initially believed to have been from the pingers on the flight recorders. The ocean floor search was completed on 28 May 2014.

column1: On June 26 the ATSB published a new search area based on refinements to the analysis of both the flight and satellite data. The priority area of approximately 60
column2: 000 km2 extends along the arc for 650 km in a northeast direction from Broken Ridge
column3: an underwater ridge. The width of the priority search area is 93 km.

column1: On July 29
column2: 2015 a flapperon washed ashore on the French island of Réunion in the Indian Ocean. On August 5 it was established to have been from MH370.";ca 08:11;Boeing 777-2H6ER;Malaysia Airlines;Saturday 8 March 2014

column1: 20-feb-14;ATR-72-600;VH-FVR;Virgin Australia Regional;near Sydney
column2: NSW;2012-11-12  (1 year 3 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants:;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants:;Substantial;En route (ENR);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Canberra Airport
column3: ACT (CBR/YSCB)
column4: Australia;Sydney-Kingsford Smith International Airport
column5: NSW (SYD/YSSY)
column6: Australia;"An ATR 72-600 sustained damage in a in-flight pitch disconnect event near Sydney Australia.

column1: The flight departed Canberra
column2: Australia at 16:12 local time with the first officer as the pilot flying. A steeper-than-usual climb was carried out to reduce exposure to turbulence. However
column3: other than the expected turbulence during the first 1
column4: 500 ft
column5: there was nothing significant during the climb to FL170.

column1: During cruise
column2: the crew conducted a routine brief for the anticipated arrival to runway 16R
column3: which was expected to be standard except for commencement of descent 5 NM (9 km) earlier than normal to compensate for a tailwind. The captain noted the need to be cognizant of managing airspeed during the descent as the anticipated decreasing tailwind would result in a temporary increase in the indicated airspeed.

column1: The first officer commenced descent into Sydney with the autopilot engaged in vertical speed mode and a target airspeed of 235 kt (15 kt less than the maximum operating speed of 250 kt). The descent was reported to have been initially stable and smooth.

On first contact with Sydney Approach the crew were assigned runway 16L. This was different to the expected runway and required the crew to re-brief the approach and change the instrument approach diagrams and navigational aid frequencies.
Passing 8
column2: 500 ft above mean sea level (AMSL)
column3: the crew noticed a rapid airspeed increase. The first officer reported that the airspeed trend indicator was 'off the chart'
column4: indicating a very rapid increase in airspeed. The first officer reduced engine power and used touch control steering to temporarily disconnect the autopilot before manually raising the aircraft's nose to control the speed. The first officer expected that
column5: in combination
column6: the pitch correction and power reduction would be sufficient to arrest the speed trend.

column1: The first officer reported that the aircraft felt 'heavy'
column2: as was normal for this aircraft at that speed
column3: requiring two hands on the controls to move from the then -4° pitch angle.

column1: The captain reported being unsure if the first officer's control inputs would be sufficient to avoid exceeding the maximum operating speed limitation
column2: so put one of his hands on the controls and disconnected the autopilot to raise the nose further.

column1: Shortly after
column2: with both flight crew making simultaneous nose up pitch inputs on the controls
column3: the aircraft rapidly pitched up with an associated increase in the g load. The first officer responded by immediately reversing the control input to nose down. Both flight crew noticed that the controls suddenly felt different and 'spongy'. At about the same time
column4: aural and visual cockpit warnings activated. The crew verified that the aircraft was under control at a stable attitude and speed
column5: observing that it was level or in a slight descent at an airspeed of about 230 kt.

column1: One of the cockpit warnings was 'pitch disconnect'
column2: indicating that the left and right elevator control systems had uncoupled from each other. This allowed for independent movement of the left and right elevators via the captain's and first officer's control columns respectively.

column1: The crew consulted the pitch disconnect checklist and worked to identify which control column was free and working normally. After determining that both controls were free
column2: it was decided that the captain would be pilot flying for the remainder of the approach and landing at Sydney Airport. The aerodynamic loads generated during the pitch disconnect resulted in serious injury to the senior cabin crew member and significant damage to the aircraft's horizontal stabiliser. Although the aircraft was inspected after the pitch disconnect
column3: the damage was not identified until 25 February 2014.

column1: On 15 June 2016 the ATSB released an interim investigation report that contained the following safety issue:
- Inadvertent application of opposing pitch control inputs by flight crew can activate the pitch uncoupling mechanism which
column2: in certain high-energy situations
column3: can result in catastrophic damage to the aircraft structure before crews are able to react.

column1: While this issue focused on the potential for catastrophic damage during inadvertent activation of the pitch uncoupling mechanism (PUM) from opposing dual control inputs
column2: additional investigation identified that the inherent behaviour of the elevator control system design could potentially result in an ultimate load exceedance from the deliberate activation of the PUM to overcome a jam. Based on the results of this additional investigation
column3: the ATSB made the following finding on May 5

column1: - The aircraft manufacturer did not account for the transient elevator deflections that occur as a result of the system flexibility and control column input during a pitch disconnect event at all speeds within the flight envelope. As such
column2: there is no assurance that the aircraft has sufficient strength to withstand the loads resulting from a pitch disconnect.";16:40;ATR 72-212A (ATR-72-600);Virgin Australia Regional;Thursday 20 February 2014

column1: During the approach to Hammerfest the crew was informed about variable and occasional gusty wind from south-east. The wind direction favoured runway 23 and the crew planned the landing accordingly. The copilot was Pilot Flying (PF) and the commander was Pilot Not Flying (PNF). The copilot was newly hired and was flying under supervision. The crew was kept updated on the wind conditions by the AFIS operator
column2: and at times the gusty wind conditions favoured runway 05. The copilot left the control to the commander who continued the approach to runway 05. Just before landing the wind direction veered to the right and increased in strength
column3: resulting in a significant tail wind component. This resulted in a marked increase in the descent rate which the commander tried to stop by advancing to full power. However
column4: the altitude was too low and the airplane touched down hard just inside the runway edge on runway 05. At touch down the right main landing gear leg failed. The airplane slid on the belly
column5: right partly retracted main wheel and wing tip for some 650 m
column6: and stopped just after the second (TWY B) turnoff to the apron. The fire and rescue vehicles were quickly at the scene and sprayed foam on the plane to prevent fire. The cabin attendant calmed the passengers who wanted to get out of the plane quickly due to smoke and burned smell in the cabin. It took 33 seconds from the commander's order to evacuate until this was actually initiated. The delay was mainly caused by the fact that the order did not get through the cabin’s Public Address (PA) system.

column1: 14-feb-12;Airbus A319-111;G-EZFV;easyJet;London-Luton...;2010;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 6;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 142;Minor;Landing (LDG);International Scheduled Passenger;Faro Airport (FAO/LPFR)
column2: Portugal;London-Luton Airport (LTN/EGGW)
column3: United Kingdom;"An Airbus A319-111 passenger plane was involved in a landing accident at London-Luton Airport (LTN)
column4: United Kingdom. There were no injuries among the 142 passengers and six crew members.

column1: The aircraft was on a scheduled flight to London-Luton Airport (LTN)
column2: from Faro Airport (FAO) Portugal. The pilot flying (PF) was a captain-under-training
column3: occupying the left seat; the right seat was occupied by a training captain
column4: who was the commander of the aircraft.

column1: The aircraft was given an early radar vector towards the final approach track to runway 26 and the PF increased the rate of descent to close the correct descent profile from above.
The aircraft was then allocated a heading of 220°M
column2: cleared to intercept the localiser and
column3: once established
column4: to descend on the glidepath. The PF realised that the aircraft would be high and configured the aircraft with flap 2 and the landing gear down
column5: to capture the 3° glideslope from above. He armed the localiser mode and then attempted to arm the approach mode but inadvertently selected the EXPED pushbutton. The expedite climb mode engaged but
column6: to prevent a climb or any mode confusion and to regain the correct profile
column7: the PF disconnected the autopilot and the autothrust. The aircraft passed through the localiser and ATC issued a revised heading to enable the aircraft to intercept from the south.

column1: The PF decided to continue flying the approach manually and the aircraft was established on the localiser at 5.5 nm. It was configured for landing
column2: with full flap
column3: at 5 nm. Landing clearance was issued
column4: with a reported surface wind of 320°/15 kt. A subsequent wind check of 320°/16 kt was broadcast three minutes before touchdown. The wind conditions were gusty and gave rise to some turbulence on the approach.

column1: Stabilised approach criteria were met at 1
column2: 000 ft and 500 ft radio altitude (RA). The VAPP (final approach) speed was 129 kt and at 50 ft RA the approach remained stable. Just below 50 ft there was a small nose-up pitch input followed by two nose-down inputs and
column3: below 50 ft
column4: the flight data indicated an increasing rate of descent from about 600 fpm to about 850 fpm. The data also showed that
column5: below 100 ft RA
column6: there were some left and right roll control inputs.

column1: Below 30 ft
column2: over the runway
column3: both pilots sensed that the aircraft was sinking rapidly and both initiated a TOGA 10 go-around. The PF momentarily retarded the thrust levers to idle before advancing them to the TOGA (Takeoff and Go-around) position. At the same time
column4: he made a full forward sidestick input
column5: within one second
column6: which was then rapidly reversed to full aft sidestick. As the PF made the forward sidestick input
column7: the commander initiated an aft sidestick input which reached the full aft position within one second.

column1: He followed through the PF
column2: pushing the thrust levers fully forward and announced ""I HAVE CONTROL"". The aircraft made firm contact with the runway at 2.99g and a 12.5 ft/sec rate of descent. It touched down on all three landing gear legs simultaneously
column3: before lifting off and starting to climb. During this phase the PF relinquished control and reverted to the PNF role.

column1: The commander remained as the PF
column2: completed the go-around and subsequently carried out an uneventful landing on the same runway. There were no reported injuries.";13:59;Airbus A319-111;easyJet;Tuesday 14 February 2012

column2: 847 pounds with wing flaps at 35 degrees
column3: an approach speed of 121 knots

column3: but was unable to avoid striking an orange control box with the right propeller.

column9: United Arab Emirates. The takeoff was planned as a reduced-power takeoff and the first officer was the handling pilot for the departure. At 22:31:53
column10: the captain called for the first officer to rotate. The first officer attempted to rotate the aircraft
column11: but it did not respond immediately with a nose-up pitch. The captain again called 'rotate' and the first officer applied a greater nose-up command. The nose of the aircraft was raised and the tail made contact with the runway surface
column12: but the aircraft did not begin to climb. The captain then selected TOGA on the thrust levers
column13: the engines responded immediately
column14: and the aircraft commenced a climb.

column1: The crew notified air traffic control of the tail strike and that they would be returning to Melbourne. While reviewing the aircraft’s performance documentation in preparation for landing
column2: the crew noticed that a takeoff weight
column3: which was 100 tonnes below the actual takeoff weight of the aircraft
column4: had inadvertently been used when completing the takeoff performance calculation. The result of that incorrect takeoff weight was to produce a thrust setting and takeoff reference speeds that were lower than those required for the actual aircraft weight.

column1: The aircraft subsequently landed at Melbourne with no reported injuries. The tail strike resulted in substantial damage to the tail of the aircraft and damaged some airport lighting and the instrument landing system.

column2: the aircraft operator has advised the Australian Transport Safety Bureau that it is reviewing a number of procedures including human factors involved in takeoff performance data entry.";22:32;Airbus A340-541;Emirates;Friday 20 March 2009

column1: The airplane operated on Merpati flight MZ8968 from Sorong (SOQ) to Kaimana (KNG)
column2: Nabire (NBX)
column3: and Biak (BIK). The flight took off from Sorong at 12:50 for the one hour and four minutes flight to Kaimana. Cruising altitude was 15.500 feet and weather forecast for Kaimana indicated rain with a visibility of 8 km
column4: half of the sky covered with clouds with cloud base at 1400 ft
column5: winds from the southeast at 6 mph (5.2 kts) and temperature of 29°C.

column1: At 13:25 the crew received updated weather information
column2: indicating that visibility had decreased to 3-8 km
column3: with cumulonimbus clouds at 1500 ft.

column1: At about 13:37
column2: MZ 8968 reported at 7 nautical miles from the airport
column3: descending through an altitude of 8000 ft.

column1: Five minutes later the Kaimana AFIS (Aerodrome Flight Information Service) officer informed the crew that it was still raining at the airport and the ground visibility was 2 kilometers.
During the approach to Kaimana
column2: the flight crew flew to the south of the airport in an attempt to make a visual approach. The auto-pilot was disengaged at 960 feet pressure altitude. At 376 feet pressure altitude
column3: the crew decided to discontinue the approach and climbed
column4: turning to the left. Engine power was increased and flaps were retracted from 15 to 5 and subsequently to 0 degrees. The landing gear was also retracted. The aircraft rolled to the left with a bank angle of 11° and continuously increased up to 38°. The rate of descend increased significantly up to about 3000 feet per minute and the airplane finally impacted into the shallow sea.

column1: Kaimana Airport has a single runway
column2: 01/19 (asphalt
column3: length 5249 feet / 1600 m) which runs parallel to the coast with the sea to the west and mountains to the east. The airplane crashed into the sea about 800 m southwest of the runway 01 threshold and 550 m from the beach. It broke up and sank to a depth of about 15 metres.

column4: United Arab Emirates;"At 11:52 hours (06:52 UTC) the Challenger 604 jet took off from runway 36 at Malé

column1: At 07:20 UTC the airplane reached cruise level FL340. After entering Indian airspace (Mumbai FIR) the aircraft was cleared to fly to reporting point KITAL via route L894. At approximately 08:18 UTC the co-pilot radioed reaching reporting point GOLEM.
At 06:55 UTC an Airbus A380-861 (A6-EUL) had taken off at Dubai Airport
column2: United Arab Emirates
column3: for flight EK412 to Sydney
column4: Australia. The aircraft flew at FL350 with a southern heading.

column1: At 08:38:07 UTC the A380 had passed the Challenger overhead with a vertical distance of 1
At 08:38:54 UTC the Challenger
column2: with engaged autopilot
column3: began to slightly roll right. At the same time a counter-rotating aileron deflection was recorded and fluctuation of the vertical acceleration began.

column1: In the subsequent approximately 10 seconds the airplane had a right bank angle of 4° to 6°. At 08:39:03 UTC the right bank angle began to increase. Within one second the bank angle increased to 42° to the right. At the same time the aileron deflection to the left increased to 20° and the vertical acceleration to 1.6 g. In the following second vertical acceleration changed to -3.2 g.
At 08:39:04 UTC a lateral acceleration of 0.45 g to the right was recorded. The pitch angle changed from about 3° to about 1°
column2: then within one second increased to 9° and decreased again in the following second to -20°. At the same time the FDR recorded a rudder deflection to the left reaching 11.2° after about two seconds whereas the bank angle changed from 42° right to 31° left.

column1: Between 08:39:05 UTC and 08:39:10 UTC Indicated Airspeed (in knots) changed from approximately 277 KIAS to 248 KIAS. The N1 of the left engine of 95% began to decrease.
The lateral acceleration then reached 0.94 g left
column2: the autopilot disengaged
column3: and a master warning
column4: lasting seven seconds
column5: was recorded.

column1: Both pilots had actuated the aileron to the right in order to stop the rolling motion. But the airplane had continued to roll to the left thereby completing several rotations. Subsequently both Inertial Reference Systems (IRS)
column2: the Flight Management System (FMS)
column3: and the attitude indication failed.

column1: Between 08:39:09 UTC and 08:39:41 UTC the FDR recorded a loss of altitude of approximately 8
column2: 700 ft. Large control surface deflections and acceleration were recorded. The speed increased and at 08:39:31 UTC reached approximately 330 KIAS. At 08:39:30 UTC the spoilers extended and 13 seconds later were retracted again. The N1 of the left engine had decreased to approximately 40% when the Interstage Turbine Temperature (ITT) began to increase and nine seconds later had reached 850°. The left engine was shut off.

column1: At about 08:56 UTC the Pilot in Command (PIC) informed the air traffic controller in Mumbai of the occurrence
column2: declared emergency
column3: and reported their position
column4: altitude and their intention to fly via KITAL to Oman.

column1: At about 09:15 UTC the crew restarted the left engine. Subsequently the airplane climbed to FL250. At about 09:56 UTC the autopilot was re-engaged.
At 11:05 UTC the Challenger landed at Muscat Airport.
The A380 continued the flight to Sydney and landed there at 19:58 UTC.

The aircraft manufacturer determined that the Challenger's airframe structure could not be restored to an airworthy state as it exceeded the airframe certification design load limits during the upset encounter.";null;Canadair CL-600-2B16 Challenger 604;MHS Aviation;Saturday 7 January 2017

column3: Philippines;"Flight PR 137 was a regular scheduled passenger flight and departed Manila for Bacolod at 18:40. The airplane departed with the thrust reverser of engine no. 1 inoperative.

column2: PR137 called Bacolod Approach Control and reported passing FL260 and 55 DME to Bacolod . The crew then requested landing instructions and was instructed to descend to FL90 after passing Iloilo and descend to 3
column3: 000 ft for a VOR runway 04 approach. Wind was 030° at 08 kts
column4: altimeter 1014 mbs
column5: transition level at FL60 and temperature at 28°C. At 19:28
column6: the flight requested to intercept the final approach to runway 04 and Approach Control replied ""PR 137 visual approach on final"". At 19:37
column7: Bacolod Tower cleared the flight to land at runway 04 and the clearance was acknowledged by the pilot.

column1: The approach was flown with the Autothrust system was engaged in SPEED mode. The thrust lever of engine no.1 was left in Climb detent. Upon touchdown the first officer called out ""no spoilers
column2: no reverse
column3: no decel"". Engine no.2 was set to full reverse thrust after touchdown
column4: but the engine no .1 thrust lever was not retarded to idle and remained in the climb power position. Consequently
column5: the spoilers did not deploy.

column1: Because one engine was set to reverse
column2: the autothrust system automatically disengaged. With the autothrust disengaged
column3: no. 1 engine thrust increased to climb thrust. Due to the asymmetrical thrust condition
column4: the A320 ran off the right side of the runway. At this speed
column5: rudder and nosewheel steering are ineffective. Engine no.2 was moved out of reverse up to more than 70 percent N1 and the airplane swerved back onto the runway. The A320 continued past the runway end. The aircraft hit the airport perimeter fence and then jumped over a small river. It continued to slice through a hallow block fence where it went through several clusters of shanties and trees. No fire ensued after the crash.";19:41;Airbus A320-214;Philippine Air Lines;Sunday 22 March 1998

column3: United Kingdom;"Shorts 360 EI-BPD departed Dublin at 18:14 for a flight to Sheffield. The aircraft was cleared for the ILS/DME procedure for runway 28 and the crew requested the QFE which was 980 hPa. The decision height for the approach was 400 feet. At 1918:11 the crew reported that they were established on the localizer. When the aircraft intercepted the glidepath
column4: the flaps were set to 15° correctly configuring the aircraft for the approach. The handling pilot recalled that initially the rate of descent was slightly higher than the expected 650 ft/min leading him to suspect the presence of a tailwind
column5: however
column6: the rate of descent returned to a more normal value when approximately 4 nm from the runway. The propellers were set to the maximum rpm at 1
column7: 200 feet agl. When the crew reported that they were inside 4 nm they were cleared to land and passed the surface wind
column8: which was variable at 2 kt; they were also warned that the runway surface was wet. Both pilots saw the runway lights when approaching 400 feet agl; the flaps were selected to 30° and confirmed at that position. Both pilots believed that the airspeed was satisfactory but
column9: as the commander checked back on the control column for the landing
column10: the rate of descent increased noticeably and the aircraft landed firmly. Both pilots believed that the power levers were in the flight idle position and neither was aware of any unusual control inputs during the landing flare. The aircraft bounced before hitting the ground again
column11: this time with the nose wheel first
column12: before bouncing once more. The aircraft was then seen to travel about half way along the runway before slewing to the left and running onto the grass. When the aircraft stopped the left wing tip appeared to be touching the grass.";19:21;Shorts 360-100;Aer Arann Express;Sunday 4 February 2001

column2: the captain gave large pitch-up and pitch-down control inputs to assist the control of the copilot
column3: and the vertical acceleration of the aircraft fluctuated significantly twice. Due to these changes in vertical acceleration
column4: the captain felt that the aircraft had bounced and was floating

column1: About 15:40

column3: and contacted the FXE ATCT ground controller to coordinate maneuvering around a Cessna Caravan that was headed in the opposite direction on the same ramp. The ground controller replied ""...don't have you in sight if you guys are in the foxtrot one ramp that is uncontrolled."" The accident crew responded that they were aware of that
column4: but that they wanted to ""get out of the way"" of the Caravan. Ground control then asked for the accident crew's intentions
column6: the accident crew replied ""taxi out for departure and I'll get the clearance as soon as I get clear of the Caravan."" At 15:42:50 the Caravan pilot broadcast ""mayday mayday mayday watch out watch out watch out.""

column1: 24-MAY-2006;Lockheed Hercules C.1P (C-130K);XV206;RAF;Bost/Lashkar...;1967;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 7;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 20;Damaged beyond repair;Landing (LDG);Military;Kabul-Khwaja Rawash Airport (KBL/OAKB)
column2: Afghanistan;Bost/Lashkar Gah Airport (BST/OABT)
column3: Afghanistan;"The RAF Hercules was on a routine operational flight providing support to the Provincial Reconstruction Team (PRT) at Lashkar Gar
column4: Afghanistan at the time of the accident. The LKG Tactical Landing Zone (TLZ) is 6800ft long by 150ft wide with a surface of compacted sand and gravel located on the south side of LKG town. The TLZ is used by UK forces and other agencies including the UN and Red Cross.

column1: The aircraft took off at 08:50 UTC from Kabul International Airport (KBL) to fly a routine logistics sortie to deliver cargo and personnel to LKG TLZ. After an uneventful medium level transit the aircraft landed at LKG at 10:20 UTC. Using a standard tactical landing technique the aircraft touched down some 500ft in from the runway threshold
column2: reverse thrust was selected and speed reduced without the need for wheel braking.

column1: After 3 seconds
column2: as the speed was nearing 70 kts there was a loud bang from the port side of the aircraft in the vicinity of the port main landing gear
column3: the force of which was felt throughout the aircraft. At the same time the flight deck crew saw tyre debris flying up in front of the aircraft and then became aware of structural damage to the number 2 engine. The captain ordered the Emergency Engine Shutdown Drill (EESD) on the number 2 engine. He maintained directional control with nosewheel steering. Immediately after the shutdown of number 2 engine crew members observed a large amount of fuel leaking from the port wing area in the vicinity of the external tank pylon and that there was a fire in the vicinity of No.1 engine. The captain ordered the shut down of the No.1 engine using the EESD. Whilst this drill was carried out crew members observed that the fire was spreading across the whole wing. Realising the severity of the situation the captain brought the aircraft to a halt near the northern end of the landing zone some 6400ft from the touchdown point. He ordered the passengers and crew to immediately carry out the Emergency Evacuation Drill.

column1: Once all personnel had evacuated the aircraft
column2: fire rapidly destroyed the aircraft and cargo.";ca 15:30;Lockheed Hercules C.1P (C-130K);Royal Air Force - RAF;Wednesday 24 May 2006

column1: 23-MAR-2009;MD-11F;N526FE;FedEx;Tokyo-Narita...;1993;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;Landing (LDG);Cargo;Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport (CAN/ZGGG)
column2: China;Tokyo-Narita Airport (NRT/RJAA)
column3: Japan;"FedEx flight 80 departed Guangzhou (CAN)
column4: China on a cargo flight to Tokyo-Narita (NRT) with the first officer likely acting as pilot flying.

column1: The airplane contacted Narita Tower at 06:41 and received a landing clearance for runway 34L. Wind information passed on to the crew indicated gusting winds. As the airplane was probably flying through rough air
column2: the autopilot and autothrottle had difficulties to control airspeed and attitude.

column1: At 06:47:40 the CAWS announced 500 ft. The calibrated airspeed (CAS) was frequently fluctuating and at this moment the CAS was about 179 kts. The range of CAS fluctuation was from 152 to 180 kt which was 12 kts slower and 16 kts faster than the selected approach speed of 164 kts. This exceeded the stabilized approach criteria. The pilot monitoring called ""stabilize"" and most likely let the pilot flying continue approaching
column2: disregarding airspeed deviation of more than Vapp plus 10 kt.

column1: The autopilot was disconnected at 198 ft radio altitude
column2: while the autothrottle remained engaged. The pitch angle then decreased from 1.4° while the CAS was 178.5 kts. The airplane was almost on the glide slope at this point. Just after the autopilot was disconnected
column3: the pitch angle temporarily decreased as low as 0.4° but it increased to 3.5° by the time the airplane descended to 92 ft.

column1: In the meantime
column2: the CAS decreased as low as 154 ft (Vapp minus 10 kt) and the airplane descended about half a dot below the glide slope. It is highly probable that this large speed decrease stemmed from the inability of the autothrottle system to counteract the large wind velocity change (decreasing head wind component) during the descent and the fact that the thrust was kept at idle during the increment of the pitch angle to 3.5°. The increased pitch angle and corresponding column input indicates the pilot flying's intention to correct the lowered flight path.

column1: The CAS increased to 161 kt from 154 kt
column2: but it was still slower than Vapp (164 kt). The deviation from the glide slope had increased to -1.11 dot.

column1: The pilot flying began correcting the heading to correct for the cross wind component from the left and align the longitudinal axis with the runway centerline.
When the radio altimeter indicated about 48 ft
column2: the pitch angle was 1.1° and a sink rate was about 13 fps. The autothrottle was engaged
column3: and the thrust levers were in the retard mode which started to automatically decrease the thrust below 50 ft
column4: reaching idle when descending through 20 ft.

column1: The pilot flying initiated the flare later than usual at 20 ft
column2: not at 30 ft. Rapid and large column input during flare indicates the pilot's recognition of the late flare. The pitch angle remained 1.1° (about 2° lower than usual) until the flare
column3: and the pitch angle temporarily decreased to 0.7° (below 20 ft) followed by the quick increment of the pitch angle to 4.6° in 2 seconds before touchdown.

column1: The control column was pushed largely forward (-4.9°) just before the touchdown. The airplane consequently experienced a large sink rate upon the first touchdown as high as 7 fps. Vertical acceleration spiked to 1.63 G and the airplane bounced.

The forward control column input just before and during the touchdown most likely resulted in the rapid derotation from 4.6° at the first touchdown to below zero in 1.5 seconds. The decreasing pitch angle
column2: with the main landing gear still in the air
column3: may have made it difficult for the pilot flying to recognize the need for bounce recovery due to his lowering eye point.

column1: It may be possible that he didn't realize the airplane had bounced.
The airplane then touched down on the nose landing gear with a pitch angle of -1.8°
column2: followed later by the main landing gear.

column1: After touchdown the nosegear rebounded off quickly increasing the pitch angle
column2: leading to increased lift
column3: resulting in a high bounce to 16 ft above the runway.

column1: The nose dropped again and the airplane landed on the nosegear followed by the main landing gears. As the airplane was rolling to the left
column2: the left main gear first touched down
column3: followed by the center landing gear and the right main gear. The recorded vertical acceleration at this time was 3.06 G. The airplane sink rate was estimated to be 21.5 fps at the third touchdown. It is highly probable that the airplane‘s kinetic energies at the third touchdown exceeded the certification requirements by almost seven times.

column1: The left wing attachment point to the fuselage fractured. The fuselage rolled to the left with the lift generated by the right wing and a fire erupted. The airplane rolled inverted and was consumed by fire.";06:49;McDonnell Douglas MD-11F;FedEx Express;Monday 23 March 2009

column2: Indonesia;Yogyakarta-Adisutjipto Airport (JOG/WARJ)
column3: Indonesia;"Garuda flight 200 was an early morning service from Jakarta (CGK) to Yogyakarta (JOG). The pilot in command (PIC) was the pilot flying
column4: and the copilot was the support/monitoring pilot.

column1: The PIC intended to make an instrument landing system (ILS) approach to runway 09 at Yogyakarta and briefed the copilot accordingly. Yogya Approach cleared the aircraft for a visual approach
column2: with a requirement to proceed to long final and report runway in sight. Although the crew acknowledged the visual approach clearance
column3: they continued with the ILS approach
column4: but did not inform the controller. The descent and approach were conducted in visual meteorological conditions.

column2: when the aircraft was 10.1 miles from the runway
column3: it was 1
column4: 427 feet above the initial fix of 2
column5: 500 feet published in the approach chart
column6: and the airspeed was 283 knots. The pilot in command descended the aircraft steeply in an attempt to reach the runway
column7: but in doing so
column8: the airspeed increased excessively. As the aircraft was being flown at speeds that were in excess of the wing flaps operation speed
column9: the copilot elected not to extend the flaps as instructed by the PIC. During the approach
column10: the Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS) alerts and warnings sounded 15 times and the copilot called for the PIC to go around.

column1: The PIC continued the approach with flaps 5 degrees
column2: and the aircraft attained the glideslope near the runway 09 threshold. Flaps 5 degrees is not a landing flap setting. The aircraft crossed the threshold
column3: 89 feet above the runway
column4: at an airspeed of 232 knots
column5: 98 knots faster than the required landing speed for flaps 40 degrees. The wind was north easterly at 9 knots. The groundspeed was 235 knots. The aircraft touched down at an airspeed of 221 knots
column6: 87 knots faster than landing speed for 40 degrees flap. Shortly after touching down
column7: the copilot called
column8: with high intonation
column9: for the PIC to go around.

column1: The aircraft overran the departure end of runway 09
column2: to the right of the centerline at 110 knots. The aircraft crossed a road
column3: and impacted an embankment before stopping in a rice paddy field 252 meters from the threshold of runway 27 (departure end of runway 09). The aircraft destroyed by the impact forces and an intense
column4: fuel-fed
column5: post-impact fire.";07:58;Boeing 737-497;Garuda Indonesia Airways;Wednesday 7 March 2007

column1: 15-apr-02;Boeing 767-2J6ER;B-2552;Air China;near Pusan-Kimhae...;1985-10-09  (16 years 6 months);Fatalities: 8 / Occupants: 11;Fatalities: 121 / Occupants: 155;Destroyed;Approach (APR);International Scheduled Passenger;Beijing-Capital Airport (PEK/ZBAA)
column2: China;Busan-Gimhae (Pusan) International Airport (PUS/RKPK)
column3: South Korea;"Air China flight 129 departed Beijing at 08:37 on a scheduled flight to Pusan-Gimhae in South Korea. The en route part of the flight was uneventful. At 11:06 the second officer contacted Gimhae Approach. At that moment the airplane was 32 nm from the airport at an altitude of FL170. The approach controller cleared the flight to descend to 6000 feet. Runway 36L was in use and the crew could expect a straight-in approach. at 11:09 the controller notified the crew that the runway was changed to 18R
column4: with winds 210 degrees at 17 kts. This meant a circling approach which none of the crew members had flown yet at Pusan. The captain and first officer then discussed the approach to be flown. The captain cautioned: ""We won't enlarge the traffic pattern
column5: the mountains are

column1: all over that side."" At 11:13 the flight was further cleared down to 2600 feet. Two minutes later the approach controller radioed: ""Air China 129
column2: turn left heading 030 cleared for ILS DME runway 36L
column3: then circle to runway 18 right
column4: report field in sight."" At 11:17 they captured the ILS and were cleared further down to the circling altitude of 700 feet. The landing gear was extended and flaps set at 20 degrees. Then the controller instructed the flight to contact Gimhae Tower and to circle west. The second officer responded but did not read back the frequency change. The captain then instructed the first officer to disconnect the autopilot and turn left. From his position in the right hand seat the first officer was able to observe the runway. As the aircraft passed abeam the

column1: runway the autopilot was reengaged with heading select. At that moment the approach controller again contacted flight 129 instructing them to contact
the tower. The crew were busy looking outside to see when they passed abeam the end of the runway. Simultaneously the Gimhae Tower controller contacted
the flight using the emergency frequency. As they passed abeam the threshold at 11:20:02 they started timing to measure the commencement f turning to
base. Eleven seconds after the call on the emergency frequency
column2: the second officer reported to the Tower controller that they were on the circle approach. At 11:20:17 the captain took over control from the first officer and said he was going to turn base. He slowly began a widening turn
column3: causing the first officer to urge him: ""turn quickly
column4: not too late."" Meanwhile the flight was cleared to land . At 11:20:32 the captain disconnected the autopilot and banked the plane to the right. Twenty-two seconds later the first officer cautioned: ""Pay attention to the altitude keeping
column5: and the captain asked him to help him get a visual on the runway. Due to the limited visibility they were not able to see the runway. The first officer then advised the captain to initiate a go around
column6: but the captain did

column1: not respond. At 11:21:15 the first officer said
column2: ""Pull up! Pull up!"" Pitch attitude was increased to 11.4 degrees but thrust was not increased. Two seconds later the aircraft impacted a mountain
column3: about 4.6 km from the runway.";11:21;Boeing 767-2J6ER;Air China;Monday 15 April 2002

column4: Afghanistan;"Kam Air Flight 904 from Herat to Kabul
column5: Afghanistan
column6: was destroyed when it impacted a mountain side during descent. All 105 on board were killed.

column1: The Boeing 737-242 aircraft
column2: with Kyrgyz Republic registration EX-037
column3: departed from Herat at 10:02 UTC. The estimated time of arrival (ETA) at Kabul International Airport was 10:55 UTC.

column1: The aircraft was cruising at flight level 270 when it contacted Bagram Radar Approach Control (""Bagram"") for descent and landing. The flight was normal until it failed to level at flight level 130 during the VOR/DME approach.
At 10:43 UTC
column2: Bagram cleared the flight to descend at its discretion and to expect the VOR approach to runway 29. The prevailing weather was also passed on to the aircraft. Visibility was reported 2 kilometers with snow
column3: ceiling 2200 feet broken. wind calm and altimeter setting QNH 1016.

column1: When the aircraft was 35 miles west of the Kabul VOR
column2: radar contact was established with Bagram. The aircraft was advised by Bagram to cross the VOR at or above flight level 130 and cleared it for the VOR/DME approach to runway 29 at Kabul Airport. At 10:48 UTC the aircraft reported flight level 130.

column1: Bagram again cleared the aircraft for the VOR approach to runway 29 and advised the aircraft to report procedure turn inbound. The crew replied that they would report proceeding inbound for the VOR approach to runway 29. This was the last transmission from the aircraft.

Search for the aircraft was delayed and hampered due to a severe snowstorm in the region. The aircraft was located approximately three days later by an International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) helicopter
The Flight Data Recorder (FDR) was recovered
column2: but the Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR) could not be found. No data was found recorded on the FDR.";ca 15:15;Boeing 737-242 Adv.;null;Thursday 3 February 2005

column3: Colombia;At least five armed members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) hijacked the Fokker 50 during a domestic flight in Colombia. One hijacker entered the cockpit and issued specific flight instructions to the pilots. The plane was taken to a clandestine dirt airstrip near Simiti. An estimated 50 to 100 armed guerrillas herded the passengers into nearby boats on the Magdalena River. The guerrillas then took their hostages into the remote jungle area. Ransom payments were demanded for the hostages. As of December 31
column5: fifteen people
column6: including all of the flight crew
column7: remained in captivity.;null;Fokker 50;Avianca;Monday 12 April 1999

column1: 13-jun-10;Swearingen SA226-TC Metro II;ZS-ZOC;West Cape Ferries;Lanseria Air...;1979;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 13;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Domestic Non Scheduled Passenger;Lanseria Airport (HLA/FALA)
column2: South Africa;Polokwane International Airport (FAPP)
column3: South Africa;"A Swearingen SA226-TC Metro II turboprop sustained substantial damage in a gear-up landing accident at Lanseria Airport (HLA)
column4: South Africa. The 13 passengers and two pilots were not injured.

column1: The Metro II
column2: registered ZS-ZOC
column3: was chartered to fly journalists to a FIFA World Cup football match in Polokwane. It took off at 08:04 from Lanseria to Polokwane.

column1: The flight crew reported that the flight was uneventful until during descent and approach to runway 05 at Polokwane. The flight crew selected the undercarriage control lever to down position. The flight crew observed the 'undercarriage unsafe' red warning light going on inside the cockpit. The 'undercarriage unsafe' red warning light indicated that the left side main landing gear was not extending.
The approach was abandoned and the crew made a fly-by past the control tower. The ATC informed the flight crew that the left main landing gear doors were partially open
column2: but the gear had not extended.

column1: The aircraft entered into a holding pattern for approximately 15 minutes
column2: during which period the flight crew attempted to extend the landing gear. The undercarriage was recycled several times with the same indication that the left main landing gear had failed to extend. The flight crew then executed the emergency extension procedures several times
column3: with no success. The flight crew also continued with other recommended best practice emergency procedures which included various manoeuvres to induce additional ""G"" forces on the aircraft to try and release the left main landing gear
column4: but this was also unsuccessful.

column1: The flight crew elected to return to Lanseria because they thought that the facilities to handle emergencies of this nature were better. The flight crew continued to execute the emergency gear deployment procedures while en route to Lanseria
column2: without success. When the aircraft was inbound approaching Lanseria
column3: the flight crew establish contact with ATC and they were given instructions to hold over the beacon (HBV) near Hartebeespoortdam. After a while they were routed to hold over the beacon (LIV) near Lanseria
column4: where the flight crew burned off fuel. All normal and emergency procedures used by the flight crew to extend the left main landing gear were unsuccessful.

column1: After being airborne for a period of 2.9 hours
column2: the flight crew were given clearance by ATC to land on runway 06. The intention of the flight crew was to do a low level fly-past in front of the tower for confirmation that the left main landing gear was still not extended. The flight crew then recycled the gear up in preparation for the planned wheels up emergency landing. The flight crew made a teardrop manoeuvre to turn back in the opposite direction to approach runway 24R. During short finals overhead the threshold
column3: prior to touchdown
column4: the flight crew shut down both engines
column5: feathered the propellers and switched off all the electrical power. The radios were off
column6: thus no further communication between the flight crew and Lanseria ATC was possible. The aircraft came to a gradual stop on its lower fuselage on the centreline of the runway";ca 11:00;Swearingen SA226-TC Metro II;West Cape Ferries;Sunday 13 June 2010
