column1: The en route part of the first leg was uneventful. Runway in use at Terceira-Lajes Airport was runway 15. There was a partially cloudy sky
column2: good visibility
column3: a strong surface wind from southwest (190° at 22 kts gusting to 32 kts)
column4: with direction variations between 160° and 230° and the air temperature was 15°C.

column1: The commander reported that the visual approach to runway 15 seemed normal until 5 NM from touchdown. Winds were registered at a speed of up to 50 kts and there was severe turbulence along the entire approach.
Below 1000 feet the crew noticed effects of down-drafts and up-drafts
column2: with huge variations in intensity until short final. The captain stated that he opted to maintain an angle of descent (G/S) above the recommended
column3: due to severe turbulence and to ensure a safety margin. The entire approach was flown with Auto Thrust connected
column4: for effective and accurate speed control.

column1: The aircraft developed a high sink rate and lost speed instantly. This was counteracted by the captain with increasing power and attitude
column2: in an attempt to stabilize the sink-rate.

column1: Touchdown occurred with a high rate of descent and a short flare
column2: resulting in an impact on the main landing gear of 3.52 G vertical acceleration
column3: followed by a bounce.

column1: A forward push of the control column by the pilot flying resulted in a pitch-down attitude of -1.9° with a second impact of 2.75 G vertical acceleration over the nose wheel causing substantial damage in that area of the aircraft fuselage.
An inspection revealed the existence of some folded braces in the interior structure of the nose wheel bay with some bent struts
column2: cracks found in fuselage frames that had suffered structural damage from the vertical loads applied in the contact with the runway.";06:41;Boeing 737-86N (WL);Travel Service Airlines;Saturday 22 February 2014

column9: Buffalo

column11: New York
column12: and mostly confined to one residential house (6038 Long St

column1: Flight CJC3407 departed Newark-Liberty International Airport
column2: NJ (EWR) at 21:20 on a domestic flight to Buffalo Airport
column3: NY (BUF). At 22:15:14 the Buffalo Approach controller cleared the flight for an ILS approach to runway 23: ""Colgan thirty four zero seven three miles from klump turn left heading two six zero maintain two thousand three hundred till established localizer clear i l s approach runway two three."" The flight acknowledged that clearance.

column2: the engine power levers were reduced to flight idle. At that time Buffalo Approach instructed the crew to contact Buffalo Tower. The crew extended the landing gear and the auto flight system captured the ILS 23 localizer. The captain then moved the engine conditions levers forward to the maximum RPM position as the copilot acknowledged the instructions to Buffalo Tower.

column1: At 22:16:28 the crew moved the flaps to 10°
column2: and two seconds later the stall warning stick shaker activated. The autopilot disconnected at about the same time that the stick shaker activated. The crew added power to approximately 75% torque. The airplane began a sharp pitch up motion
column3: accompanied by a left roll
column4: followed by a right roll
column5: during which the stick pusher activated. During this time
column6: the indicated airspeed continued to decrease to less than 100 kts. Eight seconds after the flaps had been selected to 10°
column7: and at an airspeed of less than 110 kts
column8: the crew retracted the flaps. Sixteen seconds later the flaps were fully retracted.

column1: Following further pitch and roll excursions the airplane pitched down and entered a steep descent from which it did not recover. The airplane impacted a residential house and was destroyed.";22:17;de Havilland Canada DHC-8-402 Q400;Colgan Air;Thursday 12 February 2009

column1: The aircraft was stopped shortly after taxiing on taxiway E

column3: whereby the crew suspected a burst tyre. The crew decided to check directly at the taxiway whether the safety pins were still on the landing gear
column4: to remove them if necessary and to check whether a tire was defective. The control tower of Salzburg Airport was not informed about this by the pilots. The co-pilot opened the cabin door and left the aircraft to perform these checks. Meanwhile
column5: the pilot left the cockpit to inform the passengers in the cabin of the situation.

column2: the Salzburg Tower controller tried without success to make contact with the aircraft's crew. An aircraft passing taxiway L informed the controller about a person on the taxiway who had left the aircraft in question.

column1: The co-pilot
column2: who had gone to the landing gear
column3: recognized that the safety pins were installed and tried to remove them. When this attempt failed because hydraulic pressure was applied to the landing gear cylinder and the safety pin was jammed

column5: the main cylinders of the hydraulics of the main and nose landing gear were depressurized and the safety pins could be removed. After the co-pilot removed the nose landing gear door pin
column6: the nose landing gear doors opened and the nose landing gear folded at about 10:30. The aircraft nose lowered and hit the taxiway. 5 to 10 seconds later the engines were switched off.

column3: the other inside the elevator.

column6: United States of America;"A Gulfstream G-IV corporate jet was destroyed in a takeoff accident at Bedford-Hanscom Field
column7: MA (BED). All four passengers and three crew members were killed in the accident.

column1: During the engine start process
column2: the flight crew neglected to disengage the airplane's gust lock system
column3: which locks the elevator
column4: ailerons
column5: and rudder while the airplane is parked to protect them against wind gust loads. Further
column6: before initiating takeoff
column7: the pilots neglected to perform a flight control check that would have alerted them of the locked flight controls. A review of data from the airplane’s quick access recorder revealed that the pilots had neglected to perform complete flight control checks before 98% of their previous 175 takeoffs in the airplane
column8: indicating that this oversight was habitual and not an anomaly.

column1: A mechanical interlock between the gust lock handle and the throttle levers restricts the movement of the throttle levers when the gust lock handle is in the ON position. According to Gulfstream
column2: the interlock mechanism was intended to limit throttle lever movement to a throttle lever angle (TLA) of no greater than 6° during operation with the gust lock on. However
column3: postaccident testing on nine in-service G-IV airplanes found that
column4: with the gust lock handle in the ON position
column5: the forward throttle lever movement that could be achieved on the G-IV was 3 to 4 times greater than the intended TLA of 6°.

column1: During takeoff from runway 11 at Bedford-Hanscom Field
column2: which is 2137 m (7011 feet) long
column3: the pilot-in-command (PIC) manually advanced the throttle levers
column4: but the engine pressure ratio (EPR) did not reach the expected level due to the throttles contacting the gust lock/throttle lever interlock. The PIC did not immediately reject the takeoff; instead
column5: he engaged the autothrottle
column6: and the throttle levers moved slightly forward
column7: which allowed the engines to attain an EPR value that approached (but never reached) the target setting.

column1: As the takeoff roll continued
column2: the second-in-command made the standard takeoff speed callouts as the airplane successively reached 80 knots
column3: the takeoff safety speed
column4: and the rotation speed. When the PIC attempted to rotate the airplane
column5: he discovered that he could not move the control yoke and began calling out ""(steer) lock is on."" At this point
column6: the PIC clearly understood that the controls were locked but still did not immediately initiate a rejected takeoff. If the flight crew had initiated a rejected takeoff at the time of the PIC’s first ""lock is on"" comment or at any time up until about 11 seconds after this comment
column7: the airplane could have been stopped on the paved surface. However
column8: the flight crew delayed applying brakes for about 10 seconds and further delayed reducing power by 4 seconds; therefore
column9: the rejected takeoff was not initiated until the accident was unavoidable.

column1: The airplane thus failed to stop on the runway and continued onto the runway safety area and then the grass. The airplane continued on the grass
column2: where it struck approach lighting and a localizer antenna assembly
column3: before coming to rest in a gully
column4: on about runway heading
column5: about 1
column6: 850 feet from the end of the runway. A postcrash fire consumed a majority of the airplane aft of the cockpit; however; all major portions of the airplane were accounted for at the accident site. The nose gear and left main landing gear separated during the accident sequence and were located on the grass area between the safety area and the gully.";21:40;Gulfstream G-IV;null;Saturday 31 May 2014

column1: All Nippon Airways flight 391 took off from Nagoya Airport (NGO) at 11:53 on a regular domestic flight to Hakodate.

column2: the aircraft was radar vectored onto the final approach course by the Hakodate Approach Control
column3: and commenced an ILS runway 12 approach at Hakodate Airport.

column1: During the approach
column2: the captain assumed the duties of Pilot Not Flying (PNF) while the first officer assumed Pilot Flying (PF) duties.

column1: The aircraft encountered light turbulence during the approach. Hakodate Airport Tower reported the wind for runway 12 as 130°/28 kt
column2: a strong and slightly right crosswind. Although the approach course and flight path angle of aircraft were both normal during the approach
column3: the aircraft’s wind shear warning system issued an aural wind shear warning at around 140 m from the runway threshold
column4: at an altitude of 53 ft above ground level (AGL) while the aircraft was flying over the approach lights for runway 12.

column1: Although the crew initiated a go-around to recover from the wind shear
column2: the aircraft’s aft fuselage contacted the runway and as a result substantial damage was sustained. The aircraft continued to go around for recovery from the wind shear after contacted aft fuselage with the runway. The crew made another ILS approach to runway 12
column3: and landed at Hakodate Airport at around 13:21 uneventfully.

column1: An external check after arrival found that damage had been sustained to the lower surface of the aft fuselage.";13:03;Airbus A321-131;All Nippon Airways - ANA;Monday 21 January 2002

column3: Nigeria;"Dana Air flight 363 departed Abuja for Port Harcourt

column1: Following an uneventful flight
column2: the crew reported that the aircraft arrived overhead Port Harcourt Airport at about 18:43 and was vectored by Air Traffic Control (ATC) to descend to 3500ft and on a heading to cross the extended centre line of runway 21. Having crossed the extended centre line
column3: the crew assessed and discussed the approach: the weather as depicted on the weather radar
column4: and noted that there were no clouds from 7nm to the threshold. The aircraft was cleared for a localizer approach runway 21 and to descend initially to 2400 ft.

column1: The PF executed a left turn and a gradual descent
column2: intercepting the localizer at 17nm on the POT VOR/DME while descending to 2400ft on QNH 1008. The localizer was captured while in the descent on Auto Pilot 2 (AP2). column3: but the ride on the approach was comfortable. At this time
column4: the aircraft was in a landing configuration
column5: flaps 40.

column1: The captain reported taking over control of the aircraft at 6nm and disengaged the auto pilot at 400 ft AGL

column3: 843 ft long runway.

column2: looked and felt contaminated with flood of water that did not drain well.

column1: Spoilers and Reversers were deployed and brakes was applied. The aircraft continued on the landing roll
column2: crossed the end of the runway to the blast pad. The aircraft came to a stop at a distance of 298 m from the end of runway 21
column3: slightly left of the extended centre line.

column1: After the aircraft came to a complete stop
column2: engines were shut down and emergency power switch was turned ON. The emergency light came ON
column3: all other lights were OFF and the Public Address System was not working
column4: the lead crew had to open the cockpit door to obtain emergency evacuation instructions from the captain.

column1: Emergency evacuation was carried out using only the left forward main door and the escape slide on this door did not deploy.

column3: Indonesia;The Boeing 737 arrived in Pekanbaru on schedule after a flight from Jakarta. The airplane was prepared for the continuing flight to Batam. At 10:05 the First Officer asked for start clearance and received weather information. The weather was fine
column4: wind calm and clear. After start-up was completed
column5: the aircraft taxied to runway 18. The crew decided to use 'reduced take off power' with an assumed temperature of 35 deg. C
column6: while the actual temperature was 27 deg. C. The First Officer acted as Pilot Flying. After being cleared for takeoff
column7: the captain advanced the throttles and adjusted them to the required take off power setting. He then called the V1 and VR speeds and the First Officer pulled the control column to a 15 deg. nose up pitch. The aircraft’s nose lifted up
column8: but the aircraft did not become airborne. The stick shaker activated. The captain then added power and the speed increased to V2+15 (approx. 158 KIAS) but the aircraft still did not get airborne. The captain then decided to abort . He called 'stop'
column9: retarded the power levers to idle
column10: applied reverse thrust
column11: extended the speed brake and applied brakes. The nose of the aircraft touched down hard
column12: causing the front left door (L1) to open and two trolleys at front galley to move forward
column13: blocking the cockpit door. The flight crew turned the aircraft slightly to the right to avoid approach lights ahead. It hit some trees and stopped at approx. 275 meters from the end of runway.;10:15;Boeing 737-291;Lion Air;Monday 14 January 2002

column6: United States of America;"Boeing Stratoliner N19903
column7: built in 1940
column8: was restored to flying conditions and rolled out on June 23
column9: 2001 in Seattle. The aircraft was restored to original condition with Pan American Airlines livery
column10: carrying the name ""Clipper Flying Cloud"". On March 28
column11: 2002 the aircraft took off from Boeing Field for a local flight around 12:30. The crew were to practice takeoffs and landings and shake out any mechanical problems. Both pilots were planning to do three takeoffs and landings each
column12: with a refueling stop in between. The first pair were uneventful
column13: with the plane flying from Boeing Field to Everett-Paine Field. On takeoff there
column15: the No. 3 engine surged briefly. It returned to normal
column16: but the pilots decided to abort the rest of the practice and return to Boeing Field. On approach it appeared that the left-main landing gear had not locked down. The approach was aborted and the plane circled Vashon and Bainbridge islands as the flight mechanic manually cranked the wheel into the locked position. The pilot then resumed its approach. The airplane was about 6 miles from the runway when fuel pressure for the number three engine dropped below minimum. The boost pumps were turned on; however
column17: fuel pressure did not recover
column18: and the engine lost power. The low fuel pressure light then illuminated for the number four engine. The captain commanded the flight engineer to switch fuel feed to another tank. The flight engineer's response was
column19: ""There is no other tank. We're out of fuel."" The captain pushed the throttles forward and called for the number three engine to be feathered. When the throttles were pushed forward
column20: multiple engine surges occurred. Then the surging stopped
column21: and it appeared that the remaining engines had also lost power. The airplane was rapidly losing altitude and the captain decided to ditch in Elliott Bay. After landing
column22: the airplane remained afloat while the crew evacuated. They were quickly picked up by rescue boats. The airplane was subsequently towed to shallower water by a Seattle Police Department boat before it partially sank in the water just offshore. The day after the accident
column23: the aircraft was lifted from the water.";13:10;Boeing S.307 Stratoliner;National Air & Space Museum;Thursday 28 March 2002

column3: United Kingdom;"The left main landing gear (MLG) began a violent shimmy (yaw oscillation) when the wheelbrakes were applied after a normal landing touchdown
column4: probably damaging the MLG lower torsion link. The shimmying stopped when braking was reduced but restarted when braking was increased
column5: causing the torsion link to fracture. Further higher amplitude shimmying of the left MLG ensued
column6: resulting in severe MLG tyre
column7: wheel and brake damage and substantial oscillatory loads on the aircraft structure. Steering difficulties were experienced during both shimmying episodes.

column5: Australia;"A Boeing 747-422

column8: Australia. At the same time
column9: a Boeing 767-338ER operated by Qantas was stationary on taxiway Echo and waiting in line to depart from runway 16. The tail section of the 767 was protruding into taxiway Alpha while it was stationary on taxiway Echo awaiting a clearance to enter the runway.

column1: The pilots of the 747 received a clearance to taxi
column2: which included a taxi route from the international apron to the holding point on taxiway Bravo
column3: for a departure from runway 16
column4: via taxiways Uniform then Alpha. The pilot in command of the 747 deviated from the taxi clearance issued by the surface movement controller and turned the 747 right into taxiway Echo
column5: to pass behind the 767. The left wing tip of the 747 collided with the right horizontal stabiliser of the 767 as the 747 crew attempted to manoeuvre behind the 767.

column1: The taxiway dimensions and markings at Melbourne Airport complied with international standards and were suitable for use by the aircraft types involved in the occurrence.
The 747 crew was aware of the 767
column2: and chose to pass behind it rather than wait on taxiway Alpha until the 767 was no longer obstructing the taxiway. The decision by the pilot in command of the 747 to deviate off the centreline of taxiway Alpha and taxi behind the 767 did not comply with the taxi clearance issued by the SMC. It was based on his assessment that it was safe to do so. The pilot in command of the 747 misjudged the distance between the wingtip of the 747 and the right horizontal stabiliser of the 767
column3: which resulted in the collision.";13:08;Boeing 767-338ER;Qantas;Thursday 2 February 2006

column1: The pilot said that he had departed from Billings
column2: Montana
column3: and had climbed to 12
column4: 000 feet. About 40 nautical miles northwest of Billings

column1: Examination of the airplane by an FAA inspector revealed that the nose gear actuator mount bracket area was bent and wrinkled. The nose gear actuator shaft had fractured just above the clevis bolt

column4: 000 hours; maintenance records indicate that this one had 231.4 hours on it at the time of the accident. Metallurgists from both the National Transportation Safety Board and Hawker Beechcraft Corporation examined the failed actuator. Both concluded that all of the fractures were overstress

column1: The aircraft took off from Kisangani for Kinshasa at 12:18. The pilot in command was the pilot flying on this leg.

column2: the crew reported to Kinshasa Approach that they were over position GURUT (137 NM from Kinshasa)

column4: Kinshasa weather being reported was wind 340 degrees
column5: 8 knots
column6: visibility 10 km
column7: scattered clouds at 2500 feet
column8: Charlie Bravos (CBs) at 3000 feet
column9: CBs in the North East and South East
column10: Temperature 33
column11: dew point 23
column12: QNH 1009
column13: trend NOSIG.

column2: UNO 834 requested for descent and was cleared to descend to flight level 100. Meanwhile
column3: on the on-board weather radar
column4: the crew were able to notice presence of severe weather around and over Kinshasa airfield.

column2: when the aircraft was about 32 NMs from Kinshasa VOR/DME
column3: the crew again sought latest weather information from Kinshasa ATC. They were informed that Kinshasa was reporting ""wind 210 degrees
column4: 8 knots
column5: visibility 8 KM
column6: thunderstorm over the station
column7: scattered cloud at 2500 feet
column8: few Charlie Bravo 3000 feet
column9: Charlie Bravo located north-east
column10: south west and west
column11: broken 12000 feet
column12: temperature 33
column13: dew point 23
column14: QNH 1008
column15: trend NOSIG"". The co-pilot replied to ATC that weather was copied and read back the QNH.

column2: UNO 854 was cleared for a straight-in Localizer approach for runway 24. The crew discussed options of avoiding the severe weather being displayed on their on-board weather radar by skirting around the radar returns. The aircraft approached the airfield at high speed. The indicated air speed came below 250 knots at 13:53 when the aircraft was descending through an altitude of 4630 feet and was 13 NM from threshold runway 24.

column1: While intercepting the Localizer for runway 24
column2: the aircraft remained to the south (left) of the Localizer path. During the execution of the Localizer Approach
column3: the crew made a more than 15 degree heading change to fly even further away from the Localizer path when the aircraft was between 10-7 NM from runway 24.

column1: As the aircraft came close to the airfield
column2: the co-pilot sighted the runway on his right one o'clock position
column3: when the aircraft was about 9.7 nautical miles from displaced threshold of runway 24. The PIC too
column4: sighted the runway when the aircraft was about 6.4 NM away from threshold. At that stage
column5: the aircraft speed was 210 knots
column6: altitude was 3250 feet (or about 2252 feet above ground level) and the aircraft was in clean configuration. The crew decided to continue their Approach. The captain disengaged the autopilot
column7: turned towards the runway and gave instructions to co-pilot to configure the aircraft for landing. The crew managed to regain Localizer path and align the aircraft to the runway by the time they were 2 NM from the threshold.

column1: At around this time
column2: Kinshasa airfield was affected by a squall line. As the aircraft came on short finals
column3: it encountered rain. By this stage
column4: the aircraft was below the Minimum Descent Altitude (MDA) for Localizer Approach for runway 24. MDA for Localizer Approach for Runway 24 is 1470 feet or 472 feet Above Ground Level (AGL). The crew switched on wind shield wipers. As they descended further to about 224 feet AGL and runway was not in sight
column5: the crew decided to carry out a go around. During the process of go around
column6: a positive rate of climb was established with appropriate airspeed.

column1: While climbing through an altitude of 1395 feet (or 397 feet AGL); the aircraft encountered a severe weather phenomenon (probably a microburst). The wind shear warning came on. The aircraft pitched significantly nose down (from about 4-5 degrees nose up attitude to 7 degrees nose down attitude) in a very short period of time. The aircraft rapidly lost height. Before the crew could react to the pitch down and recover from the steep descent
column2: the aircraft impacted the terrain. The airplane broke up and the main wreckage came to rest upside down.";13:56;Canadair CL-600-2B19 Regional Jet CRJ-100ER;null;Monday 4 April 2011

column1: 09-MAR-2016;Antonov An-26B;S2-AGZ;True Aviation;near Cox's Bazar ...;1984;Fatalities: 3 / Occupants: 4;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;Approach (APR);Cargo;Cox's Bazar Airport (CXB/VGCB)
column2: Bangladesh;Jessore Airport (JSR/VGJR)
column3: Bangladesh;"An Antonov 26 cargo plane
column4: operated by True Aviation
column5: crashed in shallow waters of the Bay of Bengal shortly after takeoff from Cox's Bazar Airport (CXB)
column6: Bangladesh. Three Ukrainian crew members died in the crash and another was critically injured.

column1: The aircraft operated a scheduled cargo flight from Cox's Bazar to Jessore in Bangladesh. The on board cargo consisted of 802 boxes of shrimp weighing 4800 kg.
The flight crew requested startup clearance at 02:58 UTC. The aircraft was then cleared to taxi to runway 35 via taxiway S.
Takeoff clearance was given 03:05 UTC.

During takeoff a drop in oil pressure in the torque meter system of engine no.1 caused the engine to lose power the cruise mode. The captain decided to continue takeoff. Immediately after becoming airborne the pilot reported an engine failure and requested for immediate return back to Cox's Bazar Airport. He was advised by ATC to report left hand down wind.
Within 60 seconds after takeoff the no. 1 lost power completely.
The captain initially tried to maneuver the aircraft to land on runway 17 (departure runway
column2: opposite direction)
column3: but was unable to line up with the runway.

column1: The crew decided to continue on a right hand downwind at around 1000 feet with a IAS of 300km/hr in clean configuration. The aircraft turned to finals and fully configured for landing and stable at around 3.5 NM from the runway. But at 1.2 NM for reasons unknown the captain decided to go around and climbed to 400-500 feet.
ATC advised the captain to report left hand down wind. But there was no response from the crew. The aircraft had impacted the shallow waters on the coast
column2: 3 km West of the airport.";ca 09:05;Antonov 26B;True Aviation;Wednesday 9 March 2016

column1: 22-MAY-2010;Boeing 737-8HG (WL);VT-AXV;Air India Express;Mangalore-Ba...;2007-12-20  (2 years 5 months);Fatalities: 6 / Occupants: 6;Fatalities: 152 / Occupants: 160;Destroyed;Landing (LDG);International Scheduled Passenger;Dubai Airport (DXB/OMDB)
column2: United Arab Emirates;Mangalore-Bajpe Airport (IXE/VOML)
column3: India;"Air India Express flight IX-811/812 is a daily round trip between Mangalore and Dubai. The outbound flight IX-811 was uneventful and landed at Dubai at 23:44 hours Local Time. The airplane was serviced and refuelled. The same flight crew operated the return leg
column4: flight IX-812.

column1: The airplane taxied out for departure at 01:06 LT (02:36 IST). The takeoff
column2: climb and cruise were uneventful. There was no conversation between the two pilots for about 1 hour and 40 minutes because the captain was asleep. The First Officer was making all the radio calls.

column1: The aircraft reported position at IGAMA at 05:33 hours IST and the First Officer was told to expect an ILS DME Arc approach to Mangalore. At about 130 miles from Mangalore
column2: the First Officer requested descent clearance. This was
column3: however
column4: denied by the ATC Controller
column5: who was using standard procedural control
column6: to ensure safe separation with other air traffic. At 05:46 IST
column7: the flight reported its position when it was at 80 DME as instructed by Mangalore Area Control. The aircraft was cleared to 7000 ft and commenced descent at 77 DME from Mangalore at 05:47 IST. The visibility reported was 6 km. Mangalore airport has a table top runway. As the AIP India states ""Aerodrome located on hilltop. Valleys 200ft to 250ft immediately beyond paved surface of Runway."" Owing to the surrounding terrain
column8: Air India Express had made a special qualification requirement that only the PIC shall carry out the take off and landing. The captain on the accident flight had made a total of 16 landings in the past at this airport and the First Officer had operated as a Co-pilot on 66 flights at this airport.

column1: While the aircraft had commenced descent
column2: there was no recorded conversation regarding the mandatory preparation for descent and landing briefing as stipulated in the SOP. After the aircraft was at about 50 miles and descending out of FL295
column3: the conversation between the two pilots indicated that an incomplete approach briefing had been carried out.

column1: At about 25 nm from DME and descending through FL184
column2: the Mangalore Area Controller cleared the aircraft to continue descent to 2900 ft. At this stage
column3: the First Officer requested
column4: if they could proceed directly to Radial 338 and join the 10 DME Arc. Throughout the descent profile and DME Arc Approach for ILS 24
column5: the aircraft was much higher than normally expected altitudes.

column1: The aircraft was handed over by the Mangalore Area Controller to ATC Tower at 05:52 IST. The Tower controller
column2: thereafter
column3: asked the aircraft to report having established on 10 DME Arc for ILS Runway 24.

column1: Considering that this flight was operating in WOCL (Window Of Circadian Low)
column2: by this time the First Officer had also shown signs of tiredness. This was indicated by the sounds of yawning heard on the CVR.

column1: On having reported 10 DME Arc
column2: the ATC Tower had asked aircraft to report when established on ILS. It appears that the captain had realised that the aircraft altitude was higher than normal and had selected Landing Gear 'DOWN' at an altitude of approximately 8
column3: 500 ft with speed brakes still deployed in Flight Detent position
column4: so as to increase the rate of descent. As indicated by the DFDR
column5: the aircraft continued to be high and did not follow the standard procedure of intercepting the ILS Glide Path at the correct intercept altitude. This incorrect procedure led to the aircraft being at almost twice the altitude as compared to a Standard ILS Approach.

column1: During approach
column2: the CVR indicated that the captain had selected Flaps 40 degrees and completed the Landing Check List. At 06:03 hours IST at about 2.5 DME
column3: the Radio Altimeter had alerted an altitude of 2500 ft. This was immediately followed by the First Officer saying ""It is too high"" and ""Runway straight down"". In reply
column4: the captain had exclaimed ""Oh my god"". At this moment
column5: the captain had disconnected the Auto Pilot and simultaneously increased the rate of descent considerably to establish on the desired approach path. At this stage
column6: the First Officer had queried ""Go around?""

column1: To this query from the First Officer
column2: the captain had called out ""Wrong loc .. ... localiser .. ... glide path"".

column1: The First Officer had given a second call to the captain for ""Go around"" followed by ""Unstabilised"". However
column2: the First Officer did not appear to take any action
column3: to initiate a Go Around. Having acquired the runway visually and to execute a landing
column4: it appears that the captain had increased the rate of descent to almost 4000 ft per minute. Due to this
column5: there were numerous warnings from EGPWS for 'SINK RATE' and 'PULL UP'. On their own
column6: the pilots did not report having established on ILS Approach.

column1: Instead
column2: the ATC Tower had queried the same. To this call
column3: the captain had forcefully prompted the First Officer to give a call of ""Affirmative"". The Tower controller gave landing clearance thereafter and also indicated ""Winds calm"".

column1: The aircraft was high on approach and touched down on the runway
column2: much farther than normal. The aircraft had crossed the threshold at about 200 ft altitude with indicated speed in excess of 160 kt
column3: as compared to 50 ft with target speed of 144 kt for the landing weight.

column1: Despite the EGPWS warnings and calls from the First Officer to go around
column2: the captain had persisted with the approach in unstabilised conditions. Short of touchdown
column3: there was yet another (Third) call from the First Officer
column4: ""Go around captain...We don't have runway left"". However
column5: the captain had continued with the landing and the final touchdown was about 5200 ft from the threshold of runway 24
column6: leaving approximately 2800 ft of remaining paved surface.

column1: The captain had selected Thrust Reversers soon after touchdown. Within 6 seconds of applying brakes
column2: the captain had initiated a 'Go Around'
column3: in contravention of Boeing SOP. The aircraft overshot the runway including the strip of 60 metres. After overshooting the runway and strip
column4: the aircraft continued into the Runway End Safety Area (RESA) of 90 metres. Soon after which the right wing impacted the localiser antenna structure located further at 85 metres from the end of RESA. Thereafter
column5: the aircraft hit the boundary fence and fell into a gorge.";06:05;Boeing 737-8HG (WL);Air India Express;Saturday 22 May 2010

column1: 1-jun-07;DHC-6 Twin Otter 300;PK-YRU;Trigana Air Service;Mulia Airpor...;1980;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 1;Substantial;Takeoff (TOF);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Mulia Airport (LII/WABQ)

column3: Indonesia;"On Friday 1 June 2007
column4: a Twin Otter
column5: registered PK-YRU overran the right side of the runway at Mulia Airport (LII). Indonesia during the takeoff roll.

column1: The aircraft left the runway and impacted a ditch and rocks on the right shoulder of the runway. Main-wheel tire marks for more than 65 meters on the runway indicated that heavy braking action was being applied to the left brake. The aircraft was substantially damaged. None of the occupants were injured.

The handling pilot was undergoing captaincy training under the supervision of an instructor. The investigation was unable to determine why the aircraft commenced veering to the right during the early acceleration phase of the takeoff. The pilots continued the takeoff and directional control was lost during the takeoff roll. The instructor pilot was unable to regain directional control of the aircraft before it left the runway. No aircraft or system defect was found that could have contributed to the pilots’ inability to maintain directional control during the takeoff roll. The pilot under training stated that ""things happened fast"" and he was ""unaware that the power levers were still in the full on position""
column2: but was ""conscious that his left hand was on the steering handle"". He said that he did not immediately respond to a shout from the instructor to not use the steering handle.";null;de Havilland Canada DHC-6-300 Twin Otter;Trigana Air Service;Friday 1 June 2007

column1: The aircraft carried out a round trip from Shannon (SNN)
column2: Ireland to Manchester Airport (MAN)
column3: U.K. on behalf of Aer Lingus Regional. The return leg
column4: Flight EI 6305
column5: departed Manchester at 08:47. En-route operations were normal and
column6: in consultation with ATC
column7: the aircraft descended and was cleared to self-position to the DERAG waypoint for an Instrument Landing System (ILS) approach to runway 24.

column1: At 10:08 hrs the aircraft commenced an approach to runway 24 in strong and gusty crosswind conditions. Following a turbulent approach difficulty was experienced in landing the aircraft
column2: which contacted the runway in a nose-down attitude and bounced. A go-around was performed and the aircraft was vectored for a second approach. During this second approach landing turbulence was again experienced. Following bounces the aircraft pitched nose down and contacted the runway heavily in a nose down attitude. The nose gear collapsed and the aircraft nose descended onto the runway. The aircraft sustained damage with directional control being lost. The aircraft came to rest at the junction of the runway and a taxiway.

column2: when the aircraft's speed had decreased to less than 60 kt
column3: the aircraft started an uncommanded turn to the right. The nose wheel steering system was activated. The course could not be corrected

column1: The investigation has shown that the loss of control was most likely caused by a fault in the nose wheel steering. The same problem had occurred six days earlier
column2: but the commander then managed to disconnect the nose wheel steering in time and regained control. The fault could not be reproduced
column3: and the aircraft was released to service after inspection and testing without remarks.

column1: The nose wheel steering system on this aircraft type is relatively complex
column2: and over time several improvements have been made to improve its reliability. The Flight Manual has a caution related to activation of nose wheel steering at speeds higher than normal taxi speed.

column1: 18-feb-18;ATR 72-212;EP-ATS;Iran Aseman Airlines;near Yasuj Airpor...;1993-10-26  (24 years 4 months);Fatalities: 6 / Occupants: 6;Fatalities: 60 / Occupants: 60;Destroyed;En route (ENR);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Tehran-Mehrabad Airport (THR/OIII)

column3: Iran;"Iran Aseman Airlines flight 3704 from Tehran to Yasuj
column4: Iran
column5: impacted a mountainside in the Mount Dena range to the northeast of Yasuj Airport. All on board (60 passengers
column6: two flight crew members
column7: two cabin crew members and two security officers) were killed.

column1: The flight departed Mehrabad Airport at 08:05 hours local time and climbed to the cruising altitude of FL210. At 09:22 the aircraft was over the Isfahan (IFN) VOR. The flight requested permission to descend from FL210 to FL170. This was approved by Tehran ACC. The flight followed Airway W114 from the OBTUX navaid to the Yasuj DVOR/DME. Minimum altitude on that airway is FL170. Minimum safe altitude over the sector close to Yasuj Airport is 15500 feet.

Flight tracking website Flightradar24 shows that the aircraft reached FL170 at 09:25:59. At 09:29:10 the aircraft was 14 nautical miles from the airport. Last radio contact with the flight was at 09:30:10
column2: when the pilots acknowledged a weather report.

column1: At 09:32:00 the pilot keyed the mic but there was no transmission. Attempts to contact the flight by the Yasuj controller at 09:34 were fruitless.
The wreckage was located the following day at an elevation of about 3600 m (11800 feet). Weather conditions at the crash site included snow and strong winds.
The approach procedure for Yasuj Airport is a circling NDB approach with a 25NM minimum safe altitude circle of 11500 ft - 15500 ft. Flights from Tehran first have to cross Mount Dena
column2: which is an 80 km mountain range with a highest elevation of 4
column4: 465 ft). After arriving over the NDB at the airport at 15
column5: 000 feet
column6: a teardrop approach has to be flown for landing on runway 13/31.";09:32;ATR 72-212;Iran Aseman Airlines;Sunday 18 February 2018

column1: 20-apr-12;Boeing 737-236A;AP-BKC;Bhoja Airlines;near Islamabad-Be...;1984-12-13  (27 years 5 months);Fatalities: 6 / Occupants: 6;Fatalities: 121 / Occupants: 121;Destroyed;Approach (APR);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Karachi-Jinnah International Airport (KHI/OPKC)
column2: Pakistan;Islamabad-Benazir Bhutto International Airport (ISB/OPRN)
column3: Pakistan;"A Boeing 737-236 passenger plane
column4: operated by Bhoja Airlines
column5: was destroyed in an accident near Islamabad
column6: Pakistan. All 121 passengers and six crew members were killed. Bhoja Airlines flight 213 departed Karachi (KHI) at 17:05 on a domestic flight to Islamabad (ISB). This was the inaugural evening flight for the airline on this route.

column1: The flight climbed to a cruising altitude of FL310 and continued towards Islamabad. Weather at the destination was poor due to a passing thunderstorm. At 18:19 the captain at a distance observed the squall line. Moments later the flight was cleared to descend to FL200. During the descent the captain and first officer discussed the weather. They were worried about the severity of the thunderstorm ahead.

At 18:26 the first officer contacted Islamabad Approach and received clearance for the One Foxtrot arrival for an ILS approach to runway 30. After receiving further descent clearance the first officer discussed opportunities to approach the airfield through a gap in the squall line. The Approach controller gave radar vectors and descent instructions to fly through the gap in the storm.

column2: Islamabad Approach gave a weather update and said ""Bhoja 213 surface wind at Islamabad ah is varying between 180° to 270°
column3: 10 kts and ah sometimes gusting to 20 kts and runway condition is wet
column4: light drizzle is ah uhm going on
column5: braking action not known"".

column1: Two minutes later the airplane entered the squall line. Although the Bhoja Air Operational Manual prohibited flight in these conditions
column2: the captain decided to continue. The airplane was configured for the approach with flaps and slats selected and the undercarriage was down. The first officer then reported the speed to be 220 knots
column3: which was 30 knots higher than the recommended speed. The captain reacted surprised as he did not expect this because the he was flying with the auto-throttle engaged. Likely the increase in speed was a result of windshear. The aircraft then entered the active weather cell with precipitation continuing in varying intensity. At 18:39 the airplane captured the ILS and descended on the glide slope. At this point the aircraft should have been in landing configuration with flaps at 30°. However
column4: only flaps 5 were selected.

column1: The aircraft then encountered an increasing downdraft. The pitch attitude increased and computed airspeed decreased as the autopilot attempted to maintain the glide slope. The GPWS consequently sounded with the aural alarm: ""Wind shear - Wind shear - Wind shear"". Although the first officer anxiously called for a go around
column2: no action was taken.

column1: The downdraft dissipated and the pitch attitude decreased but the aircraft deviated left of the extended runway centerline

column1: The flight crew received a left thrust reverser unlock indication while holding for takeoff. The captain cycled the reverser
column2: and had decided to return to the gate when the messages cleared. With the issue apparently resolved

Approximately 3 minutes into the flight
column6: the left engine thrust reverser unlocked parameter changed to ""On"" for about 1 second. About 11 minutes and 20 seconds after takeoff

column10: left
column11: and right again over about a 4-second period. The decrease in engine parameters lasted over 3 minutes before returning to normal. column12: below the levels previously recorded during the flight
column13: and approximately to the level of the right engine vibration. The vibration and engine speed variations suggested separation of the left engine translating cowling at that point. column14: the FDR data revealed that the left engine vibration levels were elevated and left engine thrust reverser did not deploy on the two previous flights. column1: The aircraft

column3: was scheduled to depart Goose Bay Airport at 19:20 and arrive at the Gander at 20:54. The flight was operated by Exploits Valley Air Services.

column1: Before departing
column2: the captain checked the weather at Gander and the alternate airport
column3: Deer Lake Airport (CYDF). The visibility at Gander was 1/8 statute miles (sm) in heavy snow.

column1: The weather forecast for the time of arrival was wind 360° magnetic (M) at 35 knots
column2: gusting to 55 knots; visibility 1/4 sm in heavy snow and blowing snow; vertical visibility 100 feet above ground level (agl). Starting at 22:30
column3: the visibility was forecast to increase to 1/2 sm in moderate snow and blowing snow
column4: and the vertical visibility was to improve to an overcast ceiling at 400 feet agl. A significant meteorological information (SIGMET) message was issued indicating severe turbulence below 3000 feet agl over an area of Newfoundland that included Gander.

column1: The crew planned to conduct the instrument landing system with distance measuring equipment precision approach for runway 03 (ILS/DME RWY 03) at Gander.
The captain called the company's acting operations manager to discuss the potential operational impact if the flight had to divert to its alternate. At first
column2: the intent was to delay the flight for an hour to wait for the snowfall intensity to diminish and for the visibility to improve. However
column3: after speaking with the acting operations manager
column4: the captain decided to depart as scheduled
column5: anticipating that the weather conditions would improve by the time they reached Gander. The crew was unaware that other carriers had cancelled their flights to Gander.

column1: The aircraft departed at 19:45 on an instrument flight rules flight plan. There were 14 passengers and 2 crew members on board. The first officer (F/O) was the pilot flying. While en route
column2: the F/O indicated that he did not feel comfortable conducting the approach and landing due to his limited experience and the potential challenges associated with the anticipated weather conditions. The captain agreed to conduct the approach and landing.

column1: During the flight
column2: the crew received updated weather reports from both the Gander Area Control Centre and Gander Tower
column3: which indicated an increase in visibility from 1/8 sm to 1/2 sm and a reduction in the snowfall intensity from heavy to light. The crew decided that the visibility was sufficient to conduct the approach as initially planned. The winds and blowing snow were not identified as concerns.

column1: While the flight was en route
column2: snow removal was in progress at Gander. The airport plows were focused on clearing the middle 120 feet of the 200-foot-wide runway. The plows had pushed the snow into windrows along both sides of the runway
column3: about 60 feet from the centreline.

column1: The crew contacted the tower controller for the runway surface condition report. The latest runway condition report for runway 03
column2: taken at 2044
column3: was as follows: 120 feet cleared width
column4: 40% dry snow with a depth of 0.13 inches and 60% bare and dry; remaining width 100% dry snow with a depth of 4 inches; remarks - windrows along reported width with a depth of 10 inches.

column1: The snowplows continued plowing the runway until about 21:10
column2: at which point they began to plow a path for the aircraft to follow from the runway to the apron.

column1: On the approach
column2: about 12 minutes before touchdown
column3: the aircraft began to encounter moderate turbulence through 5700 feet above sea level. This turbulence continued until landing and was significant enough that the passengers were experiencing discomfort.

column1: Once the aircraft intercepted the localizer
column2: control of the aircraft was transferred to the captain as planned. The landing gear was lowered and the flaps were set to full
column3: as per the company's standard operating procedures.

column2: the tower controller cleared flight 7804 to land and provided the crew with the current tower winds of 360°M at 36 knots
column3: gusting to 44 knots. The crew acquired the runway approach lighting at about 800 feet agl
column4: more than 2 nautical miles (nm) from the threshold.

column1: At approximately 21:30
column2: while on short final
column3: the crew asked for a wind update. The tower controller informed the crew that the tower winds were currently unavailable and provided the last aerodrome special meteorological report (SPECI)
column4: which had been taken 18 minutes before. The SPECI indicated that the winds were 350°M at 29 knots
column5: gusting to 41 knots.

column1: In the landing flare
column2: the captain asked the F/O to call out the heights on the radar altimeter to help them determine how high they were above the ground. Almost immediately
column3: the 10- and 0-foot calls were made. There was no indication that the crew lost visual contact with the runway edge lighting.

column1: At about 21:30
column2: the aircraft touched down on its main landing gear (MLG) to the right of the centreline at a normal descent rate and in a relatively flat attitude about 2800 feet from the threshold. The crew was unaware how far to the right of the centreline they were when they touched down. Almost immediately
column3: the aircraft veered to the right when the right-side MLG encountered snow. The nose landing gear (NLG) struck the windrow of compacted snow
column4: which caused the NLG to collapse. As the aircraft's nose began to drop
column5: the propeller blades struck the snow and runway surface. All of the left-side propeller blades and 3 of the right-side propeller blades separated at the blade root. A portion of a blade tip from the right-side propeller penetrated the cabin wall at floor level.

column1: The aircraft slid down the runway
column2: with the nose coming within 27 feet of the runway edge
column3: before crossing back through the windrow toward the centreline.

column1: The aircraft came to a stop about 14 seconds after touchdown on a heading of about 350°M. The nose was about 15 feet to the right of the centreline and 3400 feet from the threshold.
Once the aircraft came to a stop
column2: the F/O opened the cabin door and evacuated the passengers. The captain shut down the engines. The tower controller did not have any ground radar and was unaware that the aircraft was stopped on the runway. The captain contacted the tower controller to report the situation and request assistance. The tower controller immediately activated the crash bell.

column1: The first fire truck left the station within 1 minute of the crash bell being activated. About 2 minutes later
column2: the plow drivers
column3: who were cross-trained as fire rescue personnel
column4: drove the remaining 2 fire trucks and the rescue vehicle to the aircraft.

column1: Because the location of the aircraft was not known
column2: the vehicles started at the north end of runway 03. They proceeded cautiously because of the reduced visibility from blowing snow and because the passengers were out on the runway. The first fire truck arrived at the aircraft about 6 minutes after the accident. In total
column3: 3 fire trucks
column4: 1 rescue vehicle
column5: and 2 pickup trucks responded.

column1: Once the firefighters established that there was no fire
column2: the rescue vehicle and pickup trucks started transporting passengers to the terminal. Within 25 minutes of the crash bell being activated
column3: all passengers and crew had been transported to the terminal. Three passengers sustained minor injuries. None of the injuries were attributed to the portion of the propeller blade that had penetrated the cabin.";21:30;Beechcraft 1900D;null;Wednesday 20 April 2016

column1: The aircraft sustained damage to the engines
column2: propellers
column3: and cowlings. The lower longerons and adjacent structures in the engine nacelles were damaged due to impact with the landing gear axles. column3: Hong Kong;"Cathay Pacific Airways flight CPA780
column4: an Airbus A330
column5: was scheduled to operate from Surabaya
column6: Indonesia to Hong Kong. The crew had carried out the sector from Hong Kong to Surabaya on the previous day. The accident aircraft stayed overnight at Surabaya Airport and was parked at Stand 8.

column1: The accident aircraft uplifted 24
column2: 400 kilogram (kg) of fuel and was prepared for departure. The flight was airborne at 08:24 local time. During the climb
column3: the flight crew noticed some abnormal Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) fluctuations on No. 2 engine
column4: with a range of approximately ± 0.015 around EPR target. No. 1 engine also had abnormal EPR fluctuations but within a narrower range.

column2: shortly after levelling off at FL390
column3: an ECAM message ""ENG 2 CTL SYS FAULT"" was annunciated. ECAM information ""ENG 2 SLOW RESPONSE"" was shown for crew awareness. After consulting with a maintenance engineer
column4: it was decided to continue since all engine parameters were considered normal other than the EPR fluctuations.

column1: Almost two hours into the flight
column2: the same ECAM message appeared
column3: with an additional information message ""AVOID RAPID THR CHANGES"". The engine anti-ice was selected on for both engines
column4: but this had not effect. The crew then again contacted a maintenance engineer
column5: who told them that he had seen these EPR fluctuations before and that the Fuel Metering Unit (FMU) of engine no. 2 would be replaced after landing.

column1: Nearing the destination
column2: the crew began to prepare for a runway 07L arrival. According to recent weather information
column3: significant windshear was forecast for both runway 07L and 07R.

column1: At 13:19 hrs local time during the descent to a cleared level of FL230
column2: ECAM messages ""ENG 1 CTL SYS FAULT"" and ""ENG 2 STALL"" were annunciated within a short period of time. According to the Commander
column3: a light ""pop"" sound was heard and some ""ozone"" and ""burning"" smell was detected shortly before the ECAM message ""ENG 2 STALL"". At that time the flight was at about 110 nautical miles southeast of Hong Kong
column4: and was descending through FL300 with a Calibrated Air Speed (CAS) of 295 kt. Vertical mode ""Open Descent"" was selected. The flight crew completed the necessary ECAM actions and set No. 2 thrust lever accordingly to IDLE position. ECAM information ""ENG 1 SLOW RESPONSE"" and ""AVOID RAPID THRUST CHANGES"" were also annunciated. No. 1 thrust lever was advanced to Maximum Continuous Thrust (MCT) position as per the ""SINGLE ENGINE OPERATIONS"" strategy stated in the Quick Reference Handbook (QRH). However No. 1 engine N1 only temporary increased to about 57% N1 and then dropped back to about 37% N1 at 13:21 hrs.

column1: At 13:21 hrs
column2: the flight crew declared ""PAN PAN"" to Hong Kong Radar and advised that No. 2 engine was operating at idle thrust. The crew made the request to shorten the track for a priority landing. Hong Kong Radar then cleared the flight to proceed directly to waypoint ""LIMES"".

column1: At about 13:26 hrs
column2: the Commander took control of the aircraft as the PF in accordance with Cathay standard operating procedures for one engine inoperative and the co-pilot became the Pilot Monitoring.

column1: At 13:30 hrs
column2: when the aircraft was approximately 45 nm southeast from Hong Kong and was about to level off at 8
column3: 000 ft AMSL
column4: ECAM message ""ENG 1 STALL"" was annunciated. The CAS at that moment was about 295 kt. ECAM actions were carried out by the flight crew and No. 1 thrust lever was put to IDLE position accordingly. Autothrust (A/THR) was disengaged and both engine master switches remained at the ""ON"" position. With both thrust levers at IDLE position
column5: the Commander then tested the controllability of the engines by moving the thrust levers one at a time. There were no thrust changes corresponding to the engine lever movements initially. At 13:32 hrs
column6: ECAM messages ""ENG 1 STALL"" was annunciated again.

column1: At 13:32 hrs
column2: the crew declared ""MAYDAY"" and advised Hong Kong Approach of the double engine stall situation. CPA780 was then cleared to descend to 3
column3: 000 ft AMSL. At that time
column4: the aircraft was still in Instrument Meteorological Conditions (IMC) and the CAS was at about 233 kt and reducing. At around the same time
column5: the Commander disconnected the Autopilot and the Flight Directors (FD) and flew the aircraft manually. The altitude increased from 6
column6: 760 ft to 7
column7: 164 ft AMSL with the CAS reducing and the aircraft started to descend again when the CAS decreased to about 200 kt.

column1: When the aircraft was on base leg during the approach
column2: the flight crew reported that they were flying in VMC.

column1: The crew moved the thrust levers to check the engine control but there was no direct response from the engines. The No. 1 engine speed eventually increased to about 74% N1 with the No. 1 thrust lever in the CLB (climb) detent position. The No. 2 engine speed remained at sub-idle about 17% N1
column2: with the No. 2 thrust lever at the IDLE position.

column1: At 13:37 hrs
column2: the ATC made both runways 07L and 07R available for CPA780. During the descent and approach
column3: there were a number of other ECAM warning messages announced in the cockpit which were not relevant to the engine control problem.

column1: The flight crew carried out the ""ENG ALL ENG FLAMEOUT - FUEL REMAINING"" checklist in the QRH for No. 2 engine in an attempt to clear the thrust control fault of that engine. As per the checklist
column2: the Ram Air Turbine (RAT) was deployed manually
column3: APU bleed was selected ""ON"" and No. 2 engine MASTER switch was set to ""OFF"" then ""ON"" at 13:38 hrs. However
column4: No. 2 engine remained at a sub-idle speed of 17% N1.

column1: At 13:38 hrs
column2: Flap CONF 1 was selected. At 13:39 hrs
column3: when CPA780 was at 5
column4: 524 ft AMSL
column5: a CAS at 219 kt and a distance of nine nm from the airport
column6: the Commander tried to decrease the speed by retarding the No. 1 thrust lever. However
column7: there was no corresponding decrease in No. 1 engine speed. Eventually
column8: No. 1 thrust lever was left at the IDLE position and No. 1 engine speed remained at 74% N1.

column1: At 13:40 hrs
column2: Hong Kong Approach cleared CPA780 for a visual approach for Runway 07L. Flight crew deployed the speedbrakes when the aircraft was at 5
column3: 216 ft AMSL descending with a CAS of 234 kt at around 8 nm from the runway. Flight crew selected landing gear down shortly afterwards.

column1: The Commander aimed to fly the aircraft at a CAS as close as possible to the Minimum Selectable Speed (VLS)
column2: which was 158 kt at that time. The aircraft went through the runway extended centreline and recaptured the centreline from the north in order to manage altitude and airspeed.

column1: At around 13:41 hrs
column2: with the Maximum Allowable Speed (Vmax) at 240 kt and actual CAS at 244 kt
column3: an overspeed warning was generated by the onboard system. A short while later Hong Kong Approach cleared CPA780 to land on runway 07L and advised that the current surface wind was 150 degrees at 13 kt. Flight crew stowed the speedbrakes when the aircraft was at 984 ft AMSL and armed the ground spoilers at 816 ft AMSL.

column1: At 13:42 hrs
column2: when CPA780 was still at flap CONF 1
column3: with a CAS of 227 kt and a vertical speed of 1
column4: 216 ft per min at an altitude of 732 ft AMSL and at about two nm to touchdown
column5: the warning ""Too Low Terrain"" was generated by the Enhanced Ground Proximity Warning System (EGPWS). Flap CONF 2 was selected at around one nm to touchdown with a CAS of 234 kt and at an altitude of 548 ft AMSL. A flashing ""F RELIEF"" message was displayed at Engine Warning Display (EWD) as the TE flap was extended to 8-degree position instead of the commanded 14-degree position. With a Vmax of 205 kt
column6: another overspeed warning was generated shortly after Flap 2 selection. The ""Too Low Terrain"" warning changed to ""Pull Up"" warning briefly at 176 ft AMSL and back to ""Too Low Terrain"" within a very short timeframe. The EGPWS warning stopped at 24 ft above the ground.

column1: During the final approach
column2: No. 1 engine speed decreased to about 70% N1 at touchdown
column3: with the No. 1 thrust lever at IDLE position. No. 2 engine speed remained at about 17% N1 throughout the final approach and landing.

column1: CPA780 touched down on runway 07L at 13:43 hrs at a position between abeam Taxiways A4 and A5 and with a distance of around 680 metres (m) from the beginning of the runway threshold at a ground speed of 231 kt. The landing weight was approximately 173
column2: 600 kg. The landing wind was 143 degrees at 14 kt. Immediately after both main gears touched down on the runway
column3: the right main gear bounced and the aircraft became airborne again briefly. The aircraft then rolled left seven degrees and pitched down to -2.5 degrees at the second touchdown during which
column4: the lower cowling of No. 1 engine contacted the runway surface. Spoilers deployed automatically. Both engine thrust reversers were selected by the Commander. Only No. 1 engine thrust reverser was deployed successfully and ECAM message ""ENG 2 REV FAULT"" was annunciated. Maximum manual braking was applied. As required by the company procedure for the purpose of drawing the PF’s attention in the status of the deceleration devices
column5: the co-pilot called out ""no spoilers
column6: no REV green
column7: no DECEL"" during the landing roll.

column1: The aircraft came to a complete stop on the runway at a position just passed Taxiway A10
column2: with its nose wheel at about 309 m from the end of Runway 07L. The total distance for stopping the aircraft from the initial touchdown was approximately 2

column1: The crew shut down the engines and requested the tower controller to check for a possible wheel fire. There was no sign of fire. An emergency evacuation was then ordered just after 13:45.
One passenger sustained serious injuries in the evacuation while 56 passengers and six crew members sustained minor injuries.";13:43;Airbus A330-342;Cathay Pacific Airways;Tuesday 13 April 2010

column1: The airplane took off at 15:26 from LaGuardia's runway 04. The first officer was pilot flying. As they were reaching an altitude of 3000 feet the crew saw a formation of Canada geese. Before they knew it
column2: the windscreen turned dark brown and several loud thuds were heard. Both engines began to lose power and there was a burning smell. The captain took over control of the flight. They radioed ATC about their emergency situation: ""Aaah
column3: this is Cactus 1549. We lost thrust in both engines. We are turning back toward LaGuardia."" It quickly became evident that they were not able to reach LaGuardia. A possible landing at the Teterboro Airport (TEB) was considered. The captain decided that they would not be able to land safely on the short runway in the middle of a built-up area. The flight descended over the Hudson River until it ditched.

column1: All occupants evacuated the airplane
column2: climbing onto the wing and entering escape slides. Coast Guard vessels and commuter ferries rescued everyone on board.

column10: to Kosrae Airport and finally Pohnpei Airport
column11: both in the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM). This was the operator's inaugural scheduled regular public transport service to Kosrae and Pohnpei.

column1: Travelling on-board were the Nauruan President
column2: the Nauruan Minister of Aviation
column3: and the Chairman of the Board of Directors of Nauru Air Corporation. In the six weeks preceding this flight
column4: the operator had flown three charter flights to the FSM airports. The captain also stated that he had flown a couple of charter flights (during the day) into Kosrae before this inaugural scheduled service.

column1: The flight was originally scheduled to leave Nauru at 02:30 UTC (14:30 Nauru Time). However
column2: a technical issue with the original aircraft led to a change to VH-NLK. This resulted in the aircraft departing 60 minutes late.

column1: The sector from the Marshall Islands to Kosrae was delayed a further 17 minutes due to ground handling issues. The flight departed after last light at 07:40 and the planned flight time was 1 hour 19 minutes. The approach and landing at Kosrae was at night.
For this sector
column2: the captain was the pilot flying
column3: and the first officer was the pilot monitoring.

column1: During the climb to the planned cruising altitude of FL360
column2: in accordance with standard procedures
column3: the flight crew selected the standard atmospheric pressure of 1013 hPa on the altimeters.

column1: The flight crew stated that
column2: prior to commencing the descent for Kosrae
column3: they obtained the weather and the local QNH. The weather had deteriorated from that forecast. The flight crew also stated that
column4: during the descent and approach
column5: the local flight information service radio operator provided a considerable number of weather updates on the local airport conditions at Kosrae. Visibility was around 3 NM
column6: rain showers were in the area with low cloud and wind 'pretty much straight down the strip for (runway) 05'. The captain
column7: as pilot flying
column8: conducted the briefing for the non-directional beacon (NDB)/distance measuring equipment (DME) approach to runway 05. The captain stated that
column9: at this time
column10: they had made special mention of the unusually low transition level of FL 55. The captain stated that at most airports they operated into
column11: the transition level was between FL 110 and FL 130. The crew then completed the descent checklist. They had decided that
column12: based on the expected weather conditions
column13: they would make two approach attempts
column14: and if they could not land
column15: would divert to Nauru Airport
column16: the nominated alternate airport. Prior to descending below the transition level
column17: the crew did not complete the approach checklist
column18: which consisted of one item: set the altimeters to the local QNH and crosscheck them. Leaving the altimeters' subscale set to the standard atmospheric pressure setting of 1013 hPa
column19: and not setting the subscale to the local barometric pressure of 1007 hPa
column20: resulted in the indicated altitude over-reading
column21: such that when the altimeter indicated 500 ft
column22: the aircraft's actual altitude was about 320 ft above the mean sea level.

column1: At about 08:56
column2: the aircraft passed overhead the NDB at 5
column3: 000 ft
column4: and continued the descent
column5: tracking outbound on a heading of 300°
column6: to about 10 NM from the NDB (10 DME). The flight crew were controlling the aircraft through the auto-flight systems
column7: with an autopilot and the autothrottle engaged. At this point
column8: the crew turned the aircraft left
column9: and at 09:01
column10: the aircraft intercepted the inbound track to the NDB at about 1
column11: 800 ft. The crew selected the landing gear down at 1

column13: and flap 15 at 1

column1: The crew stated that they established visual contact with the runway as the aircraft passed through 900 ft indicated altitude
column2: about 5 NM from the DME. At about 740 ft indicated altitude
column3: the crew selected flap 25. The crew elected to delay selection of the nominated landing flap of 40 degrees until they made positive visual contact with the runway. They did not subsequently select flap 40 on that approach.

column1: As the aircraft descended to the minimum descent altitude for the approach of 500 ft
column2: the captain selected the altitude hold (ALT HOLD) mode to level the aircraft at 500 ft indicated altitude. At 09:03:13
column3: an Enhanced Ground Proximity Warning System (EGPWS) Terrain Clearance Floor (TCF) alert sounded
column4: and lasted for 5 seconds. The aircraft was over water
column5: at 368 ft radio altitude. The crew reported that they were in visual meteorological conditions (VMC) at night
column6: with the runway lights in sight. The crew stated that
column7: at the time
column8: they believed the EGPWS alert was due to a 'map shift' in the aircraft's navigation position. The flight crew selected 'terrain inhibit'
column9: which cancelled the current EGPWS TCF alert. The crew were not aware that the EGPWS had its own internal GPS.

column2: the aircraft was at 4.31 DME
column3: 480 ft indicated altitude and 340 ft radio altitude
column4: and descending at about 313 fpm
column5: when the EGPWS TCF alert again sounded
column6: and lasted for 12 seconds. The aircraft maintained 480 ft indicated altitude for about 12 seconds
column7: before descending again.

column1: The crew reported losing visual reference with the runway when the aircraft was about 3 NM from the DME. In response to losing visual reference
column2: the captain disconnected the autopilot and autothrottle and pressed the take-off/go-around (TOGA) switches on the thrust levers. At this time the recorded aircraft pitch angle was 9.5°. The flight data recorder data showed that TOGA was selected at 09:03:47
column3: at 448 ft indicated altitude
column4: or 304 ft radio altitude
column5: and the aircraft was about 3.5 NM from the DME. At this time
column6: the aircraft's computed airspeed reduced to 129 kt.

column1: The captain stated that he pressed the TOGA switches on the thrust levers once. In the Flight Director engaged go-around mode
column2: one TOGA switch press results in a reduced thrust autothrottle setting
column3: and two presses of the TOGA switch advances the autothrottle to full go-around thrust. The crew stated that the aircraft pitch angle was initially raised to 15°
column4: however
column5: the captain observed the airspeed decay and pitched the aircraft down to increase the airspeed. The first officer stated he called 'sink rate' twice. The captain then realised and rectified the situation
column6: depressing the TOGA switch a second time commanding full go-around thrust.

column2: the aircraft was at 3.3 DME
column3: and the third EGPWS TCF alert sounded

column5: or 244 ft radio altitude
column6: and descended 5 seconds later to its lowest radio altitude of 200 ft before climbing.

column2: the flaps were retracted to 15° and the aircraft reached its maximum pitch up angle of 16°. Two seconds later
column3: the flaps were retracted to 10°. From the time the captain set the thrust to TOGA until the aircraft was stabilised on the missed approach path (at about 09:05)
column4: the recorded aircraft pitch angle varied from -0.35° to +16°.

column6: 000 ft

column5: United States of America;"A McDonnell Douglas MD-83

column8: Michigan

column1: The flight crew prepared for take-off and calculated V-speeds (V1
column2: VR
column3: V2) using ""Normal Thrust Takeoff""
column4: a 10 kts headwind
column5: and a take-off weight of 146
column6: 600 lbs. The V-speeds for this configuration were 139 kts
column7: 142 kts
column8: and 150 kts
column9: respectively. However
column10: the flight crew chose to increase VR to 150 kts to allow for more control during take-off in the presence of windshear.

column1: During takeoff roll
column2: at 14:51:56 (about 3
column3: 000 ft down the runway) and about 138 kts of airspeed
column4: the control column was pulled back slightly from a non-dimensional value of -7 to -5.52. The airplane’s left elevator followed the control input and moved from a position of -15° trailing edge down to -13° trailing edge down. The right elevator did not change and stayed at approximately -16° trailing edge down. At 14:52:01 a large control column input was made (151 kts and 4100 ft down the runway) to a non-dimensional 18.5 and the left elevator moves to a position near 15° trailing edge up. After 14:52:05 the right elevator moves to -13° trailing edge down
column5: but no more. The airplane does not respond in pitch and does not rotate. The captain decided to abort the takeoff.

column1: The maximum groundspeed was 163 kts (173 kts airspeed) and the airplane began to decelerate as soon as the brakes were applied at 14:52:08. Spoilers were deployed at 14:52:10 and thrust reversers were deployed between 14:52:13 and 14:52:15. The aircraft could not be stopped on the runway. The airplane’s ground speed was 100 kts when it left the paved surface.
The aircraft overran the end of the runway
column2: damaged approach lights
column3: went through the perimeter fence and crossed Tyler Road.

column1: It came to rest on grassy terrain
column2: 345 meters past the end of the runway
column3: with the rear fuselage across a ditch. The nose landing gear had collapsed.

column1: Runway 23L is a 7543 ft long runway.
Post-accident examination by the NTSB revealed movement of the control column in the cockpit appeared normal; the control columns were free to move
column2: and the elevator control tabs moved as commanded. However
column3: when investigators tried to move the elevator surfaces by hand
column4: the left elevator moved normally
column5: but the right elevator was jammed in a trailing edge-down position (airplane nose down). Upon further inspection
column6: the right elevator geared tab inboard pushrod linkage was found damaged which restricted movement of the right elevator surface but allowed movement of the control tab. After the damaged components were removed
column7: the elevator could be moved by hand.

column1: Examination of the flight data recorder data indicates that during the taxi and take-off roll
column2: the left elevator moved normally
column3: but the right elevator did not move. During takeoff roll
column4: the left elevator began a large airplane nose-up movement (consistent with rotation) at an airspeed of about 152 knots and continued for five seconds to about 166 knots. There was no change in the airplane pitch attitude during this time. The airplane data then are consistent with the takeoff being rejected. The maximum recorded airspeed was about 173 knots.

column1: Review of previous flight data showed normal movement of both the left and right elevator surfaces.  The airplane flew to Ypsilanti two days before the accident.";14:52;McDonnell Douglas MD-83;Ameristar Jet Charter;Wednesday 8 March 2017

column2: 6 knots. Initially the flight crew did not have the runway in sight

column5: requesting to land
column6: Sir"". The flight was again cleared to land. The pilot read back: ""cleared to land runway 02""
column7: though clearance had been given for runway 20 initially. The air traffic controller then also read back the clearance for runway 02.

column4: South Sudan;"The pilot-in-command
column5: accompanied by the co-pilot
column6: aircraft loader and 18 passengers
column7: departed on a World Food Programme (WFP) flight from Marial Bai Aerodrome in Southern Sudan to Rumbek Aerodrome in Sudan at approximately 09:30Z. The intention was then to fly from Rumbek Aerodrome to Lokichoggio in Kenya. During the VFR flight to Rumbek Aerodrome
column8: the crew experienced a north-easterly wind with extremely turbulent conditions.

column1: Prior to landing at Rumbek Aerodrome
column2: the crew calculated the approach and landing indicated air speeds (IAS) to be 85 kts and 75 kts respectively. The crew then joined the circuit accordingly for landing on runway 01. Approximately 4 nm away from landing
column3: the co-pilot warned the pilot-in-command of a whirlwind in the area
column4: close to the threshold of runway 01.

column1: The whirlwind appeared to have dissipated and the pilot-in-command continued with the landing with full flaps. At approximately 100 ft above ground level and 100 m before the threshold of runway 01
column2: the IAS suddenly decreased to 70 kts. The pilot-in-command said that he immediately selected full power in order to arrest the rate of descent as wind shear in Southern Sudan and especially at Rumbek at this time of the year was a common factor. The aircraft nevertheless continued to descend and the left-hand propeller and left-hand main landing gear collided with a tree approximately 20 m before the threshold of runway 01. The tree was approximately 6 ft high and on an embankment. The aircraft then struck a drainage ditch before the threshold
column3: causing the left-hand main landing gear to collapse. The aeroplane bounced and landed on the runway. The co-pilot immediately retracted the flaps and the aircraft continued down the runway on the right-hand main landing gear
column4: but as its speed decayed
column5: the left-hand propeller impacted with the runway surface. The aircraft veered to the left off the runway and entered a drainage ditch parallel to the runway. Both left and right-hand main landing gear were torn out of their attachment points and the aircraft eventually came to rest on its lower fuselage section.

column1: The crew and passengers sustained no injuries and evacuated the aircraft safely through the emergency exits and rear main entry door.
The aircraft was substantially damaged: both left and right-hand main landing gear were damaged; the left-hand outboard aileron was forced out of the outboard hinge point
column2: and the lower fuselage frame and attachment stringers subsequently collapsed and were damaged.

column1: The aircraft was temporary repaired on site by replacing two main landing gear
column2: tailwheel
column3: two engines
column4: two props
column5: one aileron and some skin repair. It was flown back to South Africa on 17 April 2003.";11:00 UTC;Aero Modifications AMI DC-3-65TP;null;Monday 10 March 2003

Both crewmember's primary flight display (PFD) displayed the V-speeds with the standard blue lines with no discrepancies noted. column9: 000 feet msl. The PNF did not recall being distracted during the checklist or before takeoff procedures. The flight crew requested and was cleared for departure on runway 04.

column5: Canada;"On 27 March 2013
column6: an Air Labrador Twin Otter was landing at St. Anthony Airport
column7: with 2 crew members and 8 passengers on board. On approach to runway 10
column8: the captain and first officer discussed approach and landing considerations due to the strong crosswinds
column9: and it was decided that the first officer would continue the approach. Immediately prior to landing
column10: the first officer experienced difficulty
column11: so control of the aircraft was transferred to the captain. The transfer of control was completed less than 2 seconds prior to landing. The aircraft touched down on the left main wheel
column12: bounced
column13: and landed hard on the nosewheel; the nose landing gear collapsed due to overstress failures. Directional control was lost
column14: and the aircraft skidded on its nose and came to rest 96 feet off the north side of the runway. There were no injuries
column15: and the aircraft was substantially damaged.

column1: The investigation determined that
column2: when control of the aircraft was passed to the captain
column3: there was insufficient time to position the aircraft for a successful landing due to the substantial crosswind. The Air Labrador Twin Otter standard operating procedures (SOPs) do not state when the captain should permit the first officer to act as pilot flying or relieve the first officer from that role. When allowing the first officer to fly in challenging conditions
column4: the captain must be prepared to take control of the aircraft in adequate time to ensure the safety of the flight. Also
column5: there is an increased risk of a landing accident if a required briefing is not conducted. Crew members may not share a common plan for the approach and landing
column6: and
column7: as in this case
column8: transfer of control may not be conducted in a timely manner.";12:53;de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter 300;Air Labrador;Wednesday 27 March 2013
