ARFF services attended to the no.1 engine while injured passenger who was seated near the lost window was rushed to hospital. The passenger is reported to have died.

column2: Indonesia;Taipei-Chiang Kai Shek International Airport (TPE/RCTP)
column3: Taiwan;"China Airlines flight 676 was destroyed when it stalled and impacted a residential area of Taipei during an attempted go around at Chiang Kai Shek Airport. All 196 on board and seven persons on the ground were killed.

column1: The aircraft
column2: an Airbus A300B4-622R
column3: originated from Denpasar Airport
column4: Indonesia and was bound for Taipei. The flight was cleared for an ILS/DME runway 05L approach to Taipei Chiang Kai Shek Airport in light rain and fog. The aircraft remained high on the approach. At 1
column5: 2nm short of the threshold
column6: the altitude was 1515 feet
column7: whereas it should have been at 500 feet at that point.

column1: The flight crew selected full flaps. At 20:04:50 hours local time the autopilot was disconnected. Subsequently
column2: as the aircraft crossed the runway threshold at 1475 feet
column3: go around thrust was applied.

column1: The aircraft rapidly pitched up
column2: reaching +35° as it climbed trough 1723 feet at an airspeed of 134 knots. The gear had just been raised and the flaps set to 20 degrees.

column1: At 20:05:16 the aircraft had reached 2327 feet at a +42.7° pitch. Nine seconds later the speed had fallen to 43 knots as the aircraft stalled. The aircraft nosed down with a 79° left bank. The flight crew was not able to regain control and the aircraft impacted the ground left of the runway. It hit a utility pole and a highway median and then skidded into several houses
column2: surrounded by fish farms
column3: rice paddies
column4: factories and warehouses. A fire erupted.

column1: Visibility at the time of the accident was 2400 feet
column2: the runway 05L RVR (runway visual range) was 3900 feet
column3: 300 feet broken ceiling
column4: 3000 feet overcast.";20:05;Airbus A300B4-622R;China Airlines;Monday 16 February 1998

column1: The mishap flight was a chartered flight to tranpsort personnel of Pakistan Petroleum Limited from Karachi to Sui. The takeoff weight was within limits. The calculated V1 and V2 speeds were 104 Kts and 106 Kts respectively
column2: whereas the stalling speed was 84 Kts. The captain was Pilot Flying (PF) and the first officer was Pilot Monitoring (PM) for this sector. However
column3: the first officer was a qualified captain on Beechcraft 1900D aircraft.

column1: The aircraft taxied out at 08:05 hours local time. The aircraft start up and taxiing was normal.
The flight was given runway 25L for takeoff and the aircraft lined up on the runway. After obtaining takeoff clearance
column2: the flight crew completed pre take off checks with no abnormalities observed.
take off thrust was applied very gradually and the aircraft started to roll. Five seconds after reaching maximum power
column3: at 08:23:35 the PM announced the speed being 80 kts. FDR data indicated an increasing trend in torque and drop in propeller rpm of engine no. 2
column4: which was not monitored by the flight crew. The propeller rpm dropped to a minimum 709 rpm in the next 11 seconds. Also
column5: torque of engine no.1 began to drop

column11: 000 feet and set up for a shallow dive along a 090-degree track. This time no problems were noted. The airplane subsequently turned back to the west and began to climb back to 39
column12: 000 feet to set up for another dive to the flight test point along a 270-degree magnetic track. This run also was uneventful. The pilot was then cleared to the next test point. However
column13: the pilot did not acknowledge the clearance
column14: but instead

column16: and he couldn't stop it. About 30
column17: 000 feet

column20: from about 30

column1: Although the manufacturer’s engineering analysis (which did not include any high-speed wind tunnel testing) had predicted positive lateral stability up to Mach 0.90

column3: United Kingdom;"A Beechcraft B200 Super King Air
column4: OO-LET
column5: was substantially damaged when its landing gear collapsed while landing at the Cambridge Airport (CBG)
column6: England. All four other crew members on board were not injured. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed for the local flight which departed Cambridge Airfield.

column1: The airplane had been operating as a communications relay for the London Olympics and was returning to Cambridge. While descending to FL180 the pilots experienced a progressive failure of all of the electrical equipment
column2: with the exception of the left instrument panel Electronic Flight Information System display. This remained powered by a backup power supply. However
column3: as the display was giving erroneous information
column4: the pilots decided to turn it off. The abnormal checklist did not contain a procedure for a total electrical failure
column5: so the Pilot Flying turned off both generators and the battery switch before selecting them on again in an attempt to restore the electrical supply. He also selected the alternate inverter and the PNF recycled the cabin power supply switches. The PF stated that he did not attempt to select the generators to RESET. The left instrument panel had functioning ASI and vertical speed indicator (VSI) instruments; the right panel had a working attitude indicator (which was vacuum-driven)
column6: ASI and altimeter indications. The engine rpm gauges and standby compass remained operational.

column1: Mindful of avoiding a security alert during the Olympic Games
column2: the crew carried out the pre-briefed communications failure procedure and turned the aircraft onto a northerly heading to clear the London TMA
column3: before proceeding towards a designated holding area. As the aircraft approached the Wisbech area
column4: the commander recognised some land features. The aircraft descended to 5
column5: 000 ft from where the crew were able to identify additional landmarks and navigate visually towards Cambridge Airport. By this time the aircraft had been flying for some time without electrical power and therefore without operating fuel gauges
column6: and the crew were concerned about the aircraft's remaining endurance.

column1: When they arrived near the airport
column2: they circled it to alert ATC to their presence and then carried out the Landing Gear Manual Extension procedure. When carrying out the procedure the pilots operated the landing gear control handle
column3: but omitted to pull the landing gear relay circuit breaker. The PF operated the alternate extension handle to extend the landing gear. Initially
column4: the handle was easy to operate and the pilots could see the main landing gear as it started to extend. The PF stated that he stopped operating the handle when heavy resistance was felt
column5: in order not to damage the system. The PF also stated that the PNF had mentioned to him not to force the handle. The PF asked the PNF to check the resistance of the handle
column6: which he did. The PF continued to operate the handle whilst they positioned the aircraft downwind and onto base leg
column7: but stopped pumping each time he felt heavy resistance.

column1: The PF carried out a flapless approach and the aircraft touched down gently at approximately 100 kt. Almost immediately after touchdown
column2: the landing gear started to collapse. The PNF immediately operated the fuel condition levers which shut down the engines and feathered the propellers. The aircraft settled onto the centreline luggage pod and the main undercarriage doors. It came to rest after a total ground run of approximately 400 m
column3: during which it yawed slightly to the right. The PF was able to counteract the yaw with rudder sufficiently to prevent the aircraft from leaving the paved surface.

column1: After it had come to a halt
column2: the commander ordered the technicians to evacuate. The pilots then completed the shutdown checklist before also vacating the aircraft. The flight time from the electrical failure until the landing was approximately 37 minutes.";16:40;Beechcraft B200 Super King Air;ASL - Air Service Liege;Saturday 28 July 2012

column3: and asked the pilot the airplane's altitude. There were no further transmissions received from the pilot. Between 0959:49 and 0959:58
column4: the airplane descended from an altitude of 21
column5: 300 ft to 16

column1: 01-MAY-2012;Airbus A300B4-605R;TC-OAG;Onur Air
column2: op.for Saudi Arabian;Jeddah-King ...;1994-12-02  (17 years 5 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 10;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Ferry/positioning;Madinah-Mohammad Bin Abdulaziz Airport (MED/OEMA)
column3: Saudi Arabia;Jeddah-King Abdulaziz International Airport (JED/OEJN)
column4: Saudi Arabia;"An Airbus A300B4-605R
column5: TC-OAG
column6: sustained damage in a nosegear-up landing at Jeddah International Airport (JED)
column7: Saudi Arabia. There were no injuries.

column1: The airplane operated on a ferry flight from Madina (MED)
column2: Saudi Arabia carrying ten crew members.

column1: The visibility at Jeddah was good with a few clouds present. During the initial ILS approach to runway 16R
column2: while at 8 nautical miles and 2600 feet
column3: the landing gear handle was lowered. Both main landing gears extended and locked down and
column4: the nose gear doors opened but the nose landing gear did not lower. The captain who was then the Pilot Monitoring (PM) took over the controls and carried out a missed approach.

column1: The First Officer (FO) became the Pilot Monitoring (PM). SVA 2865 was then given an area to the northeast of Jeddah to carry out attempts at lowering the nose gear.
The flight crew attempted to manually free fall the nose landing gear at least ten times. The nose landing gear would not lower into the locked position
column2: but the nose gear doors remained open during all those attempts.

column1: As a precautionary measure
column2: SVA 2865 performed a fly-by of runway 16R at 500 ft. The air traffic controller confirmed that the nose landing gear was not down.

column1: SVA 2865 was vectored over the Red Sea to lower the fuel load
column2: thus reducing the landing weight. During this period
column3: the Fire & Rescue Services (FRS) at Jeddah foamed a portion of runway 16L between taxiway Kilo 5 (K5) and K2.

column1: SVA 2865 was vectored for an instrument approach for runway 16L. The Auto Pilot and the Auto Throttle Systems were OFF. The surface winds were from 220° at 12 knots (kt)
column2: gusting to 19 kt and the temperature was +37 Celsius (°C).

column1: The flight crew used the ""Landing with Nose Landing Gear Abnormal"" checklist ensuring the aircraft was properly prepared and configured for the approach
column2: the before landing
column3: the flare and the touchdown sequences
column4: including when the aircraft stopped and the necessary procedures to secure the aircraft before evacuation.

column1: The aircraft landed on its main landing gear 4000 ft past the threshold of runway 16L. The nose of the aircraft was slowly lowered to the runway with the nose landing gear doors touching the runway within the foamed area 4500 ft from the end of runway 16L. The front of the fuselage then touched the runway within the last portion of foam
column2: 3500 ft from the end of runway 16L. The nose area of the aircraft slid on the runway
column3: where sparks were present until the aircraft came to a full stop 1500 ft prior to the end of runway 16L. There was no fire.";14:49;Airbus A300B4-605R;null;Tuesday 1 May 2012

column1: Following takeoff and raising the landing gear
column2: the red warning light in the landing gear handle failed to go out. The pilot said that he recycled the landing gear
column3: but could not get the red light to go out. The pilot said that he continued with the test flight. On his return to the airport the pilot said he put the landing gear handle down and nothing happened. He recycled the handle two additional times with no results. The pilot overflew the airport and confirmed with his company's maintenance that the landing gear were still up. The pilot said that he then manually pumped the landing gear down
column4: but only the nose gear and right main gear green indicator lights illuminated. The pilot overflew the airport again. His company's maintenance told him that the three gear were down. The pilot came into land. He said that he touched down on the right main gear first
column5: and then gently lowered the left main gear to the runway. The landing gear held. The pilot said he then tried to apply some reverse thrust. Suddenly
column6: the left main gear collapsed
column7: and the left wing struck the runway. The airplane slid off of the left side of the runway and came to a stop in the grass.";18:40;Beechcraft 99A Airliner;Bemidji Airlines;Monday 17 May 1999

column5: United States of America;The airplane touched down on runway 31 about 1
column6: 500 feet from the threshold and the rain become extremely heavy at that point. The pilot deployed thrust reverser and applied brakes. He felt the airplane was not slowing down
column7: believing the airplane's tire was hydroplaning on the runway surface due to the amount of rain falling
column8: and elected to perform a go-around. He closed the thrust reverser and advanced the throttles to increase engine power. The airplane did not accelerate. At this point
column9: the pilot realized he was running out space on the runway and braced for impact. The airplane traveled past the end of the runway passing a section of grass and gravel area before crossing taxiway F. The nose and main gear sheared off from the fuselage at that point due to the step up to the taxiway from the grass area. The fuselage slid the remaining way on its belly and knocked down a chain link fence protecting a wild life reserve area for ground owls and turtles. The fuselage came to stop in a nose-high attitude on a sand embankment in front of a ditch.;11:37;Learjet 55;Hop-A-Jet Inc;Monday 19 July 2004

column1: After an uneventful flight of approximately two hours
column2: the aircraft was established on ILS
column3: for landing on runway 30 at Ponta Delgada Airport. Final approach was performed with both autopilots engaged in LAND mode and Auto Throttle engaged with SPEED mode selected. The aircraft was stabilized on glide slope and localizer
column4: with an approach airspeed Vapp of 132 kts
column5: for a Vref of 126 kts. Descending through 286ft (Radio Altimeter) the autopilots were disengaged. The aircraft was thereafter flown manually
column6: assisted by the use of flight directors and autothrottle.

column1: Below 20 feet at a slightly high descent rate there was a short flare followed by a light bounce with spoilers extended. The ensuing aircraft's natural aerodynamic tendency was an increase in the pitch attitude in conjunction with a pulling force exerted on the control column with a high pitch rate (3°/s) and increasing high pitch up attitude (up to 14.82°). This manoeuvre
column2: most likely to avoid a hard nose wheel ground contact
column3: made the tail strike the ground. By the time the main landing gear shock absorbers were fully compressed the aircraft’s pitch angle had exceeded the ground/ tail clearance of 13.2°.

column1: The aircraft was taxied to the apron and a maintenance preliminary check was performed. The aircraft had sustained serious damage to the underside of the rear fuselage

column1: Flight 981 departed Dubai at 18:37 hours UTC on March 18.
A preliminary flight data analysis revealed that the crew was performing a manual approach to runway 22 with the autopilot disconnected . Weather conditions were poor with a cloud base at 630 meters
column2: wind 230 degrees at 13 meters per second
column3: maximum 18 meters per second
column4: light rain shower
column5: mist
column6: severe turbulence and moderate windshear.

column1: At 22:42 UTC (01:42 local time) in the course of the initial approach at a height of 340 meters (1115 feet)
column2: the flight received a windshear alert. The flight crew decided to go around and then continued to a holding pattern waiting for improved weather conditions.

column1: The flight left the holding pattern at 00:28 UTC (03:28 LT) and descended towards Rostov for another attempted approach to runway 22.
As the crew were proceeding with another manual approach
column2: they decided to go around again at a height of 220 meters (721 feet)
column4: 5 km before the runway. They initiated a climb with a vertical speed of up to 20 m/s and setting the engines to maximum takeoff/go-around (TOGA) thrust.

column1: One of the probable causes of the go-around decision could have been the 20-knot increase of indicated speed to as much as 176 knots within 3 seconds
column2: which might have been an indication of a windshear.

column1: In the course of the go-around the crew set flaps to 15° and retracted the landing gear.
At the height of 1900 ft (approx. 600 m) after reaching the pitch angle of 18° the pilot flying pushed on the control column
column2: which led to a decrease in vertical acceleration of up to 0.5
column3: increase in forward speed and
column4: consequently
column5: automatic retraction of flaps from 15° to 10° at a speed of over 200 knots.

column1: The short-term decrease in engine thrust within 3 seconds resulted in decreasing speed and flaps extension to 15°
column2: although the following crew inputs to regain maximum takeoff/go-around thrust led to speed increase and reiterated automatic flaps retraction to 10°. The flaps remained in the latter configuration until the impact.

column1: The pilot flying
column2: by pulling up the control column
column3: continued climbing with a vertical speed of as much as 16 m/s.

column1: At a height of 900 m there was a simultaneous control column nose down input and stabilizer nose down deflection from -2
column2: 5 deg (6
column3: 5 units) to +2
column4: 5 deg (1
column5: 5 units). The FDR recorded a nose down stabilizer input from the stabilizer trim switch of the control wheel lasting 12 seconds
column6: while the CVR record contains a specific noise of rotation of the trim wheels located on both sides of the central pedestal. As a result the aircraft
column7: having climbed to about 1000 m
column8: turned into descent with a negative vertical acceleration of -1g. The following crew recovery actions did not allow to avoid an impact with the ground.

column1: The aircraft hit the runway about 120 m from the threshold with a speed of over 600 km/h and over 50 degrees nose down pitch.

column4: yet no instrument scanning was done by the crew. At 1000 feet climbing
column5: the pilot flying released the flight controls for 55 seconds without having engaged the autopilot. The bank angle of the airplane increased continuously by itself very slowly up to 34 degrees right and the captain appeared unaware of the airplane’s changing attitude.

column2: taxied to runway 04 at Abuja Airport and was later airborne at 14:58. Fuel endurance was 3.5 hours. The flight climbed to a cruise altitude of 26

column1: DAN992 made contact with Lagos Area Control Center at 15:18. At the time the captain and first officer were in a discussion of a nonnormal condition regarding the correlation between the engine throttle setting and an engine power indication. However
column2: they did not voice concerns then that the condition would affect the continuation of the flight. The flight crew continued to monitor the condition and became increasingly concerned as the flight transition through the initial descent from cruise altitude at 15:22 and the subsequent approach phase.

column1: DAN992 reported passing through 18
column2: 100 at 15:30. Shortly afterwards the crew confirmed that there was no throttle response on the left engine and subsequently the Captain took over control as Pilot Flying (PF). The flight was however continued towards Lagos with no declaration of any distress message. With the confirmation of throttle response on the right engine
column3: the engine anti-ice
column4: ignition and bleed-air were all switched off. At 15:32
column5: the crew observed the loss of thrust in engine no. 1.

column1: Between 15:37 and 15:41 the flight crew were engaged in pre-landing tasks including deployment of the slats
column2: and extension of the flaps and landing gear. At 15:41:16 the first officer inquired
column3: ""both engines coming up?"" and the captain replied ""negative."" The flight crew subsequently discussed and agreed to declare an emergency. At 15:42:10
column4: DANA 992 radioed an emergency distress call indicating ""dual engine failure...negative response from throttle.""

column2: the flight crew lowered the flaps further and continued with the approach and discussed landing alternatively on runway 18L. At 15:42:45
column3: the captain reported the runway in sight and instructed the first officer to raise the flaps and 4 seconds later to raise the landing gear.

column1: At 15:43:27 hours
column2: the captain informed the first officer ""we just lost everything
column3: we lost an engine. I lost both engines"". During the next 25 seconds the flight crew was attempting to restart the engines.

column1: The airplane did not reach the runway and crashed in a residential area about 9
column2: 3 km short of the runway 18R.

column1: During the impact sequence
column2: the airplane struck an incomplete building
column3: two trees and three buildings. The wreckage was confined
column4: with the separated tail section and engines located at the beginning of the debris field. A fire erupted.

column1: An investigation by AIB Nigeria showed that the captain was employed by Dana Air on 14th March
column2: 2012. He was originally from the United States
column3: but was suspended in 2009 by the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) for some misdemeanours.

column1: It was noted that most of the recommendation letters submitted by the captain were also signed. Further
column2: the line trainings that preceded the captain's checkout had a lot of adverse remarks made by the training captain.

column1: He started flying as checked out captain on 2nd May
column2: 2012 and had accrued over 120 hours of flight time before the accident.

column1: Tear down of the engines showed that the no.1 engine was overhauled in the U.S in August 2011 and was not in compliance with Service Bulletin SB 6452. Both engines had primary and secondary fuel manifold assemblies fractured
column2: cracked
column3: bent
column4: twisted or pinched which led to fuel leaks
column5: fuel discharge to bypass duct
column6: loss of engine thrust and obvious failure of engine responding to

column1: throttle movement.
This condition was similar to the no.1 engine of a different Dana Air MD-80
column2: 5N-SAI
column3: that was involved in an incident in October 2013 when the aircraft returned to the departure airport with the engine not responding th throttle movements. This engine also was not in compliance with Service Bulletin SB 6452. This bulletin was issued in 2003 and called for the installation of new secondary fuel manifold assemblies
column4: incorporating tubes fabricated from new material which has a fatigue life that was approximately 2 times greater than the previous tube material.";15:45;McDonnell Douglas DC-9-83 (MD-83);Dana Air;Sunday 3 June 2012

column5: United States of America;"Two maintenance technicians where on board Northwest Airlines' Airbus A.319 N313NB which was taxied from a maintenance area to Gate 10.

column2: the mechanic who was steering the plane
column3: activated the parking brake and waited for ground personnel and a jetway operator to arrive. After the ground personnel arrived he released the parking brake. The airplane did not move and he advanced the throttles out of their idle detents ""a couple of inches
column4: about halfway."" The airplane began to move at a ""fairly decent speed
column5: and he realized the throttles were still out of the idle detent position. He pulled the throttle back and applied brakes; however
column6: the airplane did not slow and continued until it struck the concrete support column of the jetway
column7: and the left wing contacted the right side of the Boeing 757
column8: parked at gate 9. The nose gear sheared off the Airbus
column9: and the right side of the Boeing sustained a 6-foot long
column10: 2-foot wide gash
column11: just aft of the R1 door.

column1: The mechanic estimated that the airplane was about halfway down the parking line when he pulled back the throttles. Initial review of the flight data recorder for the time period surrounding the accident revealed that about 10 seconds after the parking brake was released

column3: before they were returned to the idle position. During that time
column4: the engines N1 and N2 speeds increased to about 71
column5: and 85 percent
column6: respectively.";07:15;Boeing 757-251;Northwest Airlines;Sunday 19 January 2003

column3: Japan;"A Bombardier DHC-8-315
column4: JA727B operated by the Japan Coast Guard (JCG) took off from Hanamaki Airport  at 13:58 local time for a training flight. The captain
column5: who was an instructor
column6: sat in the right seat and the trainee in the left seat for training to obtain the type rating for First Officer certification in the Japan Coast Guard.

column1: The final part of the training was a  flap up landing at Sendai Airport
column2: Japan. The captain and the trainee completed the flap up landing checklist just before the arrival at Yuriage (a visual reporting point of Sendai Airport) and the captain told the trainee that if the pitch angle (nose-up angle) exceeded 6°
column3: corrective control would have to be performed by pushing the control column forward. Vref (reference speed for landing) was 126 kt. The aircraft entered the traffic pattern of runway 09 and landed around 15:58.

column1: Although the trainee made the main landing gear touch down near the aiming point marking for the runway 09
column2: he felt it took a great deal of time to lower the nose. This time the captain on the right seat pushed the control column forward since he feared a tail strike. Then the nose landing gear touched the ground with stronger impact than usual (+1.47 g). In. Both the captain and the trainee were not aware of irregularity of the aircraft in landing roll
column3: therefore they continued taxi and the aircraft arrived at the apron at around 16:05.

column1: After the engines were shutdown
column2: the nose landing gear was found to be damaged in post-flight inspection by the on-board mechanic. Afterward
column3: detailed inspection was conducted
column4: which revealed abrasion marks on the lower part of the nose landing gear
column5: damage on components of the nose landing gear
column6: and deformation of the forward fuselage skins of the airframe.";15:58;de Havilland Canada DHC-8-315Q MPA;Japan Coast Guard;Saturday 30 May 2015

column1: 5-jan-14;Airbus A320-231;VT-ESH;Air India;Jaipur Inter...;1994-02-11  (19 years 11 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 6;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 173;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Guwahati-Lokapriya Gopinath Bordoloi International Airport (GAU/VEGT)
column2: India;Delhi-Indira Gandhi International Airport (DEL/VIDP)
column3: India;"An Airbus A320-231
column4: operated by Air India
column5: sustained substantial damage in a landing accident at Jaipur International Airport (JAI)
column6: India. Flight AI890 was a domestic service from Imphal to Guwahati and Delhi in India.

column1: The aircraft landed at Guwahati at 11:15 UTC and departed for Delhi at 12:05 UTC with 12.7 tonnes of fuel on board. The filed alternates for the sector were Lucknow and Jaipur in that order.
Overhead Lucknow
column2: the crew received the Lucknow weather and when the aircraft was in range the Delhi ATIS weather was also copied.

column1: While in contact with Delhi ATC
column2: the flight was advised to join the hold as the runway 28 RVR at Delhi had dropped to the lower end of CAT I operations. At this point runway 29 was below minima. AI890 was number twelve in sequence and continued to remain in the holding pattern for the next 20-25 minutes. During this period there was no attempt on the part of flight crew to seek Lucknow weather. Air India Flight dispatch also did not given any advice to the flight about Jaipur or Lucknow weather. The weather (visibility / RVR) reported on runway 29 was below CAT I conditions so runway was not available for this flight at that moment as the First Officer was only Cat I qualified. The aircraft flew 3 holds before intercepting the localizer runway 28 at 35 miles. RVR runway 28 also dropped below Cat. I minimas
column3: therefore the crew discontinued approach and climbed to 8000 feet on runway heading before going on heading 180.

column1: Though the first planned diversion alternate was Lucknow
column2: which had visibility of 2000 m (above minima)
column3: the captain elected to divert to Jaipur. Reason was that they were closer to Jaipur and they had inquired about the visibility from Dispatch for Jaipur
column4: which was provided as 2000 m. At this stage the crew did not check complete weather of Jaipur. Minimum diversion fuel to Jaipur was 2.9 tonnes. AI890 commenced diversion to Jaipur with Fuel on Board of 3.1 tonnes.

column1: The aircraft came in contact with Jaipur for the first time when it was at 68 DME from Jaipur. At that time the crew came to know of the complete weather of Jaipur from the ATIS
column2: which read: visibility of 900 m
column3: dew point 13°C
column4: temperature 13°C
column5: and RVR 1000m. At 60 miles and passing flight level 138
column6: the crew informed Jaipur that the aircraft was descending for flight level 100 as cleared by Delhi control. The aircraft again informed Jaipur ATC its position at 55 miles
column7: 50 miles and 42 miles from Jaipur which were also acknowledged by Jaipur ATC. During these contacts
column8: weather of Jaipur was neither asked by the crew nor provided by ATC. When the aircraft was at flight level 83
column9: the crew asked ATC Jaipur to confirm that they could carry out an ILS approach for runway 27 via the 10 DME arc. While confirming the requested approach
column10: Jaipur ATC informed all the stations about the weather at that moment as visibility 400 m and RVR 1000 m. When the aircraft was at 30 miles from Jaipur
column11: Jaipur ATC passed weather as visibility 400 m
column12: RVR 1000 m and trend visibility becoming 350 m. At 28 DME from Jaipur
column13: the aircraft was maintaining 6000 feet and on request was cleared by Jaipur ATC to descend to 5000 feet.

column1: When the aircraft was at 25 DME
column2: from Jaipur
column3: ATC advised that the weather was deteriorating rapidly and visibility was 400 meters. The crew however informed ATC that they were committed to land at Jaipur due to the aircraft fuel state. The fuel on board at that point of time was approx 2.6 tonnes and approach was commenced for Jaipur with a visibility of 500 m with trend reducing.

column1: The aircraft was no. 2 in approach at Jaipur and was cleared for the VOR/DME arc ILS approach runway 27 at 25 nm.
Due to reducing visibility
column2: Jaipur ATC asked all the aircraft inbound for Jaipur to come over head and join the JJP hold. The crew of AI890 asked for the weather which was provided as visibility 400 m and RVR 1000 m though RVR deteriorating to 550 m. The flight continued and flew the VOR/DME arc for an ILS runway 27 approach. ATC transmitted the RVR as 200 m and visibility as 50 m with trend reducing. Another scheduled flight ahead of AI890 carried out a missed approach and diverted to Ahmedabad. When the aircraft was above MDA (1480 feet AGL)
column3: ATC reported RVR 50 m and cleared the aircraft to land subject to minima. Both the flight crew maintained that they had seen the runway lights. The ILS approach was performed with dual auto pilot until 200ft Radio Altitude. After descending below MDA on auto pilot
column4: the commander disconnected the auto pilot. The captain performed the final approach manually. The aircraft deviated to the left of the runway centre line and touched down on soft ground (in kutcha) on the left hand side of the runway. During touchdown and landing roll
column5: the visibility was zero and crew were unable to see any of the reference cues. The crew had heard rumbling sound during landing roll. The commander stated that he did the manual landing as he was not sure if he could do an auto-land on a ground facility which is CAT I certified airfield in actual zero visibility.

column1: The aircraft continued to roll/ skid on the unpaved surface and during this period the left wing impacted trees causing damage to the left wing. Thereafter aircraft turned right and entered the runway finally coming to a halt on the left hand side of runway. There was no fire.
The aircraft was disabled on the runway
column2: forcing the following flight (a SpiceJet Boeing 737-800
column3: flight SG256) to carry out a missed approach. That flight was already low on fuel after diverting from Delhi to Jaipur
column4: just like AI890.

column1: The captain of SG256 then decided to return to Delhi irrespective of reported visibility and RVR. After diverting to Delhi
column2: the aircraft came in contact with ATC Delhi
column3: declared a MAYDAY due fuel with a request for straight and short vector for ILS 28. During the ILS approach for runway 28
column4: the tower had reported RVR for runway 28 as 375m/900m/50m. A dual channel auto land was carried out.  Fuel remaining at that time was 400 kgs. Fuel remaining during engine shut down was 150 kgs.";21:10;Airbus A320-231;Air India;Sunday 5 January 2014

column1: 7-apr-99;Learjet 24D;PT-LEM;Manacá Táxi Aéreo;Ribeirão Pre...;1973;Fatalities: 5 / Occupants: 5;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Damaged beyond repair;Landing (LDG);Training;São Paulo (unknown airport)
column2: SP
column3: Brazil;Ribeirão Preto-Leite Lopes Airport
column4: SP (RAO/SBRP)
column5: Brazil;"The Learjet operated on a training flight from São Paulo to Ribeirão Preto where the pilot was to conduct a revalidation of his pilot's license.

column1: The flight crew conducted an NDB approach for a touch and go on runway 18 at Ribeirão Preto Airport. Just before touchdown
column2: the aircraft banked right
column3: causing the right hand wing tip tank to touch the runway. The pilot overcorrected
column4: causing the aircraft to roll to the left to an inverted position. The aircraft impacted the runway and burst into flames.

column3: Italy;"Singapore Airlines flight SQ368 departed Changi Airport at 02:05 local time for a flight to Milan-Malpensa Airport
column4: Italy.

column1: About 30 minutes into the flight
column2: when the aircraft had climbed to 30
column3: 000 feet
column4: the flight crew noticed that the oil quantity parameter in the Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System (EICAS) showed 17 units for the left engine but only 1 unit for the right engine.

column1: The flight crew also noticed from the EICAS display that the right engine oil pressure was fluctuating between 65 and 70 psi while the oil temperature for the right engine was 10°C higher than the left engine. However
column2: both the oil pressure and temperature parameters were within the normal operating range.

column1: The flight crew looked through their available manuals but was unable to find an appropriate procedure that addressed the low engine oil quantity situation.
At 03:04 hours
column2: the Pilot-in-command (PIC) contacted their company's engineering control centre for assistance. The engineer informed the PIC that since the oil pressure was within the normal operating range
column3: there could be a faulty oil quantity indication. The engineer advised the PIC to continue with the flight but monitor the right engine oil parameters. The engineer told the PIC that he would also contact the company's technical services personnel for advice.

column1: After being briefed by the engineer on the situation
column2: the technical services personnel believed that it was a faulty oil quantity indication. As the aircraft had just departed and was not far from Singapore
column3: the technical services personnel recommended that the aircraft return to Singapore.

column1: According to the flight crew
column2: as they were passing waypoint VPG at approximately 03:20 hrs
column3: the First Officer performed a routine fuel quantity check. After comparing the TOTALIZER fuel quantity with the planned fuel remaining quantity
column4: it was determined that the fuel consumption was better than expected as the fuel on board was 600 kg more than the expected value.

column1: At 03:28 hrs
column2: the engineer sent a message via the Aircraft Communication and Reporting System (ACARS) to the flight crew informing them about the recommendation by the technical services personnel for the aircraft to return to Singapore and requesting them to contact the engineering control centre.

column1: The PIC contacted the engineering control centre and a conference call among the PIC
column2: the engineering control centre and the technical services personnel was held
column3: which lasted for about 20 minutes. The PIC informed the rest that the flight crew had been monitoring the right engine oil parameters for 50 minutes and other than the indicated low oil quantity
column4: the parameters appeared normal. It was jointly assessed that the flight could continue to Milan with the proviso that the flight crew monitor the right engine oil parameters and contact the engineering control centre for assistance if needed.

column1: Shortly after the conference call ended
column2: the flight crew felt an unusual vibration in the control column and cockpit floor. The flight crew tried to diagnose the problem by changing the engine power settings and found that the vibration disappeared when the power of the right engine was reduced. At about the same time
column3: the flight crew caught a momentary wisp of burnt smell in the cockpit but the smell disappeared quickly.

column1: At 04:04 hrs
column2: the PIC informed the engineering control centre about the vibrations which the flight crew experienced whenever the right engine was operated at higher power settings. In the ensuing conference call among the PIC
column3: the engineering control centre and the technical services personnel
column4: it was assessed that there was no need to shut down the right engine and decided that the aircraft would return to Singapore with the right engine operating at idle power. In the midst of the conference call
column5: the In-flight supervisor (IFS) informed the flight crew that there was a burnt smell detected in the cabin. In response
column6: the flight crew turned off the right engine bleed system.

column1: According to the cabin crew
column2: the smell was particularly strong in the forward part of the aircraft. The cabin crew distributed wet towels for the passengers to hold over their nose and breathe through it.

column1: After the conference call ended
column2: the flight crew reduced the right engine to idle power and proceeded to turn the aircraft around to return to Singapore. For the return journey to Singapore
column3: the flight crew adopted the procedure for single engine operation
column4: including a descent to 17
column5: 000 feet before reducing the right engine to idle power.

column1: When the IFS informed the flight crew that the burnt smell in the cabin was still present
column2: the right air conditioning pack and recirculating fans were switched off. Shortly after
column3: the smell in the cabin subsided.

column1: At 05:21 hrs
column2: the flight crew received a FUEL DISAGREE message on the EICAS. The flight crew performed the FUEL DISAGREE checklist. The FUEL DISAGREE checklist suggested four scenarios in which a fuel leak should be suspected and when the flight crew should perform the FUEL LEAK checklist. One such scenario is when the TOTALIZER fuel quantity is less than the CALCULATED5

column1: fuel quantity.
The flight crew observed from the display of the flight management system that TOTALIZER fuel quantity was about 79 tonnes and the CALCULATED fuel quantity was about 83 tonnes.
However
column2: the flight crew did not perform the FUEL LEAK checklist. According to the flight crew
column3: they believed the CALCULATED fuel quantity was no longer accurate because input changes had been made to the flight management system after the right engine was set to idle power and they were no longer on the planned flight route.

column1: Thus
column2: the flight crew performed their own fuel calculation by subtracting the amount of fuel consumed from the total amount of fuel at the start of the flight. The fuel consumed was calculated to be about 79 tonnes. As this tallied well with the TOTALIZER fuel quantity figure
column3: the flight crew concluded that the FUEL DISAGREE message was a spurious one and that there was no need to proceed with the FUEL LEAK checklist.

column1: Several times on the return journey and as the aircraft approached Singapore
column2: the flight crew was queried by the Air Traffic Control (ATC) if they needed any assistance. The flight crew replied that
column3: other than the need to fly at the lower altitude of 17
column4: 000 feet
column5: no assistance was needed as all other operations were normal.

column1: Prior to landing
column2: the flight crew jettisoned about 41
column3: 500 kg of fuel to bring the aircraft to below its maximum landing weight.

column1: At 06:49 hrs
column2: the aircraft landed on runway 20C. About 20 seconds after the thrust reversers on both engines were deployed
column3: the occupants in the cabin heard two loud bangs
column4: accompanied by two flashes
column5: originating from the right engine area. At the same time
column6: the flight crew heard a soft thud. The Airport Rescue and Firefighting Service (ARFF) personnel who were monitoring the aircraft's arrival informed the Control Tower on seeing the fire at the right engine. The Control Tower informed the flight crew of the fire and instructed the aircraft to stop at the intersection between the runway and rapid exit taxiway E7. The flight crew did not receive any fire warning in the cockpit.

column1: The first foam tender arrived on scene after 57 seconds and started discharging foam at the right engine. The fire was eventually brought under control after about two minutes. Disembarkation commenced at 07:10 hrs via a mobile stairs positioned at the front left door of the aircraft. All occupants
column2: including the flight crew
column3: vacated the aircraft by 07:31 hrs.";06:49;Boeing 777-312ER;Singapore Airlines;Monday 27 June 2016

column1: It left the holding about 15:38 UTC and positioned for an ILS approach to runway 22. During the approach to Schiphol
column2: at approximately 16:30 hours
column3: ATC requested the crew to hold over reporting point SUGOL at flight level (FL) 110 for 20

column1: minutes because landing runways available were limited at Schiphol because of the strong surface wind. ATIS information “Kilo” reported winds from direction 240º with a
velocity of 35 knots
column2: gusting to 40 knots. METAR information reported winds at 37 knots

column1: gusting to 46 at 15.55 (UTC
column2: 16.55 local time).

column1: From SUGOL the crew initially received radar vectors inbound Schiphol. They then were
cleared to intercept the Instrument Landing System (ILS) for runway 22. The ILS for the
approach to runway 22 was intercepted at 18 NM.
During the descent
column2: at 15:49 UTC
column3: the autopilot disengaged because of gusting winds in the approach and was reengaged by the crew shortly after.

column1: The arrival was flown in speed control mode with an airspeed of 170 knots. Final speed was selected at 130 knots
column2: i.e. normal landing threshold speed (VREF) plus 10 knots to compensate for the gusting winds. At around 15:51 UTC
column3: approximately 5.5 NM from the runway touchdown point
column4: the landing gear was selected down
column5: giving three greens indication in the cockpit shortly after. The crew confirmed the indication
column6: 15 degrees flaps were selected and de-icing systems were selected.

column1: The crew then changed radio frequency to Schiphol Tower and received a clearance for landing on runway 22. The air traffic controller reported the wind from direction 240 degrees with speeds of 36 knots gusting to 48 knots. The crew finished the before landing checklist. They then selected 5 degrees flaps and selected gear down. They confirmed ‘ice protection on’
column2: ‘landing gear three greens’
column3: selected 15 degrees flaps and checked ‘bleed air on’.

column1: At an altitude of 300 feet the flight crew disengaged the autopilot for landing. On short final the crew noticed the PAPI showing they were on the glide path. Although the pilots were aware they would encounter strong winds during landing
column2: including crosswinds
column3: the wind conditions were not extreme and were not above the aircraft’s limitations. Short final was flown under crosswind conditions
column4: with the nose of the aircraft about 20 degrees right of centre line. Just before touch down the pilot flying aligned the nose of the aircraft with the runway centreline and lowered the right wing to compensate for the crosswind
column5: causing the right-hand main wheel to touch the runway first. The aircraft touched down at 15:54 UTC. The crew considered the landing to be firm
column6: but not hard. Almost immediately after touch down the crew noticed the right wing dropping
column7: and a red warning light appeared on the landing gear panel in the cockpit.

column1: The right-hand propeller
column2: right-hand engine nacelle
column3: lower fuselage
column4: wing tip and aileron collided with the runway and the aircraft continued for several hundred meters before coming to a complete stop. This resulted in damage to the right hand propeller
column5: the lower fuselage structure and right-hand outboard wing tip. The right-hand fuselage was also damaged due to fragments from the right-hand propeller and stone strikes. The left-hand main landing gear and nose gear remained extended.

column1: The crew transmitted a MAYDAY call and after coming to a complete stop the cabin attendants started evacuating the passengers via the two aft doors. The crew then shut down the aircraft in accordance with the checklist. As a precaution

column1: 14-feb-10;Cessna 550B Citation Bravo;OK-ACH;Time Air;near Reinhardtsdo...;2005;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;En route (ENR);Ferry/positioning;Praha-Ruzyne International Airport (PRG/LKPR)

column3: Sweden;"A Cessna 550B Citation Bravo corporate jet
column4: registered OK-ACH
column5: was destroyed in an accident in the area of the Großer Zschirnstein Mountain. Both pilots were killed.

column1: Flight TIE039C departed Prague-Ruzyne International Airport (PRG) at 20:08 on an IFR flight to Karlstad Airport (KSD)
column2: Sweden. The copilot was Pilot Flying.
while the airplane was climbing to cruising altitude
column3: the copilot asked the captain if she had ever flown a roll at night. Meanwhile
column4: the air traffic controller at Prague cleared the flight to climb to FL260.

column1: The flightcrew continued their conversation about performing a roll with Citation Bravo jets. At 20:17 the Pilot Flying rolled the 30° to the left and immediately 20° to the right. Prague ATC then instructed the flight to contact Munich ATC. Contact was established and clearance was given to climb from FL260 to FL330. This was confirmed by the crew.
At 20:18 the captain asked the copilot if their altitude was high enough to perform a roll. The copilot confirmed that the altitude was sufficient.

At 20:19 the flight levelled off at FL270. Five seconds later the nose pitched up to 14° and a roll to the right was initiated. Within four seconds the airplane was flying upside down. It rolled a further 90° in the next four seconds. Meanwhile the heading began to change and the nose dropped in an almost vertical dive of -85°.
The computed airspeed increased from about 240 knots at the initiation of the roll to 380 knots during the descent.
The flight crew were not able to recover and the airplane impacted a forest.";20:20;Cessna 550B Citation Bravo;Time Air;Sunday 14 February 2010

column3: United States of America;Miami International Airport
column4: FL (MIA/KMIA)
column5: United States of America;"The flight was assigned an airspeed of 230 knots and cleared to descend from FL240 to 16
column6: 000 feet in preparation for landing at Miami. The FDR indicated that while the autopilot was engaged in the descent
column7: the power levers moved from the mechanical autothrottle limit of 44 degrees to the manual limit of 37 degrees. As the aircraft leveled at 16
column8: 000 feet the airspeed decreased. The F/O began a right turn to enter a holding pattern and added some power
column9: which stabilized the airspeed at 178 knots. However
column10: the right bank and the resultant angle of attack (AOA) continued to increase
column11: despite left aileron input by the autopilot. As the autopilot reached the maximum input of 20 degrees
column12: bank angle increased past 50 degrees
column13: and the AOA increased rapidly from 7 degrees to 12 degrees. At this point the stick shaker activated
column14: the autopilot independently disconnected
column15: the power was increased
column16: and full left rudder was used to arrest the roll. The bank angle reached 56 degrees
column17: and the AOA reached 13.7 degrees at 177 knots. The aircraft then pitched down
column18: and entered a series of pitch
column19: yaw
column20: and roll maneuvers as the flight controls went through a period of oscillations for about 34 seconds. The maneuvers finally dampened and the crew recovered at approximately 13
column21: 000 feet. One passenger was seriously injured and one flight attendant received minor injuries during the upset.

column1: An analysis showed that the forces during the upset not only had gone above the design limit of the vertical stabilizer
column2: they also apparently had reached the ultimate limit. In June 1997
column3: Airbus requested that American Airlines perform another inspection of the jet to ensure it was not damaged. American inspectors
column4: following Airbus' instructions
column5: examined the tail fin. But they did not use methods that would have allowed them to see inside the tail fin. They saw no damage from their visual inspection
column6: and the jet continued to fly until an ultrasound inspection of the horizontal stabilizer was done in March 2002. The inspection found two crescent-shaped cracks at one of the points where the tail fin attaches to the fuselage. The fin was replaced.";15:29;Airbus A300B4-605R;American Airlines;Monday 12 May 1997

column1: The aircraft departed from Balikpapan at 23:00 UTC with a planned flight time of 55 minutes at an altitude of 7000 feet. There were 13 people on board; two pilots
column2: a maintenance engineer
column3: and 10 passengers. The pilot in command (PIC) was the pilot flying for the sector to Tanjung Bara
column4: and the copilot was the monitoring pilot.

column1: The flight was normal until 5 minutes before landing when the number 1 (left engine) generator malfunctioned. The pilot in command (PIC) asked the maintenance engineer on board the aircraft
column2: who advised that there was no problem for the aircraft operations.

column1: The aircraft made its final approach to runway 04 at Tanjung Bara at 23:50. The aircraft touched down to the right of the centreline
column2: then diverged right into soft wet ground
column3: impacting a channel embankment and subsequently a barbed-wire airport perimeter fence.

column1: The investigation determined that aircraft was not being flown on a stabilized approach and subsequently touched down to the right of the runway centerline. It then veered to the right of centerline after touchdown and the PICs effort to bring the aircraft back to the runway centreline by using aileron was ineffective.
There was no evidence that visibility affecting visual acquisition of the runway was a factor. However
column2: the investigation considered that a visual approach guidance system such as Visual Approach System Indication (VASI)
column3: may have provided additional visual cues to alert the pilots to the prevent the unstabilized approach.";23:50 UTC;CASA/IPTN NC-212 Aviocar 200;Aviastar Mandiri;Thursday 11 January 2007

column1: 7-apr-03;Cessna 501 Citation I/SP;EC-HFA;Ibiza Flights;Zürich-Klote...;1974;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 1;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Damaged beyond repair;Landing (LDG);Private;Barcelona-El Prat Airport (BCN/LEBL)
column2: Spain;Zürich-Kloten Airport (ZRH/LSZH)
column3: Switzerland;"Cessna Citation I/SP
column4: EC-HFA
column5: took off at 10:00 from Barcelona (BCN) on a private flight to Zurich (ZRH). The flight took place under instrument flight rules. Using radar vectors
column6: EC-HFA was cleared at 12:05 for an ILS approach to runway 14. The right hand seat on the flight deck was occupied by a PPL-rated passenger. During approach
column7: the passenger read out various checklist points
column8: which were each confirmed or commented upon by the pilot.

column2: at a distance of approximately 10 NM from ILS DME 14
column3: the aircraft descended below 4000 ft QNH. At 12:07:07 the ATCO informed the pilot that he would be allowed to leave 4000 ft QNH only at a distance of 8 NM from ILS DME 14. The aircraft was already at 3600 ft
column4: so he instructed EC-HFA to climb to 4000 ft QNH in order to be able to reach the ILS glide slope. The pilot answered: ""(...) I got the ILS catched
column5: but I go to 4000 ft."" Subsequent to this radio conversation
column6: the passenger mentioned the following to the pilot
column7: with reference to the approach chart: ""Lo pone aquí. Tenemos las montañas ahí – Here it is. We have hills there."" EC-HFA then climbed back to an altitude of 4000 ft QNH
column8: which it reached at approximately 8 NM. At about 7 NM
column9: it began the descent and therefore found itself above the ILS glide slope. With the message ""All stations
column10: ah... we have now RVR one thousand four hundred metres
column11: that’s ah... showers of snow coming ah... overhead the field and the final
column13: the Zurich final ATCO informed all aircraft on the frequency that a snow shower was approaching the airport. A little later
column14: the ATCO asked EC-HFA whether the aircraft was now stabilised on the ILS; the pilot confirmed this. At this time the aircraft was between 7 NM and 8 NM from the threshold of runway 14
column15: approximately 200 ft above the glide slope. The ATCO also informed the pilot that the runway visual range (RVR) was now 1200 m. The pilot thanked him and asked the passenger to continue reading out the checklist.

column1: When the aircraft was approximately six miles from the threshold of runway 14
column2: EC-HFA was asked to contact Zurich aerodrome control. This was confirmed by the pilot on the radio. He repeated the frequency several times to the passenger
column3: who was busy entering the frequencies in this phase of the flight. At 12:09:10
column4: the pilot contacted aerodrome control. There followed a further discussion between the two persons in the cockpit during which the passenger mentioned that it was now essential to fly precisely straight
column5: because there was a 2500 m high tower to one side. It is highly probable that the passenger was referring to an obstacle which is shown on the approach chart with a tower symbol. This obstacle is approximately 9 NM from ILS DME 14
column6: just to the east of the approach centreline and shows an altitude of 2566 ft AMSL. The passenger further suggested that for this reason the autopilot should be used. He finally quoted the value of 2200 ft and asked the pilot whether he did not want to set the flaps to ""full flaps"" position. At this time
column7: EC-HFA received landing clearance for runway 14. This was immediately acknowledged by the pilot. The pilot then confirmed with the words: ""Full flaps... landing gear"" that everything was now ready for the landing. According to the radar recordings
column8: throughout the final approach phase EC-HFA was always between 200 and 300 ft above the glide slope. At approximately 12:11:15
column9: EC-HFA reached the decision height of 1602 ft. The passenger asked the pilot not to fly manually but to continue to let the autopilot fly EC-HFA
column10: because there was no ground contact at this time. Shortly afterwards
column11: the passenger mentioned that he could now see some of the ground. A few seconds later
column12: the passenger said: ""Arrivando...Pista
column13: ahí!...La vés?...Muy bien
column14: vamos muy bien. Dejalo
column15: dejalo que baje - We’re arriving... The runway
column16: there!... Do you see it?... Very good
column17: we’re very good. Let her go
column18: let her go
column19: she has to descend."" At 12:11:14 the aircraft touched down on the grass about 700 m before the runway threshold and skidded in a wide right turn in the direction of the threshold of runway 16.";12:12;Cessna 501 Citation I/SP;Ibiza Flights;Monday 7 April 2003

column2: after completing the pre-landing checks

column4: after touchdown
column5: he held the nose wheel off the ground. He stated that the initial landing and roll-through on the steel matting surface were normal. When applying brakes

column4: Canada;An Ilyushin Il-76 cargo plane was chartered by the Canadian Department of National Defence. It was on an ILS approach to runway 24 at CFB Trenton (YTR). The weather at the time was reported as one half mile in fog
column5: vertical visibility 500 feet
column6: RVR 600 feet
column7: temperature and dew point 12 degrees Celsius and the wind was 210 at 06 knots. The aircraft struck the airport perimeter fence with the main landing gear and briefly touched down on the left main landing gear approximately 430 feet from the threshold of runway 24. The flight crew aborted the landing and applied engine power. The aircraft climbed to 3000 feet asl and entered a hold at this altitude. After approximately one hour it diverted to the Ottawa/MacDonald-Cartier airport. Ottawa tower was contacted by Trenton and advised of the incoming aircraft and that it had struck the fence on approach. Ottawa tower called out ARFF as a precaution. The Il-76 flight crew did not declare an emergency. The aircraft landed uneventfully and taxied to the local FBO. ARFF followed the aircraft and assisted the crew in removing the barbed wire that was wrapped around the left main landing gear. After a period of time the aircraft took off from Ottawa and arrived in Trenton where the onboard cargo was offloaded. Examination of the aircraft revealed substantial damage to the underside of the fuselage as a result of the impact with the fence.;null;Ilyushin 76TD;Silk Way Airlines;Thursday 10 May 2007

column1: The Xian MA-60 operated on a scheduled domestic passenger flight from Bajawa Airport (BJW) to Kupang (KOE). There were 46 passengers and four crew members on board. The flight from the departure until commencing for approach was uneventful. The weather at Kupang was fine and a visual approach was flown to runway 07.
During the approach
column2: the power lever lock was selected to open position in accordance with the operator's normal checklist. and remained in that position. The autopilot was disconnected while descending trough 1100 feet. At that point the airplane was just above the 2.9° approach angle.

column1: The first officer
column2: who had 117 hours on the MA-60
column3: had the habit of delaying the movement of the power levers to the Ground Idle position during landing. He then possibly tried to prove that he had overcome the error by operating the power lever stop slot during approach and unintentionally moved the power lever beyond flight idle. The left power lever was moved in the range of Beta Mode while the aircraft altitude was approximately 112 ft and followed by the right power lever at 90 ft. The airplane lost altitude quickly and touched down at a vertical acceleration on impact of 5.99 G. The wing separated from the fuselage and both underwing engines tilted forward
column4: contacting the runway surface. The airplane came to rest after sliding 200 m down the runway. There was no fire. Five occupants sustained serious injuries.";09:54;Xian MA60;Merpati Nusantara Airlines;Monday 10 June 2013

column1: The aircraft landed safely on runway 27 and was about to vacate the runway via taxiway N9 when the right main landing gear collapsed. There were no injuries to any person onboard the aircraft. The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The landing was carried out by co-pilot and captain was carrying out Supervised Line Flying (SLF). During landing flare
column2: aircraft floated a little and the touchdown was normal. The aircraft landed with a  vertical acceleration of 1.44 G. About 16 seconds after touch down
column3: at a speed of around 58 kts
column4: there was right roll of 4.57° and the aircraft started veering to the right with a noise which felt like a tire burst to the cockpit crew. To maintain directional control first officer moved the tiller. The aircraft vacated via taxiway N9 and stopped on the taxiway with the tail of the aircraft not fully clear of runway 27. Taxiway N9 is about 2600 meters/8550 feet down the runway 27.

column1: Flaps were moved to 40
column2: in case if the situation warranted an evacuation. Thereafter
column3: the captain contacted the Jet Airways dispatcher. Also
column4: the APU was started and engine no.2 was shut down
column5: followed by engine no.1.

column1: Meanwhile the airport fire service attended as the ATC controller had observed sparks from the right side of the aircraft after landing. On arrival of passenger stairs
column2: the occupants were safely disembarked through the L1 door and no emergency evacuation was carried out.

column1: An investigation revealed that a main landing gear aft trunnion pin had failed as a result of improper grinding during overhaul. Several trunnion pins were overhauled by the same company. The first failure occurred on April 13
column2: 2015 to a Jet Airways Boeing 737-800. During landing rollout at Khajuraho Airport
column3: the left hand main gear aft trunnion pin failed.

column1: Accoring to maintenance records two sets of trunnion pins had been overhauled. As a precautionary measure
column2: on 20 August 2015
column3: the aft trunnion pins of VT-JGC were removed from the aircraft. After the accident involving VT-JGD
column4: it appeared from maintenance records that in fact three sets of trunnion pins (including VT-JGD) had been overhauled by the same company.";21:52;Boeing 737-95R;Jet Airways;Thursday 3 March 2016

column5: Canada;"The Beechcraft King Air 100 took off from the Montréal/St-Hubert Airport
column6: Quebec
column7: Canada at 17:00
column8: on a local flight under visual flight rules with 1 pilot and 3 passengers on board.  The purpose of the flight was to check the rudder trim indicator and to confirm a potential synchronization problem between the autopilot and the global positioning system (GPS).

column1: At approximately 17:14
column2: once the tests were completed
column3: the aircraft
column4: which was about 25 nautical miles (nm) south of St-Hubert Airport
column5: set a direct course for St-Hubert Airport. At 17:16
column6: the pilot advised air traffic control (ATC) that the tests had been completed and asked to return to St-Hubert Airport with a simulated instrument landing system (ILS) approach to runway 24R.

column2: the propeller sound fluctuated
column3: as the fault warning light and RH FUEL PRESSURE light illuminated. The pilot noted that the engine nacelle fuel tank gauges showed E (empty). The pilot activated the left and right auxiliary boost pumps and opened the crossfeed valve. At 17:23:44
column4: the aircraft intercepted the localizer of runway 24R at St-Hubert Airport at an altitude of 2800 feet asl. At 17:23:58
column5: the propeller sound fluctuated again
column6: and the right engine stopped.

column2: when the aircraft was 2.5 nm northwest of Saint-Mathieu-de-Beloeil Airport and 2600 feet asl with a ground speed of 190 knots
column3: the pilot advised the controller they were going to land at there instead of St-Hubert. At 17:24:34
column4: when C-GJSU was 2400 feet asl
column5: 7.4 nm away from the runway and on a path toward St-Hubert
column6: the left engine stopped. The pilot initiated a left turn toward the new destination. Over the next 40 seconds
column7: C-GJSU's ground speed dropped from 180 knots to 110 knots.

column2: the controller provided traffic information to C-GJSU and cleared C-GJSU to the enroute frequency. The pilot acknowledged immediately. There was no further communication by C-GJSU.

column1: During the turn
column2: when the aircraft was at the highest point of the turn at 1600 feet asl
column3: the pilot lowered the landing gear. When C-GJSU was 1000 feet asl
column4: the stall warning horn sounded
column5: then sounded 3 more times over the next 10 seconds. When the aircraft was approximately 450 feet above ground level (agl) and 0.85 nm from the threshold of runway 15
column6: the pilot decided to land in a field to the right. Twelve seconds before impact
column7: the pilot warned the maintenance engineer
column8: who was seated in the co-pilot seat
column9: that a forced landing was imminent. At that point
column10: the engineer was not aware that the engines had stopped. The engineer immediately alerted the other 2 passengers that a forced landing was imminent and warned them to hold on tight.

column1: Four seconds later
column2: C-GJSU experienced an aerodynamic stall. The right wing touched the ground at an angle of approximately 45°
column3: then the aircraft hit a fence and a tree before severing 2 electrical wires and violently striking the grass-covered ground. The aircraft kept moving for another 120 feet before coming to a stop on its belly. The 4 occupants
column4: who sustained minor injuries
column5: egressed by means of the emergency exit on the right side of the aircraft
column6: which was extensively damaged.

column1: Th investigation learned that
column2: while preparing for the flight
column3: the pilot relied exclusively on the fuel gauges
column4: misread them
column5: and assumed that the aircraft had enough fuel on board for the flight. During the flight
column6: the pilot did not monitor the fuel gauges and
column7: when returning to the airport
column8: decided to extend the flight to practice a simulated instrument landing approach
column9: without noticing there was insufficient fuel to complete it.

column1: The investigation found the pilot had a history of performance that did not meet expected standards to act as pilot-in-command for that aircraft type. Despite a marginal performance during the check flight
column2: the pilot had successfully passed a pilot proficiency check
column3: and TC had approved the individual's appointment to the position of chief pilot.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the company's operations manager
column3: who had no previous experience in commercial air carrier operations
column4: was unable to fully appreciate the significance of the chief pilot's marginal performance or to detect deviations from regulations in the commercial flights performed over the company's first three months of operations
column5: which preceded the accident. The regulator
column6: Transport Canada
column7: had also approved the appointment of the operations manager.

column1: In addition
column2: the investigation revealed that the person responsible for maintenance (PRM)
column3: a new co-pilot on the company's BE10
column4: had no previous experience in maintenance or in air taxi flight operations. Transport Canada had also approved the appointment of the PRM.

column1: The TSB determined that Transport Canada's appointment approval process was not effective and that
column2: once the appointments had been approved
column3: the management team's inability to perform the duties and responsibilities was not grounds for Transport Canada to revoke them.";17:26;Beechcraft 100 King Air;Aviation Flycie;Monday 10 June 2013

The crew did not use the full runway length available but attempted the takeoff run with only 870ft (265 m) of runway available. The aircraft failed to become airborne and overran the runway

column1: Calculations

column2: Russia;Borki Airport
column3: Russia;The Let 410 was involved in skydiving flights out of Borki aerodrome. The aircraft in question was owned by Mr Yu. M Kabanov
column4: deputy director of the Aviation Complex Myachkovo (AKM) and used by the Borki Air Club. On the day of the accident 23 skydivers boarded the Let 410. This was illegal since the maximum number of skydivers allowed on a Let 410 is 12 with lateral seating. In this case nearly all skydivers were sitting on the airplane's floor
column5: one even occupied the toilet. As a result the airplane was overloaded by 618 kg and the centre of gravity was probably about 32% MAC where the maximum rear CofG was 28% MAC. At an altitude of about 3900 metres eleven skydivers prepared to exit the plane. When four of them had gotten out the CofG moved further aft (probably to about 35%) causing the Let to pitch up. The plane stalled
column6: fell to the left and descended out of control. At an altitude of 2000 metres the aft fuselage section failed. Several skydivers were thrown out and the airplane crashed in a field.;14:25;Let L-410UVP;Borki Air Club;Saturday 1 March 2003

column1: 9-jan-08;Airbus A319-114;N349NB;Northwest Airlines;Detroit-Metr...;;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 5;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 68;Substantial;Approach (APR);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;New York-La Guardia Airport
column2: NY (LGA/KLGA)
column3: United States of America;Detroit-Metropolitan Wayne County Airport
column4: MI (DTW/KDTW)
column5: United States of America;"An Airbus A319-114
column6: N349NB
column7: operated by Northwest Airlines as flight NW853
column8: experienced an engine fan cowling separation while on approach to land on runway 27R at the Detroit Metro Airport (DTW)
column9: Michigan. The pilot
column10: co-pilot
column11: 3 flight attendants
column12: and 68 passengers on board were not injured. The airplane received substantial damage. The flight originated from New York-LaGuardia Airport (LGA)

column1: The accident flight was the first one for the airplane after having maintenance performed on the number two (right) engine during the previous evening. The first officer reported he used a flashlight when conducting his preflight inspection of the airplane as it was still dark outside. He reported the engine cowlings were flush
column2: and he did not see any ""hanging"" cowl latches when he looked underneath the engines.

column1: The captain reported that the logbooks indicated the number two engine vibration monitor had been replaced during the previous night. He reported the preflight
column2: taxi
column3: and takeoff were normal. The captain reported that during climb out the cockpit received a call from the lead flight attendant who informed them that a passenger reported that the number two engine cowling was flapping after takeoff. A pilot-passenger who was sitting behind this passenger reportedly did not see the cowling move
column4: nor did the flight attendants when they looked out the window. The captain reported he then began to monitor the N1 vibration indications on the number two engine. He reported that the number two engine vibration was approximately double the indication from the number one engine
column5: but the indicator was not flashing nor had it turned amber. During cruise flight the number two engine vibration decreased to equal that of the number one engine. The captain reported that about 20 minutes after they leveled off
column6: the airplane shuddered as if flying through wake turbulence. He reported the remainder of the flight was normal until they were taxiing after landing and the lead flight attendant called the cockpit stating that ""part of the right engine had come off."" The first officer called ground control to warn them that there might be debris on the runway. The crew then shut down the number two engine and taxied to the gate.

column1: The pilot of another airplane later reported seeing part of the engine cowling come off when flight 853 was on a 1-mile final. The other half of the engine cowling was found on the runway and was contacted by an airplane that landed after the accident airplane.
Contract maintenance personnel reported they changed the N1 sensor on the number two engine during the evening prior to the accident. They reported they then shut the fan cowling
column2: but did not latch it as they still needed to perform an engine run and check for leaks. After the engine run was performed
column3: one of the mechanics thought that the other had latched the fan cowling when in fact he had not. While they were doing another task in the cockpit
column4: another mechanic asked for help at another gate. The mechanics left the accident airplane to assist the other mechanic. Neither mechanic returned to the accident airplane to either latch or verify that the fan cowling had been latched.

column1: The maintenance log stated the N1 speed sensor was removed and replaced in accordance with aircraft maintenance manual (AMM) 77-11-10. This section of the AMM states
column2: ""Close the fan cowl doors (Ref. AMM TASK 71-13-00-410-040)."" According to the maintenance personnel
column3: this task was not completed prior to the airplane being returned to service.

column1: The separated cowling contacted the right side of the horizontal stabilizer which resulted in substantial damage to the stabilizer. In addition
column2: the fan cowl doors
column3: number two engine pylon
column4: the number two engine reverser
column5: and the right wing number one slat were damaged.";07:49;Airbus A319-114;Northwest Airlines;Wednesday 9 January 2008

column1: 13-apr-11;Airbus A330-203;F-GZCB;Air France;Caracas-Simó...;2001-11-29  (9 years 5 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 13;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 202;Substantial;Landing (LDG);International Scheduled Passenger;Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport (CDG/LFPG)
column2: France;Caracas-Simón Bolívar International Airport (CCS/SVMI)
column3: Venezuela;"An Airbus A330-203 sustained substantial damage in a hard landing accident at Caracas-Simón Bolívar International Airport (CCS)
column4: Venezuela. There were no injuries among the 202 passengers and 13 crew members.

column1: Flight AF470 took off from Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport (CDG) at 08:55 UTC on a regular service to Caracas
column2: Venezuela. The en route part of the flight was uneventful. Weather at the destination was poor due to the presence of several thunderstorms and rain. The captain was pilot flying during the ILS approach to runway 10 at Caracas.

column1: The airplane was aligned with the localizer at 10 NM from the threshold and the glideslope was intercepted at 6 NM. The crew selected a Vapp approach speed of 136 kts and moments later disconnected the autopilot and autothrottle. Passing 1000 feet above aerodrome level the crew was able to observe the runway. Descent rate at the time was -950 feet per minute and the airplane had rolled 3° to the right at an airspeed of 153 kt (Vapp + 17 kt). Shortly before passing 500 feet the captain had to correct some deviations
column2: causing roll angles reaching 9°. At 200 feet the airplane was above the glide path and the pilot monitoring reported that the airspeed increased from 138 kt to 153 kt. The airspeed decreased again to below 136 kts with the GPWS warning ""Sink Rate!"" at 35 feet.

column1: The airplane touched down at 2
column2: 74 G with a descent rate of -1200 ft/min.

column1: Flight 470 taxied to the terminal without any problems. The captain reported the hard landing in the Aircraft Technical Log and reported it to the station manager at Caracas. One Air France technician performed a walk around check in very heavy rain and low light conditions. The Aircraft Condition Monitoring System (ACMS) did not generate an automated 'hard landing' report
column2: and no report was received at the company's Maintenance Control Center (MCC). The Data Management Unit (DMU)
column3: part of the ACMS was checked and it was concluded that there was no defect. Consequently
column4: the airplane was released for the return flight to Paris.

column1: Upon takeoff from Caracas at 18:30 local time
column2: the crew were not able to raise the undercarriage. Several alarms related to cabin conditioning were triggered and displayed on the ECAM. After burning off fuel the crew landed safely back at Caracas. After parking
column3: significant damage was found on the right hand main landing gear and fuselage structure.";13:55;Airbus A330-203;Air France;Wednesday 13 April 2011

column4: Sint Maarten;"The commander intended to fly the BN-2 Islander aircraft from Anguilla Wallblake International Airport (AXA) to the neighbouring island of St Maarten (SXM) to await cargo inbound on another flight. The cabin of the aircraft was configured for cargo operations with no passenger seats fitted
column5: as the only other planned occupant was the operator’s Chief Engineer
column6: who would be sitting beside the commander in the right hand seat. However
column7: the commander asked the operator if he could take a family member with him to SXM. The operator agreed and an extra seat was fitted. Witnesses stated that the commander appeared ""rushed"" prior to departure.

column1: The commander stated that he partially carried out the normal pre-flight inspection. He then started the engines. Before taxiing he realised that the nose landing gear chocks were still in place so he shut down the left hand engine
column2: removed and stowed the chocks and then restarted the left engine.

column1: The aircraft took off from runway 10 at 14:15 hrs. At between 100 ft and 150 ft the commander initiated a left turn but after some initial movement the ailerons jammed. When he discovered that he was unable to straighten the ailerons he attempted to return to land on runway 10. The other flight controls did not appear to be restricted.
With the ailerons jammed
column2: the aircraft continued to turn to the left
column3: losing altitude as it flew over a settlement to the north of the aerodrome
column4: until pointed directly at the Air Traffic Control tower
column5: causing the Air Traffic Control Officer (ATCO) to abandon the tower. The commander judged that the aircraft was too fast and high to attempt a landing and therefore initiated a go-around
column6: applying full power. He continued the left turn
column7: losing height and speed to position the aircraft for another approach but
column8: as the aircraft descended over the northern edge of the runway
column9: its left wing struck the perimeter fence.
