column1: 13-apr-15;Swearingen SA226-TC Metro II;C-GSKC;Carson Air;near North Vancou...;1977;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;En route (ENR);Cargo;Vancouver International Airport
column2: BC (YVR/CYVR)
column3: Canada;Prince George Airport
column4: BC (YXS/CYXS)
column5: Canada;"The Carson Air Swearingen SA226-TC Metro II was operating as flight 66
column6: a weekday cargo flight between Vancouver International Airport (CYVR) and Fort St. John (CYXJ)
column7: British Columbia
column8: Canada
column9: with planned stops in Prince George (CYXS) and Dawson Creek (CYDQ).

column1: On the morning of the occurrence
column2: CA66's first officer arrived at the airport at approximately 06:00. The first officer appeared to be in good spirits and spent about 5 minutes in the flight planning room before going to the aircraft to prepare it for that day's flights. The captain arrived at approximately 06:15 and went directly to the flight planning room to begin preparing the morning's flight plan. He appeared to be in a positive state of mind and spent a few minutes speaking with other company pilots who were also preparing to operate flights. He used a company computer to access weather information and placed a telephone call to NAV CANADA to file an instrument flight rules flight plan. No abnormal behaviour was observed by anyone with whom he had contact. The captain then walked to the aircraft and spent about 10 minutes in the flight deck before assisting the first officer with loading the flight's cargo. Final flight preparations were carried out by both flight crew members before they boarded the aircraft and started the engines
column3: at about 06:45.

column2: CA66 began its take-off run. The aircraft lifted off after an approximate ground-run distance of 2800 to 3000 feet. This was within the expected normal performance for the aircraft type.

column1: Shortly after takeoff
column2: CA66 contacted CYVR terminal departure control and was cleared to 9000 feet above sea level (ASL). A short time later
column3: the air traffic controller assigned the flight a northbound heading. At 07:07
column4: CYVR terminal departure control instructed CA66 to change radio frequencies and contact CYVR centre control. Upon initial contact with CYVR centre control
column5: while climbing through 7500 feet
column6: CA66 was again cleared to the aircraft's final flight planned altitude of flight level 200. At 07:08
column7: the crew acknowledged a clearance to climb to flight level 200; this was CA66's last radio transmission. One minute and 20 seconds later
column8: while climbing through an altitude of 8700 feet on an assigned heading of 350° magnetic
column9: the aircraft disappeared from secondary surveillance radar displays at air traffic control.

column1: CA66's radar track
column2: from the time it first became visible on radar at 07:02 until a steep descent toward ground
column3: was approximately 7 minutes. The track showed an apparently routine climb from CYVR
column4: at an average climb rate of 1500 feet per minute. Aircraft speed during the climb increased gradually until a ground speed of approximately 185 knots was reached.

column1: The last 3 radar returns from CA66 showed the aircraft beginning an abrupt
column2: steep descent. At 07:09
column3: a radar return showed that the aircraft was at 8700 feet; this was the highest altitude it reached. The 2 subsequent radar returns showed that the aircraft had dropped rapidly to 7600 feet and then 5000 feet while continuing in the direction of flight. There were no further returns.

column1: During the initial stage of the descent
column2: the aircraft pitched down at about 6° per second
column3: and its vertical acceleration reached -0.6g. The descent to 5000 feet likely occurred within 10 to 14 seconds. During that period
column4: the aircraft's descent rate exceeded 30 000 feet per minute
column5: and aerodynamic forces caused structural disintegration of the aircraft (in-flight breakup). There was no Mayday call or other communication from the aircraft during this period.

column1: Deteriorating weather conditions with low cloud and heavy snowfall hampered an air search; however
column2: aircraft wreckage was found on steep
column3: mountainous
column4: snow-covered terrain by ground searchers at approximately 16:45. Both pilots had been fatally injured.

column1: Investigation showed that the captain had 0.24% blood alcohol content [BAC]. To obtain this
column2: the captain would have had to consume approximately 17 to 20 standard drinks over a 12-hour period.

column1: An autopsy also identified focal severe coronary artery atherosclerosis and both steatosis and hepatitis in the captain’s liver. Finding these conditions in a 34-year-old person suggests excessive alcohol consumption over a significant period.
The captain had recently applied for the position of Vancouver base chief pilot for the company’s cargo operation. On 26 March 2015
column2: the company advised him that the position had been awarded to another candidate. Around the same period
column3: on 24 March 2015
column4: 20 days before this accident
column5: a first officer who had been having symptoms of depression and psychosis deliberately flew a Germanwings Airbus A320 into terrain
column6: killing all on board.

column1: Although there were several coincidental factors
column2: the investigation could not make any conclusions about the captain’s predisposition to committing an intentional act. Other scenario's like pitot system blockage or crew incapacitation were also considered
column3: but deemed not very probable.";07:09;Swearingen SA226-TC Metro II;Carson Air;Monday 13 April 2015

MAFFS is a self-contained aerial firefighting system owned by the U.S. Forest Service that can discharge 3

column1: About 15:40

The ground controller replied ""...don't have you in sight if you guys are in the foxtrot one ramp that is uncontrolled."" The accident crew responded that they were aware of that
column4: but that they wanted to ""get out of the way"" of the Caravan. Ground control then asked for the accident crew's intentions
column6: the accident crew replied ""taxi out for departure and I'll get the clearance as soon as I get clear of the Caravan."" At 15:42:50 the Caravan pilot broadcast ""mayday mayday mayday watch out watch out watch out.""

column1: According to the pilot of the Caravan
column2: he had deplaned his passengers and was taxiing his airplane to its parking location. Since the Sabreliner was blocking his intended path
column3: the Caravan pilot stopped to let the Sabreliner pass. He then saw the Sabreliner coming towards him
column4: and the left wing of the Sabreliner struck the Caravan's propeller. The Sabreliner continued moving at a speed that the Caravan pilot estimated to be 10 knots
column5: and the right wing of the Sabreliner struck a DH-125 that was under tow by a tug. The Sabreliner continued to move forward until it struck another
column6: stationary Sabreliner (N430MP). The Caravan pilot estimated that the accident Sabreliner had traveled 20 to 30 yards beyond the Caravan before it finally stopped.

column2: no. 1 engine and right hand wing.";15:42;Rockwell Sabreliner 80;Qualint;Friday 1 February 2008

column1: The ATR-42-600
column2: operated by TransNusa Aviation Mandiri and registered PK-TNJ
column3: was parked at stand B-1 on the north apron of Halim Airport and was to be moved from the north to the south apron. For this the aircraft had to cross the active runway.

column1: A towing car was used with a driver and one supporting personnel. Two engineers occupied the pilot seats in the aircraft. The engineers were assigned to apply aircraft brakes if required during the towing process.
The towed aircraft was towed without aircraft electrical power fed to the system and the navigation light
column2: strobe light and the aircraft radio communications were off. The communication between the towing car driver and Halim Tower was performed by a handheld radio communication on frequency 152.7 MHz.

column1: At 19:45 local time flight ID7703 requested pushback clearance to the Halim Tower controller on frequency 118.6 MHz. The aircraft was parked on parking stand B-2 and was approved to push back.
After the ID7703 completed the pushback
column2: the towing car driver of the towed aircraft requested clearance to Halim Tower Control Unit to reposition from parking stand B-1 to the south apron. The towing car driver was instructed to follow ID7703 and to report when on taxiway C. The communication between the towing car driver and Halim Tower was handled by the assistant controller.

column1: The controller heard the communication between the assistant and towing car driver
column2: he recognized the position of the towed aircraft was on the parking stand B-1.

column1: The ID7703 flight crew did not know that there was a towing aircraft behind as communications with the car were on a different frequency. At 19:48
column2: ID7703 received taxi clearance to runway 24 via taxiway C.
the controller instructed ID7703 to hold on taxiway C due to an arriving aircraft. The assistant stated that when ID7703 was holding on short taxiway C
column3: the towing car began moving the ATR-42.

column2: ID7703 received clearance from controller to enter runway 24 to back track for departure. The aircraft that had just arrived would use parking stand B-1. Therefore
column3: the assistant controller instructed the towing car driver to expedite the tow and report when on taxiway C. The controller was not observing the ATR at that time. The towing car was about to enter taxiway C at that time.

column2: ID7703 reported ready for takeoff. The controller did not see any vehicle or object on the runway then issued clearance for takeoff. The pilot stated that during line up
column3: the lights surrounding the turn pad were very bright and affected his forward vision for a short time. It was common practice in Halim to lineup at the turn pad beyond the threshold runway 24.

column1: After receiving the takeoff clearance
column2: the Second in Command (SIC) as pilot flying (PF) opened the power and pressed the Take Off / Go Around (TOGA) button.

column1: The towing car driver stated that
column2: when he saw ID7703 was lining up for takeoff
column3: he asked Halim Tower whether ID7703 was initiating the takeoff. There was no reply from Halim Tower. The towing car driver then sped up the towing and turned to the right side of the runway.

column1: When ID7703 was accelerating through approximate 80 knots
column2: the SIC saw an object warned the captain. The pilots could not identify the object but later on when the object became closer
column3: the SIC realized that there was an aircraft.

column1: The captain took over control and applied the right rudder towards the right side of runway centerline and maintained a course between the runway centerline and the runway edge. The PIC intended to reject the takeoff shortly after they felt an impact. The impact occurred at a ground speed of about 130 knots
column2: after passing V1. The pilot rejected takeoff and the aircraft stopped at approximately 400 meter from the towed aircraft which stopped at the left of the runway 24 centerline at approximately 100 meters from taxiway G.

column1: The captain noticed fire on the left wing tip and immediately shut down both engines
column2: activated the fire extinguishers of both engines and Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) and commanded to the flight attendant ""evacuation from the right"".

column1: The flight attendants opened all aircraft passenger doors and the escape slides deployed. Most of passengers were evacuated from the left forward door (L1).
Both aircraft sustained substantial damage. There were no reported injuries to the accident.
The outer portion of the left wing of the Boeing 737
column2: about 5
column4: was severed. The ATR-42s left hand wing
column5: outboard of the no.1 engine
column6: was severed
column7: along with the entire empennage.";19:57;Boeing 737-8GP (WL);Batik Air;Monday 4 April 2016

column5: United States of America;"A Cessna 208B Grand Caravan operated by Makani Kai Air sustained substantial damage in a landing accident at Kalaupapa Airport

column1: Kalaupapa Airport is an uncontrolled (nontowered) airport with a single runway and no taxiways. The pilots use a common frequency to state their intentions.
The pilot of the Grand Caravan reported that she was going to establish an approach and landing to runway 05. While on a seven-mile final
column2: she communicated with the pilot of an airplane that was on short final for the same airport. The pilot that was on short final reported that he would report when he was clear of the runway
column3: and he did. The commuter pilot acknowledged the other pilot's clear of runway transmission
column4: and initiated the approach.

column1: As the pilot descended through 150 feet above ground level
column2: she noticed that the airplane that she had communicated with was not clear of the runway. The airplane on the ground was near the runway 23 numbers with the propeller turning
column3: facing toward her landing airplane. She aborted the landing but the airplane did not climb. The airplane impacted the runway hard and bounced. She reported that when the airplane touched down after the bounce
column4: she ""applied left rudder pedal to steer the aircraft off the runway and out of the way of the other aircraft's possible flight path."" The airplane exited the left side of the runway and ground-looped to the left. The airplane sustained substantial damage to the right side of the fuselage and the right wing.

column1: After the ground-loop
column2: the pilot of the airplane near the runway 23 numbers attempted to takeoff. He was contacted via radio transmission by the airport manager and vehemently told that the runway was closed until further notice.";08:30;Cessna 208B Grand Caravan;Makani Kai Air;Saturday 11 March 2017

column5: Canada;"At 23:20

column9: Halifax
column10: St. John's and back to Mirabel again. At 05:45
column11: the aircraft departed Halifax for St. John's. The pilot flying was completing his line indoctrination training after having recently upgraded to captain. En route the crew were advised of a NOTAM that the ILS for runway 11 was unserviceable. Because of the marginal weather
column12: the loss of runway 11/29
column13: and his greater experience
column14: the training captain decided to switch seats and assume the duties and full responsibilities as captain and pilot flying.

column1: Clearance for an ILS approach to runway 16 was obtained from Gander ACC
column2: and the crew was advised to contact St. John's tower. Just over two minutes before landing
column3: the tower advised that the wind was 050º (estimated) at 20
column4: gusting to 35
column5: knots. The aircraft crossed the final approach fix on the ILS glideslope at 150 KIAS. During the final approach
column6: the airspeed steadily increased to 180 KIAS (ground speed 190 knots); the glidepath was maintained with a descent rate of 1000 feet per minute. From 1000 feet above sea level
column7: no airspeed calls were made; altitude calls were made and responses were made. The Royal Boeing 737 operations manual states that the PNF shall call out significant deviations from programmed airspeed. In the descent
column8: through 900 feet above sea level
column9: the aircraft encountered turbulence resulting in uncommanded roll and pitch deviations and airspeed fluctuations of ±11 knots. At about 300 feet above decision height
column10: the crew acquired visual references for landing. They were cleared to land. The aircraft touched down at 164 KIAS (27 KIAS above the desired touchdown speed of Vref)
column11: 2300 to 2500 feet beyond the threshold. The wind at this point was determined to be about 050º at 30 knots. Shortly after touchdown
column12: the speed brakes and thrust reversers were deployed. With approximately 1100 feet of runway remaining
column13: through a speed of 64 KIAS
column14: reverse thrust increased to about 1.97 EPR on engine 1 and 2.15 EPR on engine 2. As the aircraft approached the end of the runway
column15: the captain attempted to steer the aircraft to the right
column16: toward the Delta taxiway intersection. Twenty-two seconds after touchdown
column17: the aircraft exited the departure end of the runway into deep snow. The aircraft came to rest approximately 75 feet beyond and 53 feet to the right of the runway centreline.

column1: The 737 has been stored at Saint John's since the accident. The aircraft sustained serious damage to the landing gear and the left engine detached from the wing.

Royal Airlines was acquired by Canada 3000 later that year. The 737 has been stored at Saint John's since the accident. Royal Airlines was acquired by Canada 3000 later that year. Canada 3000 went bankrupt late 2001.";null;Boeing 737-2E1F;Royal Airlines;Wednesday 4 April 2001
16-jul-04;Antonov An-28;YL-KAB;Rigas Aeroklubs;Østre Æra Ai...;1991;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Damaged beyond repair;Landing (LDG);Parachuting;Østre Æra Airport (ENAE)
column2: Norway;Østre Æra Airport (ENAE)
column3: Norway;"Two AN-28 turboprop aircraft
column4: operated by Rigas Aeroklubs Latvia
column5: were dropping parachutists at the National Parachute Sport Centre
column6: Østre Æra airstrip in Østerdalen
column7: Norway. The company had had a great deal of experience with this type of operations
column8: and had been carrying out parachute drops in Norway each summer for the last 9 years.

column1: On Friday morning
column2: 16 July 2004
column3: the weather conditions were good when the flights started. They first performed six routine drop flights. After stopping to fill up with fuel
column4: normal preparations were made for the next flight with 20 parachutists who were to jump in two groups of 10.

column1: The seventh departure was carried out at time 13:05. The Commander asked for and was given clearance by the air traffic control service to climb to flight level FL150. The parachutists were then dropped from that altitude. The first drop of 10 parachutists was made on a southerly course above the airstrip
column2: and the aircraft continued on that course for a short time before turning through 180° and getting ready for the next drop at the same location on a northerly course.

column1: A large cumulonimbus cloud (CB)
column2: with precipitation
column3: had approached the airfield from the north at this time. To reach the drop zone above the runway
column4: the aircraft had to fly close to this cloud. The aircraft was not equipped with weather radar. The last parachutists to leave the aircraft were in a tandem jump that was being filmed on video. The film showed that the parachutists became covered in a layer of white ice within 2-3 seconds of leaving the aircraft. The ice on the parachutists only thawed once they had descended to lower altitudes where the air temperature was above zero.

column1: Once the parachutists had jumped
column2: the aircraft was positioned close to the CB cloud at a low cruising speed. They were exposed to moderate turbulence from the cloud. The Commander started a sudden 90° turn to the left while also reducing engine power to flight idle in order to avoid the CB cloud and return to Østre Æra to land.

column1: At this point
column2: the First Officer observed that ice had formed on the front windshield
column3: and he chose to switch on the anti-icing system. He did this without informing the commander. A few seconds later both engines stopped
column4: and both propellers automatically adopted the feathered position.

column1: The pilots had not noticed any technical problems with the aircraft engines before they failed. During the descent
column2: the first officer
column3: on the commander's orders
column4: carried out a series of start-up attempts with reference to the checklist/procedure they had available in the cockpit. The engines would not start and the commander made a decision and prepared to carry out an emergency landing at Østre Æra without engines.

column1: The runway at Østre Æra is 600 m long and 10 m wide. The surrounding area is covered by dense coniferous forest and they had no alternative landing areas within reach. Because they were without engine power
column2: there was no hydraulic power to operate the aircraft's flaps. This meant that the speed of the aircraft had to be kept relatively high
column3: approx. 160-180 km/h. The final approach was further complicated because the commander had to avoid the last 10 parachutists who were still in the air and who were steering towards a landing area just beside the airstrip.

column1: The commander first positioned the aircraft on downwind on a southerly course west of the airfield
column2: in order then to make a left turn to final on runway 01. The landing took place around halfway down the runway
column3: at a faster speed than normal - according to the Commander's explanation approximately 160-170 km/h. The commander braked using the wheel brakes
column4: but when he realized that he would not be able to stop on the length of runway remaining
column5: he ceased braking. He knew that the terrain directly on the extension to the runway was rough
column6: and chose to use the aircraft's remaining speed to lift it off the ground and to alter course a little to the right. The aircraft passed over the approx. 2.5 m high embankment in the transition between the runway level and the higher marshy plateau surrounding the northern runway area.

column1: The aircraft ran approx. 230 m in ground effect before landing on its wheels in the flat marshy area north of the airfield. After around 60 m of roll-out
column2: the nose wheel and the aircraft's nose struck a ditch and the aircraft turned over lengthways. It came to rest upside down with its nose section pointing towards the landing strip. The floor of the cockpit was pushed up so that the nose wheel came through the floor and partially into the cockpit.";13:24;Antonov 28;Rigas Aeroklubs;Friday 16 July 2004

column4: the captain decided to divert to Bhairahawa

column6: the captain did not take into consideration the surrounding terrain and continued descent turning right.

column1: The aircraft initially slashed a small tree and finally impacted a ridge. Due to the heavy impact the left wing was first disintegrated and then the front part of the aircraft toppled over beyond the ridge with several subsequent impacts.

column3: Greenland;"A de Havilland Canada DHC-8-200 operated by Air Greenland was involved in a gear collapse and runway excursion accident at Ilulissat Airport (JAV)
column4: Greenland. Flight GL-3205 originated in Kangerlussuaq
column5: Greenland. Three passengers were taken to the hospital for observation
column6: there were no fatalities or serious injuries.

column1: On initial radio contact with Ilulissat AFIS
column2: the flight crew got the information that runway 07 was in use. Weather information showed wind from 150° magnetic at 24 knots
column3: maximum 33 knots
column4: minimum 17 knots; a 24 knots cross wind
column5: and a headwind of 5 knots. The wind at threshold runway 25 was gusting to 41 knots. Visibility was fine (10 km) with broken clouds at 12000 feet.

column1: The flight crew got visual contact with the Ilulissat area and due to the wind conditions and consequently expected turbulence on final
column2: the flight crew prepared for a NDB/DME approach to runway 07 via JV NDB. Due to the cross wind conditions
column3: the flight crew decided to do a landing with a flap setting of 15°.

column1: The flight crew asked Ilulissat AFIS for a confirmation of whether or not the cross winds of 24 knots included the gusting wind conditions up to maximum 33 knots. Ilulissat AFIS replied that the maximum wind was 35 knots and the cross wind was 26 knots.
On a 5 miles final to runway 07
column2: the wind conditions were reported to be 140° magnetic at 28 knots with a maximum of 35 knots and a cross wind of 26 knots. On short final to runway 07
column3: the wind conditions were reported to 140° magnetic and 25 knots
column4: maximum to 39 knots.

column1: Upon touchdown on runway 07
column2: the left main landing gear collapsed. With the left main landing collapsed and after approximately 104 meters of runway rolling
column3: the flight crew started to loose aircraft directional control. After approximately 389 meters
column4: the aircraft ran off the left side of the runway and into the safety zone. The aircraft skidded sideways
column5: hit the Precision Approach Path Indicator (PAPI) to runway 25
column6: skidded down a steep slope and impacted a rocky area approximately 10 meters below the runway elevation.

column1: The crew members initiated an evacuation of the aircraft. The flight crew found the flight deck door jammed and evacuated the flight deck through the flight compartment emergency exit hatch. The cabin crew member and a passenger had difficulties opening a partly jammed main entrance door. In cooperation with the commander from the outside of the aircraft
column2: they succeeded. From the outside of the aircraft
column3: the commander opened the forward right hand cabin emergency exit door. The passengers and the cabin crew member evacuated the passenger cabin trough the main entrance door. The overall evacuation took approximately 30-40 seconds.

column1: Ilulissat Airport has a single
column2: 07/25 asphalt runway
column3: 845 m (2772 ft) long. Runway 07 has a 0
column4: 8% downslope for the first 550 m
column5: followed by a 0
column6: 2% upslope for 295 m.";08:42;de Havilland Canada DHC-8-202Q;Air Greenland;Wednesday 29 January 2014

column1: Flight SI-308 took off from Guernsey
column2: Channel Islands at 07:05
column3: with the captain acting as pilot flying. He was conducting line training of the co-pilot
column4: a first officer who had recently joined the company.

column1: The short flight to Jersey was without incident and the weather for landing was reported as good
column2: with the wind from 210° at 16 kt
column3: few clouds at 2
column4: 000 ft and visibility in excess of 10 km. The commander elected to carry out a visual approach to runway 27 at Jersey
column5: using a planned approach speed of 107 kt and flap 30 selected for landing.

column1: During the approach
column2: the gear was selected down and the flight crew confirmed the three green 'gear safe' indication lights were illuminated
column3: indicating that the gear was locked in the down position. The commander reported that both the approach and touchdown seemed normal

column1: Just after touchdown both pilots heard a noise and the aircraft appeared to settle slightly differently from usual. The captain considered that a tyre had burst. The cabin crewmember also heard a noise after touchdown which she too thought was from a tyre bursting. The commander selected ground idle and partial reverse pitch and
column2: as the aircraft decelerated through 70 kt
column3: the co-pilot took over control of the ailerons
column4: as per standard procedures
column5: to allow the commander to take control of the steering tiller. Despite applying corrective inputs the aircraft continued rolling to the left.

column1: The aircraft continued to quickly roll to the left until the left wingtip and propeller contacted the runway. The aircraft remained on the runway
column2: rapidly coming to a halt to the left of the centreline
column3: approximately abeam Holding Point D. Both propellers continued to rotate and the commander selected the condition levers to the fuel shutoff position and pulled the fire handles to shut both engines down.

column1: It was determined that the left side brace upper arm had suffered a fatigue failure. The failure rendered the side brace ineffective and the unrestrained main trunnion continued to translate outboard
column2: leading to the collapse of the gear. The aluminium brace was found to contain a small metallurgical feature at the crack origin which was consistent with titanium rich particles (TiB2) particles which are introduced as a grain refiner during casting of the billet prior to forging. The size of the feature was within the defined specifications for AL7010-T74. Analysis of the area surrounding the crack origin revealed an area of static loading before propagating a crack in fatigue
column3: indicating that there may have been a single overload event at some point in the history of the side brace upper arm.";08:23;ATR 42-320;Blue Islands;Saturday 16 June 2012

16-MAY-1997;Swearingen SA226-TC Metro II;VH-WGV;Jetcraft;Emerald Airp...;1979;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants:;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants:;Substantial;Takeoff (TOF);Cargo;Emerald Airport

column5: Australia;"Weather at the time of departure from Emerald was reported to be 6 to 7 OKTAS of low cloud with patches of rain in the area. Light rain was falling at the time the aircraft taxied. The wind was light with a slight crosswind from the right. Visibility was in excess of 10 KM. The runway was damp and there were several patches of water on the runway.

column1: The pilot reported that the take-off proceeded normally until approximately 50 knots when he disengaged the nose-wheel steering. At this point
column2: the aircraft started to diverge to the right of the centreline. In an attempt to return the aircraft to the centreline the pilot used rudder but this was ineffective. The pilot then rejected the take-off by moving the power levers to idle but the aircraft continued to diverge to the right and departed the sealed surface of the runway.

column1: The pilot used reverse thrust in an attempt to slow the aircraft but this appeared ineffective and the aircraft continued to turn to the right and slide on the wet grass surface. The aircraft by this time was heading for a small levee bank beside a drainage ditch. The pilot assessed that the aircraft would probably climb over the levee bank
column2: so he elected to introduce power on the left engine in an attempt to turn the aircraft before the levee bank. However
column3: this was only partially successful and the aircraft came to rest adjacent to the levee bank facing approximately 180 degrees from the take-off heading. The left propeller contacted the bank as the aircraft stopped. The aircraft had travelled 121 M after leaving the runway. The distance at which the aircraft left the centreline of the runway could not be accurately determined due to the runway surface. The nose-wheel track was approximately 1

column1: metre to the left of the right hand wheel track and continued at this distance until approximately 5 metres from the end of the tracks
column2: at which point it crossed over the top of the right wheel track.

column1: The aircraft suffered damage to the left propeller and engine. Examination of the engine when removed from the aircraft confirmed that it had suffered considerable internal damage consistent with a propeller strike at high power.";null;Swearingen SA226-TC Metro II;Jetcraft;Friday 16 May 1997

column9: thus rendering it unsafe for further flight.

column1: The mishap occurred on a medium risk flying qualities test sortie out to the edges of the flight envelope. The pilot was attempting to execute a Steady Heading Sideslip (SHSS) to the RUDDER Special Alert of the Advisory Caution and Warning System (ACAWS). This is normally a prohibited maneuver
column2: but the Director of Operations at Air Force Materiel Command (AFMC/A3) signed a waiver approving the test team to fly to this limit. The MA exceeded 14.5° Angle of Sideslip (AoS)
column3: triggering the RUDDER Special Alert and continued increasing AoS until it departed controlled flight
column4: eventually tumbling to an inverted position. Shortly thereafter
column5: the aircraft recovered from the departure and the copilot took the controls to recover from the near vertical dive. In the process of the departure and recovery
column6: the aircraft lost approximately 5
column7: 000 feet of altitude
column8: experienced 3.19 times the normal force acceleration (Gs)
column9: and over sped the flaps by over 100 knots. The over G exceeded the aircraft's Design Limit Load.";12:18;Lockheed AC-130J Ghostrider;United States Air Force - USAF;Tuesday 21 April 2015

column5: United States of America;"American Airlines Flight 1340 crashed short of the runway while on a coupled instrument landing system (ILS) category II approach to runway 14R at Chicago-O’Hare. The approach was normal until the airplane passed through 200 feet above ground level (agl)
column6: where the airplane started a pitch oscillation that grew in time. The airplane descended below the ILS glide slope
column7: then climbed above it
column8: and finally descended below it again
column9: impacting the ground 300 feet short of the runway threshold. Upon impact
column10: the airplane slid over the threshold and then off the right side of the runway
column11: where it came to rest..

column1: The airplane landed on a dark night on a 2
column2: 328 ft long runway. The pilot and co-pilot reported the airplane touched down on the numbers
column3: and after initial braking and deceleration
column4: the brakes ceased to work
column5: but the brake pedals remained firm. The pilot attempted to reach the emergency brake handle but was restrained by the shoulder harness which had locked. He then pressed very hard on the brake pedals and overrode the anti-skid system and was able to momentarily push the brakes into manual. He was unable to stop the airplane on the runway and struck a rock seawall at the departure end of the runway. Post accident examination found an intermittent short in the wiring on the right wheel anti-skid system. According to the anti-skid manufacturer
column6: with an intermittent short
column7: the ANTI-SKID FAIL light would not illuminate. Photos of tire marks on the runway indicated the system was occasionally reverting to manual braking due to the pilot pushing extremely hard on the brake pedals. The required landing distance of 2
column8: 146 feet was computed with the airplane crossing the runway threshold at 50 feet.";21:44;Cessna 500 Citation I;JJU Aviation;Friday 19 June 1998

column2: Spain;Bilbao Airport (BIO/LEBB)
column3: Spain;Flight IBT1278 departed Madrid (MAD) at 06:35 for a flight to Bilbao (BIO)
column4: with 2873 kg of cargo on board. The aircraft climbed to its assigned cruising altitude of FL220
column5: which was reached at 06:53. Permission to descend was given at 07:12 and at 07:23 the crew started an ILS approach to runway 30. Two minutes later the captain experienced control problems
column6: which he attributed to an autopilot malfunction. An increase in the rate of descent went unnoticed by the crew who tried to find out the cause of the control problems. As the plane was descending over mountainous terrain
column7: the GPWS alarm sounded three times. The approach controller then asked if the flight was established on the localizer and ILS glidepath. The copilot then replied that they had captured the localizer. Approach Control then instructed the crew to contact Bilbao Tower. Contact was not established however. The copilot noticed that they had not captured the glidepath and informed the captain. The airplane´s speed and rate of descent were reduced and a smooth climb was initiated. Six seconds later the airplane flew into the side of the Monte de Santa Marina
column8: some 18 nm (33 km) from Bilbao Airport. The mountain has an altitude of 675 m (2215 ft).;07:28;Embraer EMB-120RT Brasilia;Ibertrans Aérea;Monday 14 January 2002

column1: All Nippon Airways flight 1603 took off from Osaka (ITM) at 08:21 on a regular domestic flight to Kochi. At 08:47 the flight was given clearance to land on runway 32. However
column2: when configuring the aircraft for landing
column3: it appeared that the nose landing gear would not deploy. The approach was abandoned and the airplane entered a holding pattern. The crew members attempted to deploy the nose undercarriage but the attempts failed. Two low passes were flown

column5: a touch-and-go was made so as to apply an impact to the nose landing gear. The flight crew when concluded that they had to make a landing with the nose gear retracted.

column1: 3-jan-04;Boeing 737-3Q8;SU-ZCF;Flash Airlines;near Sharm el Sheikh;1992-10-09  (11 years 3 months);Fatalities: 13 / Occupants: 13;Fatalities: 135 / Occupants: 135;Destroyed;En route (ENR);Domestic Non Scheduled Passenger;Sharm el Sheikh-Ophira Airport (SSH/HESH)
column2: Egypt;Cairo International Airport (CAI/HECA)
column3: Egypt;"Weather was perfect (excellent visibility
column4: 17 degrees C and a light breeze) when Flash Air flight 604 departed the Red Sea resort of Sharm el Sheikh for a flight to Paris-CDG with an intermediate stop at Cairo. On board were 135
column5: mostly French
column6: holidaymakers who were heading home.

column1: At 04:38 the flight was cleared to taxi to runway 22R for departure. After takeoff
column3: the plane climbed and maneuvered for a procedural left turn to intercept the 306 radial from the Sharm el-Sheikh VOR station. When the autopilot was engaged the captain made an exclamation and the autopilot was immediately switched off again. The captain then requested Heading Select to be engaged. The plane then began to bank to the right. The copilot then warned the captain a few times about the fact that the bank angle was increasing. At a bank angle of 40 degrees to the right the captain stated ""OK come out"". The ailerons returned briefly to neutral before additional aileron movements commanded an increase in the right bank.

column1: The aircraft had reached a maximum altitude of 5460 feet with a 50 degrees bank when the copilot stated: ""Overbank"". Repeating himself as the bank angle kept increasing. The maximum bank angle recorded was 111 degrees right. Pitch attitude at that time was 43 degrees nose down and altitude was 3470 feet.
The observer on the flight deck
column2: a trainee copilot
column3: called ""Retard power
column4: retard power
column5: retard power"". Both throttles were moved to idle and the airplane gently seemed to recover from the nose-down
column6: right bank attitude. Speed however increased
column7: causing an overspeed warning. At 04:45 the airplane struck the surface of the water in a 24 degrees right bank
column8: 24 degrees nose-down
column9: at a speed of 416 kts and with a 3
column10: 9 G load.

column1: The wreckage sank to a depth of approx. 900 metres.";04:45;Boeing 737-3Q8;Flash Airlines;Saturday 3 January 2004

column1: 25-MAY-2011;Embraer Phenom 100;N224MD;JetSuite;Sedona Airpo...;2009;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 3;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Domestic Non Scheduled Passenger;San Jose Municipal Airport

column5: United States of America;"An Embraer Phenom 100 corporate jet
column6: N224MD
column7: sustained substantial damage during a runway overrun during landing at the Sedona Airport (SEZ)
column8: Arizona. The captain
column9: who was the flying pilot
column10: and two of the three passengers were not injured. The first officer and one passenger sustained serious injuries. The airplane was registered to a private individual and operated by JetSuite. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed and an instrument flight rules (IFR) flight plan was filed. The flight originated from San Jose
column11: California
column12: about 14:20 hours local time.

column1: Following an uneventful flight
column2: the flight crew briefed the arrival to the destination airport and set the calculated landing speeds. The captain and the first officer reported that during final approach
column3: it felt like the airplane was 'pushed up' as the wind shifted to a tailwind or updraft before landing near the runway number markings. Upon touchdown
column4: the captain applied the brakes and thought that the initial braking was effective; however
column5: he noticed the airplane was not slowing down. The captain applied maximum braking
column6: and the airplane began to veer to the right; he was able to correct back to the runway centerline
column7: but the airplane subsequently exited the departure end of the runway and traveled down a steep embankment.

column1: Recorded communication from the cockpit voice and data recorder (CVDR) revealed that during the approach to landing
column2: the flight crew performed the landing checks
column3: and the captain noted difficulty judging the approach. About 1 minute later
column4: the recording revealed that the ground warning proximity system reported ""five hundred"" followed by a ""sink rate
column5: pull up"" alert about 16 seconds later. Data from the CVDR revealed that about 23 seconds before weight-on-wheels was recorded
column6: the airplane was at an indicated airspeed of about 124 knots and descending. The data showed that this approximate airspeed was maintained until about 3 seconds before weight-on-wheels. The recorded data further showed that the approach speed was set to 120 knots
column7: and the landing reference speed (Vref) was set to 97 knots.

column1: Using the reported airplane configuration and the 3.5-knot headwind that was reported at the time of the approach and landing
column2: calculations indicate that the Vref speed should have been about 101 knots indicated airspeed
column3: which would have required a landing distance of about 3
column4: 112 feet. Utilizing the same airplane configuration and wind condition with the flight’s reported 124 knot indicated airspeed just before touchdown
column5: the landing distance was calculated to be about 5
column6: 624 feet. The intended runway for landing was 5
column7: 132-feet long with a 1.9 percent downward slope gradient
column8: and a 123-foot long overrun area.";15:52;Embraer EMB-500 Phenom 100;JetSuite;Wednesday 25 May 2011

column2: op.for Chanchangi Airlines;Kaduna Airpo...;1988-03-17  (9 years 11 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 3;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 21;Destroyed;Taxi (TXI);Training;Kaduna Airport (KAD/DNKA)
column3: Nigeria;Kaduna Airport (KAD/DNKA)
column4: Nigeria;"The Boeing 737 completed a flight from Lagos (LOS) through Abuja (ABV) to Kaduna (KAD) and was parked for over an hour. At 14:45 UTC
column5: the Chief Pilot of Chanchangi Airline approached the Air Traffic Controller stating that he would like to fly around the circuit for a training flight. He was told that the visibility was 600 meters which was below the landing minima and was then advised against it. The pilot then suggested that he would carry out a ""Rejected Takeoff"" training.

column1: Additional persons boarded the flight to witness the exercise.
At 15:37 UTC the pilot requested a take off clearance which was granted
column2: and was directed to proceed to the holding point of runway 05. The prevailing visibility was 600 meters and the wind was 090 at 10 knots. Four rejected take off training runs were carried out within an interval of twelve minutes.

column1: In the conditions at Kaduna
column2: a single exercise of a rejected take off would have required a cooling period of at least ten minutes.

column1: At the end of the fourth run
column2: the left main landing gear number 2 brake unit had started to burn. The pilot steered the airplane off the runway into the last taxiway. Fifty meters from the runway 05 threshold the left inner wheel failed and leaving a molten rubber footprint on the taxiway and at the same time the hydraulic fluid of the brake units started to spill tracing an oily track along. Pieces of broken wheel rim were randomly shed for a distance of 150 meters when the rims appeared to undergo a major collapse. The footprint of the two left wheels became more pronounced for a distance of 120 meters when there was a positive turn to the left indicating a total failure in roll from the left wheel assembly. The zigzag motion continued for about 699 meters until the aircraft could no longer be easily moved and the pilot called for the fire trucks. The aircraft burnt to ashes on the spot.";16:23;Boeing 737-2K3;null;Sunday 22 February 1998

column3: there was no report or record of aircraft system malfunction and the aircraft was operated within the approved weight and balance envelope. On board the aircraft were two pilots and 11 passengers.

column1: The aircraft departed from in daylight conditions and cruised at an altitude of 10
column2: 500 feet. The aircraft was flying in an out through clouds when approaching Nabire.

column1: Over checkpoint BRAVO
column2: the pilot made initial contact with Nabire Tower controller and advised that the aircraft was descending and passed altitude of 6
column3: 600 feet.

column1: During descent after checkpoint BRAVO
column2: the pilot noticed development of clouds along the route and decided to avoid the clouds by deviating the aircraft track to the right of the GPS route.

column1: At about 4.5 Nm from NBR VOR/DME
column2: the flight monitoring system of the Spirit Avia Sentosa recorded the aircraft altitude was 2
column3: 000 feet.

column1: The PM noticed yellow on the aircraft GPS which meant the terrain was between 1
column2: 000 feet and 100 feet below the aircraft altitude and advised the PF. The PF decided to disengage the auto pilot
column3: reduced the rate of descend and continued to get visual reference on ground.

column1: The PM noticed an ""X"" symbol on the GPS which indicated a potential impact point and advised the PF. The PF was continuing the descent and then the second ""X"" appeared on the GPS. A few second later
column2: the PF noticed terrain ahead and pulled the aircraft. The left side of the aircraft impacted a tree.

column1: At about 2 Nm
column2: the pilot advised the controller of the aircraft position and requested to make a landing approach using runway 16. The controller approved the pilot request. The rest of the flight was uneventful and the aircraft landed safely using runway 16 at Nabire.

column1: No one injured in this occurrence and the aircraft was substantially damaged. Evidence of impact marks were found on the left side of the aircraft which were on the main landing gear strut

column3: wing and horizontal stabilizer";14:52;Cessna 208B Grand Caravan;Spirit Avia Sentosa;Monday 18 June 2018

31-jan-03;Ilyushin Il-76TD;RDPL-34141;Euro Asia Aviation;near Baucau-Cakun...;1986;Fatalities: 4 / Occupants: 4;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Damaged beyond repair;Approach (APR);Cargo;Macau Airport (MFM/VMMC)
column2: Macau;Baucau-English Madeira Airport (BCH/WPEC)
column3: East Timor;"The Ilyushin 76 departed Macau
column4: carrying 31 tons of telecommunications equipment for a Portuguese telephone company setting up operations in East Timor. Despite numerous attempts
column5: the copilot failed to contact Baucau ATS. The flight navigator then called Baucau Tower. A controller
column6: who was present at Baucau aerodrome at the time
column7: but not on operational duty
column8: advised the flight crew that ATS was not available and that landing would be at the discretion of the flight crew. The pilot in command diverted the aircraft from the published inbound track to the Baucau NDB
column9: and descended the aircraft below the published 10 NM MSA. He continued descending the aircraft through the commencement altitude for the published non-precision instrument approach for runway 14
column10: and through the LSALT.

column1: As the aircraft approached Baucau
column2: the flight crew decided to conduct an overflight of the aerodrome before making a landing approach
column3: and during the overflight
column4: the flight crew realised that the runway was not where they expected it to be. It appeared that the crew did not use the Baucau NDB but used selected data from their instrument approach charts to formulate a user-defined non-precision approach using the onboard global positioning system (GPS). Adding to this
column5: erroneous data on their Jeppesen charts meant the threshold of runway 14 was not where they thought it would be. Had the flight crew followed the non-precision runway 14 NDB approach procedure as published on either the CAD or Jeppesen charts
column6: and not descended below the relevant MDA(H) until visual flight was assured
column7: the position of the runway
column8: as depicted on the Jeppesen charts would have been irrelevant.

column1: During the overflight and the subsequent (first) landing approach
column2: the flight crew realised that the runway was not where they expected it to be as it was depicted on the Jeppesen charts. The pilot in command discontinued the landing approach
column3: and the flight navigator stated that he would apply a 4 km correction to position the aircraft for a second landing approach to where he thought the runway was located. By applying the 4 km correction
column4: the flight navigator was providing the pilot in command with inaccurate data
column5: and resulted in the aircraft being repositioned towards a point about 1.65 km (0.88 NM) northwest of the actual position of the threshold of runway 14. As the aircraft turned on to the final approach heading during the second landing approach
column6: the flight navigator stated that the aircraft was high on the approach profile
column7: based on his assumption of the location of the threshold of runway 14. The pilot in command increased the rate of descent of the aircraft to about 18 m/sec (3
column8: 543 fpm)
column9: and stated ‘Increased’. None of the other crewmembers commented on the high rate of descent
column10: or drew the pilot in command’s attention to the fact that the approach was unstabilised at that point.

column1: The flight engineer misinterpreted the pilot in command’s statement ‘Increased’ to be an instruction for him to increase the engine thrust
column2: and he advanced the thrust levers. It took about 2 seconds for the pilot in command to realise that engine thrust had been increased
column3: and he reacted by calling ‘No
column4: I increased vertical speed’ and reduced the engine thrust. The flight engineer’s action in increasing engine thrust was a significant distraction to the pilot in command at that stage of the flight
column5: and probably diverted his attention from the primary task of flying the aircraft to restoring the thrust to the proper setting.

column1: At about the same time
column2: the aircraft descended through 162 m
column3: which was the published MDH for a straight-in landing on the runway 14 NDB approach. Neither the pilot in command nor the copilot appeared to notice that the aircraft had descended through the MDH
column4: and it is probable that both were distracted by the flight engineer’s erroneous action.

column1: The high rate of descent continued unchecked until slightly less than 2 seconds before impact. It is probable that the pilot in command and the copilot were each unaware of the high rate of descent
column2: because neither was monitoring the flight instruments while they were looking ahead of the aircraft and trying to establish visual contact with the ground. The pilot in command applied back elevator to increase the aircraft pitch attitude in response to the co-pilot's urgent expression of concern that impact with terrain seemed almost certain. However
column3: the pilot in command did not simultaneously increase the engine thrust
column4: and it remained unchanged. The airplane impacted the ground. The right wingtip of the aircraft struck a partially constructed house and the aircraft broke up.";15:21;Ilyushin Il-76TD;Euro Asia Aviation;Friday 31 January 2003

column1: The flight departed Long Beach

column5: Canada. The flight time to Iqaluit was 5 hours and 36 minutes at a cruise altitude of 41 000 feet. The flight en route was uneventful; the outside temperature at the cruising altitude was approximately -60°C.

column1: The first officer was the pilot flying. An ILS/DME approach to runway 35 at Iqaluit was carried out with the autopilot on. column2: and the aircraft crossed the threshold at a speed of about 118 knots.

column3: but the aircraft continued to pull to the right. The aircraft departed the runway 4300 feet from the threshold and came to rest in packed snow 100 feet from the runway edge lights. The nose landing gear (NLG) came to rest in snow reaching the top of the wheel height

column3: Singapore;"Singapore Airlines flight SQ286 taxied to runway 05L at Auckland's International Airport and was cleared for takeoff. When the captain rotated the aeroplane for lift-off the tail struck the runway and scraped for some 490 metres until the aeroplane became airborne. The tail strike occurred because the rotation speed was 33 knots less than the 163 knots required for the aeroplane weight. The rotation speed had been mistakenly calculated for an aeroplane weighing 100 tonnes less than the actual weight of 9V-SMT. A takeoff weight transcription error
column4: which remained undetected
column5: led to the miscalculation of the takeoff

column1: data
column2: which in turn resulted in a low thrust setting and excessively slow takeoff reference speeds. The system defences did not ensure the errors were detected
column3: and the aeroplane flight management system itself did not provide a final defence against mismatched information being programmed into it.

column1: During the takeoff the aeroplane moved close to the runway edge and the pilots did not respond correctly to a stall warning.";15:28;Boeing 747-412;Singapore Airlines;Wednesday 12 March 2003

column3: Papua New Guinea;"The DHC-8-202 aircraft

column5: owned by Air Niugini and operated by LinkPNG
column6: completed flight PX713 from Bulolo to Port Moresby in Papua New Guinea. According to the Technical Log
column7: the aircraft was serviceable when it arrived at Port Moresby at 07:31 hours.

column1: The aircraft was scheduled for flight PX864
column2: from Port Moresby to Tari on the same day. The pilots carried out a normal pre-flight inspection of the aircraft before it was released to service by the licensed engineer on duty. After obtaining a clearance from air traffic control (ATC)
column3: P2-ANK departed from runway 14L at 09:04
column4: then made a right turn
column5: and commenced tracking on the 298°R of the Port Moresby VOR for Tari
column6: under IFR procedures. There were 28 passengers
column7: two pilots
column8: and one flight attendant on board. At about 09:20 while 39 nm west-northwest of Port Moresby and passing 20
column9: 000 ft during the climb
column10: both pilots heard a bang sound
column11: and felt the aircraft shudder.

column1: The copilot reported that he first thought that it was an engine failure. However
column2: visual checks of the engines and instrument gauges showed that both engines were operating normally. He then did a further quick scan of the instrument panel and said that he saw the ""unsafe left hand main landing gear door indication"" amber light illuminated. He said that he immediately advised the pilot in command (PIC). The copilot then informed ATC of their intention to return to Port Moresby
column3: and that a normal approach and landing was expected.

column1: The flight attendant then alerted both pilots that the left main landing gear door was open. That confirmed the reason for the illuminated left main landing gear door OPEN Advisory light. The PIC referred to the Quick Reference Handbook (QRH) as a precaution
column2: and descended to remain below 15
column3: 000 ft
column4: and not above 130 knots.

column1: At 10 nm from Port Moresby
column2: the copilot requested clearance from ATC to track west of Port Moresby to the Daugo Island area
column3: to hold for 30-40 minutes and burn-off fuel
column4: due to the maximum allowable landing weight.

column1: After burning off the excess fuel to achieve a landing weight of 15
column2: 650 kgs
column3: they requested a clearance from ATC to continue descent to Jacksons for a landing.

column1: After obtaining a clearance to land the copilot selected the landing gear down. With the landing gear fully extended
column2: the cockpit indication was three green lights illuminated. The copilot conducted a cross-check against the alternate landing gear selection
column3: which showed three green lights illuminated. They proceed to land
column4: assured that the nose- and main- landing gear were safe. At 10:46
column5: the aircraft landed on runway 14L
column6: and was cleared to cross runway 14R to the parking area.

column1: The PIC reported that it was at that moment they realized that everyone on the tarmac was looking at the aircraft
column2: particularly the left side. It wasn’t until the passengers and the crew disembarked
column3: that the crew were advised by the engineers that panels were missing aft of the left exhaust nacelle.

column1: Further inspection found that the left main landing gear number-two tyre was deflated and damaged. It was apparent that when the tyre blew out in the wheel well
column2: it caused substantial damage to the main structure on the inside of the nacelle. It was then the crew realised that the bang sound they heard was the tyre exploding in flight at 20
column3: 000 ft.";09:22;de Havilland Canada DHC-8-202Q Dash 8;LinkPNG;Friday 4 August 2017

column5: Canada;"A Beechcraft 1900C was damaged in a landing accident at Blue River Airport
column6: BC
column7: Canada. The aircraft sustained substantial damage.

column1: The occurrence flight was chartered by a travel agency on behalf of a wilderness adventure ski lodge. It was a regularly occurring charter flight between Vancouver and Blue River
column2: BC
column3: Canada.

column1: The travel agent verbally passed weather information to the flight crew. The captain understood that the runway had been plowed the previous day
column2: and that the weather had been good that morning in Blue River.

column1: Before departing Vancouver
column2: the flight crew had also obtained official weather data from regular flight planning sources. It was noted that although current conditions at Blue River were good
column3: a weather system was moving northbound
column4: and conditions in the area of Kelowna
column5: Kamloops (CYKA) (the alternate)
column6: and Blue River would begin to deteriorate. As the flight progressed
column7: the ski lodge radio room operator overheard the flight crew discussing weather conditions with a local helicopter pilot on the ATF as the flight overflew Blue River
column8: but the operator did not have any direct contact with the flight. The crew was satisfied with the information received from the helicopter pilot regarding local weather.

column1: Because the Blue River aerodrome does not have a published instrument approach procedure
column2: the intention was to fly over the aerodrome and proceed under visual flight rules (VFR) into the aerodrome. The flight progressed as planned until the aircraft passed overhead Blue River at the lowest useable IFR altitude
column3: and the pilot was not able to descend under VFR into Blue River.

column1: The pilot then climbed back up to an enroute IFR altitude and continued to Valemount Airport under IFR. After conducting the IFR approach into Valemount and finding the weather suitable for flight under VFR
column2: the aircraft completed the 60-nautical mile (nm) trip back to Blue River visually. The aircraft slowly descended in steps as it flew south towards Blue River at a reduced cruise speed of approximately 175 knots. As the aircraft neared the aerodrome
column3: the pilots descended to altitudes as low as 1100 feet above ground level (agl) to maintain visual contact with the ground in deteriorating weather. Approximately 4 nm from the aerodrome
column4: and 85 seconds before touchdown
column5: control was transferred from the first officer (FO) to the captain
column6: who became the pilot flying (PF).

column1: During the approach
column2: the crew rushed to complete the pre-landing checks
column3: visually acquire the runway
column4: and manoeuvre the aircraft to land. The captain turned slightly to the left
column5: away from the runway centreline. At this point
column6: the FO called visual contact with the runway
column7: and the captain turned right
column8: back towards the runway centreline
column9: and again passed through the runway centreline. The captain did not acknowledge that the runway was in sight.

column1: The aircraft was configured for landing 25 seconds prior to touchdown. As viewed from the pilot's perspective
column2: the aircraft was to the left of centreline. Several seconds later
column3: the aircraft initiated a right turn to line up with the centreline of runway 19
column4: but actually crossed to the right of the centreline. The aircraft then overflew several buildings on the right of the runway centreline
column5: approximately 75 feet adjacent to the runway threshold. The aircraft then turned sharply to the left as it passed abeam the threshold
column6: then sharply right to acquire the centreline before touching down approximately 2000 feet past the threshold. Immediately after touchdown
column7: the aircraft veered left into the snow bank.

column1: During the last 23 seconds of the flight
column2: the FO broadcast a traffic advisory to indicate that the aircraft was on final
column3: made 3 speed calls
column4: and advised the captain that the runway was to the left. There were no remarks made by the captain since the request for the landing checklist. The FO did not declare an unstable approach
column5: or prompt the captain to execute a missed approach.";11:29;Beechcraft 1900C;Northern Thunderbird Air;Saturday 17 March 2012

column1: According to the pilot-in-command (PIC)
column2: the flight departed on its third mission to disperse fire retardant over a nearby wildfire. During the airplane's climb
column3: the flight crew increased the airplane's nose up pitch by a few more degrees and the PIC subsequently responded with increasing nose down pressure. However
column4: the down pressure control input required additional force
column5: so the PIC used trim inputs to reduce the pressure. Moments later he observed an uncommanded aft movement of the control yoke with a simultaneous increase in the airplane's pitch attitude. He instructed the first officer (FO) to retract the flaps while he re-trimmed the elevator
column6: but they were not able to regain pitch control. The FO attempted to adjust his trim wheel and then re-trim the airplane using the emergency varicam
column7: but the airplane continued to maintain a pitch up attitude. He then deployed 5° of flaps at the PIC's instruction
column8: which reduced the elevator backpressure. The PIC subsequently jettisoned the load of fire retardant over vacant farm land and then asked the FO to declare an emergency with the tower controller while the PIC entered a shallow left turn to intercept the downwind leg for runway 21. As he made his control inputs he determined that the elevator was bound
column9: as he received little response from the elevator control.

column1: As the PIC had previously demonstrated the ability to land without making any adjustments to power or pitch in flight training
column2: he elected to configure the airplane for an approach without trim or elevator control. The flight crew flew a wide traffic pattern and made small adjustments to compensate for altitude. During the final approach leg
column3: the PIC used a combination of wing flaps and engine power for pitch up adjustments
column4: and the crew coordinated application of elevator for trimmed pitch and turns to make their pitch down adjustments. As the airplane reached about 500 feet above ground level
column5: the flight crew deployed the airplane's remaining 5° of flaps to increase the pitch attitude. Both the PIC and FO pulled hard on the yoke while the FO gently retarded the throttles and the PIC trimmed the emergency varicam.

column1: Postaccident examination of the airplane revealed damage to the varicam. As this secondary control surface is directly connected to the elevators and provides a primary structural load path for all elevator loads
column2: the damage was classified as substantial. Further examination of the varicam showed that one of the varicam actuator's outboard drive stop bolts had backed out of the drive coupling
column3: and that the two bolts had not been safety wired. The airplane did not sustain any damage during the airplane's landing.";20:00;Lockheed P2V-5F Neptune;Neptune Aviation Services;Saturday 5 August 2017

Shortly after takeoff the pilot requested a climb to 8000 feet msl due to icing. The pilot was issued a climb to 7000 feet msl. N868FE then contacted Minneapolis ARTCC and stated to the controller that he was not picking up any more ice at 7000 feet msl and that he was on top of the clouds. The pilot informed the controller that the ice he had picked up was mixed and that it was like wet droplets running back over the wing and freezing. The pilot of N868FE was instructed to contact Bismarck Approach who issued vectors and cleared the pilot for the ILS runway 31 approach. The pilot then contacted the Bismarck Tower and was cleared to land at 08:36. The pilot's acknowledgment was the last radio contact with the flight. The airplane impacted the terrain in a field approximately 1.6 miles from the end of runway 31. It appeared that the pilot completed his Caravan I Initial Pilot Training Course on March 27

10-feb-04;Fokker 50;EP-LCA;Kish Air;near Sharjah Airp...;1993;Fatalities: 6 / Occupants: 6;Fatalities: 37 / Occupants: 40;Damaged beyond repair;Approach (APR);International Scheduled Passenger;Kish Island Airport (KIH/OIBK)
column2: Iran;Sharjah Airport (SHJ/OMSJ)
column3: United Arab Emirates;"A Fokker 50 passenger plane
column4: operated by Kish Air
column5: was destroyed when it crashed near Sharjah Airport (SHJ)
column6: United Arab Emirates. All six crew members and 37 of the 40 passengers were killed.

column1: The aircraft was operating as a scheduled flight from Kish Island
column2: Iran to Sharjah
column3: UAE with the captain initially as the pilot flying (PF).

column1: During the cruise and just prior to descent
column2: the captain unexpectedly handed over control of the aircraft to the First Officer prior to the approach to Sharjah. The first officer did not accept this willingly and stated that he was not confident of his ability to conduct a VOR/DME approach into Sharjah. This statement was not consistent with his previous experience and could indicate either a cultural or professional issue. The captain insisted the first officer fly the aircraft and encouraged and instructed him during the approach.

column1: At 11:24 hours local time
column2: the aircraft contacted Dubai Arrivals and was cleared from 9000 ft to 5000 ft and instructed to expect a VOR/DME approach to runway 12 at Sharjah International Airport. At 11:29 hours the aircraft was further cleared to 2500 ft and cleared for the approach. The aircraft was under its own navigation and the daylight conditions were fine with excellent visibility. At 11:35 hours the aircraft was instructed to contact Sharjah Tower and the pilot reported that the aircraft was established on the VOR final approach for runway 12. The Tower cleared IRK7170 to land and advised that the wind was calm.

column1: At that point the aircraft was slightly above the approach profile. The initial speed for the approach was at least 50 kt high at approximately 190 kt with no flap and no landing gear. The aircraft should have been configured with landing gear down and flap 10° during the approach and stabilized at 130 kt prior to the MDA. Approaching the MDA at flight idle setting
column2: the auto-pilot was disengaged and the first Officer called for flap 10 at 186 kt (limiting speed of 180 kt) and flap 25 was selected by the Captain
column3: a setting uncalled for by the Pilot Flying at 183 kt (limiting speed of 160 kt)
column4: and the landing gear was called for and selected at approximately 185 kt (limiting speed of 170 kt). The captain then took control of the aircraft and shortly afterwards the ground range selectors were heard by Cockpit Voice Recorder to be lifted and the power levers moved from the flight idle stop into the ground control range.

column1: The left propeller then went to full reverse whilst the right propeller remained in positive pitch within the ground control range. column3: Italy;"An Airbus A320 of Wizz Air was damaged in a landing accident at Roma-Fiumicino Airport (FCO). There were 165 passengers and five crew members on board. Three occupants were injured.

column1: Flight W6-3141 departed Bucharest-Henri Coanda International Airport (OTP) about 06:45 hours local time (03:45 UTC) on an international passenger flight to Roma-Ciampino Airport (CIA).

The flight was approaching Ciampino Airport's runway 15 about 07:20 local time (05:20 UTC) when the crew encountered problems getting the undercarriage down and locked. A Master Warning occurred and a message was shown on the Electronic Centralized Aircraft Monitoring (ECAM) display
column2: which indicated ""L/G GEAR NOT DOWNLOCKED"".

column1: The crew flew a missed approach procedure and headed to an area north of Rome were it entered a holding pattern at an altitude of 5000 feet. The crew carried out a recycle and performed a gravity extension as well as some g-force manoeuvres
column2: but the left hand main landing gear remained stuck.

column1: The crew decided to divert to Rome-Fiumicino.
Approaching Rome-Fiumicino Airport runway 34R at 07:58 (05:58 UTC)
column2: the aircraft was instructed by the Tower controller to go-around due to some incoherency in the information provided by the crew about the current position of the landing gear. A new approach to runway 34R was performed and the aircraft touched down on the runway at 08:06 (06:06 UTC) with the left main gear only partially extended. The flightcrew shutoff the left engine just before touchdown and the right one a few seconds later.

column1: The aircraft came to rest after scraping the left engine on the runway for about 1200 m. An emergency evacuation was carried out.";08:06;Airbus A320-232;Wizz Air;Saturday 8 June 2013

column1: 06-MAR-2002;Fokker 100;N1425A;American Airlines;Dallas/Fort ...;;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 4;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 30;Substantial;Standing (STD);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport
column2: TX (DFW/KDFW)
column3: United States of America;Nashville Metropolitan Airport
column4: TN (BNA/KBNA)
column5: United States of America;"A Fokker 100 airplane
column7: operating as American Airlines Flight 334 experienced an uncontained rupture of the auxiliary power unit's (APU) turbine wheel while operating during de-icing procedures at the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW)
column8: Texas. The four crew members and thirty passengers were not injured.

column1: AA334 departed gate Alpha 14 at 06:33
column2: and taxied to ramp spot 22 for de-icing. The aircraft was parked at a northeast direction. The ground de-icing crew notified the flight crew to prepare for de-icing. Approximately ten minutes after de-icing began
column3: the captain reported that he heard and felt a ""thud-like"" noise from outside the aircraft. At the same time
column4: the APU shutdown. One of the de-icing crewmembers on the ground stated he saw a flame come from the APU exhaust and discharged the ground APU fire bottle. Approximately the same time
column5: the #2 flight attendant who was seated in the jumpseat at the rear of the cabin
column6: phoned the captain via the intercom and informed him that the emergency first aid kit sustained damage in the form of a three-inch hole in the back of the kit. The flight attendant stated that an apparent impact on the first aid kit had propelled it from the stowed position into the center aisle of the aircraft. The rear cabin jumpseat was located directly in front of the aft pressure bulkhead. The emergency first aid kit was stowed directly onto the aft wall of the cabin underneath the rear cabin jumpseat.

column1: Two spray trucks were used to de-ice the airplane with Type 1 de-icing fluid. The five-person crew consisted of a checker
column2: a driver for each truck
column3: and a spray bucket operator for each truck. The members of the de-icing crew stated that at the time they were de-icing the airplane
column4: the wind was blowing at 20 knots and gusting. Due to the windy conditions
column5: the drivers of the de-icing trucks had coordinated prior to de-icing the airplane to start at opposite ends of the airplane so the bucket operators would not be spraying each other as they de-iced the airplane. The bucket operators both stated that at times
column6: the wind was whipping the stream of de-icing fluid such that they could not even see the airplane
column7: let alone where the de-icing fluid was being sprayed. Bucket operator #1 stated that he had completed de-icing the nose
column8: right wing
column9: and right horizontal stabilizer of the airplane
column10: and had just started to de-ice the right side of the vertical fin
column11: when he heard a noise and saw that the APU was on fire. Bucket operator #2 stated that he had de-iced the left horizontal stabilizer
column12: the left side of the vertical fin
column13: and aft fuselage
column14: and after the truck was repositioned
column15: he had started to de-ice the left wing when the checker discovered the APU fire. The bucket operators stated that they knew where the F-100's APU air inlet was located
column16: and were aware that de-icing fluid should not be sprayed into the APU inlet.

column1: The Automated Surface Observing Station for DFW at 0700 reported winds from 320 degrees at 20 knots gusting to 27 knots
column2: visibility 2.5 statute miles in freezing rain and ice pellets
column3: overcast skies at 2
column4: 500 feet
column5: temperature minus 4 degrees Celsius
column6: dew point minus six degrees Celsius
column7: and an altimeter setting of 30.01 inches of Mercury.

column1: Examination of the airplane revealed APU damage
column2: which was located inside the tailcone. The turbine wheel was found fractured into five pieces. The fracture surfaces were coarse and grainy
column3: with no evidence of fatigue. The impeller was found intact and the impeller vane leading edges had nicks and gouges and were bent opposite the direction of rotation. Ridges on the rear face of the impeller were in line with the vanes on the front face. A fragment of the turbine wheel penetrated the aft pressure bulkhead
column4: and was found embedded in the first aid kit that was stored directly underneath the flight attendant's aft jump seat located at the rear of the cabin. Examination of the APU was conducted at American Airlines' maintenance facility in Tulsa
column5: Oklahoma. The examination revealed two large holes in the APU's compressor case in line with the turbine wheel's plane of rotation. The turbine wheel was broken into several pieces. The broken pieces of the turbine wheel were submitted to Honeywell's Materials Laboratory for a metallurgical examination that confirmed the APU had experienced an overspeed. Further examination did not reveal evidence of fatigue on any of the fracture surfaces. Additionally
column6: the containment ring was broken into three pieces.

column1: The APU has an electronic control unit (ECU) that meters fuel to the APU while it is in operation. The ECU monitors the rotor speed and will shut off fuel to the APU if it senses an overspeed
column2: which is 107 percent. The ECU was removed from the engine and shipped to Honeywell's Anniston
column3: Alabama facility to interrogate the ECU's non-volatile memory (NVM) and perform a diagnostic test. The NVM indicated that the APU had experienced an overspeed
column4: which is a rotor speed of 107 percent or greater
column5: and had commanded a shutdown. The diagnostic test showed that there were no discrepancies with the ECU.

column1: A review of American Airlines' de-icing training program showed that each of the 5 had completed annual refresher training in de-icing procedures for the F-100. During de-icing training
column2: personnel are advised not to spray the F-100 APU inlet area
column3: and crews are furnished diagrams of each type of airplane that highlight prohibited spray areas.

column1: In February 2001
column2: American Airlines issued a 'Winterization Bulletin' for the F-100 advising that de-ice spray should not be sprayed into the APU inlet. Additionally
column3: the F-100 maintenance manual section 12-31-00
column4: page 301 specifically advises
column5: ""Do not let de-icing and/or anti-icing fluid/water mixture go into the APU inlet. Injury to persons and/or damage to equipment can occur."" American Airlines' policy had been to operate the APU during de-icing. As a result of this event
column6: pilots were instructed to not operate the APU during de-icing operations
column7: and to refer to the operating manual and follow procedures for de-icing with an inoperative APU. De-icing crews were also informed of the change in de-icing procedures
column8: regarding the operation of the APU.

column1: As a result of this event
column2: on March 29
column4: the National Transportation Safety Board issued Safety Recommendation A-02-05 that recommended the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) immediately issue an airworthiness directive (AD) for the Fokker F-28 MK-100 and F-28 MK-4000 airplanes that prohibits APU operation during de-icing operations. The FAA issued AD 2001-07-03 that prohibits the operation of the APU during de-icing operations for all series of the F-28 airplane.";07:15;Fokker 100;American Airlines;Wednesday 6 March 2002

column1: The aircraft encountered icing conditions while en route to Lubbock. And although the airplane accumulated some ice during the flight that degraded its performance
column2: the NTSB determined that the aircraft could have landed safely had the airspeed been maintained.

column1: During the approach to Lubbock runway 17R
column2: at about 1400 feet above the ground and about 90 seconds from the runway
column3: the captain indicated a flight control problem saying
column4: ""We have no flaps."" Although the crewmembers had been trained to perform a go-around and refer to a checklist if a flap problem occurred during an approach
column5: the captain chose to continue the approach as he attempted to troubleshoot the flap anomaly while the first officer flew the plane. Neither flight crewmember adequately monitored the airspeed
column6: which decayed to the extent that the stick shaker activated
column7: which warned of an impending aerodynamic stall.

column1: The captain continued the unstabilized approach even though he received additional stick shaker activations and an aural ""pull up"" warning from the terrain awareness and warning system (TAWS). At that point
column2: the plane was descending at a rate of over 2
column3: 000 ft per minute.

column1: Although procedures for responding to either the stick shaker or the TAWS warning require the immediate application of maximum engine power
column2: the captain did not apply maximum power until 17 seconds after the TAWS warning. Seconds after maximum power was applied
column3: the airplane entered an aerodynamic stall and crashed.";04:37;ATR 42-320;null;Tuesday 27 January 2009
