column10: Indiana
column11: USA. The private pilot and passenger of the Cessna 150 sustained fatal injuries and the pilot and 4 passengers of the Cessna 525 were not injured. column1: Examination of the accident site showed that the Cessna 150 had struck the empennage of the Cessna 525 at the intersection of runways 15 and 22. Evidence at the intersection showed that the airplanes came together perpendicular to each other. The Cessna 150 then impacted the ground and a post-crash fire ensued. The Cessna 525 continued to roll out on runway 22.

Witnesses stated that they heard the Cessna 150 pilot on runway 15 UNICOM frequency. The surviving pilot of the Cessna 525 stated that he did not see the departing Cessna 150 while he was on a straight-in approach to runway 22
column2: nor did he see the 150 during the landing roll. He stated that he did not recall making a radio call on UNICOM
column3: but did utilize his on board Traffic Collision Avoidance System (TCAS) system while on approach. He stated that the TCAS did not show any traffic on the airport.

column1: Almost immediately the aircraft touched down it leaned to the right and there was an unusual noise. The commander levelled the aircraft with a left roll input.
However
column2: as the speed decayed the lean increased and it became apparent that there was a problem with the right gear. The commander continued to apply left aileron and rudder. column3: yawed to the right and slid sideways before it came to a stop 90° to the runway heading.

column3: the launcher and the droop leading edge on the wing were damaged

column4: United States of America;"Alitalia Flight 600 was approaching Newark (ERW) runway 04R in gusty crosswind

column6: and the airplane touched down with a 1.8 G load on the main landing gear
column7: followed 2 seconds later by a 2.8 G spike on the nose landing gear. After touchdown
column8: the first officer
column9: the flying pilot
column10: continued to push the control column forward
column11: and the airplane pitched nose down

column1: Examination of the airplane revealed that the nose landing gear trunnions remained attached to the bulkhead that they were affixed to; however
column2: the bulkhead was torn loose from surrounding structure. There were multiple broken stringers and cracked frames
column3: and wrinkled fuselage skin in the vicinity of the nose landing gear. In addition
column4: hydraulic lines were ripped and hydraulic fluid was sprayed into the electronic equipment bay. The cost of repairs was in excess of $20
column6: 000 US. The accident flight was the first officer's second trip into Newark

column1: The aircraft returned to Mogadishu where it landed safely at 08:53 UTC (11:53 hours local time).

column2: was booked on Turkish Airlines flight TK689
column3: which routes to Djibouti and Istanbul
column4: Turkey. Somali intelligence officials say two airport workers handled a laptop believed to have contained a bomb that later exploded in a passenger plane. They handed over the laptop to the passenger that was killed.

column1: Flight TK689 is scheduled to depart Mogadishu at 10:25 hours local time with a two-hour flying time to Djibouti. Flight D3159 departed about 11:30 hours.

On February 1 and 2 Turkish Airlines cancelled the return leg between Djibouti to Mogadishu. No known flights on this leg are known to have occurred in the 5 days after the attack. Airbus A320-232 TC-JBI was the aircraft that was scheduled to operate the February 2 flight.
The aircraft was ferried to Amman via Jeddah at low altitude (max FL120) on August 9
column2: 2016 and stored there.

column2: United Kingdom;?;The accident occurred during engine start after pushback from the stand. After the right generator came online an electrical failure occurred in the right main bus. The failure resulted in severe internal arcing and short circuits inside the two main power contactors of the right main bus. The heat generated during the failure resulted in the contactor casings becoming compromised
column3: causing molten metal droplets to fall down onto the insulation blankets below. The insulation blankets ignited and a fire spread underneath a floor panel to the opposite electrical panel (P205)
column4: causing heat and fire damage to structure
column5: cooling ducts and wiring. The flight crew responded to the bus failure and a burning smell by shutting down the right engine and taxiing to a nearby stand. The Airfield Fire Service attended the aircraft when it arrived on stand and entered the Main Equipment Centre where they discovered significant smoke but no fire. The passengers were evacuated uneventfully via steps.;10:00;Boeing 777-222ER;United Airlines;Monday 26 February 2007

column1: 28-jan-05;Learjet 35A;N911AE;Million Air;Kansas City-...;1977;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Ferry/positioning;Salt Lake City International Airport

column5: United States of America;"The Learjet 35A was operated as a positioning flight to Kansas City International Airport (MCI). Night instrument meteorological conditions prevailed at the time of the accident. The flight was en route to MCI to pick up passengers and continue on as an on-demand charter but diverted to the Kansas City-Charles B. Wheeler Downtown Airport (MKC) following the closure of MCI. MCI was closed due to a McDonnell Douglas MD83 sliding off a taxiway during an after landing taxi on contaminated runway/taxiway conditions. MKC held a limited airport certificate that did not have a snow removal plan and was served by runway 19 (7
column6: 002 feet by 150 feet
column7: grooved asphalt). Following a precision approach and landing on runway 19 at MKC
column8: the Learjet 35A slid off the departure end of the runway and impacted airport property and terrain. The Learjet 35A was operated with inoperative thrust reversers as per the airplane's minimum equipment list at the time of the accident. About 1:05 hours before the accident
column9: runway 19 Tapley values were recorded as 21-22-22 with 1/2 inch of wet snow. About 17 minutes before the accident
column10: MKC began snow removal operations. About 7 minutes before the accident
column11: the MKC air traffic control tower (TWR) instructed the snow removal vehicles to clear the runway for inbound traffic. TWR was advised by airport personnel that runway 19 was plowed and surface conditions were 1/4 inch of snow of snow; friction values were not taken or reported. While inbound
column12: the Learjet 35A requested any braking action reports from TWR. The first airplane to land was a Cessna 210 Centurion
column13: and the pilot reported braking action to the TWR as ""moderate""
column14: which was then transmitted by TWR as ""fair"" from a Centurion in response to the Learjet 35A's query. The Cessna 210 Centurion pilot did not use brakes during landing and did not indicate this to TWR during his braking action report.";22:17;Learjet 35A;Million Air;Friday 28 January 2005

column4: Japan;"Gulfstream Aerospace G-IV
column5: registered JA001G
column6: operated by the Japan Civil Aviation Bureau of the Ministry of Land
column7: Infrastructure
column8: Transport and Tourism (MLIT)
column9: took off from Obihiro Airport at 11:16 hours local time. Purpose of the flight was to carry out flight inspections to confirm the required performance of aeronautical navigation facilities. The captain was Pilot Flying.

column1: While the aircraft was flying south-southwest on Airway V31 toward the Niigata VORTAC at an altitude 9
column2: 000 ft
column3: the captain and the first officer sighted a lower layer of clouds but had visually confirmed that there was no cloud on the flight route in the vicinity of Niigata Airport. At about 14:32
column4: the aircraft commenced a descending turn from right above Niigata Airport in order to inspect on the next airway. At this time
column5: the captain and the first officer had checked on an indication on the weather radar display of the aircraft showing a precipitation area
column6: albeit not on their route
column7: and were therefore focusing attention in that direction. They then encountered scattered thin clouds
column8: but this was judged not to be thick clouds which might lead to turbulence or thunder. At about 14:35
column9: as the aircraft entered the thin cloud at an altitude about 6
column10: 500 ft
column11: a very loud noise was heard on the radio equipment while the captain
column12: the first officer and the onboard maintenance engineer were listening to it. After three to four seconds
column13: the captain and the first officer received an impact accompanied by a loud popping noise
column14: together with a strong flash from the front of the aircraft.

column1: While continuing the flight
column2: the captain and the first officer checked the instruments to check whether abnormality had occurred to the aircraft; consequently
column3: they confirmed that discoloration was found on some of the cockpit instrument displays
column4: and that the airborne DME (Distance Measuring Equipment) display on the captain's side had disappeared. However
column5: there was no abnormality in the DME display on the first officer's side and there was no problem with the visibility of the discolored instrument displays; accordingly
column6: they judged there to be no serious abnormality which would affect the flight.

column1: The captain
column2: the first officer and the onboard maintenance engineer discussed whether they should continue the flight inspection
column3: and although there was thought to be no hindrance to the flight
column4: they decided to suspend the flight and return to the base of the aircraft at Tokyo International Airport
column5: because they could not confirm damage to the airframe while on board. Thereafter the aircraft landed at Tokyo International Airport at 15:26. On the post-flight inspection
column6: damage was confirmed to the left front fuselage outer skins
column7: the front lower fuselage and the left horizontal stabilizer.";14:35;Gulfstream G-IV;Japan Civil Aviation Bureau;Friday 13 March 2015

column3: Indonesia;"Flight 421 departed Mataram around 15:00 and climbed to the cruising altitude of FL310. During the initial descent the crew decided to deviate from the planned route because of thunderstorms along their planned route. At 16:19 the flight encountered an area of severe turbulence and thunderstorm activity with extremely heavy precipitation and hail. The crew attempted to fly towards a gap between two storm cells. About 90 seconds after entering the thunderstorm
column4: as the airplane descended through about FL180 at a flight idle power setting
column5: both engines flamed out. The crew carried out three unsuccessful attempts to restart the engines followed by one unsuccessful attempt to start the auxiliary power unit (APU). The flight crew’s reported actions to restart the engines and APU however
column6: were contrary to the procedures contained in the Boeing 737 Operations Manual. For instance
column7: they waited only about 1 minute between each restart attempt instead of three minutes.

column1: As the airplane descended below an overcast cloud layer at about 8
column2: 000 feet
column3: the crew observed the Bengawan Solo River and decided to attempt to ditch the airplane into the river with flaps and landing gear in a shallow
column4: 1 metre deep part of the river. One stewardess did not survive the crash.

column1: Similar occurrences (Boeing 737-300 double engine flameout while descending in heavy precipitation with engines at flight idle) happened May 24
column2: 1988 and July 26
column3: 1988. Following these incidents OMB 88-5 and AD 6-14-88 were issued to require minimum rpm of 45% and to restrict the use of autothrust in moderate/heavy precipitation; engine modification was provided for increased capacity of water ingestion.";16:29;Boeing 737-3Q8;Garuda Indonesia Airways;Wednesday 16 January 2002

column5: the crew had a momentary problem setting power on the starboard engine after which the flight continued normally to Abuja.

column1: The aircraft which departed Abuja for Jos (JOS) at 09:00 hours UTC first officer at the controls. At FL 90 and about 30NM from Abuja
column2: the crew again had problems with the cruise power setting on the starboard engine. The torque remained at 1400. The crew retarded the right power lever to the minimum with the aim of achieving a cruise setting of 1300 but the gear warning came on. The Commander at this stage took over the controls from the first officer. At 09:23 hours UTC
column3: the aircraft contacted Kaduna Tower that it would be diverting to Kaduna (KAD) giving its flight level as 90 at a distance of 61 miles and estimating TMA at 24 miles
column4: 'KC' at 41 miles
column5: 6 souls on board and 5 hours endurance at departure. The tower then gave the aircraft an inbound clearance to 'KC' locator maintaining FL 90 and to expect no delay for a locator approach runway 05. Weather report at 09:00 hours UTC was also passed to the aircraft as wind 090/05 knots
column6: QNH 1014 and temperature 30°C. At 09:28 hours UTC the airplane at about 42 miles
column7: speed between 150-160 kts
column8: requested descent and was cleared to 4
column9: 500ft
column10: QNH 1014. At about 09:35 hours UTC
column11: the pilots contacted tower that they would make a single engine approach because they were having problems controlling power on the starboard engine and it would be shut down.

column1: The commander then reviewed the single engine approach with the first officer estimating 4
column2: 500 ft at 8NM. Approaching 4
column3: 500 ft at 11 NM
column4: the crew initiated right engine shut down after which the speed was decayed from 150 to 140 kts. At 09:46 hours UTC
column5: the pilot reported 6nm final and field in sight while the tower requested him to report 4 miles final. The controller reported having the aircraft in sight and subsequently cleared it to land on runway 05 giving wind as north easterly 06 knots. Descending at 500ft/min
column6: the commander requested for 25% of flap when the first officer selected full flap. When the aircraft was at 2
column7: 700 ft high
column8: the speed had already decayed to between 100 - 110 kts. The crew applied full power on the port engine to arrest the speed decay but to no avail. The pilot was trying to correct the descent rate
column9: speed decay and the asymmetry when the stall warning came on.

column1: The aircraft was cleared for a runway 07 ILS approach
column2: but the approach was abandoned due to indications that the undercarriage was not down and locked. The flight crew concluded that all gear were down and locked despite a red GEAR light on the forward instrument panel. The crew had failed to recognize that the green GEAR DOWN light for the nose gear was not illuminated and assumed that the red GEAR light on the forward instrument panel was a false indication. The gear was recycled
column3: but an alternate extension was not attempted.

column1: The pilot positioned the airplane for another approach. The aircraft touched down with the nose gear retracted. The nose struck the runway. The plane skidded and came to rest at 7000 feet down the runway (which is 13050 feet long). As the pilot informed the ATC of the mishap

column3: flames erupted in the front portion of the aircraft. One of the crewmembers came down through a rope ladder from the cockpit

column1: The flight crew was in cruise flight when a master caution light illuminated indicating a loss of the right hydraulic system pressure and hydraulic fluid. The crew used the checklist to trouble shoot the system and attempted to manually extend the main and nose landing gear (NLG) using the alternate extension control lever. Both main gear extended and locked into place; however the NLG did not extend. The airplane was landed with the NLG in the retracted position. Initial inspection of the airplane revealed that a B-nut to the check valve on the rudder power hydraulic shut off valve
column2: was separated from the valve resulting in a total loss of right hydraulic quantity and pressure. Examination of the hydraulic tube
column3: including the B-nut and check valve
column4: did not reveal any abnormalities. Examination of the cockpit revealed the landing gear handle was in the stowed position. A placard on the alternate landing gear extension lever stated
column5: ""Pull up forcibly Full Stroke."" The airplane was placed on jacks and maintenance personnel successfully extended the nose landing gear. The alternate gear extension control system was also inspected and no defects were noted.";16:16;McDonnell Douglas DC-9-83 (MD-83);Allegiant Air;Thursday 29 March 2007

column1: Before departure from Shoreham Airport
column2: U.K
column3: the pilot had called the destination airport
column4: Trier-Föhren. He was told it would be better to postpone the departure because of thick fog. The departure was not postponed and the Citation jet took off from Shoreham about 10:00 hours. Alternate airfields were Luxembourg and Frankfurt-Hahn. Given the weather conditions the owner of the aircraft expected a diversion
column5: and according to family members did not but pressure on the pilots to land at Trier.

column1: The en route and descent part of the flight were uneventful. At 11:45
column2: while descending from FL90 to 5000 feet
column3: the pilot in command contacted air traffic control to cancel their IFR clearance. The controller confirmed this and reported that they were 15 miles northwest of their destination airfield.

column1: The airplane was approaching runway 22 and descended until it was flying at a very low altitude
column2: clearing trees by some 15-20 meters
column3: according to eyewitnesses. It pulled up and struck an electricity pylon at a height of about 8 m above the ground. Control was lost and the airplane rolled inverted and crashed. It came to rest inverted on the site of a landfill
column4: located 3
column5: 8 km from the threshold of runway 22 and about 700 m to the left of the extended centreline. A fire erupted.

column1: The continued descent to the ground likely occurred due to an erroneous selection of the target altitude with 0 ft (sea level) instead of the real aerodrome elevation (666 ft AMSL). Good Crew Resource Management could have brought this error to light but the different personality traits of the two pilots and particularly the captain’s low appreciation of the co-pilot probably negatively
influenced the working relationship in regards to CRM principles.

column2: wind 040° at 3-5 knots
column3: temperature -1°C
column4: QNH 1020 hPa.";11:52;Cessna 501 Citation I/SP;Theo Steil GmbH;Sunday 12 January 2014

column3: Nepal;"An Airbus A330-303

column6: Nepal.

column1: Flight TK726 was a regular passenger service from Istanbul-Atatürk International Airport (IST) to Kathmandu
column2: Nepal. The flight was the first international flight to scheduled to arrive that morning. After descending from cruising altitude
column3: it entered a holding pattern at FL210 at 06:12 hours local time (00:27 UTC) until about 07:00 (01:15 UTC) when it was cleared for a VOR/DME approach to runway 02. This approach was abandoned at about the Missed Approach Point at 1DME and the aircraft performed a go around. The aircraft circled and positioned for a second approach to runway 02. The aircraft touched down to the left of the runway centerline with the left hand main gear off the paved runway surface. It ran onto soft soil and the nose landing gear collapsed.

column1: The aircraft touched down at to the left of the centerline because the FMGS NAV database contained threshold coordinates for a proposed displacement of the runway 02 threshold. This was later withdrawn through a NOTAM
column2: but had not been updated by the airline in the FMGS. Additionally
column3: the coordinates that were initially published were inaccurate
column4: causing the threshold coordinates to be offset to the left of the actual threshold. This had been noticed and reported by a previous Turkish Airlines flight on March 2. The changes to the FMGS had not been performed by the time TC-JOC landed at Kathmandu.";07:44;Airbus A330-303;THY Turkish Airlines;Wednesday 4 March 2015

column2: opb Van Air Europe;Isle Of Man-...;1990;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 3;None;Landing (LDG);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Isle Of Man-Ronaldsway Airport (IOM/EGNS)
column3: United Kingdom;Belfast City Airport (BHD/EGAC)
column4: United Kingdom;"A Let L-410
column5: OK-LAZ
column6: was operated by Czech carrier Van Air Europe
column7: on behalf of Citywing
column8: an Isle of Man-based virtual airline that sold seats on flights operated by Van Air.

column1: On February 23
column3: the aircraft was due to operate a return flight from Isle Of Man-Ronaldsway Airport (IOM) to Belfast City Airport
column4: Northern Ireland. The scheduled departure time was 07:15 UTC and the return flight was scheduled to arrive back at IOM at 08:50.

column1: Overnight and into the morning of the 23 February
column2: Storm Doris underwent explosive cyclogenesis. The centre of the storm moved rapidly through Northern Ireland in the early hours
column3: across northern England and out into the North Sea by the early afternoon.

column1: Strong winds were forecast for the area. The surface wind at Belfast
column2: where runways 04 and 22 were available
column3: was reported at 06:20 to be from 230° at 9 kt but
column4: because they received no TAF for this destination
column5: the pilots selected two alternate airports; Belfast International Airport and IOM.

column1: The latest weather information at IOM showed a wind from 230° at 32 kt gusting to 45 kt
column2: creating a maximum crosswind component of 22 kt. The relevant maximum demonstrated crosswind component for the Let L-410 is 19.4 kt and this was included in the ‘Performance Limitations’ section of the Airplane Flight Manual (AFM) but the aircraft operator did not apply a limiting component of crosswind to its operations. The only wind limit that was applied and used by the crew was 45 kt for ground operation.

column1: When the wind changed to 260° at 39
column2: gusting to 55 kt
column3: the flight was delayed because this exceeded the ground operation limit

column1: Departure
At 07:50 the crew learnt the wind was from 290° at 31 G 40 kt and as both these more recent reports were within the ground operation limit
column2: they decided to depart
column3: with 550 kg of fuel on board.

column1: Three passengers boarded and the aircraft taxied at 08:10. Shortly afterwards
column2: at the request of Belfast City ATC
column3: the crew were informed that the wind was from 320° at 31 G 46 kt
column4: and IOM ATC asked the crew for their intentions because Belfast City ATC had reported no other known aircraft movements. The crew elected to continue the flight and took off on runway 26 at 08:23 hrs
column5: when the reported wind was from 290° at 21 G 41 kt. The co-pilot was the Pilot Flying (PF) and the commander was Pilot Not Flying (PNF).

column1: No difficulties were encountered en route to Belfast.
When the PNF contacted Belfast City ATC
column2: he was told radar vectoring was available for an ILS approach to runway 04 and that the wind was now from 320° at 28 G 43 kt. The PNF informed ATC they would make one approach but would go around if the approach was not stable.

column1: The crew reported afterwards that they experienced continuous moderate turbulence during the latter part of the approach. The final wind check
column2: given after they had been cleared to land
column3: was from 320° at 35 kt. They judged that the aircraft operator’s stable approach criteria were met until the aircraft passed over the runway threshold
column4: when turbulence de-stabilised the aircraft and they initiated a go-around.

column1: ATC reported that the aircraft went around from approximately 20 ft above the runway at 08:58 hrs and climbed straight ahead to 3
column2: 000 ft amsl
column3: the standard missed approach procedure. The aircraft continued heading northeast until 09:01 hrs when the PNF informed ATC they would not make a second approach and would return to IOM.

column1: Return
Once level at FL070
column2: the PNF listened to the ATIS for the IOM
column3: which stated runway 26 was in use
column4: it was wet
column5: and detailed the 0850 METAR
column6: which noted that the wind was from 290° at 28 kt. The PF briefed for an approach with the flaps set to 18°
column7: and a target VREF of 105 kt; with a ""slightly right crosswind"". After the brief was completed he commented on the intercom that the wind was ""not so challenging"" at IOM but shortly after this ATC provided a special weather observation
column8: timed at 09:12 hrs
column9: which stated the wind was now from 310° at 41 kt and gusting between 22 and 53 kt. When asked by ATC if they wished to make an approach
column10: the PNF replied ""of course"". The crew accepted radar vectoring for an ILS approach to runway 26
column11: with the co-pilot remaining as PF. Before the aircraft was directed towards its final approach
column12: ATC reported the wind was from 310° at 43 kt but gusting between 23 and 63 kt.

column2: after the aircraft had become established on the ILS centreline and glideslope
column3: ATC radioed clearance to land
column4: with a reported wind of 300° at 41 kt but gusting between 31 and 63 kt. While receiving this message
column5: the crew were also presented with an aural ""glideslope"" caution and immediately after this the PF declared ""1
column6: 000 ft stabilised"". While the PNF was adjusting the propeller rpm
column7: another aural ""glideslope"" caution was annunciated and the PF immediately stated ""correcting"". Following an automatically generated message stating the aircraft was at 500 ft agl
column8: one further ""glideslope"" caution was annunciated and the PF responded saying ""correcting
column9: runway in sight"".

column1: The final wind check provided by ATC
column2: approximately 35 seconds before the aircraft touched down
column3: was from 300° at 48 kt
column4: but gusting between 32 kt and 63 kt.

column1: Landing
Given the environmental conditions
column2: ATC was concerned for the safety of the aircraft and its occupants when it landed
column3: so the airfield Rescue and Fire Fighting Service (RFFS) had been placed on alert with two vehicles facing towards the runway
column4: approximately 200 m from the touchdown zone. During the aircraft’s approach
column5: ATC discussed the situation with the Isle of Man Civil Aviation Administration because another of the same operator’s aircraft had been blown onto its wingtip while taxiing in 2007
column6: in winds greater than 45 kt
column7: and both parties knew 45 kt was now the operator’s maximum ground operation limit.

column1: As the aircraft crossed the threshold it seemed unstable and it rolled considerably
column2: causing the tip of the left wing (the downwind wing) to tilt down until it seemed in close proximity to the runway
column3: before the wheels made first contact. The aircraft then bounced and rolled left again before touching down for a second time
column4: on all three wheels.

column1: After travelling along the runway for approximately 20 m
column2: the right mainwheel was seen to lift off the ground and nearby RFFS witnesses estimated the left wingtip rolled to within one metre of the runway surface. The crew seemed aware of this roll because
column3: approximately nine seconds after touchdown
column4: the PF stated ""ailerons...good...too much roll"".

column1: After landing the commander took control and the co-pilot commented ""taxi carefully with the wind"". ATC then stated the surface wind was from 300° at 47 kt
column2: but gusting between 32 kt and 63 kt and asked if they wished to taxi or to hold on the runway. The crew replied ""we will try and taxi and if we can make it we will vacate
column3: otherwise we need to leave the aircraft here"". The crew then accepted taxi instructions directing them towards the terminal but
column4: 45 seconds later
column5: as the aircraft was leaving the runway
column6: ATC radioed to the crew
column7: ""direction from Isle of Man CAA
column8: hold position."" The aircraft stopped facing into the wind. Both ATC and the Isle of Man Civil Aviation Administration later indicated that they were concerned that if the aircraft continued to taxi with the wind gusting to 63 kt an accident could occur.

column1: RFFS vehicles were positioned around the aircraft
column2: to provide some screening from the wind
column3: and a bus transferred the three uninjured passengers to the terminal building. The aircraft was later tied down until the wind subsided.";09:27 UTC;Let L-410UVP-E;null;Thursday 23 February 2017

column3: Algeria;"The Sonatrach company chartered one of Tassili Airlines' Beechcraft 1900D planes to fly two employees from the oil fields near the Algerian Sahara town of Hassi R'Mel to Ghardaïa. The copilot was Pilot Flying. The Beech took off at 20:30 and arrived near Ghardaïa fourteen minutes later.

column1: At 20:44 the flight was cleared for a right hand circuit in preparation for an approach to runway 30. At that moment a Boeing 727 was on long finals. The copilot stated that he intended to carry out an NDB/ILS approach to runway 30. The captain however preferred a visual approach. The copilot carried out the captain's course and descent instructions with hesitation. At 20:57
column2: the EGPWS alarm sounded. Power was added and a climb was initiated from a lowest altitude of 240 feet above ground level.

column1: The captain then took over control and assumed the role of Pilot Flying. The airplane manoeuvred south of the airport until 21:01 when the copilot saw the runway. The captain rolled left to -57° and pitched down to -18.9° in order to steer the airplane towards the runway. Again the EGPWS sounded but the descent continued until the airplane impacted the ground and broke up.
The five occupants survived the impact
column2: but the co-pilot died a day later of his injuries.";21:01;Beechcraft 1900D;Tassili Airlines;Wednesday 28 January 2004

column1: 06-MAR-2009;National Aerospace Laboratories (NA;VT-XRM;National Aerospace Laboratories;near Bidadi;2007-04-20  (1 year 11 months);Fatalities: 3 / Occupants: 3;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;En route (ENR);Test;Bangalore-Hindustan Airport (BLR/VOBG)
column2: India;Bangalore-Hindustan Airport (BLR/VOBG)
column3: India;"A National Aeronautical Laboratories Saras prototype
column4: an Indian designed light civilian transport aircraft
column5: registered VT-XRM
column6: was destroyed in a accident during a test flight. All three crew members were killed.

column1: The Saras airplane was scheduled for carrying out test flight no 49
column2: which would include inflight engine shut down and relight procedure at 10000 feet AMSL.

column1: The aircraft took-off from Bangalore-Hindustan Airport (BLR) at 14:55. The flight was cleared to flight level 100. After completing general handling checks at 9000’AMSL without any events
column2: a single engine simulated approach was carried out on runway 09. At about 15:11 the crew were cleared to perform an overshoot.

column1: The crew contacted the Bangalore Radar controller
column2: who cleared them back to FL100 and proceed to sector Southwest 2 for carrying out the engine relight test procedure. The crew reported reaching 9000’AMSL in sector Southwest at about 15:18.

column1: The no. 1 engine was then shut down and secured following the test procedure at about 15:31. After about 47 seconds
column2: the no. 1 engine relight procedure was initiated at around 9200’AMSL.

column1: After a successful left engine shut down and its securing procedure
column2: at about 15:31 left engine relight procedure was initiated at about 9200’AMSL. The propeller blade pitch was selected from feathered to fine. This led to an increased in propeller rpm from 5 to 55%. Side slip increased up to 28 degrees and bank angle changed from 8 deg right to 70 degrees left. The pitch attitude was seen reaching -42 degrees. Propeller rpm continued to increase to 91%. Then the aircraft went into a sudden dive from 9200’ to 7300’ for about 13 secs. The aircraft was brought under control at this altitude. The crew continued their attempt to relight the engine but this was not successful. Meanwhile the side slip remained at 22 degrees with a pitch attitude of about -15 deg. The speed remained at 130 kt and altitude reduced from 7000 feet to 5200 feet.

column1: A second relight attempt was successful but the airplane was still in a rapid descent passing 4800 feet. Rudder pedal forces

increased to as high as 90 kg with aileron forces raising to 40 kg. The crew were not able to fully control the airplane and arrest the descent. It impacted the ground. The aircraft was completely destroyed due impact and fire.";15:34;National Aerospace Laboratories (NAL) Saras;National Aerospace Laboratories (NAL);Friday 6 March 2009

column5: Canada;"Peace Air Ltd. Flight PE905 departed Grande Prairie (CYQU) at 10:40 MST on the first leg of a scheduled run to Fort St. John (CYXJ)
column6: Fort Nelson
column7: BC
column8: and Grande Prairie.

column1: Air traffic control (ATC) cleared the flight to maintain 12 000 feet above sea level (asl)
column2: and to hold on the TAYLOR non directional beacon (NDB)
column3: which forms the final approach fix for the instrument landing system (ILS) approach to runway 29 at St. John. At 11:09
column4: Flight PE905 was cleared for an ILS approach to runway 29. The first approach was discontinued due to the aircraft being too high on the final approach leg
column5: and clearance was given to return to the TAYLOR NDB at 6000 feet. At 11:23
column6: ATC cleared the flight for another ILS approach to runway 29. The second approach was conducted as a full procedure with the outbound leg extended to ensure that the aircraft was positioned to follow the correct vertical approach profile.

column1: The final approach course was flown with a flap setting of 20º and at the company standard operating procedure (SOP) recommended airspeed of 130 knots. At approximately 300 feet above ground level
column2: the first officer informed the captain that he had the ground in sight. The approach lights were visual shortly thereafter. The captain discontinued his instrument scan and confirmed the appearance of the approach lights. The captain made the decision to land
column3: and called for the full flap setting of 35º. The first officer diverted his attention to setting flaps
column4: and to the Vref reference cards clipped to the instrument panel. When he looked up
column5: the aircraft was almost on the ground
column6: but short of the runway. There was insufficient time to warn the captain.

column1: The aircraft initially touched down in a nearly wings-level attitude
column2: 320 feet short of the threshold in about 16 inches of packed snow. The left main gear contacted the surface first
column3: followed by the right main gear
column4: and then the nose wheel. The aircraft then struck the last set of approach lights
column5: bounced slightly
column6: and touched down again 180 feet short of the threshold. After sliding through the threshold lights
column7: the aircraft came to rest on the right edge of the runway
column8: 380 feet beyond the threshold. The right main gear had broken off
column9: and the nose gear had collapsed rearward. Both propellers were damaged by ground contact. The aircraft was equipped with a belly-mounted cargo pod
column10: which supported the fuselage during impact.";11:33;British Aerospace 3112 Jetstream 31;Peace Air;Tuesday 9 January 2007

column1: The pilot reported that the airplane was climbing through 7
column2: 000 feet msl when he heard an explosion followed by a metal grinding noise coming from the engine section of the airplane. He felt the airplane vibrate

column4: 000 feet msl and set the flaps to 20-degree so that the 14 skydivers could exit the airplane. He attempted a forced landing to runway 18 (3
column5: 433 feet by 40 feet

column9: and did not perform the borescope inspections that were recommended by the engine manufacturer's SIL.";ca 10:30;Cessna 208B Grand Caravan;SkyDive Greensburg;Sunday 1 June 2008

column1: 3-jul-13;Canadair CL-415;C-FIZU;Gov. of Newfoundland and Labrador;Moosehead La...;2010;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Takeoff (TOF);Fire fighting;Wabush Airport
column2: NL (YWK/CYWK)
column3: Canada;Wabush Airport
column4: NL (YWK/CYWK)
column5: Canada;"On the day before the accident
column6: the flight crew had completed 53 water-drop flights at a forest fire located northeast of Wabush
column7: Newfoundland and Labrador. Each flight
column8: typically about 3 minutes long
column9: consisted of scooping water from Moosehead Lake
column10: dropping the water on the fire
column11: and then returning for another water scoop.

column1: All flights were made with the PROBES AUTO/MANUAL switch in the AUTO selection. The switch was left in this position at the end of these flights.
At about 14:00 on the day of the accident
column2: the flight crew were deployed to the same forest fire that they had been working on the day before. The captain was the pilot flying (PF) for the occurrence flight and occupied the left seat. The captain removed the centre pedestal cover during the pre-flight preparations. The first officer
column3: who was the pilot not flying (PNF)
column4: completed the exterior walk-around and carried out the pre-flight cockpit checks.

column1: The aircraft had 7000 pounds of fuel and 1000 pounds of chemical foam on board. Utilizing this information
column2: the water-drop control computer determined the maximum quantity of water to be scooped.

column1: The flight crew considered the wind speed and direction and decided to follow the same practice as the previous day and scoop water from Moosehead Lake.
After takeoff
column2: the PNF was required to complete the ""After Takeoff"" checklist
column3: and in preparation for scooping water
column4: to complete the ""Water Bombing in Range"" and ""Pick-up"" checklists.

column1: About 4 minutes after takeoff
column2: the aircraft touched down about 1250 feet from the eastern shore of the lake
column3: on a heading of 250°. The PF then applied takeoff power
column4: and the PNF began adjusting the torque limit stops. Throughout the scooping run
column5: the PNF was focused on ensuring that the soft stops were set as per the PF's instructions.

column1: While adjusting the soft stops
column2: the PNF noted that the water tanks were completely full
column3: and advised the PF that the probes were still down and the PROBE AUTO/MANUAL switch was in the MANUAL selection. The PNF then manually selected the probes up. The probes retracted about 3490 feet after touchdown.

column1: The flight crew continued the takeoff despite indication by the water status display panel that water quantity was in excess of that allowable for this takeoff.
At the time the probes were retracted
column2: the aircraft was about 2500 feet from the departure-end shoreline of the lake. The PF determined that the aircraft would require a greater distance to become airborne and initiated a left turn to follow the lake. About 2 seconds later
column3: the aircraft’s hull began to lift out of the water
column4: and the left float contacted the water.

column1: For the next 4 seconds
column2: aileron and rudder control surface deflections commanded a left turn; however
column3: during this time
column4: the aircraft was skidding to the outside of the turn. The float remained in contact with the water
column5: and the aircraft‘s hull was completely out of the water. The PF deflected the elevators up to near full deflection
column6: with no corresponding response in pitch attitude
column7: and then initiated a right turn using ailerons
column8: with no response to this input.

column1: About a second later
column2: the aircraft’s hull was about 7 feet above the water
column3: with the float still in contact with the water. The float separated from its pylon
column4: resulting in a sudden pitch-down moment.

column1: The forward section of the hull collided with the water
column2: causing the lower part of the forward fuselage to tear open. The right wing float collided with the water
column3: causing complete separation of the right float and pylon. The aircraft came to rest upright
column4: with the cockpit partially underwater. The flight crew briefly delayed their evacuation until the propellers had stopped rotating.

column1: The PNF retrieved a life vest and evacuated the aircraft through the overhead escape hatch. Once on top of the aircraft
column2: the PNF donned the life vest. The PF could not retrieve a life vest and exited the aircraft through the left-side sliding window.

column1: The flight crew remained on the wing as the aircraft continued to sink. The PNF contacted company personnel by cellular telephone and advised them of the situation. Within about 30 minutes
column2: Department of Natural Resources employees arrived by boat and transported the flight crew to shore.

column1: The aircraft settled on the lake bottom
column2: about 225 feet from the southern shore of the lake.

column1: Neither pilot attempted to remotely activate the emergency locator transmitter (ELT)
column2: shut down the engines or select electrical power OFF.";14:15;Canadair CL-215-6B11 (CL-415);Government of Newfoundland and Labrador;Wednesday 3 July 2013

column1: 6-feb-07;Beech 200C Super King Air;VQ-TIU;Air Turks & Caicos;near North Caicos...;1989;Fatalities: 1 / Occupants: 1;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 5;Damaged beyond repair;Initial climb (ICL);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;North Caicos Airport (NCA/MBNC)

column3: Turks and Caicos Islands;"A Beechcraft 200C Super King Air
column4: VQ-TIU
column5: crashed soon after takeoff from North Caicos Airport (NCA)
column6: at the start of a flight bound for Grand Turk Island Airport (GDT)
column7: Turks and Caicos Islands. On board were one pilot and five passengers. The pilot received fatal injuries in the accident; the passengers mostly suffered serious injuries. Weather conditions at the time were good
column8: but it was after nightfall; the moon had not risen and there was little cultural lighting in the area.

column1: The aircraft crashed into a shallow lagoon approximately one nautical mile south-east of North Caicos Airport. Wreckage was spread along a trail that extended in excess of 370 m along a track of 220°(M). The aircraft's fuselage had come to rest comparatively intact
column2: although lying in an inverted attitude. Evidence from the accident site indicated that the aircraft had struck the water in a nominally upright attitude
column3: with only a moderate rate of descent but at relatively high forward speed.

column1: From a detailed examination of the wreckage and the circumstances of the accident
column2: it was concluded that the aircraft was structurally intact and probably under control when it struck the surface. The evidence indicated that each engine was producing power throughout the short flight and at the time of impact. Although anomalies were found which suggested that a possible power asymmetry may have existed
column3: this should not have been sufficient to cause the pilot serious control difficulties.

column1: None of the passengers described an obvious problem with the aircraft during the flight
column2: and most remained unaware of the impending crash. The circumstances of the accident suggested that the pilot became spatially disorientated
column3: to the extent that the aircraft diverged from its intended flight path and reached an irrecoverable situation. The environmental conditions were conducive to a disorientation event
column4: and a postmortem toxicological examination showed that the pilot had a level of blood alcohol which
column5: although below the prescribed limit
column6: was significant in terms of piloting an aircraft and would have made him more prone to disorientation.

column1: The evidence indicated that the pilot had probably started a recovery to normal flight
column2: but too late to prevent the accident. However
column3: his actions had the effect of reducing the descent rate and placing the aircraft in a nearly level attitude at impact. This lessened the impact damage and helped preserve the fuselage structure relatively intact
column4: increasing the passengers' chance of survival.";18:42;Beechcraft 200C Super King Air;Air Turks & Caicos (2003);Tuesday 6 February 2007

column3: Taiwan;"A TransAsia ATR-72-600 operating as flight GE235 from Taipei to Kinmen Island impacted a highway viaduct and the waters of the Keelung River near New Taipei City shortly after takeoff. Forty-three occupants on board the airplane suffered fatal injuries. Fifteen were injured.

column1: The airplane took off from Taipei-Sung Shan Airport's runway 10 at 10:51 hours local time and turned right
column2: climbing to an altitude of 1350 feet. At 10:52 the master warning sounded in the cockpit associated with the right engine (no. 2) flame out procedure message. Some 26 seconds later the left hand (no. 1) power lever was retarded to flight idle. After twenty seconds the left engine condition lever was set to the fuel shutoff position resulting in left engine shutdown.

column1: Instead of continuing the climbing right hand turn
column2: the airplane had turned left and began losing altitude and speed with several stall warnings sounding in the cockpit. At 10:53
column3: the flight contacted the Sung Shan Tower controller declaring a Mayday and reporting an 'engine flameout'. The airplane then turned to the right while the crew attempted to restart the left hand engine.

column1: This succeeded at 10:54:20 hours. Fourteen seconds later the stall warning sounded in the cockpit. Video footage of the accident show that the airplane banked almost 90 degrees left as it hit a taxi on a viaduct. Parts of the left hand wing broke off upon hitting the barrier of the viaduct. The airplane broke up as it impacted the Keelung River and came to rest inverted.";10:54;ATR 72-212A (ATR-72-600);TransAsia Airways;Wednesday 4 February 2015

column4: the airplane subsequently impacted a utility pole and terrain about 4

column1: Flight SWT094 departed Dubai Airport (DXB) at 06:08 local time on a scheduled service to Kandahar with the first officer as pilot flying. The en route part of the flight was uneventful. Kandahar approach cleared them for an RNAV (GPS) approach to runway 05
column2: providing a direct vector to the FALOD Initial Approach Fix and to descend to 6000 ft.

column1: Runway in use was runway 05
column2: and wind was reported from 060° at 17 kt gusting to 24 kt
column3: visibility 1200 m
column4: scattered clouds at 2700 ft and broken clouds at 3000 ft
column5: temperature 1°C
column6: dewpoint -7°C and QNH 1018 mbar.

column1: The target speed associated with a landing weight of 136
column2: 000 lb was estimated at 140 KIAS (Vref 135 +5). At a radio altitude of 1000 feet the airplane was fully configured for landing with flaps 40 and landing gear down. The heading was within margins but the speed was 192 kts. It should have been between Vref (135 knots) and Vref+20 (155 knots). Also
column3: the airplane was above the theoretical glide slope. It was also descending at a rate well in excess of 1000 ft/min. The approach was not stabilized at this point.

column1: Since the captain had more operational experience at the Kandahar
column2: he decided to take over the controls and fly the last phase of the approach. The PAPI was out of service
column3: meaning they only had visual references to the runway and above the ground during the final part of the approach.

column1: During short final the captain corrected a deviation from the runway centerline by adjusting the flight path from right to left. During the flare
column2: the crew noticed the airplane was shifting to the left
column3: threatening to take them off the runway
column4: as a result of which the captain applied a +20° right bank angle at a +9° pitch angle. This caused the right wing tip to strike the ground before the wheels made contact with the ground.

column1: Touchdown speed was 122 knots
column2: which was below Vref as well as the target speed .

column1: The captain regarded the maneuver as a hard landing
column2: although the first officer thought they might have struck the runway. On exiting the runway
column3: the airport control tower ordered the crew to stop and informed them of the damage they experienced.

column1: The wing had contacted the ground some 20 m prior to the threshold
column2: resulting in five threshold lights being destroyed by the aircraft.";08:28;McDonnell Douglas DC-9-83 (MD-83);null;Tuesday 24 January 2012

column1: 01-MAR-1999;Lockheed L-188AF Electra;N285F;Renown Aviation
column2: op.for Channel Express;Shannon Airp...;1959;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 6;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Damaged beyond repair;Landing (LDG);Cargo;Dublin Airport (DUB/EIDW)
column3: Ireland;Shannon Airport (SNN/EINN)
column4: Ireland;"Channel Express Flight 6526 departed Köln/Bonn Airport (CGN) at 03:00 hours and routed directly to Dublin
column5: where
column6: after more than one hours delay due to the late arrival of a freight truck
column7: the aircraft departed for Shannon Airport at 08:16. The total freight on board was 14
column9: less than half the 33
column10: 000 lb (14970 kg) maximum amount permissible. Shannon Approach vectored the aircraft on an approach to runway 24. Due to the weather forecast for Shannon the crew decided to conduct the landing with 78% flaps set
column11: rather than the standard 100% flap normally set for landing. Slowing the aircraft to Vma (Maximum Manoeuvering Airspeed) the crew did not carry out the ""before landing"" checks. Whilst over the runway threshold the gear warning horn sounded and five seconds later the crew heard a scraping sound and felt severe aircraft vibrations. Realising that the gear was not down the captain called for a go-around. The First Officer continued to fly the aircraft and was cleared to 3000 feet by ATC. During the climb out the propeller assembly and part of No. 3 engine fell to the ground. Electrical power was lost and the only serviceable flight instruments available to the crew was the standby artificial horizon and wet compass. The First Officer relinquished control of the aircraft to the captain who had great difficulty in maintaining directional control and it took the combined efforts of both pilots

column1: to control the excessive yaw through the rudder pedals. In addition
column2: there was insufficient power available to climb to 3000 feet. In fact
column3: less than 2000 feet was

column1: attained
column2: as the aircraft commenced a slow difficult turn in a North Easterly direction and towards the high ground west of Limerick city. It was only by further manipulation of the throttles and feathering No. 4 engine that sufficient directional control was recovered. The aircraft was now flying with only no. 1 engine fully operative and No. 2 engine producing only half power and much vibration. The Radar operator vectored the aircraft again to approach runway 24. They selected ""gear down"" and while only 2 of the 3 green landing lights illuminated
column3: the captain elected to proceed with the landing
column4: with the flaps again set at 78%. This landing was successful
column5: with all the landing gear deploying correctly.";08:46;Lockheed L-188AF Electra;null;Monday 1 March 1999

column1: 10-feb-11;Swearingen SA227-BC Metro III;EC-ITP;Flightline
column2: op.for Manx2;Cork Airport...;1992;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 4 / Occupants: 10;Destroyed;Landing (LDG);International Scheduled Passenger;Belfast City Airport (BHD/EGAC)
column3: United Kingdom;Cork Airport (ORK/EICK)
column4: Ireland;"A Swearingen SA-227BC Metro III passenger plane
column5: registered EC-ITP
column6: was damaged beyond repair in a landing accident at Cork Airport (ORK)
column7: Ireland. There were 10 passengers and two crew members on board. Both crew members and four passengers were killed.

column1: The airplane operated on Manx2 flight NM7100 from Belfast City Airport (BHD) to Cork Airport (ORK). Following a fuel uplift a total fuel quantity of 3000 lb (1360 kg) was recorded
column2: which was sufficient for the planned round trip to Cork and back to Belfast. The flight plan specified Waterford Airport (EIWF) as the alternate for the sector to Cork.

column1: The accident flight took off from Belfast at 08:10 hrs
column2: and climbed to Flight Level (FL) 120. The co-pilot was Pilot Flying (PF) with the commander acting as Pilot Non Flying (PNF).

column1: At 08:48 the flight contacted Cork Approach Control. The Cork ATIS information stated that runway 35 was the active runway with Low Visibility Procedures (LVP) in operation. Cork Approach also informed the flight crew that runway 35 was the active runway with CAT II available for runway 17. The RVRs on runway 17 were passed by Cork Approach as 300 m (touchdown)
column2: 350 m (midpoint) and 550 m (stop-end) (300/350/550). Flight 7100 was given the choice of runways
column3: and while runway 35 was initially considered by the flight crew
column4: a decision was made to opt for an approach to runway 17. This was acknowledged by Cork Approach who stated ""...that’s copied
column5: just check IRVRs Runway 17 for CAT II
column6: currently at 350

column1: The aircraft first established on the ILS approach to runway 17 at 08:58 and was handed over to Cork Tower. The RVRs passed by Cork Tower at 09:00 hrs were 300/400/375. The approach was continued beyond the 3.5 nautical miles (nm) DME point (outer marker equivalent). A missed approach was carried out at 09:03 hrs
column2: the lowest height recorded on this approach was 101 ft radio altitude.

column1: A second ILS approach was then flown
column2: to the reciprocal direction runway 35
column3: with the aircraft being handed over to Cork Tower at 09.10 at 8 nm from touchdown. At 09:10:56 the flight crew reported established on the ILS runway 35. The RVRs passed by the Tower at this time were 350/350/350. Descent was continued beyond the 4.9 nm DME point (outer marker equivalent). A missed approach was carried out at 09:14
column4: the lowest height recorded on this approach was 91 ft radio altitude.

column1: At 09:15 hrs the flight crew requested to enter a holding pattern for 15 to 20 minutes to see if the weather would improve. The flight took up the holding pattern at point ROVAL maintaining an altitude of 3
column2: 000 ft. The flight crew requested the weather for Waterford. This weather
column3: which was below minima
column4: was provided by Cork Approach. The flight crew nominated Shannon Airport as their second alternate and requested weather information. Shannon weather was passed by Cork Approach
column5: it was below minima. Weather for Dublin Airport was then sought by the flight crew. This was acknowledged by Cork Approach who offered to provide the weather for Kerry Airport also. The weather at Kerry was passed with the visibility being reported as greater than 10 kilometres. Weather conditions at Dublin
column6: which were marginal
column7: were obtained and passed to the flight crew at 09:35 hrs.

column1: At approximately 09:32 hrs
column2: with EC-ITP still in the ROVAL hold
column3: the RVR values on runway 17 at Cork began to improve. Following a further improvement to 500/450/400 at 09:39 hrs
column4: the flight crew elected to attempt another approach to runway 17.

column1: At 09:45 the aircraft reported established on the ILS
column2: and was configured with landing gear down and 1/2 flaps selected. At 09:45:26
column3: when EC-ITP was at 11 nm DME on the ILS
column4: the RVR (touchdown) improved to 550 m
column5: which was passed to the flight crew by Cork Approach.

column2: the flight was handed over to the Cork Tower and the flight crew reported to the Tower at 09:46:00 passing 9 nm DME. The final RVRs passed to EC-ITP at 09.46:15 were 500/400/400 when the aircraft was 9.6 nm from the threshold of runway 17. At approximately 400 ft radio altitude
column3: recorded data shows the aircraft deviated to the right of the runway centreline
column4: paralleling the centreline track.

column1: The descent was continued below Decision Height (DH). Power was reduced momentarily before being re-applied. Just below 100 ft radio altitude
column2: a go-around was called by the PNF and was acknowledged by the PF.

column1: Recorded data shows that the aircraft rolled significantly to the left as the aircraft tracked towards the runway centreline. This was immediately followed by a rapid roll to the right which brought the right wingtip into contact with the runway surface. Runway surface contact was made with a roll angle of 97 degrees to the right. The initial impact mark was located 86 m from the runway threshold
column2: and 2 m left of the centreline.

column1: The aircraft continued to roll rapidly to the right and struck the runway in the fully inverted position 25 m beyond the initial impact point. The inverted aircraft departed the runway surface on a heading of approximately 195° M and came to a rest 189 m from the initial impact point. The propeller blades on both engines were severely damaged; three of the four propeller blades on the right-hand engine detached during the inverted impact. Fire occurred in both engines post impact.

The AOC of the operator contained approval for the aircraft to operate CAT I approaches only. In this case a decision height of 200 feet at an RVR (touchdown) minimum of 550 m for runway 17 and 750 m for runway 35.";09:50;Swearingen SA227-BC Metro III;null;Thursday 10 February 2011

column5: United States of America;"The airplane collided with two deer shortly after touchdown at Troy Municipal Airport
column6: AL (TOI). Following the collision
column7: the airplane continued down the runway with the tires smoking
column8: veered off the right side of the runway near the end
column9: crossed a taxiway
column10: impacted into a ditch and burst into flames. After the accident
column11: the captain and first officer both reported that the thrust reversers failed to operate after they were deployed during the landing.

column1: Examination of the landing gear found all three gear collapsed. The right and left main tires had areas of rubber that were worn completely through. The flaps were found extended
column2: and both thrust reversers were found in the stowed position. Examination of the cockpit found the throttles in the idle position
column3: and the thrust reverser levers in the stowed position.

column1: Aircraft performance calculations indicate that the airplane traveled 1
column2: 500 feet down the runway after touchdown
column3: in 4.2 seconds
column4: before striking the deer. The calculations also indicate that the airplane landed with a ground speed of 124 knots. At 124 knots and maximum braking applied
column5: the airplane should have come to a complete stop in about 850 feet. However
column6: investigation of the accident site and surrounding area revealed heavy black skid marks beginning at the first taxiway turnoff about 1
column7: 500 feet down the 5
column8: 010 foot runway. The skid marks continued for about 2
column9: 500 feet
column10: departed the right side of the runway and proceeded an additional 500 feet over grass and dirt.

column1: The investigation revealed that deer fur was found lodged in the squat switch on the left main landing gear
column2: likely rendering the squat switch inoperative after the impact with the deer
column3: and prior to the airplane’s loss of control on the runway. Since a valid signal from the squat switch is required for thrust reverser deployment
column4: the loss of this signal forced the thrust reversers to stow. At this point
column5: the electronic engine control (EEC) likely switched to the forward thrust schedule and engine power increased to near takeoff power
column6: which led to the airplane to continue down the runway
column7: and off of it.";13:45;Learjet 60;Ark-Air Flight Inc.;Sunday 14 January 2001

column1: 02-MAY-2005;Swearingen SA227-AC Metro III;ZK-POA;Airwork NZ;near Stratford;1983;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Damaged beyond repair;En route (ENR);Cargo;Auckland International Airport (AKL/NZAA)
column2: New Zealand;Blenheim-Woodbourne Airport (BHE/NZWB)
column3: New Zealand;"Metro III ZK-POA was scheduled to depart from Auckland (AKL) at 21:00 on an NZ Post return flight to Blenheim (BHE). The payload comprised 1790 kilograms (kg) of courier packs and parcel mail. Loading of the freight was delayed
column4: being completed at about 21:15. The crew ordered 570 litres (about 1000 pounds or 450 kg) of additional fuel and instructed the refueller to put it all into the left wing tank
column5: rather than put half of the ordered amount into

column1: each tank
column2: as was company practice. Refuelling was completed at 21:30. Two minutes later the flight taxied out to runway 23R. Takeoff was performed at 21:36. The aircraft climbed to an altitude of FL220 with the autopilot engaged for the climb and cruise. At cruise altitude the climb power remained set for about 15 minutes in order to make up some of the delay caused by the late departure. At about 22:12:28
column3: after power was reduced to a cruise setting and the cruise checks had been completed
column4: the captain noted some fuel imbalance and decided to carry out further fuel balancing. He said
column5: ""We’ll just open the crossflow again ..sit on left ball and trim it accordingly"". The captain repeated the instruction 5 times in a period of 19 seconds
column6: by telling the first officer to
column7: ""Step on the left pedal
column8: and just trim it to take the pressure off"" and ""Get the ball out to the right as far as you can ..and just trim it"". The first officer sought confirmation of the procedure and said
column9: ""I was being a bit cautious"" to which the captain replied
column10: ""Don’t be cautious mate
column11: it’ll do it good"".

column1: These instructions resulted in the aircraft being flown at a large sideslip angle by the use of the rudder trim control while the autopilot was engaged. Forty-seven seconds after opening the crossflow
column2: the captain said
column3: ""Doesn’t like that one mate.. you’d better grab it."" Within one second there was the aural alert ""Bank angle""
column4: followed by a chime tone
column5: probably the selected altitude deviation warning. Both pilots exclaimed surprise.

column1: The autopilot had probably disengaged automatically because a servo reached its torque limit
column2: allowing the aircraft to roll and dive abruptly as a result of the applied rudder trim. The crew was unable to recover control from the ensuing spiral dive before airspeed and g limits were grossly exceeded
column3: resulting in the structural failure and in-flight break-up of the aircraft. The flying conditions of a dark night with cloud cover below probably made it more difficult to notice the developing upset at an early stage.

column1: The break-up probably started when the aircraft was quite high
column2: perhaps FL199. The wreckage was scattered over a large area of at least two to three sq km of rural farmland.";22:14;Swearingen SA227-AC Metro III;Airwork
column3: NZ;Monday 2 May 2005

column1: The departure and en route portions of the flight were uneventful. As the flight neared its destination
column2: a high-altitude
column3: terrain-limited airport
column4: air traffic control (ATC) provided vectors to the localizer/distance measuring equipment (LOC/DME)-E approach to runway 15. About 12:10
column5: the local controller informed the flight crew that the wind was from 290º at 19 knots (kts) with gusts to 25 kts. About 12:11
column6: the flight crew reported that they were executing a missed approach and then requested vectors for a second approach. ATC vectored the airplane for a second LOC/DME-E approach to runway 15. About 12:21

column1: The initial part of the airplane's second approach was as-expected for descent angle
column2: flap setting
column3: and spoilers. During the final minute of flight
column4: the engines were advanced and retarded five times
column5: and the airplane's airspeed varied between 135 kts and 150 kts. The final portion of the approach to the runway was not consistent with a stabilized approach. The vertical acceleration and pitch parameters were consistent with the airplane pitch oscillating above the runway for a number of seconds before a hard runway contact
column6: a gain in altitude
column7: and a final impact into the runway at about 6 g.

column1: The weather at the time of the accident was near or in exceedance of the airplane's maximum tailwind and crosswind components for landing

column1: Given the location of the airplane over the runway when the approach became unstabilized and terrain limitations of Aspen

column4: anti-ice was off
column5: and tailwinds were less than a sustained 25 kts
column6: the airplane had the capability to complete a go-around
column7: clearing the local obstacles along that path.

column1: Both flight crewmembers had recently completed simulator training for a type rating in the CL-600 airplane. The captain reported that he had a total of 12 to 14 hours of total flight time in the airplane type
column2: including the time he trained in the simulator. The copilot would have had close to the same hours as the captain given that they attended flight training together. Neither flight crew member would have met the minimum flight time requirement of 25 hours to act as pilot-in-command under Part 135. The accident flight was conducted under Part 91
column3: and therefore
column4: the 25 hours requirement did not apply to this portion of their trip. Nevertheless

column3: Russia;"UTAir flight 471 departed Surgut (SGC) on a regular domestic flight to Belgorod (EGO) via Samara (KUF). Upon departure from Surgut
column4: the weather at Samara was below minima with a visibility of 200 m in fog. An improvement was expected to a visibility of 3000 m upon arrival.

column1: The Tupolev 134 took off at 04:08 UTC
column2: climbing to the cruising altitude of 10600 m. En route weather reports showed an improvement to a visibility of 1500 m at Samara.

column1: At 06:18 UTC (11:18 local time)
column2: shortly after contacting Samara Control
column3: the captain briefed the crew about the arrival procedures for Samara. During the briefing he incorrectly stated that the altitude at which they would capture the glide slope was 500 m (the actual height is 400 m according to the approach charts). About 06:22
column4: Samara Control cleared the flight to descend to 5400 m. During their descent
column5: about 06:30
column6: the ground wind at Samara Airport changed direction from west (270-290°) to southeast (120°) with fog again worsening the visibility.

column1: Samara Approach cleared the flight further down to 2400 m and reported of 1200 m with haze and fog. At 06:35 the crew received further clearances in preparation for an approach to runway 23 and the controller reported pressure at the airfield being 745 mm Hg.
At 06:37 visibility dropped to 800 m. The meteorological station officer did not inform air traffic control
column2: although he was aware of this significant drop in visibility. Shortly afterward a visibility of 608 m was registered
column3: which was below airport landing minima. This value was not noted by the met station officer and thus not passed on to ATC. At 06:38:53 the flight reported at 400 m. The crew was then instructed to contact the Samara Landing controller
column4: which they did. At 06:40 UCT air traffic control contacted the met station to inquire about the cloud base and horizontal visibility. The met officer reported fog with 800 m visibility but did not mention the cloud base. The cloud base according to the latest ATIS information was 490 m. The actual cloud base measured at the time of the approach was about 30 m.

column2: at a speed of 380 km/h
column3: the flight engineer lowered the landing gear and the captain trimmed the stabilizer. At 06:40:43
column4: at a speed of 350 km/h
column5: the flaps were extended to 20 degrees. At the same time
column6: the Tu-134 was 10 km on finals
column7: the controller reported the (incorrect) visibility of ""800 m in fog"". At 06:41:09.
column8: 8 km out
column9: at a speed of 320 km/h
column10: the flaps were set at 30 degrees.

column1: At 06:41:45 the airplane passed the Outer Marker at 200 m. The navigator failed to inform the crew that they had passed the Outer Marker. Thus the pilot did not inform the controller
column2: in order to obtain landing clearance. When the controller inquired about their position
column3: the crew reported ready for landing. At 06:41:55 they were cleared to land. The vertical rate of descent was 6 m/s
column4: which exceeded the recommended rate of descent. The aircraft passed the Inner Marker at a height of 60 m
column5: and a vertical rate of descent of 5
column6: 5 m/s with a lateral deviation from the runway axis to the right
column7: no less than 40 m with a further tendency to the right. At decision height the crew had not established positive visual contact with the approach lights. The approach was continued until the airplane contacted the ground
column9: 300 m short of the runway and 100 m to the right of the extended centreline. The left wing separated from the fuselage and the plane rolled on its back.";11:42;Tupolev 134A-3;UTAir;Saturday 17 March 2007

column2: and the flight was on an instrument flight plan. It was night in dark lighting conditions with reported isolated cumulonimbus clouds and thunderstorms in the area.

column1: Flight ET409 was initially cleared by ATC on a LATEB 1 D Standard Instrument Departure (SID) from runway 21. Just before takeoff
column2: ATC changed the clearance to an ""immediate right turn direct Chekka"".

column1: The Boeing 737 took off from runway 21 at 02:36. After takeoff ATC instructed ET409 to turn right on a heading of 315° and change frequencies and contact Beirut Control. ET409 acknowledged the clearance and continued a right turn. ATC instructed ET409 to turn left heading 270°
column2: which was acknowledged. The flight continued the climbing left turn to heading 270° but did not maintain that heading. The aircraft continued on a southerly track. Just prior to reaching altitude of 7700 feet
column3: the stick shaker activated

column7: the stick shaker activated again
column8: sounding for a period of 26 seconds.

column1: After reaching 9000 feet the aircraft made a sharp left turn and descended rapidly. column1: The control tower reported the wind about three minutes prior to landing
column2: which at that time was from 240° at 15 kt. The runway was wet and it was raining heavily. The crew was told to proceed on course to Seville at their discretion and in accordance with their procedures.

column1: With the tower's clearance
column2: they captured the glideslope early
column3: far above the 2
column4: 000 ft specified in the published AIP procedure and descended along the ILS glideslope without significant deviations from the localize and glidepath until they were below 1
column5: 000 ft AGL and with the runway in sight. Established on the glideslope with the gear down and flaps 30°
column6: they disengaged the autopilot at about 700 ft and shortly thereafter they started to climb above the glideslope. The aircraft then descended to the runway at very high descent rates. The EGPWS SINK RATE and PULL-UP warnings sounded shortly before touchdown.

column1: The airplane landed in the middle of an intense rain storm. Personnel in the control tower saw a flame or glow on the right side of the aircraft. During the hard impact with the runway at the aiming point
column2: some 300 m beyond the threshold
column3: the right main gear leg collapsed
column4: pivoting backwards and partially detaching. The crew was able to maintain steering control of the aircraft
column5: which came to a stop after a 900-m landing run. Full reverse thrusters were used to decelerate the airplane. The entire landing roll took place on the paved runway surface. Only at the end of the run did part of the airplane
column6: the right wingtip
column7: touch the ground in an area beyond the paved asphalt.

column1: After coming to a stop
column2: and lacking the support from the right leg
column3: the aircraft was being held up by its left leg and right engine
column4: which is forward of the airplane's center of gravity
column5: as a result of which the aircraft tilted backwards until the tail touched the ground during the final seconds of braking.

column1: There was no fuel leak and no fire. The captain gave the evacuation order
column2: which was carried out using the four doors on both sides of the airplane.

column1: The weather was fine with a recorded wind speed of 5 kt (9 km/h) from the north-north-west and a temperature of 12 °C.
Witnesses familiar with the aircraft type reported that the take-off roll along runway 17 was longer than normal. After becoming airborne
column2: the aircraft was observed to yaw left. The aircraft performed a shallow climbing left turn while maintaining a relatively level pitch and roll attitude. Airservices Australia Automatic Dependent Surveillance Broadcast (ADS-B) data indicated the aircraft reached a maximum height of approximately 160 ft above ground level while tracking in an arc to the left of the runway centreline. The aircraft collided with a building at the DFO Essendon retail area.

column1: The aircraft subsequently  collided with the roof of a building at the DFO Essendon retail are and associated concrete parapet before coming to rest in the building’s rear car park. Examination determined that
column2: at impact the aircraft was configured with 10° of flap and that the landing gear was in the extended and locked position.

column1: An engine examination found that the cores of both engines were rotating and that there was no evidence of pre-impact failure of either engine’s internal components. However
column2: a number of engine components were retained by the ATSB for further examination and testing.

column1: The Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR) was successfully downloaded however
column2: no audio from the accident flight was recorded. All the recovered audio was from a previous flight on 3 January 2017.";08:59;Beechcraft B200 Super King Air;Corporate and Leisure Charters;Tuesday 21 February 2017

column1: 21-feb-08;ATR 42-300;YV1449;Santa Bárbara Airlines;near Mérida-A Car...;1986;Fatalities: 3 / Occupants: 3;Fatalities: 43 / Occupants: 43;Destroyed;En route (ENR);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Mérida-A Carnevalli Airport (MRD/SVMD)
column2: Venezuela;Caracas-Simón Bolívar International Airport (CCS/SVMI)
column3: Venezuela;"An ATR-42-300 operating Santa Bárbara Airlines Flight 518 was destroyed when it impacted the side of a mountain shortly after takeoff from Mérida-A Carnevalli Airport in Venezuela. All 46 on board were killed.

column1: Mérida Airport is located in a mountain valley at an elevation of 5010 feet. Terrain in the valley rises from 1000 to 19.500 feet. Arrivals and departures have to use the Rio Chama corridor to the west of the airport. Runway 07 is used for landings and takeoffs have to be performed in the opposite direction
column2: from runway 25.

column1: Santa Bárbara Airlines however used an unpublished approach and departure procedure which let the aircraft use a valley to the northeast of the airport. This procedure saved about 15 minutes of flying time on the route to Caracas.
After all passengers had boarded for flight 518 to Caracas
column2: it took about 30 minutes for the pilots to arrive at the aircraft. Being late
column3: they immediately started the engines while simultaneously asking for permission to do so.

column1: Because an Avior Airlines flight was approaching the airport
column2: the crew were told to expedite their departure or wait for the arrival of the Avior aircraft. The flight crew decided to go and began taxiing 2 minutes and 40 seconds after startup. Consequently the AHRS (attitude and heading reference) system of the airplane was unusable. The aircraft needed to remain still for 3 minutes after the battery is turned on so that all gyroscopes
column3: accelerometers and magnetometers can be stabilized and synchronized.

column1: The AHRS provides attitude information for aircraft
column2: including roll
column3: pitch and yaw. The captain possibly expected to re-initialize the system while they were at cruising altitude.

column1: After departure from runway 25 the crew planned to use the unpublished procedure. Climbing through clouds a 180-degree turn was initiated. Using the unreliable magnetic compass
column2: the flight made a 270 degree turn
column3: heading towards rising terrain. The captain took over control from the copilot. When visual contact with terrain was regained
column4: the crew noted they were heading for mountains. The captain tried to avoid rising terrain but the aircraft impacted the side of a mountain at 4100 m (13.400 feet).";ca 17:00;ATR 42-300;Santa Bárbara Airlines;Thursday 21 February 2008
