column1: 3-aug-17;Boeing 737-9GPER;PK-LJZ;Lion Air;Medan-Kualan...;2009-07-16  (8 years );Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 7;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 144;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Banda Aceh-Sultan Iskandarmuda Airport (BTJ/WITT)
column2: Indonesia;Medan-Kualanamu International Airport (KNO/WIMM)
column3: Indonesia;"An ATR 72-500 operated by Wings Air as flight IW1252 (PK-WFF) and a Boeing 737-900 operated by Lion Air as flight JT197 (PK-LJZ) both sustained substantial damage in a ground collision accident on the active runway 23 at Medan-Kualanamu International Airport
column4: Indonesia.

column1: The ATR 72-500 operated as scheduled passenger flight from Medan with intended destination of Meulaboh Airport. On board IW1252 were two pilots
column2: one observer pilot
column3: two flight attendants and 67 passengers. The pilot in command acted as Pilot Flying (PF) and the second in command acted as Pilot Monitoring (PM).

column2: the flight attendant of IW1252 advised the pilot that the boarding process was completed. The pilot then requested push back and engine start clearance from the Medan Ground controller
column3: which was approved.

column2: IW1252 requested taxi clearance to the Medan Ground controller and was instructed to taxi to runway 23 following U2 taxi route
column3: which was from apron V to holding point runway 23 on taxiway C
column4: via taxiway U - T - and B.

column2: flight JT197 reported to the Medan Tower controller that the aircraft was established on the localizer of runway 23. The Medan Tower controller acknowledged this and issued a landing clearance with additional information regarding the wind conditions and barometric pressure.

IW1252 contacted Medan Tower and was instructed to continue to taxi and hold on short of runway 23. Flight IW1252 requested to depart via the taxiway D intersection with the intention to expedite the departure. This was approved. Taxiway D was a Rapid Exit Taxiway (RET) for runway 05.

IW1252 advised Medan Tower that the aircraft was close to reaching runway 23. Medan Tower then requested confirmation that IW1252 was ready for immediate departure. There was no reply and the Medan Tower controller repeated the request and received the reply that IW1252 was able for immediate departure.

column1: Medan Tower intended to let IW1252 depart immediately after flight JT197 had landed
column2: since there was another arriving aircraft behind JT197.

the Medan Tower controller radioed: ""Wings Abadi one two five two behind traffic Lion short final landed passing line up behind runway two three from intersection delta additional clearance after departure direct Meulaboh"".
IW1252 read back: ""after departure direct to Meulaboh Wings Abadi one two five two"". Thereafter
column3: IW1252 continued the taxi for line up on runway 23.

column2: IW1252 crossed the runway holding position marking (yellow line). At the same time
column3: the Medan Tower controller was monitoring the distance of the second arriving aircraft on the radar display.

column1: As JT197 was on short final
column2: the flight crew noted IW1252 ahead and assumed that the ATR aircraft would not enter the runway. Therefore
column3: the PF decided to continue the landing approach and focused on handling the aircraft.

column2: JT197 touched down and the attention of the Medan Tower controller changed back from the radar display to the runway environment.

column1: IW1252 by then crossed the runway side marking (white line) and continued to enter the runway. The flight crew of JT197 saw that the ATR was entering the runway.

column2: the left wing of JT197 impacted with the right hand wing of IW1252.

column1: The flight crew of JT197 subsequently radioed the Medan Tower controller that there was another aircraft on the runway and this was acknowledged. The Medan Tower supervisor on duty noticed two aircraft on the runway and the Medan Tower controller panicked. Thereafter
column2: the Medan Tower supervisor took over the communication of Medan Tower.
the pilot of JT197 contacted the Medan Tower twice
column3: and received a response at 11:02:01 by the Medan Tower supervisor
column4: who then instructed them to vacate the runway via taxiway G.

column2: JT197 advised the Medan Tower that the aircraft had touched down and asked why there was another aircraft on runway 23. The Medan Tower supervisor requested the pilot to standby.

the Medan Tower supervisor instructed the other arriving aircraft pilot to overshoot due to traffic. The other arriving aircraft pilot requested to make orbit to the left on final approach which was approved.

column1: While the Boeing 737-900 was taxiing to the parking bay
column2: the Medan Tower supervisor issued takeoff clearance to IW1252
column3: with additional clearance to turn left heading 315 after airborne. IW1252 responded that they were unable to depart. The Medan Tower supervisor then instructed the IW1252 pilot to hold on the runway.

column2: the Medan Tower supervisor again issued takeoff clearance IW1252
column3: to which the pilot responded by requesting to return to the apron for inspection of any damage to the aircraft. The Medan Tower supervisor approved the request and instructed them to vacate the runway via taxiway E then to contact Medan Ground.

column1: As the ATR was taxiing back to the apron another departing aircraft was cleared to line up on runway 23
column2: with takeoff clearance being issued at 11:07:21.

JT197 advised the Medan Ground controller pf the possibility of aircraft debris on the runway that might become hazard to the other aircraft. The Medan Ground controller acknowledged and relayed the information to Medan Tower supervisor. At 11:10:26
column3: the flight that had just departed advised Medan Tower that there was Foreign Object Debris (FOD) on the runway.

column1: Despite these reports
column2: Medan Tower issued landing clearance to another arriving aircraft at 11:10:44.
after landing on runway 23
column3: the other arriving flight advised Medan Tower that there was FOD on the runway. It took until 11:31 for the runway to be closed. After all the debris were collected and runway cleaned
column4: the runway was reopened and resumed to normal operation at 11:55.";11:00;Boeing 737-9GPER;Lion Air;Thursday 3 August 2017

column6: United States of America;"The airplane was substantially damaged during an in-flight recovery after the captain attempted an intentional aileron roll maneuver during cruise flight and lost control. The captain reported the airplane was ""functioning normally"" prior to the intentional aileron roll maneuver. The captain stated that the ""intentional roll maneuver got out of control"" while descending through flight level 200. The captain reported that the airplane ""over sped"" and experienced ""excessive G-loads"" during the subsequent recovery. The copilot reported that the roll maneuver initiated by the captain resulted in a ""nose-down unusual attitude"" and a ""high speed dive."" Inspection of the airplane showed substantial damage to the left wing and elevator assembly.";03:30;Learjet 35A;AirNet Systems;Wednesday 10 January 2007

column1: 5-jun-16;BAe-125-800B;RA-02773;Aerolimousine;near Neryungri Ai...;1991;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 3;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 5;Substantial;Approach (APR);Executive;Tyumen-Roschino International Airport (TJM/USTR)
column2: Russia;Neryungri Airport (NER/UELL)
column3: Russia;"The BAe-125-800B corporate jet sustained substantial damage when it impacted trees while on approach to Neryungri Airport (NER)
column4: Russia. There were no injuries among the five passengers and three crew members.

column1: The aircraft operated on a flight from Krasnodar to Neryungri with an en route stop at Tyumen. The night time approach was conducted with a visibility of 10+ km. Wind was from 350° at 2 m/s. There were broken clouds at 190 m and overcast with cumulonimbus clouds at 510 m. Temperature and dew point were both +4°C. QFE pressure was 685 mm Hg (913 hPa).
During the descent the air traffic controller informed the crew that QFE (field elevation) pressure was 685 mm Hg and QNH (sea level) pressure was 1012 hPa.
The flight crew radioed: ""I confirm 685
column2: [...] is 1012 hectopascals
column3: do we understand it correctly?"" To which the controller replied ""...QNH 1012
column4: for information the height of the threshold is 08
column5: 857 meters.""

column1: This was misunderstood by the flight crew. They did not convert the pressure at the runway level of 685 mm Hg to hectopascals (685 mm Hg corresponds to 913 hPa)
column2: but instead set the pressure at 1012 hPa on the altimeters and continued the descent.

column1: At 23:13:33 hours the EGPWS sounded: ""Sink rate""
column2: followed a second later by ""Caution terrain!"" At 23:13:36 hours the EGWS again sounded: ""PULL UP"".

column1: At 23:13:53 hours
column2: at a distance of 18 km from the threshold of runway 08
column3: the aircraft impacted trees. The flight crew managed to regain height and performed a safe landing at Neryungri Airport. A post-flight inspection revealed damage to the wing leading edges and winglets
column4: dents on the no.2 engine cowling
column5: dents to the flaps and right hand horizontal stabilizer.";23:14;British Aerospace BAe-125-800B;Aerolimousine;Sunday 5 June 2016

10-apr-10;Tupolev Tu-154M;101;Polish AF;near Smolensk Air...;1990;Fatalities: 8 / Occupants: 8;Fatalities: 88 / Occupants: 88;Destroyed;Approach (APR);Official state flight;Warszawa-Okecie Airport (WAW/EPWA)
column2: Poland;Smolensk Air Base (XUBS)
column3: Russia;"A Tupolev 154M passenger jet
column4: operated the Polish Air Force
column5: was destroyed when it crashed on approach to Smolensk Air Base in poor visibility. All on board were killed in the accident
column6: including Polish President Lech Kaczynski.

column1: The airplane departed Warszawa-Okecie Airport (WAW)
column2: Poland at 07:27 local time
column3: carrying Polish President Lech Kaczynski
column4: his wife
column5: several Members of Parliament
column6: President of the National Bank of Poland Slawomir Skrzypek
column7: Chief of General Staff Franciszek Gagor
column8: the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Andrzej Kremer and a number of passengers and crew members.

column1: During the flight the crew was in contact with air traffic controllers at Minsk
column2: Moscow and Smolensk. The crew also was in contact with the crew of a Polish Air Force Yakovlev 40 passenger plane that had landed at Smolensk Air Base 90 minutes ahead of the Presidential flight.

column1: At about 10:14 the flight descended through an altitude of 7500 m. Minsk Control radioed that the visibility at Smolensk Air Base was 400 m due to fog. The same conditions were transmitted to the crew when they contacted the controller at Smolensk. About 10:25 the pilot of the Yak-40 on the ground at Smolensk radioed that horizontal visibility was 400 m and vertical visibility about 50 m. Shortly afterwards they reported that an Ilyushin 76 transport plane had diverted to an alternate airfield after two attempts to land.
The crew continued preparations for an approach to runway 26 at the Smolensk Air Base. The cockpit door was open and during the approach there were two passengers present on the flight deck.
Meanwhile
column2: visibility worsened to 200 m. This information was transmitted to the crew at 10:37. The crew requested permission to carry out a 'trial' approach to decision height (100 m) and asked the controller to expect a go around.

column1: About 18 seconds before impact the terrain awareness and warning system (TAWS) sounded: ""Pull up""
column2: followed by an aural warning: ""TERRAIN AHEAD"". About 5 seconds before impact the autopilot and autothrottle were disconnected in order to execute a go around. The airplane contacted upsloping terrain at a distance of about 1100 meters from the runway and 40 m to the left of extended centreline. The aircraft height at that point was 15 m below the level of the runway threshold. The left wing struck a large tree causing the airplane to roll inverted. The Tu-154 crashed and broke up.";10:41;Tupolev 154M;Polish Air Force;Saturday 10 April 2010

column3: Qatar;"Boeing E-8C JSTARS
column4: tail number 93-0597
column5: assigned to the USAF 379th Air Expeditionary Wing
column6: experienced a near catastrophic fuel tank over-pressurization during aerial refuelling. The mishap aircraft terminated its mission and returned to Al Udeid Air Base
column7: Qatar. The crew and mission personnel evacuated the aircraft safely without injury.

column1: The mishap occurred during operations in the Area of Responsibility (AOR). The mishap crew had begun aerial refuelling with a KC-135
column2: when the mishap crew and personnel aboard heard and felt a loud bang throughout the midsection of the aircraft. The crew suspended refuelling to evaluate the aircraft to checkout their systems and evaluate the aircraft for any damage. Finding nothing apparently wrong
column3: the crew re-latched to the tanker and attempted to continue the refuelling when another series of loud noises and vibrations were heard and felt throughout the aircraft.

column1: Personnel aboard the KC-135 observed a stream of vapour and fuel streaming from the E-8 and alerted the crew. The crew checked for damage through a rear window and observed fuel streaming from at least two holes in the left wing
column2: just inboard of the number two engine. The crew opted to terminate the mission and return to Al Udeid. Maintenance personnel then examined the airplane and found that the number two main fuel tank had ruptured
column3: causing extensive damage to the wing of the airplane.";null;Boeing E-8C (707);United States Air Force - USAF;Friday 13 March 2009

27-MAY-2017;Let L-410UVP-E20;9N-AKY;Summit Air;Lukla-Tenzin...;2014;Fatalities: 2 / Occupants: 3;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Destroyed;Approach (APR);Cargo;Kathmandu-Tribhuvan Airport (KTM/VNKT)
column2: Nepal;Lukla-Tenzing-Hillary Airport (LUA/VNLK)
column3: Nepal;"A Let L-410UVP-E20 operated by Summit Air (formerly known as Goma Air) was destroyed in an accident when it attempted to land on runway 06 at Lukla-Tenzing-Hillary Airport in Nepal. The aircraft operated on a cargo charter flight with 1680 kg cargo on board. It took off from Kathmandu at 07:44 UTC at flight 409
column4: bound for Lukla.

column1: It was the 5th flight of the aircraft to Lukla and with the same set of crew. Lukla weather was cloudy
column2: but visibility and ceiling was reported to be fine after an hour of heavy rain. On first contact flight 409 reported abeam Rumjatar descending out of 11300 ft at 08:10 UTC. Lukla Tower provided the latest weather at the airport
column3: as well as enroute weather relayed by 9N-AGU
column4: an AS350 helicopter that had departed Lukla for Kathmandu. Almost 4 minutes after the first contact
column5: Tower informed flight 409 about the deteriorating weather. The right base leg was covered by lifting fog though there was no rain and the final approach area was still visible.

column1: Weather deteriorated further and Tower regularly updated the flight crew. About 30 seconds after flight 409 reported entering valley
column2: Lukla Tower again informed about the latest status of the further deteriorating weather. Flight 409 then informed that they would come up to Bhatkeko Daada and then decide. The pilot also informed they could see some bright spots.

column1: While continuing approach
column2: both cockpit crew sighted the runway at 9100 ft. That was 64 seconds before the impact. While continuing approach the aircraft deviated to the right by almost 15 degrees and erroneously descended too low to 8500 ft whereas threshold height is 8900 ft (on Kathmandu QNH
column3: whereas per AIP it is 9200 ft).

column1: The flight crew attempted to climb and reach the threshold in a landing configuration. The aircraft pitched up to over 25°
column2: the airspeed dropped and the aircraft stalled. Subsequently its left wing first hit a small tree and then impacted the sloping terrain 130 feet short of the runway.

column1: The captain and copilot both sustained fatal injuries.";14:04;Let L-410UVP-E20;Summit Air;Saturday 27 May 2017

column2: Albania;?;"On the night of 11 June 1999
column3: RAF Hercules XV298 was tasked to collect personnel and equipment from Kukes airstrip
column4: Albania. The aircraft flew from Italy and landed on the unlit airstrip using normal Night Vision Goggle (NVG) procedures. The crew were unable to see the end of the airstrip as artificial lighting in the near distance interfered with their night vision goggles.

column3: Nigeria;"Kenya Airways Flight 430 departed from Nairobi for a flight to Lagos and Abidjan. Due to the harmattan
column4: a dusty seasonal wind from the deserts of north Africa
column5: the flight continued directly to Abidjan. The aircraft
column6: named ""Harambee Star""
column7: landed there at 15:15. The Airbus was prepared for the return flight to Lagos and Nairobi that evening. Shortly after 21:00 the crew received clearance to taxy to runway 21 for departure. The trim was set at 0.9 nose up
column8: slats and flaps at 15 degrees. The airplane began to taxi at 21:07
column9: the tower controller informed the crew of the latest wind
column10: cleared them to take off and asked the crew the call back when they reached flight level 40. At 21:08:18
column11: the captain
column12: who was pilot non flying
column13: applied takeoff power and announced ""thrust
column14: SRS
column15: and runway"" then
column16: nine seconds later ""100 knots"". Flight 431 took off and at 21:08:57
column17: the copilot announced ""Positive rate of climb
column18: gear up"". Less than two seconds later
column19: at a height of around 300 feet
column20: the stall warning sounded. The gear was not retracted. The copilot
column21: pilot flying
column22: pushed forward on the control column in reaction to the stall warnings. At 21:09:07
column24: ""What’s the problem?"" The aircraft descended and less than a second before passing through 100 feet in descent
column25: the copilot ordered the aural stall warning alarm to be disconnected. The GPWS sounded shortly
column26: followed by the CRC (Continuous Repetitive Chime)
column27: which corresponds to a master warning of over-speed with flaps extended
column28: immediately followed by an order from the captain ""Go up!"". The airplane’s speed at this point was at least 210 knots
column29: the maximum speed limit for a configuration with slats/flaps at 15°/15°. At 21:09:24 the airplane contacted the sea and broke up. The wreckage came to rest on the sandy seabed at a depth of 40-50 metres.";21:09;Airbus A310-304;Kenya Airways;Sunday 30 January 2000

column4: an Airbus A320 impacted the Mediterranean Sea some 200 km north of the Egyptian coast line
column5: killing all 66 on board.

column1: The aircraft departed Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport
column2: France
column3: at 23:21 hours local time on May 18. Scheduled departure time was 22:45 hours. Destination of the flight was Cairo
column4: Egypt.

column1: Last contact with the flight was at FL370
column2: about 02:29 hours. According to Greek military authorities their primary radar showed the aircraft suddenly taking a 90 degree turn left
column3: followed by a 360 degrees turn in the opposite direction as it descended from FL370 to FL150 before disappearing off radars.

column1: The Flight Data Recorder and Cockpit Voice Recorder were both recovered from the sea bed on June 16
The Egyptian authorities found that:
- The flight recorders stopped operating while the aircraft was in cruise at an altitude of 37
column2: 000 feet;

column1: - The aircraft systems sent ACARS messages indicating the presence of smoke in toilets and the avionics bay;
- The data from the data recorder confirms these messages;
- The playback of the cockpit voice recorder reveals
column2: in particular
column3: that the crew mentioned the existence of a fire on board;

column1: - Several pieces of debris were retrieved from the accident site. Some of these had signs of having been subject to high temperatures
column2: and traces of soot.

column1: On December 15
column3: investigators reported that traces of explosives were found on several victims. Egyptian authorities determined that there had been a malicious act. The formal investigation per ICAO Annex 13 was stopped and further investigation fell within the sole jurisdiction of the judicial authorities.

column1: Contradicting the Egyptian finding
column2: the French BEA considered that the most likely hypothesis was that a fire broke out in the cockpit while the aircraft was flying at its cruise altitude and that the fire spread rapidly resulting in the loss of control of the aircraft.";02:29;Airbus A320-232;EgyptAir;Thursday 19 May 2016

column2: France;East Midlands Airport (EMA/EGNX)
column3: United Kingdom;"A Boeing 737-400 Freighter belonging to the Irish freight company Air Contractors suffered substantial damage in a landing accident at East Midlands Airport near Nottingham
column4: United Kingdom.

column1: The aircraft was scheduled to operate three commercial air transport (cargo) sectors: from Athens to Bergamo
column2: then to Paris Charles de Gaulle
column3: and finally East Midlands.

column1: The co-pilot completed the pre-flight external inspection of the aircraft in good light
column2: and found nothing amiss. The departure from Athens was uneventful
column3: but a combination of factors affecting Bergamo (including poor weather
column4: absence of precision approach aids
column5: and work in progress affecting the available landing distance) led the crew to decide to route directly to Paris
column6: where a normal landing was carried out.

column1: The aircraft departed Paris for East Midlands at 00:40 hrs UTC
column2: loaded with 10 tonnes of freight
column3: 8 tonnes of fuel (the minimum required was 5.6 tonnes)
column4: and with the co-pilot as Pilot Flying.

column1: Once established in the cruise
column2: the flight crew obtained the latest ATIS information from East Midlands
column3: which stated that runway 27 was in use
column4: although there was a slight tailwind
column5: and Low Visibility Procedures (LVPs) were in force. They planned to exchange control at about FL100 in the descent
column6: for the commander to carry out a Category III autoland. However
column7: as they neared their destination
column8: the weather improved
column9: LVPs were cancelled
column10: and the flight crew re-briefed for an autopilot approach
column11: followed by a manual landing
column12: to be carried out by the co-pilot. The landing was to be with Flap 30
column13: Autobrake 2
column14: and idle reverse thrust.

column1: The final ATIS transmission which the flight crew noted before landing stated that the wind was 130/05 kt
column2: visibility was 3
column3: 000 metres in mist
column4: and the cloud was broken at 600 ft aal.

column1: The captain established radio contact with the tower controller
column2: and the aircraft was cleared to land; the surface wind was transmitted as 090/05 kt. The touchdown was unremarkable
column3: and the autobrake functioned normally
column4: while the co-pilot applied idle reverse thrust on the engines.

column1: As the aircraft’s speed reduced through approximately 60 kt
column2: the co-pilot handed control to the commander
column3: who then made a brake pedal application to disengage the autobrake system. However
column4: the system remained engaged
column5: so he made a second
column6: more positive
column7: brake application. The aircraft ""shuddered"" and rolled slightly left-wing-low as the lower part of the left main landing gear detached. The captain used the steering tiller to try to keep the aircraft tracking straight along the runway centreline
column8: but it came to a halt slightly off the centreline
column9: resting on its right main landing gear
column10: the remains of the left main landing gear leg
column11: and the left engine lower cowl.

column1: The two crew members were uninjured and there was no fire.";02:28;Boeing 737-476SF;Air Contractors;Tuesday 29 April 2014

column3: India;"A Beechcraft B200 Super King Air operated by the Indian State of Haryana Government sustained substantial damage in a takeoff accident. All ten occupants survived the accident.

On clearance from ATC the take off roll was initiated and all the parameters were found normal. The rotation was initiated at 98 knots and the aircraft climbed to 10-15 feet AGL. The commander has stated that after lift-off
column3: immediately the left rudder got locked in the forward position resulting in the aircraft yawing and rolling to left. The pilots tried to control it with right bank but the aircraft could not be controlled. Within 3-4 seconds of getting airborne the aircraft impacted the ground in a left bank attitude. The initial impact was on pucca (tar road) and the wing took the first impact loads. After the aircraft came to final halt
column4: the co-pilot opened the door and evacuation was carried out. There was no injury to any of the occupants.";11:39;Beechcraft B200 Super King Air;State of Haryana Government;Thursday 27 March 2014

column3: Iran;"The crew executed an approach in manual mode with the co-pilot flying the airplane. The airplane landed normally on runway 29L at Tehran-Mehrabad. After compression of the main struts of the landing gear
column4: the spoilers were extended. At the same time the reverser on the left engine was brought to maximum mode. The reverse thrust lever of the right engine was not used since the reverser was deactivated. After deceleration to a speed of 80 knots the reverse thrust lever of the left engine was brought to the intermediate position between maximum and minimum reverse thrust. As this was happening the throttle control lever of the right engine was brought from idle to the position of ~55 degrees according to FDR data. Further movement of the reverse thrust lever of the right engine was accompanied by the simultaneous shifting of the throttle control lever of the left engine practically as far as the nominal mode.

column1: At this moment the airplane captain interfered in the control
column2: shifted the throttle control lever of the right engine to idle and again activated maximum reverse of the left engine. However
column3: in spite of the actions taken
column4: the airplane overshot the runway at a speed of about 40 knots.";02:20;Airbus A310-304ET;Mahan Air;Monday 7 March 2005

column1: Te aircraft initially arrived at Nice-Côte d'Azur Airport (NCE) following a flight from Istanbul-Sabiha Gökçen International Airport
column2: Turkey. Three passengers deplaned at Nice. Since the parking area at Nice was full
column3: the airplane was to be ferried to Le Castellet.

column1: Takeoff was accomplished at 14:56 hours local time and the aircraft climbed to FL160 for a short flight to Le Castellet.
At the destination
column2: the crew was cleared to perform a visual approach to runway 13. The autopilot and the auto-throttle were disengaged
column3: the gear was down and the flaps in the landing position. The GND SPOILER UNARM message
column4: indicating nonarming of the ground spoilers
column5: was displayed on the EICAS and the associated single chime aural warning was triggered. This message remained displayed on the EICAS until the end of the flight since the crew forgot to arm the ground spoilers during the approach.

column1: At a height of 25 ft
column2: while the aircraft was flying over the runway threshold slightly below the theoretical descent path
column3: a SINK RATE warning was triggered. The pilot flying corrected the flight path and the touchdown of the main landing gear took place 15 metres after the touchdown zone
column4: which is 365 metres from the threshold
column5: and slightly left of the centre line of runway 13. The ground spoilers
column6: not armed
column7: did not automatically deploy. The crew braked and actuated the deployment of the thrust reversers
column8: which did not deploy completely. The hydraulic pressure available at brake level slightly increased. The deceleration of the aeroplane was slow.

column1: Four seconds after touchdown
column2: a MASTER WARNING was triggered. A second MASTER WARNING was generated five seconds later.

column1: The nose landing gear touched down for the first time 785 metres beyond the threshold before the aeroplane's pitch attitude increased again
column2: causing a loss of contact of the nose gear with the ground. The aircraft crossed the runway centre line to the right
column3: the crew correcting this by a slight input on the rudder pedals to the left. They applied a strong nose-down input and the nose gear touched down on the runway a second time
column4: 1050 metres beyond the threshold.

column1: The speedbrakes were then manually actuated by the crew with an input on the speed brake control
column2: which then deployed the panels. Maximum thrust from the thrust reversers was reached one second later. The aircraft at this time was 655 metres from the runway end and its path began to curve to the left. In response to this deviation
column3: the crew made a sharp input on the right rudder pedal
column4: to the stop
column5: and an input on the right brake
column6: but failed to correct the trajectory. The aeroplane
column7: skidding to the right
column8: ran off the runway to the left 385 metres from the runway end at a ground speed of approximately 95 knots.

column1: It struck a runway edge light
column2: the PAPI of runway 31
column3: a metal fence then trees and caught fire instantly.

column1: An aerodrome firefighter responded quickly onsite but did not succeed in bringing the fire under control.";15:18;Gulfstream G-IV;Universal Jet Aviation;Friday 13 July 2012

column2: Indonesia;Manokwari-Rendani Airport (MKW/WAUU)
column3: Indonesia;"Sriwijaya Air flight SJ570 was a scheduled passenger flight from Makassar-Hasanuddin Airport
column4: South Sulawesi
column5: Indonesia to Manokwari-Rendani Airport
column6: West Papua
column7: Indonesia with one transit stop at Sorong-Domine Eduard Osok Airport
column8: West Papua. The flight was uneventful since the first departure from Makassar until commencing the approach at Manokwari.

column1: At 08:15 hours local time
column2: the aircraft departed Sorong to Manokwari. On board were two pilots
column3: four flight attendants and 146 passengers. On this flight
column4: the Second in Command (SIC) acted as Pilot Flying (PF) and the Pilot in Command (PIC) acted as Pilot Monitoring (PM).

column2: the pilot made first contact with the Rendani Tower controller and informed that the aircraft was descending from FL230 and requested weather information. The Rendani Tower controller informed the pilot that the wind was calm
column3: ground visibility 6 km
column4: cloud FEW CB 1
column5: 400 feet
column6: temperature and dew point 26/25°C.

column2: Rendani Tower instructed to the pilot to descend to 11
column3: 000 feet and to report when on Visual Meteorological Conditions (VMC).

column2: the pilot informed that they were in VMC and passing altitude 13
column3: 000 feet at 32 NM from the ZQ NDB (Non-Directional Beacon).

column1: The Rendani Tower controller instructed to fly overhead
column2: descend to circuit altitude
column3: join right downwind runway 35
column4: and to report when overhead Manokwari.

column2: the pilot reported that the aircraft was over Manokwari and the Tower controller informed the pilot that the visibility had changed to 5 km. Two minutes later Rendani Tower instructed the pilot to continue approach and to report on right base runway 35.
at approximately 600 feet
column3: the PIC as PM took over control by called ""I have control"" and the SIC replied ""You have control"". A few seconds later the pilot reported that the aircraft was on final runway 35
column4: and Rendani Tower instructed to the pilot to report when the runway 35 in sight. The pilot immediately replied that the runway was in sight
column5: which was acknowledged by Rendani Tower who then issued landing clearance with additional information that the wind was calm and the runway condition wet.

column1: At approximately 550 feet
column2: the PIC instructed the SIC turn on the wiper and reconfirmed to SIC that the runway was in sight. Between altitude 500 feet to 200 feet
column3: the EGPWS aural warnings ""Sink Rate"" and ""Pull Up"" sounded.

column2: the aircraft touched down on runway 35. The spoilers deployed and the pilot activated the thrust reversers. The crew did not feel significant deceleration.

column1: The aircraft failed to stop on the runway and overran by approximately 20 meters from the end of runway pavement. After the aircraft stopped

column1: 25-feb-09;Boeing 737-8F2;TC-JGE;THY;near Amsterdam-Sc...;2002-01-24  (7 years 1 months);Fatalities: 4 / Occupants: 7;Fatalities: 5 / Occupants: 128;Destroyed;Approach (APR);International Scheduled Passenger;Istanbul-Atatürk International Airport (IST/LTBA)
column2: Turkey;Amsterdam-Schiphol International Airport (AMS/EHAM)
column3: Netherlands;"Turkish Airlines Flight TK1951
column4: a Boeing 737-800
column5: departed Istanbul-Atatürk International Airport (IST) for a flight to Amsterdam-Schiphol International Airport (AMS)
column6: The Netherlands. The flight crew consisted of three pilots: a line training captain who occupied the left seat
column7: a first officer under line training in the right seat and an additional first officer who occupied the flight deck jump seat. The first officer under line training was the pilot flying. The en route part of the flight was uneventful.

column1: The flight was descending for Schiphol and passed overhead Flevoland at about 8500 ft. At that time the aural landing gear warning sounded.

The aircraft continued and was then directed by Air Traffic Control towards runway 18R for an ILS approach and landing. The standard procedure for runway 18R prescribes that the aircraft is lined up at least 8 NM from the runway threshold at an altitude of 2000 feet. The glidepath is then approached and intercepted from below. Lining up at a distance between 5 and 8 NM is allowed when permitted by ATC.
Flight 1951 was vectored for a line up at approximately 6 NM at an altitude of 2000 feet. The glide slope was now approached from above.
The crew performed the approach with one of the two autopilot and autothrottle engaged.
The landing gear was selected down and flaps 15 were set. While descending through 1950 feet
column2: the radio altimeter value suddenly changed to -8 feet. And again the aural landing gear warning sounded.

column1: This could be seen on the captain’s (left-hand) primary flight display. The first officer’s (right-hand) primary flight display
column2: by contrast
column3: indicated the correct height
column4: as provided by the right-hand system. The left hand radio altimeter system
column5: however
column6: categorised the erroneous altitude reading as a correct one
column7: and did not record any error. In turn
column8: this meant that it was the erroneous altitude reading that was used by various aircraft systems
column9: including the autothrottle. The crew were unaware of this
column10: and could not have known about it. The manuals for use during the flight did not contain any procedures for errors in the radio altimeter system. In addition
column11: the training that the pilots had undergone did not include any detailed system information that would have allowed them to understand the significance of the problem.

column1: When the aircraft started to follow the glidepath because of the incorrect altitude reading
column2: the autothrottle moved into the ‘retard flare’ mode. This mode is normally only activated in the final phase of the landing
column3: below 27 feet. This was possible because the other preconditions had also been met
column4: including flaps at (minimum) position 15. The thrust from both engines was accordingly reduced to a minimum value (approach idle). This mode was shown on the primary flight displays as ‘RETARD’. However
column5: the right-hand autopilot
column6: which was activated
column7: was receiving the correct altitude from the right-hand radio altimeter system. Thus the autopilot attempted to keep the aircraft flying on the glide path for as long as possible. This meant that the aircraft’s nose continued to rise
column8: creating an increasing angle of attack of the wings. This was necessary in order to maintain the same lift as the airspeed reduced.

column1: In the first instance
column2: the pilots’ only indication that the autothrottle would no longer maintain the pre-selected speed of 144 knots was the RETARD display. When the speed fell below this value at a height of 750 feet
column3: they would have been able to see this on the airspeed indicator on the primary flight displays. When subsequently
column4: the airspeed reached 126 knots
column5: the frame of the airspeed indicator also changed colour and started to flash. The artificial horizon also showed that the nose attitude of the aircraft was becoming far too high. The cockpit crew did not respond to these indications and warnings. The reduction in speed and excessively high pitch attitude of the aircraft were not recognised until the approach to stall warning (stick shaker) went off at an altitude of 460 feet.

column1: The first officer responded immediately to the stick shaker by pushing the control column forward and also pushing the throttle levers forward. The captain however
column2: also responded to the stick shaker commencing by taking over control. Assumingly the result of this was that the first officer’s selection of thrust was interrupted. The result of this was that the autothrottle
column3: which was not yet switched off
column4: immediately pulled the throttle levers back again to the position where the engines were not providing any significant thrust. Once the captain had taken over control
column5: the autothrottle was disconnected
column6: but no thrust was selected at that point. Nine seconds after the commencement of the first approach to stall warning
column7: the throttle levers were pushed fully forward
column8: but at that point the aircraft had already stalled and the height remaining
column9: of about 350 feet
column10: was insufficient for a recovery.

column1: According to the last recorded data of the digital flight data recorder the aircraft was in a 22° ANU and 10° Left Wing Down (LWD) position at the moment of impact.

The airplane impacted farmland. The horizontal stabilizer and both main landing gear legs were separated from the aircraft and located near the initial impact point. The left and right engines had detached from the aircraft.
The aft fuselage
column2: with vertical stabilizer
column3: was broken circumferentially forward of the aft passenger doors and had sustained significant damage. The fuselage had ruptured at the right side forward of the wings. The forward fuselage section
column4: which contained the cockpit and seat rows 1 to 7
column5: had been significantly disrupted. The rear fuselage section was broken circumferentially around row 28.";10:26;Boeing 737-8F2;THY Turkish Airlines;Wednesday 25 February 2009

column1: 19-MAR-1999;DHC-6 Twin Otter 300;C-FWLQ;Provincial Airlines;near Davis Inlet ...;1980;Fatalities: 1 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Damaged beyond repair;Approach (APR);Cargo;Goose Bay Airport

column3: Canada;Davis Inlet Airport

column5: Canada;"Flight 960 operated under a defense visual flight rules flight plan and departed Goose Bay for Davis Inlet at 08:15 AST. During the first approach
column6: the first officer had occasional visual glimpses of the snow on the surface. The captain descended the aircraft to the minimum descent altitude (MDA) of 1340 feet asl. When the crew did not acquire the required visual references at the missed approach point
column7: they executed a missed approach. On the second approach
column8: the captain flew outbound from the beacon at 3000 feet asl until turning on the inbound track. It was decided that if visual contact of the surface was made at any time during the approach procedure
column9: they would continue below the MDA in anticipation of the required visual references. The captain initiated a constant descent at approximately 1500 feet per minute with 10 degrees flap selected. The FO occasionally caught glimpses of the surface. At MDA
column10: in whiteout conditions
column11: the captain continued the descent. In the final stages of the descent
column12: the FO acquired visual ground contact; 16 seconds before impact
column13: the captain also acquired visual ground contact. At 8 seconds before impact
column14: the crew selected maximum propeller revolutions per minute. The aircraft struck the ice in controlled flight two nm from the airport. The aircraft was destroyed with wing and partial fuselage separation
column15: and other incursion damage. The tail section where the ELT was mounted was badly damaged. Aircraft parts and cargo were scattered over the ice. The co-pilot was found approximately 20 feet from the main wreckage. He had expired before searchers reached the scene. The pilot was located in the rear of the aircraft
column16: apparently thrown there during the crash sequence. He was semi-conscious with serious injuries. There was no fire.";09:45;de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter 300;Provincial Airlines;Friday 19 March 1999

column1: 25-jan-07;Fokker 100;F-GMPG;Régional;Pau-Uzein Ai...;1991-10-15  (15 years 4 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 4;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 50;Substantial;Takeoff (TOF);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Pau-Uzein Airport (PUF/LFBP)

column3: France;"Fokker 100 F-GMPG arrived at Pau (PUF) at 10:37 after a flight from Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport (CDG). The airplane was to return to Paris as Air France flight 7775. After startup the crew were cleared to taxi to runway 13 for departure. Takeoff clearance was given at 11:25:15. A few seconds later TOGA power was selected. At 11:26:00 the crew noticed birds in the vicinity. The takeoff roll was normal and the airplane lifted off the runway at 11:26:08 at a speed of 128 kts. Immediately after takeoff
column4: it banked suddenly to the left with a maximum bank angle of 35 degrees. The aural ""Bank Angle"" alarm sounded on the flight deck. The airplane then banked to the right with a maximum bank angle of 67 degrees. After a second left bank (59 degrees) an aural alarm ""Don't Sink"" sounded. The airplane had reached a height of 107 feet. At 11:26:21 the airplane bounced after the right main landing gear had touched the ground. The captain decided to abort the takeoff. The speed at that time was 160 kts. Engine power was reduced and the Fokker contacted the ground again at 11:26:27
column5: near the end and to the right of runway 13. The thrust reversers were briefly deployed. The airplane ran 340 m
column6: collided with the perimeter fence. Upon crossing a road
column7: the left main landing gear struck the cabin of a truck
column8: killing the driver. Both main gears were sheared off as the airplane struck a slope past the road. It continued into a field and came to rest at 11:26:49.";11:24;Fokker 100;Régional Compagnie Aérienne Européenne;Thursday 25 January 2007

column1: 17-MAR-2007;Cessna 500 Citation I;N511AT;Air Trek;Beverly Airp...;1974;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 4;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Ambulance;Punta Gorda-Charlotte County Airport

column5: United States of America;"a Cessna 500
column6: N511AT
column7: operated by Air Trek
column8: Inc.
column9: was substantially damaged during landing at Beverly Municipal Airport (BVY)
column10: Massachusetts. None of the four crewmembers or two passengers were injured. The air ambulance flight was flying a GPS runway 16 approach at Beverly (BVY). After passing the initial approach fix they entered a cloud
column11: and noticed that there was ""quite a bit of wind"" which they had to compensate for. Moments later
column12: the first officer noticed that they were picking up a trace amount of rime ice on the windscreen; however
column13: since neither pilot saw any ice on the wings
column14: the de-icing boots were never activated. As they neared the final approach fix (FAF)
column15: they ""added a notch"" of approach flaps
column16: and then added full flaps when they crossed the FAF. After reaching the minimum descent altitude
column17: they acquired the field and the visual approach slope indicator (VASI). Once established on the VASI
column18: the approach to landing seemed normal until reaching approximately 100 feet above ground level. The crew then experienced what they described as a ""burble
column19: and the airplane rolled ""steeply"" to the right
column20: striking the surface of the runway overrun area. After landing and taxiing to the ramp
column21: the flight crew conducted a postflight inspection of the airplane. They noted that approximately 4 feet of the right wing was bent upward about 10 degrees
column22: and ""Light rime ice"" was present on the leading edges of the wings
column23: horizontal stabilizer and radome.";14:30;Cessna 500 Citation I;Air Trek;Saturday 17 March 2007

column1: 18-MAR-1998;Saab 340B;B-12255;Formosa Airlines;near Hsinchu Airp...;1993;Fatalities: 5 / Occupants: 5;Fatalities: 8 / Occupants: 8;Damaged beyond repair;En route (ENR);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Hsinchu Airport (HSZ/RCPO)
column2: Taiwan;Kaohsiung International Airport (KHH/RCKH)
column3: Taiwan;"When the crew boarded the aircraft in Hsinchu for the flight to Kaohsiung it had been a long and demanding day for the captain who was to fly the aircraft. He had been on duty more than 11 hours and performed nine flights. The accident flight
column4: which was planned to be his last flight of the day
column5: was to take place in darkness. The weather was above minima but IMC. During the pre-flight check the crew noted a failure in the RH Main Bus. This caused a number of systems to be unavailable
column6: a.o.: the autopilot
column7: the left hand EFIS
column8: LH/RH Flight Director
column9: LH RMI
column10: EFIS Comparators
column11: and the no. 2 engine anti-ice start bleed valve being open (as a result of this
column12: the ITT on this engine was approximately 15°C higher than normal at selected power on this engine). Despite the fact that
column13: according to the Minimum Equipment List (MEL)
column14: taking off for a flight with any of the Main Buses inoperative was not allowed
column15: the captain decided to continue.

column1: During taxi to runway 05 the aircraft was cleared for a Chunan One (CN1) departure. The aircraft took off at 19:29:09.
Because of the autopilot was not available
column2: the captain now had to fly manually. In addition
column3: the flying had to be performed without support from the yaw-damper that was also inoperative as a result of the RH Main Bus failure. This means that more active rudder control was required
column4: while the DFDR-data shows that such input was not made.

column1: The more than 30°C ITT-split between the engines
column2: of which approximately 15°C was caused by the RH Engine Anti-ice Start Bleed Valve being open
column3: did have little effect on the behavior of the aircraft in the initial start-sequence. But when the crew
column4: 30 seconds after lift off
column5: disengaged CTOT and started to manually adjust the RH PLA downwards
column6: possibly to get equal ITT in the engines
column7: this ended up in a torque-split of more than 13% between the engines
column8: with the RH engine being lower in torque. This asymmetry tended to yaw and roll the aircraft to the right and required higher aileron input than normal to the left in order to keep the aircraft at a constant bank angle.

column1: Normally the flaps are retracted at around 1
column2: 000 feet during initial climb. In this flight the flap retraction was not initiated until the first officer was reading the Climb Check List in which the flap position should be checked and verified. Flap retraction was done just prior to the aircraft reaching VFE15 (175 KIAS
column3: which is the maximum allowed speed with flaps extended).

column1: When the climb power was set
column2: a symmetric PLA change was made. However
column3: due to the earlier RH Power Lever Angle (PLA) pull in combination with the normal backlash in the power lever cables between the PLA and the HMU
column4: the RH engine torque was decreased while the LH engine torque remained unchanged. Hence
column5: a torque split occurred. This resulted in an increased aerodynamic asymmetry giving a force tending to yaw and bank the aircraft to the right. Consequently
column6: still more aileron input was required in order to maintain a correct bank angle.

column1: Because the behavior of the aircraft was very different from what the captain was used to
column2: the need for continuous manual flying under IMC-conditions may have totally occupied his capacity. This could also explain why
column3: during this phase of flight
column4: he did not observe the aircraft starting a turn to the right 78 seconds after take off instead of continuing the left turn for a heading of 260. At about this same time
column5: and for no obvious reasons
column6: the positive rate of climb decreased and the aircraft leveled out at approximately 2
column7: 000 feet for a short time instead of continuing the climb to its assigned altitude of 3
column8: 000 feet. The captain's actions could be interpreted as signs that he might have been suffering from fatigue or spatial disorientation.

column1: It is difficult to determine if the F/O was aware of the captain's deviation from the cleared departure route. All indications point to the fact that he was not aware or that he out of respect for the captain did not report of the deviations. For example
column2: the F/O transmitted back to Taipei Approach 114 seconds after takeoff
column3: ""Left 230
column4: Bravo 12255
column5: while at the same time the aircraft was in a right turn with a 21 degree right bank
column6: passing through a heading of 312 degrees. In fact
column7: his primary means for monitoring the flight were very limited due to dark
column8: IMC-conditions since his EFIS instruments were black or flagged. This could also explain why the captain did not receive any support from the F/O about the flight becoming more and more uncontrolled.

column1: Not until 124 seconds after takeoff and 37 seconds prior to the last DFDR-recording did the captain state that he was having a problem with the heading and asked for help with the magnetic compass. At that time the aircraft was in a 24° right bank and 10° pitch up position and had a heading and roll rate by one degree per second. From that moment a continuous decrease in pitch angle was recorded down
to -65
column2: 4° just prior to the impact. Just 19 seconds before the last DFDR-recording
column3: with a heading of 022 and a bank angle of 36° to the right
column4: the captain said ""Ask for a radar vector."" At this moment
column5: he also initiates a short aileron input to the right
column6: further increasing the bank angle.

column1: The other crewmembers did not answer or give any notable response to the captain's request for help with the magnetic compass. The reason might be that they also were very confused about the situation and unable to take any relevant action. When the captain
column2: 14 seconds before the last DFDR-recording
column3: said ""Wah Sei!!! Everything is wrong."" the aircraft was in a 8
column4: 4° pitch down and the right bank angle was 47
column5: 5°. Finally
column6: only 10 seconds before the last data point was recorded
column7: the first officer responds by asking ""Sir
column8: shall we look at this one? "". Pitch down was then 15
column9: 8° and the right roll angle 71

column1: In the last part of the flight the pitch and bank angles were at extreme values not to be experienced in normal operation. At this stage of the flight
column2: the control inputs recorded are rapid aileron inputs to the right that further increased the adverse attitudes. The aircraft was then totally uncontrolled and the airspeed and sink rate increased dramatically. Four seconds before impact the Vmo warning started. The aircraft then crashed into the sea.";19:32;Saab 340B;Formosa Airlines;Wednesday 18 March 1998

column1: 23-MAR-2004;Beech 200C Super King Air;VH-NTH;Northern Territory Medical Service;Darwin Airpo...;1980;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 2;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Ambulance;Katherine-Tindal Airport

column5: Australia;"Shortly after take-off from Katherine
column6: Australia
column7: the left main landing gear of the Beech 200 aircraft did not retract. The flight continued to Darwin with the landing gear extended. During approach to Darwin airport the pilot advised air traffic control that he could not obtain a green 'down and locked' indication for the left main landing gear
column8: and declared an emergency prior to landing. During touchdown
column9: the left main landing gear collapsed and the aircraft slewed off the runway. Both occupants evacuated the aircraft with no injuries.

column1: The aircraft operator's maintenance organisation examined the aircraft and found that the left main landing gear drive shaft had severed as a result of fretting against a bleed air duct clamp tail. The bleed air duct clamp (jubilee clamp) had been fitted to the aircraft during an aircraft refurbishment program in September 2003. The jubilee clamp tail had been fastened in close proximity to the landing gear drive shaft. Subsequently
column2: the jubilee clamp tail had come into close contact with the drive shaft
column3: leading to severe wear of the drive shaft section and eventual failure.";12:50;Beechcraft 200C Super King Air;Northern Territory Medical Service;Tuesday 23 March 2004

column1: 17-apr-11;Boeing 777-F6N;B-2078;China Cargo Airlines;København-Ka...;2010-07-20  (9 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 4;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Cargo;Shanghai-Pudong International Airport (PVG/ZSPD)

column4: operated by China Cargo Airlines
column5: sustained substantial damage in a landing accident at Copenhangen
column6: Denmark.

column1: The flight from Shanghai
column2: China
column3: was uneventful and a normal final approach was established to Copenhagen Airport's runway 22L at 1000 feet AGL with the autopilot off and the auto throttle engaged. The airspeed was 152 knots and the vertical speed was 830 feet/min.

column1: During the flare the pilot flying started to correct the rate of decent by increasing the pitch attitude. At touchdown the pitch attitude was 4.6°
column2: the computed airspeed was 143 knots
column3: the vertical speed was 160 feet/min.

column1: The aircraft touched down and bounced three times. After the first bounce
column2: the ground spoilers automatically retracted and the auto braking system disarmed. A second bounce occurred followed by a third bounce. After the third bounce
column3: the speed brakes handle was pulled either by the pilot flying or by thrust reverser command
column4: which deployed the ground spoilers and the thrust reversers.

column1: The reversers were deployed in 11 seconds. During the deceleration
column2: the pitch angle gradually increased to 10.5° and the aircraft suffered a tailstrike. At the same time the pilot flying felt an increasing pitch up attitude and decided to initiate a go-around.

column1: An initiation of a GA after thrust reverser activation is very risky and not an option according to the Boeing 777 Flight Crew Operating Manual (FCOM) and the Boeing 777 Flight Crew Training Manual (FCTM).
After the ground spoilers were retracted and the reversers were stowed
column2: the pitch angle was decreased to 7.0°. At that time
column3: the indicated airspeed was 117 knots. Engine power was applied and as the airspeed increased. The increase of the forward engine thrust caused a further nose up pitch moment
column4: resulting in an increasing pitch angle of 11.9°.

column1: During lift off the indicated airspeed (IAS) was 140 knots
column2: which was 8 knots below the V2 calculated speed. The lower speed gave less lift and kept the main landing gear compressed. The result was less aft tail belly clearance
column3: leading the second tail strike. During initial climb
column4: the flight crew noticed a beeper aural warning and the tailstrike caution on the upper Engine Indication and Crew Alerting System (EICAS) display. The flight crew performed a tail strike Malfunction Check List and a Go Around Check List. The pilot not flying informed ATC about the go around and the tailstrike indication and that the pilots didn't have control problems with the aircraft. A new approach was requested to runway 22L.The aircraft landed without further problems.";15:00;Boeing 777-F6N;China Cargo Airlines;Sunday 17 April 2011

column6: United States of America;"A Beechcraft A100

column12: VA

column1: According to the flight crew
column2: the airplane was flying in smooth IMC conditions at FL200
column3: with an area of ""moderate to heavy to extreme"" precipitation located about 30 miles to the northwest. As the airplane approached 20 miles from the weather
column4: it began to experience moderate turbulence and rime ice on the windscreen. The pilot flying deviated course 40-degrees to the south. Turbulence increased further for about 10 seconds
column5: and the airplane then entered an uncommanded left roll and dive. The autopilot disengaged and the pilot's electrically driven attitude indicator tumbled. The flight crew reduced the engine power levers to idle and were able to recover utilizing the copilot's vacuum driven attitude indicator. The airplane was returned to straight and level flight at an altitude of 8
column6: 000 feet; however
column7: flight control instability persisted. The flight crew subsequently diverted to Tri-Cities Regional Airport (TRI)
column8: Blountville
column9: Tennessee
column10: where the airplane landed without further incident.

column1: Subsequent examination of the airplane by a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) inspector revealed that the outboard one-third of the left elevator separated in flight
column2: and the outboard right elevator was deformed downward. In addition
column3: the horizontal stabilizer bulkhead frame was fractured and the aft portion of the airframe sustained several areas of deformation.";14:05;Beechcraft A100 King Air;Dynamic Avlease;Wednesday 15 June 2011

12-feb-09;BAe 3102 Jetstream 31;SX-SKY;Sky Express;Heraklion-N....;1988-09-05  (20 years 6 months);Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 3;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 15;Substantial;Landing (LDG);Domestic Scheduled Passenger;Rhodes/Paradisi-Diagoras Airport (RHO/LGRP)
column2: Greece;Heraklion-N. Kazantzakis Airport (HER/LGIR)
column3: Greece;"A BAe 3102 Jetstream 31 passenger plane
column4: SX-SKY
column5: sustained substantial damage in a landing gear collapse at Heraklion-N. Kazantzakis Airport (HER)
column6: Greece.

column1: The airplane operated on a scheduled return flight between Heraklion and Rhodes. The entire return flight was uneventful until the landing back at Heraklion. The aircraft crossed the threshold with a speed of 112 kts and after flaring the captain
column2: who was pilot flying
column3: reduced speed to flight idle and touched down with a speed of 86 kts. As the speed was being gradually reduced
column4: the captain had difficulty with controlling the aircraft along its longitudinal axis and noticing that the aircraft was leaning somewhat to the right
column5: reported to the first officer that ""the gear has broken"". Immediately afterwards
column6: the blades of the right propeller of the aircraft struck the runway. The aircraft continued to move with the left main landing gear wheel operating normally and the collapsed right main landing gear
column7: folded backwards under the wing. The crew stopped the engines
column8: reported to the Airport Control Tower that the right landing gear had broken and requested evacuation.

column1: Investigation revealed that the forward yoke pintle on the right main landing gear fitted to SX-SKY failed on landing. The landing gear had flown 23
column2: 940 cycles since new and had been overhauled 148 landings prior to the accident. The aircraft landing weight was calculated to be 14
column4: which was within the maximum limit of 14
column6: and the FDR recorded a normal acceleration on landing of 1.79 g. A review of the data on the FDR identified two possible heavy landings of 2.5 g and 2.87 g that had occurred 5 and 27 landings prior to the accident.";17:23;British Aerospace 3102 Jetstream 31;Sky Express;Thursday 12 February 2009

14-MAR-2015;Airbus A330-343;9M-MTA;Malaysia Airlines;Melbourne-Tu...;2011-02-23  (4 years );Fatalities: 0 / Occupants:;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants:;Substantial;Landing (LDG);International Scheduled Passenger;Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KUL/WMKK)
column2: Malaysia;Melbourne-Tullamarine Airport
column3: VIC (MEL/YMML)
column4: Australia;"On 14 March 2015
column5: at about 07:50 LT an Airbus A330-343 aircraft operated by Malaysia Airlines
column6: began its final approach to runway 34 at Melbourne Airport in Australia. The flight was a regular passenger service from Kuala Lumpur
column7: Malaysia to Melbourne. The flight crew consisted of a captain
column8: who was the pilot flying (PF) and a first officer
column9: who was pilot monitoring (PM).

column1: The approach to runway 34 at Melbourne airport was not equipped with an Instrument Landing System (ILS)
column2: so a non-precision approach was performed
column3: aided by PAPI lights.

column1: Flight data showed that the PF disengaged the autopilot at approximately 700 feet above ground level (AGL) and from that point until touchdown there was an increase in the frequency and magnitude of sidestick pitch control inputs by the PF.
In response to these inputs the aircraft’s autothrottle system varied the engine thrust to maintain a target speed
column2: as per system design
column3: and the aircraft pitch angles fluctuated between approximately -0.5° nose down and +5.0° nose up. The net result of the varying thrust settings and pitch angles was a fluctuating rate of descent between approximately 380 and 960 feet per minute.

column1: Large sidestick inputs
column2: specifically nose-down
column3: also have the potential to inhibit the vertical speed reduction function
column4: which is an automated function that provides some protection against touchdown at very high vertical speeds.

column1: As the aircraft passed 300 feet a rate of descent of 960 feet per minute was recorded. This neared the operator’s maximum stabilised approach limit of 1000 feet per minute when below 500 feet AGL. As well as a high rate of descent
column2: actual exceedances of the operator’s stabilisation criteria included: large changes to pitch inputted by the pilot flying
column3: including negative pitch values
column4: fluctuations in the rate of descent over a large range that were abnormal for the phase of flight
column5: incorrect glide path.

column1: From approximately 250 feet AGL
column2: the aircraft was trending low and continuing below the glide path. At this point the pilots would have been able to observe 3 red lights and one white light on the PAPI. This trend was allowed to continue until the aircraft was well below the desired glide path to the extent that the PAPI would have indicated 4 red lights from approximately 125 feet AGL. From this point the PF made numerous pitch commands which were mostly nose down. These included a full range nose down deflection at 24 feet AGL.

column1: The company procedures and manufacturer’s recommendations dictated that if an approach becomes unstable below 500 feet AGL
column2: a go-around must be initiated by the pilot flying (PF) and/or the pilot monitoring (PM) must alert the PF of the unstable approach and encourage a go-around.

column1: At 60 feet AGL the captain moved the thrust levers forward momentarily into the TOGA (Take-off/Go Around) detent. The captain stated that this was done in response to a feeling that the aircraft was sinking below the path
column2: and the intention was to reduce this sink by applying more thrust to the engines. The placement of the thrust lever into TOGA placed the aircraft automation into the go-around autopilot modes and changed the display on the primary flight display flight mode annunciator (FMA). The captain subsequently reduced the thrust levers.

column1: The PM
column2: on seeing the modes on the FMA change assumed that a go-around was being conducted and awaited further announcement from the captain. The PM reported noticing the thrust levers reducing and that the aircraft was not flaring and applied nose up input to the sidestick at the same time as the PF.

column1: At the time of the occurrence there was no procedure on the A330 for the use of manual thrust for this purpose. Prior to 2009
column2: a procedure existed in the Airbus A330 documentation that allowed a specific use of manual thrust in difficult environmental conditions. Airbus advised that after an analysis of in-service events the procedure was removed from all operational documents.

column1: Manipulation of the thrust levers in this manner had the effect of disengaging the autothrottle thereby inhibiting some of the available auto flight system protections including the target speed function (which automatically maintained the desired speed and adjusted for fluctuation in the wind)
column2: and the vertical speed reduction function.

column1: It also caused a pitch up tendency which usually requires a large nose down input by the pilot flying to prevent the aircraft from pitching up. At this stage in the approach applying large nose down inputs differed from the gradual nose up input normally required to complete the flare.
Furthermore
column2: it resulted in breaking down of the shared mental model between the pilot flying and pilot monitoring in that the pilot monitoring believed the advancement of the thrust levers was the initiation of a go-around.

column1: Shortly after this action
column2: the aircraft touched down at a vertical speed of approximately 700 feet per minute and a vertical acceleration of 2.61 G was recorded. The aircraft also touched down at approximately 170m (560 feet) from the landing threshold
column3: short of the normal touchdown zone of between 304m (1000 feet) and 609m (2000 feet).

column1: The manufacturer of the aircraft produced a complete load analysis of the event based on recorded flight data provided by the operator. The conclusion of this analysis was that several components in the left and right gear had ""exceeded their design load limits and may have been detrimentally overloaded"".
There were no injuries reported as a result of the hard landing.
The airplane remained at Melbourne until March 26
column2: when it was ferried at low altitude to Darwin
column3: Australia
column4: and continuing to Kuala Lumpur the next day for further repairs.";07:52;Airbus A330-343;Malaysia Airlines;Saturday 14 March 2015

column1: 18-MAY-2003;Beech 300 Super King Air 350;N2SM;Oso-Rio;Houston-West...;1990;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 1;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Damaged beyond repair;Takeoff (TOF);Private;Houston-William P. Hobby Airport

column5: United States of America;"A Beechcraft 300 Super King Air 350
column6: N2SM
column7: was substantially damaged during a runway overrun while landing on runway 33 at the Houston-West Houston Airport
column8: TX (IWS). The airline transport pilot
column9: who was the sole occupant of the airplane
column10: received minor injuries. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed for the personal flight
column11: and a flight plan was not filed. The flight departed Houston-William P. Hobby Airport
column12: TX (HOU) at approximately 09:15.

column1: The pilot reported that while on the base leg
column2: the annunciator light for the ""low pitch stop"" propeller system on the right side illuminated. The pilot pulled the circuit breaker and left it out
column3: as per the pilot operating handbook (POH). During the landing-roll
column4: the pilot encountered a severe yaw to the right. The pilot added power to the right engine and realigned the airplane down the centerline. He then applied brakes and reverse thrust. The pilot stated that "" it felt like I had no braking action and then felt the right side grab and brake
column5: but not the left."" The combination of right side braking and the right low pitch system malfunction caused considerable adverse yaw
column6: jerking the plane to the right. The pilot applied power again and straightened the nose of the airplane. He then made the decision to go around
column7: but at this point did not have adequate airspeed or runway length to safely accomplish a go around. He applied the brakes again
column8: and the airplane immediately yawed to the right again
column9: at which time the pilot was unable to compensate before the airplane caught the edge of the runway. The airplane went into the grass
column10: where the pilot attempted to control the direction of the airplane and bring it to a complete stop. Examination of the hydraulic brake hoses from the left and right main landing gears revealed that both hoses appeared to have been damaged with a hand tool.";09:35;Beechcraft 300 Super King Air 350;Oso-Rio LLC;Sunday 18 May 2003

12-MAY-2010;Airbus A330-202;5A-ONG;Afriqiyah Airways;near Tripoli Inte...;2009-08-12  (9 months);Fatalities: 11 / Occupants: 11;Fatalities: 92 / Occupants: 93;Destroyed;Approach (APR);International Scheduled Passenger;Johannesburg-O.R. Tambo International Airport (JNB/FAOR)
column2: South Africa;Tripoli International Airport (TIP/HLLT)
column3: Libya;"On May 12
column4: 2010 the Airbus A330-202 passenger plane
column5: operated by Afriqiyah Airways as flight 771
column6: left Johannesburg-O.R. Tambo International Airport (JNB)
column7: South Africa on an international passenger flight to Tripoli. There were 11 crew members and 93 passengers on board. The co-pilot was pilot flying.

column1: The en route part of the flight was uneventful. The captain contacted the Tripoli ACC controller at 05:29 local time and received clearance direct to Tripoli for a TW locator approach to runway 09. Weather was reported as: wind calm
column2: visibility 6 km
column3: clear sky
column4: temperature/dew point 19/17°C
column5: QNH 1008. After receiving further descent clearances
column6: the crew contacted the Tripoli Tower controller at 05:58. Tripoli Tower notified the aircraft to continue the approach and to report runway in sight.

column1: The flight then received information from a flight that had landed ahead of them

column1: At 06:00 the flight passed the TW locator beacon at an altitude of 1000 feet
column2: 200 ft below the prescribed altitude. The captain then informed ATC that he would report when runway in sight. The approach was continued below the Minimum Descent Altitude of 620 feet but the crew still did not have the runway in sight. At an altitude of 280 feet the GPWS sounded ('too low terrain'). The captain then instructed the co-pilot to execute a go-around
column3: after which he informed the Tower controller. The aircraft began to climb
column4: reaching an altitude of 450 feet above ground level. The Airbus then nosed down
column5: causing the captain to take priority over the flight controls by pushing on priority button and the aircraft was fully under the captain's control who applied a sharp nose down input. The captain did not verbally state that he was taking control. He applied a pitch-up and a pitch-down input on his stick until the airplane impacted the ground.

column6: United States of America;"The Falcon 900 jet was being prepared for at flight from Santa Barbara (SBA) to Tampa (TPA). The captain supervised the fueling and the weight and balance computations
column7: while the first officer filled out the takeoff and landing distance (TOLD) card; a center of gravity (CG) location was not computed. The first officer entered a takeoff gross weight of 45
column8: 400 pounds on the TOLD card
column9: with the V-speeds for that weight entered on the card (V1 116 knots and Vr 129 knots). Post accident calculations revealed that the actual gross takeoff weight was 46
column10: 481 pounds and the CG was 15.73% of mean aerodynamic chord (MAC)
column11: which was within the maximum gross takeoff weight and center of gravity limits of 46
column12: 500 pounds and 14 to 31% MAC
column13: respectively. The V-speeds for the actual gross weight are V1 118 knots and Vr 131 knots. The crew set the stabilizer trim at -5.5 degrees
column14: which is in the takeoff range
column15: from -4.5 degrees to -7.5 degrees. For the airplane’s calculated CG of 15.73% MAC
column16: the right setting for the stabilizer trim should have been between -7 and -7.5 degrees. The captain said that everything was normal in the takeoff. The first officer called V1
column17: followed by Vr
column18: at which time he pulled back on the yoke
column19: but with no response. When the speed was well into the upper 130-knot range he relaxed the yoke
column20: then pulled aft again
column21: and again there was no response from the airplane. Power was then immediately reduced to the stops
column22: full nose forward pressure was applied to the yoke
column23: and maximum braking effort was applied. The airplane departed the end of runway 25 just to the right of centerline. After exiting the end of the runway the airplane impacted a berm
column24: which resulted in the nose landing gear collapsing rearward and the airplane sliding on its nose before coming to a stop about 100 yards off the end of the runway into the dirt.";14:15;Dassault Falcon 900;null;Sunday 10 June 2007

column1: The flight took off from Helsinki-Vantaa Airport
column2: Finland at 09:46 local time. The flight was uneventful until 10:14 hours
column3: 9.5 nm from Tallinn runway 26. When the power levers were retarded to flight idle the crew noticed engine vibration and smelled a smoke in the cockpit. The engine chip detector indicator in the cockpit was lit. After a short discussion about which engine should be shut down the flight engineer shut down the left engine and the captain tried to start the APU to gain more thrust.

column1: During the approach the air traffic controller noticed the aircraft deviating from the approach path to the left and notified the crew. The crew was unable to maintain a proper approach path both in lateral and vertical dimensions. The attempts to start the APU engine failed. Visual contact with the runway was established 0.5 nm from the threshold. The aircraft crossed the airport boundary being not configured for landing and with an indicated airspeed (IAS) of 295-300 km/h. The flaps were extended for 10° over the threshold; the landing gear was lowered after passing the runway threshold and retracted again.

The aircraft made a high speed low pass over the runway at an altitude of ca 10-15 feet with the landing gear traveling down and up again. Flaps were extended over the runway. At the end of the runway full power on the right engine was selected
column2: and the aircraft climbed 15-20 feet and started turning left. The crew started retracting flaps and lowered the landing gear. The aircraft crossed the highway at the end of the runway at ca 30 feet
column3: then descended again
column4: colliding with treetops at the lake shore and made a crash-landing on the snow and ice-covered lake waterline. Due to the thick ice the aircraft remained on the ice and slid 151 m on the ice with heading 238° before coming to a full stop.

column1: After the impact the flight engineer shoot down the right engine and power and released all engine fire extinguishers. All persons onboard escaped immediately through the main door. No emergency was declared and despite suggestions from first officer
column2: a go-around was not formally commanded.

column1: The airplane gradually sank through the ice after the accident.";10:16;Antonov 26B;null;Thursday 18 March 2010
