column3: United Kingdom;"The crew reported for duty at 06:25 UTC at London-Stansted Airport (STN) and were scheduled to position the aircraft
column4: without passengers
column5: to Chambéry Airport (CMF) in France. They were then scheduled to return
column6: with passengers
column7: to London-Gatwick Airport (LGW).

column1: An onboard hand-held Electronic Flight Bag (EFB) HP iPAQ computer was used to calculate the takeoff performance data. Once this was completed
column2: the EFB was placed in the standby mode. The flight

column1: to Chambery was uneventful and the aircraft landed at 09:15
column2: 15 minutes behind schedule.

column1: The return flight to Gatwick was scheduled to depart at 10:00. The pre-flight preparations proceeded normally and the pilots reported no distractions other than those normally experienced during a turnaround. The co-pilot
column2: who was the non-handling pilot for this flight
column3: completed the manual load sheet whilst the commander programmed the route into the Flight Management Computer (FMC). The commander reported that he then cross-checked the load sheet information and
column4: having ensured it was correct
column5: entered the Zero Fuel Weight (ZFW) into the FMC. The FMC then calculated the Takeoff Weight (TOW) using the fuel weight automatically retained in the system. The commander read back the FMC calculated TOW to the co-pilot
column6: who cross-checked it against the load sheet data and confirmed that they agreed.

column1: Having loaded the ZFW into the FMC and cross-checked the TOW
column2: the commander used the EFB computer to calculate the takeoff performance data. This involved waking up the EFB from the standby mode
column3: then entering the airfield
column4: weather and aircraft data
column5: which included the flap position for takeoff. A specific flap setting could be entered
column6: or the computer could be used to provide an optimum setting. The commander stated that he normally entered Flap 5 for the takeoff performance calculation. However
column7: at airports where performance was considered to be more critical
column8: he would set the performance computer to select the optimum setting. As the runway at Chambery is relatively short
column9: the commander chose the optimum flap position calculated by the performance computer. This gave a selection of Flap 1 which
column10: under the circumstances
column11: he did not consider unusual. Similarly
column12: the computed takeoff speeds did not seem unusual to the commander
column13: particularly as they were predicated on a flap setting he did not normally use.

column1: The computed figures
column2: based on the data entered on the EFB
column3: allowed for a reduced thrust takeoff. The calculated assumed temperature to be set to achieve this did not seem unreasonable at the time
column4: although the commander stated that
column5: in hindsight
column6: he considered it to be too high for the airfield and the prevailing conditions.

column1: Both pilots stated that they would normally cross-check the performance figures once they had been calculated on the EFB. However
column2: on this occasion
column3: and for reasons the pilots could not recall
column4: this was not done. The commander wrote the speeds he had computed using the EFB on the flight paperwork and then entered them into the FMC
column5: overwriting the FMC generated speeds. The commander stated that this was standard practice and on this occasion he did not take note of any difference between the two sets of speeds. The rest of the pre-flight preparation was completed and the aircraft took off from runway 36 at Chambery at 10:08 UTC (12:08 local time)
column6: on schedule
column7: with 131 passengers onboard. The pilots reported the weather at the time was good
column8: with a light wind from the east
column9: good visibility and dry conditions. The ATIS reported a temperature of 8°C and a QNH of 999 hPa.

column1: On takeoff both pilots felt a slight judder
column2: which they considered was due to turbulence from the preceding aircraft. Early in the climb they received a call on the intercom from the rear cabin station informing them that the cabin crew to the rear of the aircraft had also felt a judder. This call was intended for the cabin purser at the front of the cabin
column3: but was mistakenly made to the flight deck. The pilots reassured the cabin crew member
column4: still believing the judder was due to turbulence. Their opinion was reinforced by the absence of any abnormal flight deck indications or calls from ATC at Chambery to the contrary.

column1: The remainder of the flight went without incident and the aircraft landed at Gatwick at 11:30. The aircraft was taxied to stand and
column2: after shutting down
column3: the pilots were informed by ground personnel that the underside of the rear fuselage had sustained damage consistent with a tailstrike. This prompted the crew to reconsider the cause of the judder felt at takeoff and they reviewed the takeoff performance data. This revealed that the commander had omitted to enter the aircraft's TOW into the EFB computer at Chambery
column4: with the result that the computer had reverted to the previous TOW data retained from Stansted to calculate the takeoff performance figures.";12:08;Boeing 737-33A (QC);Titan Airways;Saturday 14 April 2012

column1: The accident flight departed the Bedford-Hanscom Field
column2: MA (BED) at 07:00
column3: and flew to New York-La Guardia Airport
column4: NY (LGA) with only the pilot and pilot-rated passenger onboard. At LaGuardia
column5: five additional passengers boarded the airplane
column6: which subsequently departed on an IFR flight plan to Bedford. While en route
column7: the crew amended the destination to Fitchburg. According to the surviving passenger
column8: the intent was to drop off two passengers at Fitchburg
column9: then continue on to the Martha's Vineyard Airport
column10: MA (MVY)
column11: with the remaining passengers.

column1: While on approach to Fitchburg Airport
column2: the airplane entered a left turn
column3: which the surviving passenger described as ""almost completely upside down."" The airplane briefly levelled
column4: then entered another left turn with a bank angle of the same severity. The airplane seemed to roll level
column5: then entered a steep dive
column6: until it impacted a building. The passenger reported that the engines were running normally throughout the entire flight
column7: and the steep turns performed by the pilot did not concern her
column8: as she had flown with him before and knew he ""liked to make sharp turns."" Examination of the airplane and engines revealed no pre-impact mechanical anomalies
column9: and weather at the time of the accident included a broken cloud ceiling of 1
column10: 100 feet
column11: with 3 miles visibility in mist.

column1: Toxicology testing performed on the pilot revealed imipramine and carbamazepine in the pilot's urine and blood
column2: and morphine in the pilot's urine. According to the pilot's medical and pharmacy records
column3: he suffered from a severe neurological disorder
column4: possibly a seizure disorder
column5: which resulted in frequent
column6: unpredictable episodes of debilitating pain. Additionally
column7: approximately three months prior to the accident
column8: the pilot was diagnosed with viral meningitis
column9: and a severe skin infection with multiple abscesses on his extremities. The pilot had been prescribed imipramine
column10: an antidepressant that has detrimental effects on driving skills and other cognitive functions. He had also been prescribed carbamazepine
column11: typically used to control seizures or treat certain chronically painful conditions. Carbamazepine has measurable impairment of performance on a variety of psychomotor tests. Morphine
column12: a prescription opiate painkiller
column13: is also a metabolite of heroin and many prescription medications
column14: such as codeine
column15: used to control moderate pain. No indication was observed in the pilot's medical records that he was recently prescribed any opiates. Neither the pilot's medical condition
column16: nor the medication he was routinely taking was reported on his application for an airman medical certificate.";09:35;Beechcraft B200 King Air;FS Corsair Inc;Friday 4 April 2003

column2: United Arab Emirates;Düsseldorf Airport (DUS/EDDL)
column3: Germany;"The Boeing 747 operated on a cargo flight from Dubai to Düsseldorf on behalf of Emirates. The en route part of the flight was uneventful.

column1: The flight crew established radio contact with Düsseldorf Radar at 05:43. The crew were told that runway 23L was in use.

Two minutes later the radar controller contacted flight 8995: ""I just talked to the tower and ah for the time being braking action on all parts of the runway is supposed to be good. They are measuring again right now because it started to snow again and I'll keep you advised."" The flight was then cleared to descend to FL80. The flight crew decided to set the autobrakes for landing on Medium
column2: to account for the snow.

column1: At 05:50 the radar controller again contacted the flight about the current weather circumstances: ""...latest update on the weather situation ahm the friction tester has reported braking action to be good for the moment however as its continuing to snow they are ah afraid that it might worsen
column2: so they are going to do another friction test right before you land.""

column1: In the following minutes the flight was given descent instructions and vectors for an approach to runway 23L.
At 05:54 the controller radioed: ""weather update we now have a surface wind of three four zero degrees eleven knots
column2: that's slight tail wind component by two knots. Visibility is down to one thousand five hundred meters
column3: still in snow showers and ah cloud base is now five hundred feet only.""

column1: The flight was subsequently cleared for the approach.
At 05:57 the radar controller instructed the crew to contact Düsseldorf Tower. The Tower controller stated: ""Good morning
column2: ... we are just waiting for the braking action values from the friction tester stand by a second. The surface wind is actually three three zero degrees one two knots.""

column1: Two minutes later the controller radioed: ""... the braking action was measured to be medium at all parts. And ah the visibility dropped right now due to the heavy snow showers at the field ah. The RVR value at the touch down zone is presently nine hundred meters
column2: at the mid-point one thousand one hundred meters and ah stop end one thousand one hundred meters."" At that moment the flight was 3
column3: 5 nautical miles out. The flight was subsequently cleared to land.

column1: The airplane touched down about 1700 ft (518 m) past the runway threshold. Ground spoilers and thrust reversers deployed and the autobrakes activated. Still the airplane did not decelerate as expected and the pilot applied manual braking. The airplane failed to stop and overran the runway end. It collided with ILS aerials
column2: which caused a fire in engines no. 2 and no. 3.

column1: The aircraft was withdrawn from use at Düsseldorf until being scrapped there in April 2006.";06:01;Boeing 747-212BSF;Atlas Air;Monday 24 January 2005

column4: registration HC-COX
column5: operated by TAME as Flight EQ173 from Quito's Mariscal Sucre International Airport experienced an apparent intentional emergency ground-loop during a runway overrun in light rain weather conditions at Mariscal Lamar International Airport (SECU)
column6: in Cuenca
column7: Ecuador. The airplane sustained substantial damage and there were no reported injuries among the 6 crew and 87 passengers onboard.

column1: The aircraft departed Quito at 06:51 hours local time.
During the landing preparation briefing
column3: the pilot indicated that they would hold the glide slope until they had a runway in sight
column4: inhibit the glide slope alarm
column5: and continue visual. Four minutes later the flight was cleared for the VOR ILS ZULU approach for runway 23. The runway was wet due to drizzle and the braking efficiency reported by an Airbus A319 was good to average. The A319 had landed on the runway in Cuenca 36 minutes before flight 173.

column2: the flight radioed that they were ten miles out and established on the localizer. They were cleared to the ILS approach for runway 23. Three minutes later the controller reported that they had flight 173 in sight and informed that the wind was calm
column3: and cleared the flight to land on runway 23. T

column2: the pilot indicated that he had three red and one white lights on the PAPI system.  The aircraft crossed the runway threshold at 37 feet high instead of 50 feet
column3: which meant the aircraft approached below the normal glidepath. It touched down 277 m past the threshold at an airspeed of 127 knots. Spoilers were deployed 585 meters from the threshold
column4: followed by reverses at 643 m.

column1: The pilot
column2: not feeling an effective braking of the aircraft
column3: tried to activate the autobrake system but this did not work. The aircraft was hydroplaning and could not be brought to a halt on the runway. The pilot groundlooped the aircraft on the grass.

column1: Runway 23 is a 1900 m long runway with an upslope of 15 m (+0.78%). Distance from the centre of the end of the paved runway to the boundary fence and an active road is 31 m.	The Operational Landing Distance calculations with manual braking for the weight of the aircraft with wind on touchdown
column2: indicate that a runway length of 2
column3: 122 meters was necessary.";07:51;Embraer ERJ 190-100 IGW (ERJ-190AR);TAME Ecuador;Thursday 28 April 2016

12-feb-07;Lockheed Hercules C.4 (C-130J-30);ZH876;RAF;near Al-Amarah;1999;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 6;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 58;Damaged beyond repair;Landing (LDG);Military;?;?;"The crew of ZH876 were tasked to fly a routine roulement of troops to a Tactical Landing Zone (TLZ) in Maysaan province
column2: Iraq. Weather at the TLZ was good
column3: with a visibility of 25 km
column4: no significant cloud and a light surface wind.

column1: The flight to the TLZ was routine and at approx 17:00 UTC the Hercules began to make its approach to the TLZ. Comms had already been established between ZH876 and the Tactical Air Traffic Controller (Tac ATC) at the TLZ
column2: and the aircraft was subsequently cleared to land. An uneventful approach followed flown by the co-pilot.
as the aircraft was about to touchdown at the TLZ
column3: the crew experienced a load bang and a bright flash. The flash temporarily blinded the flight-deck crew. Virtually simultaneously
column4: the aircraft touched down. The first flash was followed
column5: a second later

column1: During the final turn to intercept the localizer

column3: the extra fuel that would be used to manoeuver the aircraft for runway 14

column1: The final approach course was intercepted at 7 nm. The aircraft began its final descent upon interception of the glideslope

column4: at a speed of 139 KIAS. The aircraft did a very smooth touchdown

column7: United States of America;"A Lockheed  P2V-7 Neptune (Air Tanker mod.) N14447
column8: coded ""Tanker 11""
column9: under contract to the US Forest Service
column10: crashed about 20 miles north of Modena
column11: Iron County
column12: Utah
column13: during a fire fighting operation against the White Rock Fire in the Hamblin Valley Area.

column1: Tanker 11 departed the tanker base to conduct its second fire retardant drop of the day in the same location. Upon arriving in the fire traffic area
column2: Tanker 11 followed the lead airplane into the drop zone
column3: which was located in a shallow valley 0.4 mile wide and 350 feet deep. The lead airplane flew a shallow right turn onto final and then dropped to an altitude of 150 feet above the valley floor while approaching the intended drop zone. While making the right turn onto final behind the lead airplane
column4: Tanker 11's right wing tip collided with terrain
column5: which resulted in a rapid right yaw and subsequent impact with terrain. The wreckage created a 1
column6: 088-foot-long debris field
column7: and a post impact fire ensued.

column1: Two witnesses took photographs of the accident sequence photos
column2: and an examination of these photographs showed that the lead airplane was positioned ahead of the tanker throughout the flight; however
column3: the orientation of the lead airplane compared to the orientation of Tanker 11 indicated that Tanker 11 did not directly follow the lead airplane's path to the final drop course. Rather
column4: it was about 700 feet left of the lead airplane's path and made a wider right turn as it attempted to align with the final drop course. The accident flight crewmembers had previously flown nearly the same exact drop and the lead pilot cautioned them about tailwind conditions during the flight; however
column5: the wider turn suggests that they did not properly compensate for the wind conditions while maneuvering. In addition
column6: the previous flight was conducted at an altitude above the ridgeline. GPS evidence indicates that the accident flight was conducted below the ridgeline
column7: which would have made it more difficult to detect the rising terrain during the wider turn. A review of the airplane's cockpit voice recorder audio information revealed that the flight crew did not recognize or attempt to correct the reduced clearance between Tanker 11 and the rising terrain until about 2 seconds before impact.";13:47;Lockheed P-2H Neptune;Neptune Aviation Services;Sunday 3 June 2012

column1: 31-jan-00;DC-9-83 (MD-83);N963AS;Alaska Airlines;near Anacapa Isla...;1992;Fatalities: 5 / Occupants: 5;Fatalities: 83 / Occupants: 83;Destroyed;En route (ENR);International Scheduled Passenger;Puerto Vallarta-Gustavo D. Ordaz Airport (PVR/MMPR)
column2: Mexico;San Francisco International Airport
column3: CA (SFO/KSFO)
column4: United States of America;Alaska Airlines Flight 261 departed Puerto Vallarta at about 14:30 PST for a flight to San Francisco and Seattle. En route to San Francisco a FL310 a problem arose with the stabilizer trim. At 16:10 the crew radioed Los Angeles ARTCC that they were having control problems and that they were descending through FL260. At 16:11 Los Angeles ARTCC asked the condition of the flight and were told that they were troubleshooting a jammed stabilizer. The crew requested
column5: and were granted
column6: a FL200-FL250 block altitude clearance. At 16:15 the crew were handed off to Los Angeles sector control. The Alaska Airlines crew reported problems maintaining their altitude and told their intentions to divert to Los Angeles International Airport. They were cleared to do so at 16:16. The crew then requested permission to descend to FL100 over water to change their aircraft configuration . Los Angeles cleared them to FL170. Last message from Flight 261 was when they requested another block altitude. The request was granted at 16:17
column7: without a readback from the crew. During the descent the crew was also talking to Alaska Airlines maintenance personnel in Seattle and Los Angeles to troubleshoot their stabilizer trim problems. As the crew attempted to diagnose or correct the problem the out-of-trim condition became worse
column8: causing a tendency for the plane to pitch nose-down. When preparing the plane for landing control was lost and the MD-83 was seen 'tumbling
column9: spinning

column2: India;Hubli Airport (HBX/VAHB)
column3: India;"A DHC-8-400 operated by SpiceJet sustained damage in a landing accident at Hubli Airport (HBX)
column4: India.

column1: The aircraft operated flight SG1085 from Bangalore to Hubli and departed at around 13:00 UTC. At the time the visibility reported for Hubli was 10 km.
When the aircraft came in contact with Mangalore ATC
column2: the controller cleared the aircraft direct to Hubli and informed heavy rains and thunder showers over Hubli with visibility 3000 m. At around 60 nm from Hubli
column3: the weather reported was heavy rain and visibility 4000 meters. ATC cleared aircraft for the NDB approach runway 26
column4: however the captain preferred to carry out a VOR/DME trial procedure for runway 26. The descent was commenced and about 25 nm short of Hubli
column5: ATC again advised visibility has reduced to 3000 m due heavy rain and thunderstorm.

column1: Thereafter the crew decided to hold over Hubli until the weather improves. Twenty minutes into holding
column2: ATC again informed that visibility has improved to 4000 m in moderate rain.

column1: Subsequently descent was requested by the pilot for runway 26. The captain stated that he had established visual reference with runway at about 6 nm on the final approach course. The crew also selected wipers on short finals to have a better visibility. The aircraft landed normally.
The captain stated that after touch down and reducing power
column2: he was concentrating on the far end of the runway. As the runway was wet
column3: he did not realize that the aircraft was drifting to the left of the center line. He further mentioned that he selected full reverse on both the engines to maintain the aircraft on the center line however the aircraft veered toward the left side of the runway and in the process overran the runway edge light
column4: after which the left main landing gear collapsed. The propeller blades hit the runway surface and sheared off from the root attachment. The captain maneuvered the aircraft however the nose wheel tyre failed under over load conditions and the nose landing gear collapsed as well.

column1: Subsequently
column2: the aircraft exited the runway on the left side on kutcha (dried mud) and came to a final stop at round 52 meters away from the runway center line. The cockpit crew shut down the engines and the electrical power supply and cockpit door and announced evacuation. The cabin crew opened and the cabin doors on the right for evacuation.

column1: There was no injury to any of the occupants on board the aircraft. There was no postaccident fire.";ca 19:30;de Havilland Canada DHC-8-402Q Dash 8;SpiceJet;Sunday 8 March 2015

column1: 04-MAR-2004;Ilyushin Il-76MD;UR-ZVA;Azov-Avia Airlines;near Baku Airport...;1986;Fatalities: 3 / Occupants: 7;Fatalities: 0 / Occupants: 0;Damaged beyond repair;Initial climb (ICL);Cargo;Baku-Bina International Airport (BAK/UBBB)
column2: Azerbaijan;Kabul Airport (KBL/OAKB)
column3: Afghanistan;"The Ilyushin freighter departed Ankara
column4: Turkey for a cargo flight to Kabul
column5: Afghanistan. In Ankara the airplane was loaded with 39980 kg of cargo. The next stop was Baku
column6: Azerbaijan for refueling. The airplane took 47 tons of fuel
column7: bringing the takeoff weight to 189 tons
column8: and the centre of gravity to 29
column9: 3% MAC
column10: which was within the prescribed limits. During the eight-hour stopover the crew decided to rest in the aircraft instead of a hotel. As the aircraft started taxiing to the runway the flight engineer was heard saying that he would select the flaps at 30 degrees and slats at 14 degrees for takeoff. This however was not done. Prior to takeoff the position of the flaps was not verified by any of the crew members. Takeoff was thus commenced with flaps and slats retracted and the stabilizer trimmed at the takeoff position -4 degrees (corresponding to actual takeoff weight
column11: CofG and flaps at 30°). At a speed of 210 km/h the pilot pulled on the control column to lift off the nose gear. At a calculated unstick speed of 265 km/h the angle of attack reached 9 degrees but the plane did not lift off the runway. Accelerating through 290 km/h the angle of attack of the aircraft reached 14
column12: 5 degrees
column13: setting off the angle of attack warning on the flight deck. Some 1750 meters down the runway
column14: the aft fuselage struck the runway. Seventy meters further on
column15: at a speed of 300 km/h and an angle of attack of 19
column17: the Ilyushin lifted off the runway. The air traffic controller who witnessed the departure advised the crew to abort the takeoff
column18: but the captain apparently continued. The airplane rolled to the left until the wing contacted the runway. Then the flight engineer noted his error and
column19: without informing the captain
column20: began extending the flaps and slats. Again without informing the captain
column21: the flight engineer brought back the power levers of the four engines to idle. After three seconds he moved them from idle to the 'engine shutdown' position. The captain three times yelled ""takeoff"" but the engines were already shut down. After flying for 490 meters the aircraft struck the ground and crashed.";ca 09:40;Ilyushin 76MD;Azov-Avia Airlines;Thursday 4 March 2004

column1: The aircraft took off from Tokyo-Haneda Airport at 14:41 local time on a ferry flight to Konan Airfield.
The pilot switched from IFR to Visual Flight Rules (VFR) at about 15nm short of Kibi VOR. The aircraft passed over the vicinity of Saidaiji (the published visual reporting point
column2: 6.7 nm northeast from the airfield) at an altitude of about 3
column3: 000 ft and a speed of about 200 kt at 15:41
column4: and acquired information on the active runway and wind condition from Konan Flight Service.

column1: This was reported as runway 09
column2: with a wind direction 090° at 5 kts
column3: and the aircraft was requested to report on the left downwind leg.

column1: The captain remembered the wind condition being 4 kts from the south
column2: and assessed both runway directions to be available. He thus requested to land using runway 27
column3: which was a shorter flight path
column4: and was requested to report at 2 nm short of runway 27 or on the base leg.

column1: The aircraft was configured for landing and at 15:44:59 the aircraft descended through 500 feet.
The captain stated that he made straight-in approach at 117 kt
column2: adding 10 kt as usual above the VREF displayed on the speed indicator to avoid stalling. According to EGPWS records
column3: there was a warning ""Too Low
column4: Flaps"" at 15:45:11 when the aircraft was at 205 ft AGL
column5: with an airspeed 155 kt and ground speed 160 kt. This voice warning was repeated two times.

column1: EGPWS records showed the aircraft gradually reduced speed on the final approach
column2: with the last record being at 87 ft AGL with an airspeed 142 kt and ground speed 147 kt.

column1: The main landing gears of the aircraft touched down forward of the aiming point marking. About half way down the runway the pilot noticed a bird and turned a little bit to the right to avoid the bird
column2: which was flying away. The captain then strongly applied the brakes
column3: but he did not feel the usual deceleration. Continuing to apply the brakes
column4: the aircraft avoided the stopway edge lights to the right and entered a grass area; accordingly
column5: it went into a pond used as a regulating reservoir located west of the runway at about 20 to 30 kts.

column1: Konan Airport is former Okayama Airport (OKJ/RJOB) with a single runway 09/27 measuring 1200 m x 30 m (20 m grooving) and 0 ft elevation. After opening of new Okayama Airport in 1988
column2: the airport was renamed as Konan Airport and is used for general aviation.";15:46;Cessna 525A CitationJet CJ2+;Auto Panther;Wednesday 10 June 2015
